abstract: The loss by the burning of CRAIG'S Mills is over a hundred thousand dollars, of which $25,000 is insured on the machinery, including $15,000 in the Etna Insurance Company of Hartford. The building contained two hundred and sixty-six looms, (belonging to various parties,) engaged on army flannels. Two hundred operatives were thrown out of employment.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, Oct. 31.

abstract: We have conversed with an intelligent lady who was at Lexington, Mo., when it was taken by PRICE, and she gives sickening details of the barbarities committed by the rebels. Among the prisoners taken was Dr. WHITE, who was offered a pass by PRICE after the capitulation, with which he went about two miles beyond Richmond, with Maj. BECKER and Capt. NEAT. While at their dinner, a party headed by the well-known desperadoes CHARLEY MARTIN, STEVE EMERSON and IKE LIGHTNER, came up and took the officers off in a coach, but refused to let the Doctor, who was an old man, go with them, but he was subsequently taken one mile from the house into a by-path and there shot twice through the breast; he laid from Thursday till Tuesday, and when the inquest was held, the hogs had eaten all the flesh off the body except that which was protected by his boots. Two weeks after this fiendish murder, his wife, with our informant and a lad, went to Richmond and brought away his remains. Mrs. WHITE, who is a niece of Ex-Gov. DESHA, of this State, occupied a fine farm of about five hundred acres, nearly all in a state of cultivation. The ruffians entered upon this, destroyed one hundred acres of corn, fifty of oats, valuable peach and apple orchards, broke the cider machine, smashed the grand-children's playthings, thrust bayonets through the windows, carried off the carriage and sixteen horses, killed seventeen head of cattle, fifty sheep, and a hundred hogs, and ripped up nine feather-beds in fiendish wantonness, leaving Mrs. WHITE without a place to sleep on, and compelling her to borrow bedding for herself and family.
lead_paragraph: We have conversed with an intelligent lady who was at Lexington, Mo., when it was taken by PRICE, and she gives sickening details of the barbarities committed by the rebels. Two weeks after this fiendish murder, his wife, with our informant and a lad, went to Richmond and brought away his remains. Mrs. WHITE, who is a niece of Ex-Gov. abstract: In the Matter of John Beaman. -- The relator's name was in some manner placed upon the muster rolls of Col. Mulligan's Regiment, known as the Fremont Cavalry. Relator averred that he was kidnapped, and was never sworn into the service, and alleged that he had been unlawfully confined and detained in a porter-house in Houston-street, at the instance of the valiant Mulligan. Mulligan solemnly asseverated that the relator had regularly enlisted, and that his story of the kidnapping was all gotten up to effect his release. The matter came before the Court upon an application for a writ of habeas corpus. which was granted, but not particularly respected by Col. Mulligan. The matter was finally settled, however, by the withdrawal of the writ and the surrender of the recruit by the commander of the Fremont Cavalry. Meantime, in endeavoring to effect his escape, (as told by the boy,) he had jumped from a third story window of the house in Houston-street, and broken one of his ankles.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of John Beaman. -- The relator's name was in some manner placed upon the muster rolls of Col. Mulligan's Regiment, known as the Fremont Cavalry. Relator averred that he was kidnapped, and was never sworn into the service, and alleged that he had been unlawfully confined and detained in a porter-house in Houston-street, at the instance of the valiant Mulligan. Mulligan solemnly asseverated that the relator had regularly enlisted, and that his story of the kidnapping was all gotten up to effect his release. The matter came before the Court upon an application for a writ of habeas corpus. which was granted, but not particularly respected by Col. Mulligan. The matter was finally settled, however, by the withdrawal of the writ and the surrender of the recruit by the commander of the Fremont Cavalry. Meantime, in endeavoring to effect his escape, (as told by the boy,) he had jumped from a third story window of the house in Houston-street, and broken one of his ankles.

abstract: Having visited the extreme right wing of the army, going by way of the Chain Bridge, I devoted a day to that portion of it which lies along the main road to Fairfax. The country here is more open or less hilly than that on the right, and if it were not for the dense forests that occur at intervals, would not be bad for military movements on a large scale. As you advance further inland, however, the country becomes worse. After having traversed so many of the great battle-fields of Europe, and examined them minutely, I have looked somewhat with dismay at the character of the region in which our vast army has got to manoeuvre. It is made for nothing but guerilla fighting. How any general can handle a hundred and twenty thousand men on such a field baffles my comprehension. Heavy columns, it is true, can move along the roads, but to keep a continuous communication with each other, it seems to me, would be an impossibility. I should say that fifty thousand men, well posted, ought to resist successfully an attack of nearly double that number. Wherever the forests are felled, it becomes totally impassable. On our right wing there are large tracts, so densely covered with the tops of fallen trees, that I defy an army to get over them under fire. I should not like to attempt it alone, even though allowed to take my own time. Many of the headquarters of the generals are on elevations that overlook the country to a great extent, and I can appreciate the perplexity with which they survey the field on which they are to operate. I am not so sanguine that a great battle will be fought here as I was before I saw the character of the country. If there is, it will be composed of separate battles, fought by separate armies, and one which will puzzle a European strategist to comprehend the plan of.

abstract: Notwithstanding the clamors of the manufacturers and merchants of France and England for the reopening of the cotton ports, we have no apprehension that they will be responded to by their respective Governments. Interference would only add to their calamities, as it would deprive them of the trade of the North as well as the South, and involve a war which would destroy their commerce with other countries as well as that with our own. At this crisis, too, corn with Europeancountries is a much more important matter than cotton; and, till the period of the present dearth is passed, which in many countries is excessive, we have little fear of any disturbance in our foreign relations.

abstract: The sutler of the Twentieth Indiana Regiment, which came so near falling into the hands of the rebels at Hatteras Island some weeks ago, had a narrow escape from being captured or killed. In a private letter he states that he lingered behind the rest of the regiment when on the retreat to assist three lame men whom he desired to rescue. They were finally overtaken by a dozen rebels, and his companions surrendered. He continues:

abstract: Contrary to the usual custom of New-York tax-payers, the majority did not this year defer the payment of their taxes till the last day of October, (the day on which a deduction of 7 per cent. terminates, and after which an addition of one per cent. is made.) The crowd yesterday was hardly worth the name, and the receipts about half of those on the same day last year. The aggregate paid in, however, up to, and including yesterday, is the largest received in any year, even when the books have been open much longer. The receipts of the office from Sept. 30, (the day the books were opened,) up to, and including Oct. 31, amount to four millions seven hundred and fifty-six thousand and odd dollars, being more than one-third of the entire tax which has been collected within thirty-one days. This does not look very much like a dearth of money.

abstract: Phillip Allen et al. vs. Schuchardt et al. The sample of a quantity of madder was put into the hands of a broker in the City of New-York, by the defendants, to make sale of it for them. A sale was ...
lead_paragraph: Phillip Allen et al. vs. Schuchardt et al. -- The sample of a quantity of madder was put into the hands of a broker in the City of New-York, by the defendants, to make sale of it for them. A sale was made accordingly to the plaintiffs, in the State of Rhode Island, upon an inspection of the sample bottle, which the broker refused to open on account of instructions from his principals. The sample bottle had been forwarded from Amsterdam to the defendants, previous to the shipment of the bulk, and was the only sample of the goods, as none accompanied thorn. The madder was in barrels in the vessel, which had arrived in New-York about the time of the sale. The sale was made in the name of the defendants, their principal not being disclosed.

abstract: Hon. J.I. SLINGERLAND died at his residence in New-Scotland on Saturday, aged 57 years. In early life he received but a limited education, as his entire time was occupied in working upon his father's farm. In 1843 and in 1859 he was elected to the State Legislature by overwhelming majorities on the strength of his personal popularity, for the district in which he resided generally cast a heavy vote for the party opposed to that to which he belonged. He was also elected to represent his district in the Thirtieth Congress.
lead_paragraph: Hon. J.I. SLINGERLAND died at his residence in New-Scotland on Saturday, aged 57 years. abstract: A special dispatch to the St. Louis Republican says:  "Gen. FERMONT and Staff arrived here yesterday, and the Benton Cadets, Col. CARR'S Cavalry, Maj. HOLMAN'S Sharpshooters, and Gen. SIEGEL'S command at different periods during the same day, finding no professed rebels in the place. Our troops were received with delight, the Stars and Stripes being displayed at numerous houses, and men, women and children waving handkerchiefs from almost every doorway."

abstract: We have an intimation from Fortress Monroe that the destination of the fleet, which left that place on Tuesday last, is to he divulged on Saturday. Undoubtedly the public will be gratified by receiving this intelligence, but it strikes us that in view of our numerous failures to achieve what we have heretofore undertaken to accomplish, it would be quite as well to curb our curiosity a few days longer, and then learn the actual result of the expedition. It would be decidedly mortifying to announce that we intended to capture Charleston, if we should be compelled to content ourselves with a less valuable prize, or possibly with another repulse. Let the fleet tell its own story, by all means.
lead_paragraph: We have an intimation from Fortress Monroe that the destination of the fleet, which left that place on Tuesday last, is to he divulged on Saturday. abstract: It has been suggested that the report  of Adj.-Gen. THOMAS to the Secretary of War was published by the Government, in order to vindicate with the public the foreordained removal of Gen. FREMONT. That it may render ...
lead_paragraph: -- It has been suggested that the report of Adj.-Gen. THOMAS to the Secretary of War was published by the Government, in order to vindicate with the public the foreordained removal of Gen. FREMONT. That it may render his removal necessary, by embroiling him in bitter personal quarrels with all his subordinates whose opinions were sought and have now been betrayed, is quite possible. When a high officer of the Government applied, in conversation, to Gen. HUNTER for his opinion of his commander, Gen. H. had a right to suppose that what he might say would be treated as confidential, and reserved for the use and guidance of the Government. He could not anticipate its publication to the world, especially while Gen. FREMONT was still in [???] -- her after such betrayal of his confidence could he possibly remain on such terms with his superior as are absolutely necessary to their effective cooperation in the field. And the same thing is true of every other officer who has been subjected to similar treatment.

abstract: -- It may be recollectedby many of our readers, that about four years ago we published the awful account of the burning of the house of the PERKINS family at Milburn, at night, when all the family, including father and mother, grandmother and eight children, eleven in all, perished in the flames. A Scotchman, by the name of WALTER MITCHELL, who lived in the neighborhood at the time, and who had a dispute with PERKINS as to the property, was suspected of the murder, but noproof could be found against him. He left soon after for the West. Before the burning of the house he warned PERKINS off the premises, and threatened if he did not leave to burn the house over his head. This MITCHELL recently died in Illinois, and on his deathbed confessed that he committed the horrible crime. He stated that he threw into the house a bottle of liquid, which set fire to it, and stupefied the inmates -- that Mr. PERKINS aroused himself and came to the door, when he knocked him back again, killing him. -- Binghamton Republican.
lead_paragraph: -- It may be recollectedby many of our readers, that about four years ago we published the awful account of the burning of the house of the PERKINS family at Milburn, at night, when all the family, including father and mother, grandmother and eight children, eleven in all, perished in the flames. A Scotchman, by the name of WALTER MITCHELL, who lived in the neighborhood at the time, and who had a dispute with PERKINS as to the property, was suspected of the murder, but noproof could be found against him. He left soon after for the West. Before the burning of the house he warned PERKINS off the premises, and threatened if he did not leave to burn the house over his head. This MITCHELL recently died in Illinois, and on his deathbed confessed that he committed the horrible crime. He stated that he threw into the house a bottle of liquid, which set fire to it, and stupefied the inmates -- that Mr. PERKINS aroused himself and came to the door, when he knocked him back again, killing him. -- Binghamton Republican.

abstract: This regiment, Col. FERRERO, which has been quartered since its organization at Palace Garden, left Wednesday morning for the seat of war. The regiment numbers over nine hundred men, all of whom are fully uniformed, armed and equipped. Long before the time named for their departure, Fourteenth-street in the vicinity of Palace Garden was crowded with people anxious to see the men off. Punctual to the time mentioned in the orders for departure line was formed, and the regiment marched down Broadway to Pier No. 1 North River, where the boat was taken for South Amboy, en route to Washington. Col. FERRERO and the majority of his Staff were mounted. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: We print in another column the opinion of Provost-Judge FREESE, of Alexandria, giving his reasons for his summary method of making the rebels pay their debts. He decides that when the debtor is shown to be aiding the rebels, any property of his may be seized by the Government, and handed over to his creditors. The decision is now before the President for final review, and, if sustained, marks an era of hope for Northern merchants having claims against the South. Judge FREESE, it will be observed, takes a bold stand. Whether he will be sustained by the Government remains to be seen.

abstract: To all who claim kindred to Ireland, it is eminently desirable that measures should be taken that some adequate share of the lustre which Irish soldiers may, in the present war, win for our national arms, should be reflected on the land of their nativity.
lead_paragraph: To all who claim kindred to Ireland, it is eminently desirable that measures should be taken that some adequate share of the lustre which Irish soldiers may, in the present war, win for our national arms, should be reflected on the land of their nativity. Noris this object desirable to men of Irish race alone, but to the nation; for while the concurrent opinion of military men attests the fact that the Irish make as fine soldiers as the world produces, it also bears witness that their efficiency is much increased by their aggregation in regiments and larger divisions, without the admixture of other nationalities. They have a nature and characteristics in common, which officers of their own race share with them and can best understand stand. The same appeals which rouse the enthusiam of the individual soldier, touch electrically the whole mass; the same incentives to daring; the same motives for discipline; the same ancestral recollections, traditions and pride are common to all. Each man feels that the honor of his native land, as well as the cause for which he fights, is at stake in his conduct, whether in camp or on the field of battle. Hence the advantages of association, and hence the experience of all armies, in which Irishmen have served, affirms their unproved efficiency when united in organization. The English Government, whose experience has been larger than that of any other, has recognized and acted on these truths. Certain regiments in its service are always recruited in Ireland, and have borne for generations titles importing their origin and nationality. In the French service the historical glories of the Irish Brigade which, for a century and a half, maintained the prestige of the national valor, are imperishable. Even in our own recent experience, who can believe that the novices in war, who composed the rank and file of the Sixty-ninth, would have borne themselves so gallantly on the disastrous field of Manassas, had they been distributed through several regiments of various nationalties, having nothing in common with their fellow-soldiers, but the cause for which they fought? Aggregated together, the exploits of their countrymen at Fontenoy, Rainillies, Cremona, Badajos, and through all the battle-fields of Europe, appeal to the heart and nerve the arm or every man to an Irish regiment whenever the cry of battle swells upon his ear; he feels instinctively that the honor of his native land, and the military traditions of his race are committed to his personal keeping, and must at any sacrifice of self be transmitted untarnished to his posterity. Many other considerations concur to render it desirable that the Irish soldiers enlisted in the present war should, as far as practicable, be kept together, and not be carelessly suffered to become a mere dilution of the mass of the Union armies in the field. The President has, accordingly, authorized the formation of an Irish brigade for the service of the United States, and patriotic men have undertaken the work. Three regiments are to be raised in New-York; one in Pennsylvania, and one in Massachusetts. The command has been offered to Brig.-Gen. SHIELDS, whose arrivalfrom California is now looked for, and of whose acceptance satisfactory assurances have been given. The organization of the force is already in a state of forwardness; but come pecuniary means are needed, which the Government does not furnish, to advance it to completion with the rapidity necessary for the public service. Inevitable recruiting expenses are but partially defrayed by the War Department. Temporary subsistence of men from the time of enlistment till they go into camp -- an interval in the case of rural recruits of some days -- has also to be borne by individuals. The allowance made under the acts of Congress for military music -- indispensable for discipline, order and cheerfulness in the toils of the march or the entrenchment -- is found inadequate at a time when the demand has become so suddenly enlarged. The bounty provided by Government to the soldiers is payable only at the conclusion of their term or service; and their pay, although counted from the time or enlisting, is not received till the end of three months. Men who depend for the support of their families on their daily labor, absolutely need some temporary aid to enable them to bridge over the first three months, which happens, in the present instance, to be the hardest three months in the year. To aid in the formation and dispatch of the Irish Brigade, a Committee of citizens, who sympathize with the movement, has been organized, and now appeal to to the public, and particularly to all who claim Irish birth or lineage, for assistance in this most important object.

abstract: The steamship Keystone State arrived at this port on Friday last, as has been already announced, bringing, as a prize, the steamer Salvor, captured off Key West, while attempting to run the blockade. As soon as the announcement of the arrival of the Keystone State was telegraphed to Washington, an order was issued by the Secretary of the Navy for the arrest of Capt. SCOTT, of the Keystone State, the charge being that of leaving his station. The order was telegraphed to Commander TURNER, at the Navy-yard, on Saturday, and the arrest was accordingly made. It is understood that the Government considered that it was the duty of Capt. SCOTT to have taken his prize into Key West, and to have condemned and sold her at that place; and it is intimated that the search for the privateer Sumter required the continued presence of the Keystone State in the cruising grounds to which she had been assigned.

abstract: Dr. LIEBER, in commencing his second lecture on this subject, quoted a passage from LIVY, that -- "There are also rights of war as well as of peace, and we so maintain that wars ought not only to be carried on by force, but also by justice," -- and remarked that he was willing to deliver all of his lectures with this motto at the head. He wished, he said, to add a few remarks to those he gave as introductory the last time. I wish, said he, to add an illustration of the fact that the greatest military genius is by no means necessarily the representative of the spirit of the times. ALEXANDER the Great was the greatest military genius, not only of his time, but of any time previous, but he was not the representative of his time. He did not represent Macedonian or Grecian ideas. I think ARISTOTLE represented far more than ALEXANDER everything that could be called Grecian. It might be said that CHARLEMAGNE was the great representative or his time, but he was in advance of his time, and far greater than a representative. Why do I dwell upon this subject? Because we have entered on a great martial period both in Europe and in this country, and the time will shortly come when prominent Generals will make great claims, which, he that loves civil liberty, will not be inclined to grant; and it is well to remember that these claims are not so well founded as some philosophers think they are. I am, by no means, of that class of men who, like Dr. CHANNING, think that military men are not men of great mental power and grandeur; I believe that real genius is necessary to make a great Captain. But there is a talent and genius frequently shown in other spheres; for instance, take the opinion of a great constitutional lawyer or England at some dangerous period, and see what an influence one or their decisions has upon the  successive history of England, -- take the dicisions of Judge HALE or SUMMER.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a number of petitions and resolutions ware referred. Mr. ORTON moved an amendment to the ordinance creating a relief fund for the families of volunteers, by limiting the weekly sum to $1 for each head of a family and 30 cents for each ...
lead_paragraph: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a number of petitions and resolutions ware referred. Mr. ORTON moved an amendment to the ordinance creating a relief fund for the families of volunteers, by limiting the weekly sum to $1 for each head of a family and 30 cents for each child, provided that not more than $3 per week be paid to the family of any one volunteer. Mr. ORTON supported his resolution by a statement that unless some such provision was made, the means on hand would be exhausted before December, and the Comptroller would be compelled to advance the amount of the unsold bonds. Mr. KEECH thought a saving might be made by beginning at once and cut off the sum of $9,600 for the salaries of parties employed and he ridiculed the idea of paying $2,400 to such a man as the one who was called General-Superintendent. He thought that was the proper way to economize the money for the suffering families. Mr. STEVENSON took the same ground, and thought the beginning should be made with these useless salaries officers. The discussion eventually took a wide range, many members taking part, nearly all agreeing in the necessity of abolishing the expenses of the highly paid officers controlling the fund. Mr. ORTON showed that the whole amount paid by the Comptroller for the distribution of the money was only $1,200 per month, under the half-million ordinance. The subject was eventually disposed of by ordering the resolution to lie over.

abstract: The immense fleet, under Flag-officer DUPONT, sailed this morning. The Wabash, with the gunboats, leading the van; then the troopship and the rear, protected by the Mohican, Seminole, Augusta, Florida and Alabama. The day was a fine one, and early in the morning, the report of a gun and a blue light, from the Wabash, were the signal for the fleet to get under weigh. The rear went to sea about 9 A. M.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Tuesday, Oct. 29, 1861.

abstract: Never before, perhaps, has the German element of our New-York population been so thoroughly aroused and in such complete political activity as at the present time. In the very height of the Native American excitement, when thousands of foreign-born citizens seriously believed that they were to be driven from the country, as well as excluded from franchise and office, no such general movement was visible on the surface, at least, as can now be observed among the German voters. The old distinction of Graybeards and Greenhorns, into which the earlier and later immigrations seemed to be divided, during the interval from 1850 to 1860, has, to all appearances, been laid aside or worn out; and although the division between Republicans and Democrats still subsists, both these parties try which shall shout the watchwords of the Union most loudly.

abstract: Hon. GERRIT SMITH delivered a free lecture on Wednesday evening, at the Church of the Puritans in Union-square, upon the "State of the Nation and the Conduct of the War." After prayer by Rev. Mr. DAVIS, the speaker was introduced to the audience by Mr. OLIVER JOHNSON, who said he was requested to state that Mr. SMITH intended writing out his address for publication, and it was his especial request that reporters would confine themselves to a brief abstract of his remarks. He then presented the speaker, who was very cordially, and with great unanimity, greeted by as large an audience as the house could conveniently hold. Mr. SMITH commenced by reading a text for his remarks in the shape of a resolution, to the effect that in the opinion of the audience there assembled this country would surely perish if our rulers persisted in recognizing the rights of rebels to all their possessions, spurning the aid in putting down the rebellion, of persons on account of their color and social condition ; and neglecting to substitute the swift, sure and effective instrument of martial law for the slow and uncertain processes of the civil law.
lead_paragraph: Hon. GERRIT SMITH delivered a free lecture on Wednesday evening, at the Church of the Puritans in Union-square, upon the "State of the Nation and the Conduct of the War." After prayer by Rev. Mr. DAVIS, the speaker was introduced to the audience by Mr. OLIVER JOHNSON, who said he was requested to state that Mr. SMITH intended writing out his address for publication, and it was his especial request that reporters would confine themselves to a brief abstract of his remarks. He then presented the speaker, who was very cordially, and with great unanimity, greeted by as large an audience as the house could conveniently hold. Mr. SMITH commenced by reading a text for his remarks in the shape of a resolution, to the effect that in the opinion of the audience there assembled this country would surely perish if our rulers persisted in recognizing the rights of rebels to all their possessions, spurning the aid in putting down the rebellion, of persons on account of their color and social condition ; and neglecting to substitute the swift, sure and effective instrument of martial law for the slow and uncertain processes of the civil law.

abstract: Messrs. BEYER & PEACOCK, of Manchester, England, are constructing fifty locomotives for a new railway in Spain. This is just one of a hundred examples that might be mentioned, of the large purchases made in England of machinery that could be more advantageously bought in the United States. Statistics show that the maintenance of locomotives costing $18,000 to $15,000, and running on smooth roads, in England, is very little less than that of locomotives costing $8,000 to $10,000, and running on rough roads in America. The superiority of the latter is largely in the distribution of weight and equalization of strain. And wherever the railway machinery of the two countries has run side by side, as in South America, the advantage is largely in our favor.

abstract: A year since over one-third of the resident population of Fairfax County were men of Northern birth and their families. About fifteen years since, attracted by the salubriousness of the climate and the beauty of the country, a number of Northern farmers  removed to Fairfax and Alexandria Counties with their families. The country was then in a miserable ...
lead_paragraph: A year since over one-third of the resident population of Fairfax County were men of Northern birth and their families. About fifteen years since, attracted by the salubriousness of the climate and the beauty of the country, a number of Northern farmers removed to Fairfax and Alexandria Counties with their families. The country was then in a miserable condition -- the soil exhausted by the thriftless system of slave cultivation -- and many farms, which had been the homesteads of old Virginia familes, had gone to ruin and were in some cases covered with young pines which were allowed to grow up everywhere. Wherever a Northern farmer bought a worn out farm two or three years sufficed to bring it up to an excellent condition. Others came and were continuing to come until the war broke out, at which time they constituted a large and influential class of the population. They settled generally in the eastern part of the county, and are to be found most numerous between Drainsville and Alexandria. Groups of four or five families are to be found in other parts of the county, and between Centreville and Manassas Northern families are not unfrequently met.

abstract: We learn from Washington that severe inconvenience is already felt in that city by reason of the loss of the navigation of the Potomac. The sole railroad line that remains is wholly inadequate to the comfortable supply of the population of the city and the vast army in its front. The pinch of this deprivation will grow more severe as Winter approaches, and may become a distressing social evil. But this is a trifle to what would happen in certain, perhaps very improbable, contingencies of the present insurrection.

abstract: The Directors of the Juvenile Asylum have under their care at the House of Reception in Thirteenth-street, and at the Asylum near the High Bridge, from 500 to 600 children. These children are gathered from the streets for vagrancy, begging, petty thefts, &c., brought under carful training and instruction, and as rapidly as their characters will warrant are sent out to Western homes. Forty-three boys and girls, who had received from one to three years' care, were sent out on Monday to Western homes undercharge of Mr. ALLAN, the Indenturing Agent.

abstract: It needs no great skill in reading, between the lines of Earl RUSSELL's "fine Italian hand," to detect in his late banquet-speech at Newcastle a spirit which, if not absolutely hostile, is certainly very far from being friendly to the United States. The Foreign Secretary has convinced himself that there is to be no restoration of the Union. He arrives at this con- ...
lead_paragraph: It needs no great skill in reading, between the lines of Earl RUSSELL's "fine Italian hand," to detect in his late banquet-speech at Newcastle a spirit which, if not absolutely hostile, is certainly very far from being friendly to the United States. The Foreign Secretary has convinced himself that there is to be no restoration of the Union. He arrives at this conclusion, not from any question as to the power of the American Government to put down the Pro-Slavery Rebellion -- but because a restoration of the Union is undesirable! It is his conviction that neither the voluntary submission of the South -- "the seceded States again with all the rights of the Constitution" -- nor a forced rehabilitation of the Union by the conquest and subjugation of the insurgent States -- is a thing to be wished. The train of reasoning that led up to this conclusion is remarkable in no respect except as showing the kind of evidence on which an English statesman makes up his mind on a great question of national right.

abstract: There is nothing to prevent unlimited intercourse between Texas and Mexico. It is but an affair of crossing a few miles of desert, and a few more of water, that puts the American traveler at Tampico, whence constant opportunities are offered to Vera Cruz. From Vera Cruz sails the English mail steamers to the West Indies, there connecting with the extended line which terminates at Southampton; so that between New-Orleans and London there is nothing to interrupt regular communication. The facilities are not perhaps equal to those offered at New-York; but they have advantages. Rebels may make use of them without risking their invaluable liberties by a transit over loyal territories; or incurring pursuit upon the high seas of National ministers of vengeance. The assertion of the right of search in its most offensive form would be necessary to enable us to stop Royal Mail steamships, and ascertain by personal inspection whether there were agents of treason on the passenger list. So convenient is the way to Europe via Vera Cruz, that an enterprizing gentleman at New-Orleans, one ANTONIO COSTA, proposes in a paper of that city to establish forthwith passenger and express communications twice monthly by so feasible a route.

abstract: Letters have been received in this city from Paris stating that, contrary to partial expectation there, the Emperor NAPOLEON has not been in the least "exercised" by the Count DE PARIS and his cousin, the DUC DE PENTHIEVRE, having obtained commissions in the Federal army of the United States. In 1859, the DUC DE CHARTRES (second son of the late DUC D'ORLEANS) served, during the Italian war, under VICTOR EMANUEL's banner, and, though then little more than eighteen years old, fairly won his commissionof lieutenant in the Dragoon Guards of Nice.He frequently shared the perils of the French armyin the field, and, with NAPOLEON's special concurrence,was treated by his officers with the respect generallypaid, in Europe, to royal princes. At all events, NAPOLEON has no control, moral or legal, over the ex-royal family of France.

abstract: We regret to see that our anticipations as to the result of the trial of the privateers of the Savannah, proved correct. The jury, after being out from half-past three o'clock in the afternoon of Wednesday until eleven in the forenoon of Thursday, announced that they were unable to agree, and were discharged. Possibly it would have been well for the Court to keep them still longer, in view of the fact stated by one of them to the Court that there was a difference of opinion among the jurymen about the charge of the Judge, some of them thinking that the others did not under, stand the charge, while those others thought they did. But, on the whole, we are inclined to think that no other result would have been arrived at, for the Judge's charge was so clear, as it seems to us, that any doubt as to its meaning can only be accounted for by the old rule, that none are so blind as those who will not see.

abstract: Amongst the passengers who reached here in the Louisiana from Old Point Comfort was a gentleman named BROMWELL, a merchant doing business in Brooklyn, who, during the few minutes he remained here, having to go North in the first train, gave an interesting account of affairs in Richmond during the the present month. Mr. BROMWELL left that city on ...
lead_paragraph: Amongst the passengers who reached here in the Louisiana from Old Point Comfort was a gentleman named BROMWELL, a merchant doing business in Brooklyn, who, during the few minutes he remained here, having to go North in the first train, gave an interesting account of affairs in Richmond during the the present month. Mr. BROMWELL left that city on last Thursday, and reached here by the James River and land route from Great Bethel to Old Point. In company with several officers of the Confederate army ho came down the river in a small steam tug, and landed at a place called Brooktown, about 12 miles from Newport's News Point. He experienced but little difficulty in passing the pickets of the Federal forces, being in undress uniform, and his only object in going North was to meet some obligations of a financial character.

abstract: There was an immense Union demonstration in Detroit a few days ago. Speeches were made by Hon. E.V.N. LOTHROP, and others. During the progress of the meeting Gen. CASS entered the room, and was received with deafening cheers. He was called on for a speech, but replied that his presence was the best testimony he could give to the interest which he still felt in the cause.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent informs us that there is a probability that the present system of accepting volunteers only through the State authorities will be dropped, and that the Government will revert to the system of accepting companies and regiments direct. This, it is believed, will be found necessary, on account of the growing disinclination of the men to pass through the long routine of red tape and swindling to which they are now in many cases subjected.

abstract: The Pacific Telegraph has been in contemplation for ten or twelve years, at least, during which time Messrs. O'RIELLY and others have presented to Congress several applications for Government aid. These several projects successively failed. Some years ago the Western Union Telegraph Company, of this city, brought the subject before the representatives of all the Telegraph Companies in the United States,who expressed themselves favorably to the project, and agreed to cooperate with the Western Union in procuring the passage of a bill through Congress granting such Government aid as was deemed indispensable to success.

abstract: Much ill-natured speculation is indulged in here at the apparent inactivity of the army, some blaming the President and Cabinet, and some the Commanding Generals. I have reason to believe that the President has devolved the whole responsibility of a forward movement on Gen. McCLELLAN, and placed every facility in his power to accomplish it. If he fail to advance, it will be because his army ...
lead_paragraph: Much ill-natured speculation is indulged in here at the apparent inactivity of the army, some blaming the President and Cabinet, and some the Commanding Generals. I have reason to believe that the President has devolved the whole responsibility of a forward movement on Gen. McCLELLAN, and placed every facility in his power to accomplish it. If he fail to advance, it will be because his army is not perfect in all of its appointments, or that the enemy is too numerous, or too well intrenched, to justify an attack. Gen. MCCLELLAN's movements thus far have been characterized by extreme caution -- a quality, perhaps, which was required by the exigency of the times. He has shown great powers of organization, but that organization has not even yet been brought to the highest state of efficiency. It now remains to be proved whether he is possessed of that strategic skill, that power of wielding great masses, and throwing them with overpowering effect on a given point, which will entitle him to be enrolled among the great commanders. His onward course is beset with difficulties, but they are such as a great general, backed by the resources of the North, can overcome. In front, BEAUREGARD has withdrawn to his intrenchments, about Manassas Junction, and is busily engaged in preparing his Winter quarters. The nature of the intervening ground, between the hostile camps is impracticable for the manoeuvring of a large force; and his position, I have reason to believe, is so strong that it can be destroyed only by regular approaches, which is a slow and tedious process. In the meanwhile, his communications with the South and West are such that he can concentrate men and munitions by rail, quite as rapidly as we can by the common roads of the country. It then becomes reduced to a question of superiority of resources, at a point of eligibility, of the enemy's selection. I therefore predict that thig season will not be made historical by another battle near Bull Run.

abstract: The Hispano-Gallo-Anglican expedition to Mexico involves, it seems, a joint action, with a judicious distribution of parts. There were wrongs to be redressed, outrages to be punished, European subjects to be protected, and a stable government to be created; and these ...
lead_paragraph: The Hispano-Gallo-Anglican expedition to Mexico involves, it seems, a joint action, with a judicious distribution of parts. There were wrongs to be redressed, outrages to be punished, European subjects to be protected, and a stable government to be created; and these details of the business are assigned to the fleet and land forces of France and Spain. An army of six thousand men will be landed, and after the capture of Vera Cruz, will be marched to the City of Mexico. When once there, we are left in a maze of doubt as to its action. The Spanish official papers take pains to assert that the troops of that Government will lend themselves to the support of neither of the two factions now dividing the republic. But there is an apparent difficulty in achieving the task set down for the inland expedition if this programme be strictly adhered to by both its members. There must of necessity be a setting up and a putting down of factions, if anything like the contemplated reform of the Government be effected; and this Spanish declaration can only be construct as meaning that by a [???] partition of roles, France is to execute so much of the undertaking, as involves a forcible arbitration between the Liberals and Reactionists. But there need be no refining upon the subject. The mere fact of invasion, in the actual state of the Liberal Administration, practically settles the question. At the coming of the abhorred Gachupins, there may be a temporary rally of the people, forgetful for the moment of the priesthood, to the support of the Government. "Death to foreigners" will instantly become a national cry. The reckless massacre it will provoke will simply madden the invaders, and compel them to abandon the idea of relying upon the efficacy of a mere display of physical force; practical and positive warfare will ensue; and there can be little doubt as to which of the contestants will be driven to the wall. It will be a conflict between a disorganized and impoverished people; and two nations whose purses are long enough, and armies large enough, to fight thus conjointly the strongest isolated Government in the world.

abstract: There were no movements of more than ordinary importance at the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, although business is as brisk as ever. The officers on duty at the yard, and those in and around the City, were paid off yesterday, but the men have not yet been paid. The storeship Supply is taking in her stores, and will be ready for sea in the course of a few days. The bark Roebuck has hauled into the berth vacated by the Sheppard Knapp, and is being armed and supplied with stores and provisions. The steamer New-London left the yard and anchored off the Battery. She will sail at once. The Santiago de Cuba, which we reported ready for sea yesterday, will not be put into commission until next week.
lead_paragraph: There were no movements of more than ordinary importance at the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, although business is as brisk as ever. abstract: A paper obviously published for a specific object, may be suspected of having been written for a specific object, and therefore unfairly. We are accordingly not surprised to find the report of Adjt.-Gen. THOMAS accused of inaccuracy, and that by witnesses of his own choosing, and whose testimony he proposes to report.
lead_paragraph: A paper obviously published for a specific object, may be suspected of having been written for a specific object, and therefore unfairly. We are accordingly not surprised to find the report of Adjt.-Gen. THOMAS accused of inaccuracy, and that by witnesses of his own choosing, and whose testimony he proposes to report. E.W. DAVIS, Assistant Quartermaster under Gen. FREMONT, has written a letter for publication, marking several palpable errors in Gen. THOMAS' representation of his testimony, especially denouncing the report in regard to contracts for blankets. These, it seems, were a compulsory purchase, and at a price so low as to preclude all idea of corruption; and it also appears that when the character of the goods was brought to the notice of Gen. FREMONT, he at once ordered better ones, if better were procurable, to be at once substituted. The average price of these blankets was one dollar and fifty cents.

abstract: The retirement of the veteran patriot, Lieut.Gen. SCOTT, is announced this morning. On Thursday last, he sent to President LINCOLN a letter announcing his determination to avail himself of the provisions of the act for retiring officers, recently passed by Congress his physical infirmities rendering it absolutely necessary that he should seek repose.
lead_paragraph: The retirement of the veteran patriot, Lieut.Gen. SCOTT, is announced this morning. On Thursday last, he sent to President LINCOLN a letter announcing his determination to avail himself of the provisions of the act for retiring officers, recently passed by Congress -- his physical infirmities rendering it absolutely necessary that he should seek repose. A special Cabinet meeting was in consequence convened yesterday morning, at which it was unanimously agreed to place the command, of the army in the hands of Gen. MCCLELLAN -- after which the President and Cabinet waited upon Gen. SCOTT in a body, and the President read to him the order retiring him in accordance with his request, and fully recognizing his eminent services to the country. Gen. SCOTT responded in a brief and feeling speech of thanks, and the ceremony concluded with the assurance from the President that the General's Staff should be properly provided for. Gen. SCOTT, it is understood, will leave Washington for his home in this City to-day.

abstract: Whenever "Mozart" calls, it is needless to say that there will be at least a numerous response from that part of the Democracy which owes allegiance to the rival of Tammany, and the ratification meeting held last evening at the Cooper Institute disappointed no one in regard either to the numbers or enthusiasm of the audience. In character and intelligence, they perhaps compared unfavorably with those who filled the hall a few evenings since, and the standing and ability of the speakers (with one or two exceptions) was not such as to promise a remarkably rich treat of eloquence. Music and torches, however, by sweetness and brilliancy, did much to make up for any shortcomings in other respects.

abstract: The election of next Tuesday excites comparatively but little interest, and the probability is that a light vote will be cast. Public sentiment throughout the State seems to be unanimous in favor of the vigorous prosecution of the war, and even the Democratic Party has been compelled to modify and explain its platform so as to conform, in appearance at least, to this universal demand.
lead_paragraph: The election of next Tuesday excites comparatively but little interest, and the probability is that a light vote will be cast. Public sentiment throughout the State seems to be unanimous in favor of the vigorous prosecution of the war, and even the Democratic Party has been compelled to modify and explain its platform so as to conform, in appearance at least, to this universal demand. The resolution originally adopted in its Convention in favor of a peace policy, was first repudiated by both the Tammany and Mozart wings of the party here, then explained by the Central Committee, and afterwards thrown overboard by the candidates themselves. All these movements, however, are mere electioneering tricks, and intended to win for the ticket, by indirect means, a degree of support which it could never have secured on its merits. The vote which may be cast for it will be very widely regarded as a protest against the war.

abstract: The Hamburg steamship Borussia passed Cape Race yesterday, with advices from Europe three days later, a telegraphic summary of which is given elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The Hamburg steamship Borussia passed Cape Race yesterday, with advices from Europe three days later, a telegraphic summary of which is given elsewhere. The commercial news is interesting. Another advance of 1/4d.@1/2d. had taken place in Cotton, while Breadstuffs were again declining, and Provisions were dull. An abundance is reported in the London Money Market. Consols had advanced, being quoted at 92 3/8@92 1/2 for money. Political advices from the Continent are not of particular importance. Further reactionary movements are expected in Italy. Agitation was increasing in Poland, especially in Warsaw.

abstract: THOMAS MCCREARY, a ship-carpenter, working on one of the new gunboats under Mr. ENGLISH, fell on Monday, Oct. 28, and was instantly killed. He leaves a wife and five children in perfect destitution, The widow is a respectable and industrious person, and lives at No. 374 Tenth-street, near Avenue C. The benevolent are earnestly requested to inquire into this case, which is one of great distress; and to either call or send to this number to assure themselves that this is no fictitious call, but a genuine case of suffering, caused by God's inscrutable providence, and not by idleness or improvidence.

abstract: In pursuance of a purpose announced by us some ten days since, and for reasons which we then assigned, Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT has withdrawn from active service, and, upon his own application, been placed on the retired list of the army of the United States. The incident is one of universal interest, and was very properly made the occasion of a simple but impressive ceremony. Upon receiving the General's application for leave to retire, the President, attended by the Cabinet, waited upon him at his residence, and with every demonstration of respect and honor, informed him that his request was granted. The General replied in some unpremeditated remarks, full of grateful emotion, expressing his ardent love of the Union, and his prayers for its preservation, and his cordial confidence in the patriotism and wisdom of the Administration.
lead_paragraph: In pursuance of a purpose announced by us some ten days since, and for reasons which we then assigned, Lieut.-Gen. abstract: The Hong Kong Press of the 10th of Aug. says: "The United States storekeeper at Shanghai was a politician named 'Judge' CLEARY. We believe he earned the title from having been a magistrate in California. It seems by the last advices from Shanghai that this man, in connection with Col. WARD, (the celebrated fillibuster,) Capt. ALLEN, (who brought the steamer Surprise from California,) and Capt. LYNCH, (for some years in command of the steamer Antelope, and lately of the Contest,) purchased the schooner Neva, equipped her from the United States naval stores, and intend to cruise off this coast as a privateer. The steamer Saginaw hurried up yesterday, on the intelligence being made known, and, we make small doubt, will capture her.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS -- SUIT AGAINST THE COUNTY -- THE RELIEF FUND -- CHANGE OF A RULE. -- An adjourned meeting of this Board was held in the Assessors' office Thursday evening. The Chairman presented a peremptory mandamus against the Board, requiring them to audit and allow the account of George Remsen, late Sheriff, amounting to $10,891 80. The document was referred to the Law Committee, with power to employ counsel and defend the suit. A communication was presented from the Superintendents of the Poor transmitting a statement of the fund in their hands for the relief of families of volunteers, of which the annexed is a balance sheet:

abstract: There seems to be little doubt that, nearly a week ago, a special messenger left Washington with a letter to Gen. FREMONT, ordering him to transfer his command to Gen. HUNTER until a successor shall be specially designated. [We have good reason to believe that such a letter as the one spoken of by our correspondent has been prepared, but that it has or will be forwarded is not so certain. ED. TIMES.]

abstract: An officer on board the ship Vandalia, till lately one of the squadron off Charleston, writes with reference to some of our strictures on the imperfections of the blockade at that point. He thinks the Navy Department, which did not send proper vessels, and more of them, is to blame, and not the force, which did the best it could.
lead_paragraph: An officer on board the ship Vandalia, till lately one of the squadron off Charleston, writes with reference to some of our strictures on the imperfections of the blockade at that point. He thinks the Navy Department, which did not send proper vessels, and more of them, is to blame, and not the force, which did the best it could. Perhaps he is right. But his explanations are certainly not of a cheering character. For three months out of the five since the establishment of the blockade, he tells us, a large steam-frigate, which did no service, and the Vandalia, a sailing vessel, drawing quite a heavy draught of water, and therefore incapable of capturing the small sloops and schooners that ran along the shore," composed the whole blockade off Charleston! What wonder, with this state of things, that the French Consul at Charlestos has recently been able to flaunt in Paris a schedule of three or fourscore "vessels" that had run the Charleston blockade! The writer of the communication cannot see how the Nashville could have escaped; there was the Roanoke commanding the entrance of the harbor, the Flag the southern channel, the Vandalia the northern, the Monticello cruising everywhere, and a bright moonlight all night! It is very extraordinary to be sure; but as not indeed the Nashville, but the Gorson really did escape, and carried Messrs. MASON, SLIDELL and suite to Cuba, we don't see but what somebody must have been napping. Perhaps they got out the same way the Thomas Watson got in. This vessel, from Liverpool, with a valuable cargo of salt, blankets, cloths, &c., successfully ran the blockade of Charleston on the night of the 14tth of October, but chanced to ground off the mouth of Stone Inlet. Next morning, hours after the affair, she was discovered by our squadron, and was there burnt by them --an exploit for which they have claimed a great deal more applause than people would have been willing to accord them had it been known that the whole affair was a crowning proof of their imbecility.
headline: {'main': 'The Blockade off Charleston.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Blockade off Charleston.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A few days since we published in the TIMES an account of a horrible murder, supposed to have been committed in New-Jersey. The murdered man, SIGISMUND FELLNER, was a German Jew, about 40 years of age, who arrived in this country, on the 19th of October, by the steamship Bavaria. His body was found floating in the water, near Applegate's Landing, NewJersey.
lead_paragraph: A few days since we published in the TIMES an account of a horrible murder, supposed to have been committed in New-Jersey. The murdered man, SIGISMUND FELLNER, was a German Jew, about 40 years of age, who arrived in this country, on the 19th of October, by the steamship Bavaria. His body was found floating in the water, near Applegate's Landing, New-Jersey. The Detectives of this City had the matter placed in their charge, for the purpose of ferreting out the party or parties who committed the crime, after the New-Jersey authorities had done what they could towards bringing it to light. The matter was placed in the hands of Detectives FARLEY and TIEMAN, and they at once set to work upon what was deemed an almost hopeless undertaking; but after much labor and effort, they succeeded in arresting a Mrs. MARKS and her sister, Miss ALBERTINA FLAUN, two Polish Jewesses who had accompanied the illfated FELLNER on his voyage to this City. They were taken to headquarters and there detained until Friday night, when Miss ALBERTINA FLAUN was taken to the Fourteenth Precinct Station-house and confined, enough having been ascertained by the officers to warrant them in the belief that she was an important witness in the investigation of the case. It was ascertained that on the passage over, the murdered man, Mr. FELLNER, and the two ladies above named, were very intimate -- so much so as to be noticeable to the passengers. Upon their arrival here FELLNER went to the Prescott House, and the ladies to a boarding-house, No. 45 East Broadway. Shortly after the two ladies called upon Mr. F. at the Prescott House, and during the interview there had, Mrs. MARKS is known to have charged Mr. F. with improper intercourse with her sister, Miss FLAUN, and demanded of him redress, with a dagger in her hand. Immediately after this meeting, FELLNER, who was known to have a confidant in the person of one RADETSKI, also a Polish Jew, boarding at No, 4 Carroll-street, Brooklyn, took counsel of him, and by his advice he removed his quarters from the Prescott House to Brooklyn. This was about ten days ago, and on the 22d ult., FELLNER disappeared from the boarding-house in Brooklyn, in company with his new-found friend, RADETSKI, and no more was seen of him until his body was found in the waters of New-Jersey. FELLNER was known to be possessed of a large amount of gold and diamonds, and it is believed by the police, that RADETSKI, with the aid of accomplices, had murdered him, and afterwards cast his body into the waters on the Jersey coast, in the hope that it would float out into the ocean, and never be heard or seen again.

abstract: The funeral of ALEXANDER B. ELDER, late Lieutenant-Colonel of the Tenth Regiment, took place yesterday from the residence of his sister, No. 731 Third-avenue. His remains were escorted to the Albany boat, to be taken to Albany, his late residence, for interment. Lieut.-Col. ELDER was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, and was in his 28th year at the time of his death. He came to this country in 1835, and was one of the original members of the Tompkins Blues, Twelfth Regiment N.Y.S.M., in which corps he was Captain of Company C. On the organization of the Tenth Regiment, (Col. MCCHESNEY), he was elected Lieutenant-Colonel, and went to Fortress Monroe with his regiment. When Col. MCCHESNEY resigned, he was unanimously elected Colonel of the regiment by the line officers, and acted in that capacity for three or four months, until the appointment of Col. BENDIX. Whilst at Fortress Monroe he contracted the typhus fever, and returning to this City to recruit his health and obtain volunteers for his regiment, he unfortunately had a relapse which terminated fatally. He was a brave and efficient officer, and in private life was universally beloved.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of ALEXANDER B. ELDER, late Lieutenant-Colonel of the Tenth Regiment, took place yesterday from the residence of his sister, No. 731 Third-avenue. His remains were escorted to the Albany boat, to be taken to Albany, his late residence, for interment. Lieut.-Col. ELDER was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, and was in his 28th year at the time of his death. He came to this country in 1835, and was one of the original members of the Tompkins Blues, Twelfth Regiment N.Y.S.M., in which corps he was Captain of Company C. On the organization of the Tenth Regiment, (Col. MCCHESNEY), he was elected Lieutenant-Colonel, and went to Fortress Monroe with his regiment. When Col. MCCHESNEY resigned, he was unanimously elected Colonel of the regiment by the line officers, and acted in that capacity for three or four months, until the appointment of Col. BENDIX. Whilst at Fortress Monroe he contracted the typhus fever, and returning to this City to recruit his health and obtain volunteers for his regiment, he unfortunately had a relapse which terminated fatally. He was a brave and efficient officer, and in private life was universally beloved.

abstract: It cannot be otherwise than that the retirement of Gen. SCOTT from the command of the army, will be noted as an era in the military history of the country. His career, indeed, embodies all there is of the National military life since the revolutionary period. His first services as a soldier were in the second war with Great Britain.
lead_paragraph: It cannot be otherwise than that the retirement of Gen. SCOTT from the command of the army, will be noted as an era in the military history of the country. His career, indeed, embodies all there is of the National military life since the revolutionary period. His first services as a soldier were in the second war with Great Britain. With all that was creditable and successful in that contest his name was associated; and when peace was concluded, it was found that while the honors of the navy were disputed by a half-score of heroes, between whose relative merits it was scarcely possible to distinguish, the palm of superior military skill was, by almost universal consent, assigned to Gen. SCOTT. It was after the conclusion of peace that Gen. JACKSON, by his gallant and successful defence of New-Orleans, appropriated a share of fame and respect, which his conduct of the Seminole war subsequently so augmented as perhaps to unduly overshadow and depreciate the genuine merits of SCOTT. But, while with less ambitious views than JACKSON, SCOTT confined himself strictly to a professional career, his hold upon the confidence and affection of the people was never weakened; and cotemporaries will recall the general expression of satisfaction, when he succeeded MACOMB as General-in-Chief of the army. It was not, as events proved, a succession to a sinecure. The South was about to precipitate the nation into a conflict with a neighboring Republic, the population of which had, in a random but continuous fashion, practiced themselves in the art and skill of fighting; while the existing generation of the American people, during a long period of peace, not otherwise broken than by frontier skirmishing with Indians, had lost all familiarity with the profession of soldiership. It fell upon Gen. SCOTT to convert a war, beginning with a series of victories in no wise earned by scientific management, or the observance of the maxims of practiced generalship, but rather secured by the exhibition of splendid valor, in a war of masterly conduct, where all the resources of military science were brought into action. No contrast could be greater than that between the operations of TAYLOR and those of SCOTT. The former carried into his campaigning the rapidity, courage and dash of a knighterrant; the latter moved slowly to his object, with a passionless adaptation of means to ends, a thorough appreciation of the relative strength and resources of the combatants, and the oversight of no element of safety and certainty. In short, he overcame the enemy by professional rule, and acquired the fame of a great General rather than of a daring leader. While such qualities command the respect of the masses of the people, the achievements of the cavalier are more to the popular taste. TAYLOR and JACKSON were heroes of popular idolatry; SCOTT was the object of profound regard; his reputation a matter of national pride: and his military talents have been looked to by the entire people as an always reliable defence, upon which, in case of danger to the country, confidence might be unhesitatingly reposed. Traits appealing to the imagination are the materials of which popularity is made. The characteristics of Gen. SCOTT appealed rather to the judgment and the understanding, and JACKSON and TAYLOR grasped the honors of the Presidency, which eluded the hand of the great soldier, as they had eluded the hands of civilians in their province equally great.

abstract: managed suspense, in the development of a dramatic plot, is among the most effective resources of the playwright. We are now having a National experience of that mood in an intensity and on a scale that overtops all fictions, for ours is suspense over a tremendous reality. Never, perhaps, was there concentrated on a single object an interest, an anxiety, and a hope, so intense as that with which the naval expedition sailed freighted last Tuesday. Five days have passed, and no wordfrom the armada, save the report brought back by a returning vessel that she left the fleet off Cape Hatteras! Those who would follow it further must do so i' the mind's eye.

abstract: -- Adah Isaacs Menken's divorce suit comes off this week at Woodstock, Ill. Adah's attorneys are a Chicago lawyer, well known for his musical talent, and Judge Murphy, of Woodstock. In Adah's prayer which is on file in the records of the Clerk's office at that place, she says that Heenan lived on her earnings acquired by her upon the stage, so long as she would give them to him, and that site even deprived herself of luxuries, as well as her child, (born from marriage with him, but now deceased,) in order to support him in his dissipated and licentious habits. She says that he never contributed to her support, and when she ceased to give him money he cast her off. That he has lived in open adultery with a notorious woman, which is a source of constant disrespect and insult to herself. That last Fall he committed adultery with one Harriet Martin, in the City of Chicago. In view of all these and other grievances, she prays for a divorce. Heenan has paid no attention to the case and denies that he was ever her husband.
lead_paragraph: -- Adah Isaacs Menken's divorce suit comes off this week at Woodstock, Ill. Adah's attorneys are a Chicago lawyer, well known for his musical talent, and Judge Murphy, of Woodstock. abstract: TRIAL TRIP OF THE FLAMBEAU. -- The steamer Flambeau made a trial trip on Friday, and proceeded outside beyond the Light-ship, and returned to her berth, in the Atlantic Basin, at about 5 P.M. The Flambeau is owned by Mr. FORBES, of Boston, and is intended for the China Seas. The dimensions of the hull, which was built by LAWRENCE & FOULKS, are one hundred and sixty-five feet keel; one hundred and eighty feet on deck; breadth, thirty feet ; depth of lower hold, eleven and a-half feet; between decks, seven feet. The engine and boilers were built byHENRY ESSLER & Co., of the Atlantic Works, Atlantic Basin, Brooklyn. Engine over-head beam, cylinder fifty inches diameter; stroke of piston, five feet. The propeller shaft is driven by three heavy wheels, with wooden cogs, making two and three-quarter revolutions to one of the engine. The steam is condensed by one of SEWELL's Patent Surface Condensers, which returns to the boilers all the used-in steam, perfectly fresh. A limited number of guests were on board. There was a bountiful and excellent lunch furnished by her liberal owner, to which ample justice was done. Everything passed off in a very agreeable manner, and all were highly pleased with the excursion.
lead_paragraph: TRIAL TRIP OF THE FLAMBEAU. -- The steamer Flambeau made a trial trip on Friday, and proceeded outside beyond the Light-ship, and returned to her berth, in the Atlantic Basin, at about 5 P.M. abstract: A terrible crime has recently been perpetrated at Marcellus Falls, about three miles from Marcellus village, which resulted in the death of JOHN GALLIGHAN and JAMES ENGLISH. It appears that a man named BEASY, who was employed at OLNEY's distillery at Marcellus Falls, went to the village on Tuesday morning after a physician to attend a man who was hurt at the distillery. Upon repairing to the place, the dead body of JOHN GALLIGHAN, book-keeper in the distillery, was found in a beer vat with his neck lying across the chime of a water-pail, and the body of JAMES ENGLISH was found at the foot of a flight of stairs. Beside him, JOHN ENGLISH, his brother, was lying. He had seven wounds upon his face, and was so stupefied with whisky as to be unable to answer any questions.
lead_paragraph: A terrible crime has recently been perpetrated at Marcellus Falls, about three miles from Marcellus village, which resulted in the death of JOHN GALLIGHAN and JAMES ENGLISH. abstract: A patient endurance of monotonous routine is as much a soldier's duty as gallantry upon the field, so that an occasional approach to the actual dangers of his career carries with it an inspiriting relief.  The march of Gen. FREMONT from St. Louis presents little more than that systematic attention to military detail, which constitutes the ordinary precursor to the conflict.

abstract: The attempt to array the judicial power on the side of the Southern rebellion, is one of the indications of a system long pursued by DAVIS, FLOYD & Co., to secure the army, the navy and the Judiciary to support the coup d'etat of March 4, 1861, when Washington was intended to be seized by armed conspirators from Virginia and Maryland; President LINCOLN to be assassinated, DAVIS made President in his place, and BRECKINRIDGE continue as Vice-President. With the whole Government in the hands of this military aspirant, DAVIS resolved to become a Napoleon or Cesar, an American Imperator, under the name of President. Gov. HICKS, of Maryland, Secretaries DIX and HOLT, Gen. BUTLER, DANIEL S. DICKINSON, and the great mass of the Jackson Democracy in the Free States, aided by many patriotic men in Maryland, Western Virginia, Kentucky and Missouri, took away from this American Cesar the American crown and the American throne, when it seemed within his grasp. God's Providence so ordered events that the coup d'etat failed, and the overthrow of this conspiracy and its armed hosts is as certain as any future event. It is but a question of time.

abstract: Times of trouble and disaster are touchstones. They not only bring out hidden elements of strength or weakness in those upon whom the disaster falls, but they throw new lights upon all with whom life has brought them in connection.
lead_paragraph: Times of trouble and disaster are touchstones. They not only bring out hidden elements of strength or weakness in those upon whom the disaster falls, but they throw new lights upon all with whom life has brought them in connection. Many a man has seen when the period of his reverses had come, displays of kindness and nobleness where he had never looked for them, selfishness and malignity where he had thought never to find them -- and this latter display is often one which adds a bitterness before unfelt to the sorrow which had assailed him, so that the words come naturally to his lips, "It was not an enemy that reproached me; then I could have borne it."

abstract: At an adjourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, the several vacancies in the offices of Canvassers and Inspectors, caused by resignation, were filled. Several bills and petitions were appropriately referred. The bill of J.A. Hasbrouck, for printing, &c., amounting to $1,500, which was lost at the last meeting, was taken up, and, with a communication from Mr. Hasbrouck, referred to the proper Committee, with instructions to report on Thursday next.

abstract: As the announcement of the death of Gen. HOUSTON comes to us now through two different channels -- Nashville and Galveston -- both concurring as to the day on which the event took place, we incline to believe that it is true. It may be a harsh thing to say, but it is a truth nevertheless, that if old "San Jacinto" had died a year ago his memory would have been cherished by millions and millions of his countrymen, who will now only think of him as one who, after having maintained the flag of his country on many a well-fought field, had not the moral courage to stand by that flag when it most needed his support.
lead_paragraph: As the announcement of the death of Gen. abstract: Last evening Mr. FRANK E. HOWE, of this City entertained six of the Fifteenth Massachusetts Regiment, who were wounded in the battle of Bad's Bluff. They have received a furlough, and were on their way home, in charge of Lieut. FULLER. They are all evevely wounded, one having had his leg shot off another a wound in his shoulder and breast, and a third a ball through his thigh. They were all in good spirits, and determined to return to the war, if they are able, at the end of their furlough. They speak in the highest terms of their Colonel, CHARLES DEVINS, and say that every soldier of the regiment will stand by him till they die. The wounded men left on the 6 o'clock train last evening for Boston.
lead_paragraph: Last evening Mr. FRANK E. HOWE, of this City entertained six of the Fifteenth Massachusetts Regiment, who were wounded in the battle of Bad's Bluff. abstract: The severe easterly rain storm which prevailed yesterday and last night seriously interfered with military and telegraphic operations. From Washington we have little of importance. Gen. MCCLELLAN, it is announced, will retain the immediate command of the army of the Potomac. A sword was presented to him yesterday by a Committee of the City Councils of Philadelphia, and during the ceremony he took occasion to express his confidence in the ultimate success of the National arms.

abstract: The nice barometer of Wall-street yesterday gave signs of prevalent, fears lest the storm should have worked ill for the great Southern naval expedition. There is every likelihood, however, that our armada, which resembles the renowned one of Spain in the grandeur of its proportions, as had a very different fate. There is, in fact every probability that our fleet is now riding securely in some commodious Southern harbor. The expedition sailed on Tuesday, and could easily by this time have rounded Cape Sable. But -- we may now safely make the disclosure -- the expedition was not designed to go as far as the Gulf, and its destination, not ten parallels south of New-York, was without doubt reached some days ago. The Ethan Allen, which returned to Fortress Monroe on Thursday, saw the fleet safely off Cape Hatteras, and so passed one of the most dangerous points of the coast. A telegram from Baltimore, received last night, brings word from a vessel which passed the fleet off Cape Hatteras on Wednesday, and reports that the storm was brewed this side of the Cape. We have thus every reason to expect that the expedition met nothing but fine weather, while if it did catch the outer rim of the gale of yesterday, the only inconvenience experienced may have been a temporary delay in effecting a landing. We may look out, then, one of these mornings, for a brilliant bulletin.

But -- we may now safely make the disclosure -- the expedition was not designed to go as far as the Gulf, and its destination, not ten parallels south of New-York, was without doubt reached some days ago. The Ethan Allen, which returned to Fortress Monroe on Thursday, saw the fleet safely off Cape Hatteras, and so passed one of the most dangerous points of the coast. A telegram from Baltimore, received last night, brings word from a vessel which passed the fleet off Cape Hatteras on Wednesday, and reports that the storm was brewed this side of the Cape. We have thus every reason to expect that the expedition met nothing but fine weather, while if it did catch the outer rim of the gale of yesterday, the only inconvenience experienced may have been a temporary delay in effecting a landing. We may look out, then, one of these mornings, for a brilliant bulletin.

abstract: The schooner Susquehanna, DANIEL MYERS, (colored,) captain, and owned by him conjointly with Messrs. APPLEGATE  SON, of Baltimore, reached this port on Tuesday, having succeeded in running the rebel blockade of the Potomac. Capt. MYERS is very well known among the merchants of this city, and especially among the flour shippers. He is about 69 years of age, and has been a ship-master, trading to and from Baltimore for the last 55 years.

abstract: SUICIDE IN PRISON. -- On Friday forenoon, about 11 o'clock, a German named CHARLES VEITMER committed suicide in his cell in the County Jail at Hudson City, where he was confined, awaiting sentence for larceny. He had cut his throat with a razor, and died within half an hour after having been discovered. An inquest was held by Coroner DONNELLY, and a verdict of death by suicide was rendered.

abstract: Brig Lotus, of Granville, N.S., Capt. THOMPSON, arrived, Sunday, Nov. 3, from Arrozo, P.R., 18 days with sugar and molasses to master. Left no American vessels. Oct. 21st, lat. 28, long. 70, she was spoken by a fore-and-aft schooner, of about 160 tons, showing the Confederate flag, the Captain of which inquired whether they had seen any American vessels or left any in port when she left. He took in most of her sail and lay to, head to south and west. She carried one pivot-gun amidships, and had a crew of about fifty men.
