abstract: The heavy easterly storm which culminated on Saturday night, was one of the severest that has been experienced for twelve months on this part of the coast. The tide on Saturday evening and Sunday morning, in the East and North Rivers, rose higher than it has been known for over 20 years, several of the docks being completely submerged, while the streets fronting the river were kneedeep with water.
lead_paragraph: The heavy easterly storm which culminated on Saturday night, was one of the severest that has been experienced for twelve months on this part of the coast. The tide on Saturday evening and Sunday morning, in the East and North Rivers, rose higher than it has been known for over 20 years, several of the docks being completely submerged, while the streets fronting the river were kneedeep with water. In Broad-street the tide extended as high as Beaver-street, a distance of five blocks The cellars along South, Front, Water and Beaver streets, were flooded, and a large quantity of flour stored in many of these cellars was badly damaged. On the North River, the cellars along Washington, West and Greenwich streets, were also flooded, and many of the poor families occupying the basements in that locality, suffered severely. The bar-room in the basement of the Northern Hotel, on the corner of West and Cortlandt streets, was also flooded; and in order to serve their customers a small boat was brought into requisition to carry the parties to the bar, at a nominal charge of two cents per head, many availing themselves of the opportunity, as it was so novel and ludicrous. The Atlantic and other docks along the Brooklyn shore were also submerged; there being but little or no merchandise on the docks, of course but slight damage could be sustained to goods.

abstract: The storm that passed over this city on Saturday evening was one of the most violent experienced here for many years. The rain fell in torrents, and almost without cessation, until midnight, and the wind blowed in fearful gusts, doing considerable damage, particularly to moveable fixtures. As usual on such occasions, signboards, awnings, chimney-tops, and ornamental frees were the first to yield to the blast, and were scattered in admirable confusion in every direction, so that pedestrianism was an unsafe experiment during the height of the gale. A new three-story brick house (unoccupied) on Elliot-place, between De Kalb and Lafayette avenues owned by JOHN BROPHY, was blown down, and a large number of buildings were more or less injured in different parts of the city. The sewers were all flooded, and some gave way under the action of the water. On Fulton-avenue, near Lafayette, the pavement sank into the sewer a distance of twenty or thirty feet. The high tide flooded many of the cellars on the low grades near the East River, and considerable damage must have resulted therefrom. The shipping at the wharves and the ferry-boats rode out the gale in safety.

abstract: Mr. SMITH O'BRIEN has, through the columns of the Dublin Morning News, addressed a long letter, dated Dublin, Oct. 21, to Capt. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER, on the American war. Mr. O'BRIEN deprecates the views taken by Mr. MEAGHER, who advocates the war against the South; and proceeds to snow that,even supposing the Northerns were successful, they would not be able to keep the conquered States in subjection. Mr. O'BRIEN offers his own services as a mediator between the belligerent parties, to assist in restoring peace.

abstract: Major ZAGONYI having stated in his official dispatch that Major WHITE had not participated in the attack on Springfield, the following telegram received from Maj.-Gen. FREMONT, via St. Louis, by Judge WHITE, of this City, (Major WHITE's father,) fully explains the cause: St. LOUIS, Nov. 1, 1861.

abstract: The People have determined that this election shall not be controlled by partisan considerations. They desire that it should be simply a declaration of this City and State in favor of the Union and against rebellion. And they have put in nomination a State, County and Judiciary ticket, which represents their sentiments and embraces men of all political parties who agree on this one cardinal point.
lead_paragraph: The People have determined that this election shall not be controlled by partisan considerations. They desire that it should be simply a declaration of this City and State in favor of the Union and against rebellion. And they have put in nomination a State, County and Judiciary ticket, which represents their sentiments and embraces men of all political parties who agree on this one cardinal point. That ticket is published in our advertising columns, and justly claims the support of all who concur in the principles and the purposes which it represents. The men whose names are upon it are all of high character, and deserve the public confidence and support.

abstract: Our news from all parts of Central and South America is unusually meagre and uninteresting by the mails which centre here. There are slight ripples on the surface in Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia, but no great chance, apparently, that they will culminate into "mountain waves." Chili is quiet, happy, and even jubilant under the new millennium of conciliation and compromise inaugurated by her new President.

abstract: - In the directions given the females of Secessia for knitting socks for the rebel soldiers, they are told that "the foot should be at least eleven or twelve inches long." For the "Chivalry," one of the proudest of whose badges is the delicacy of their understanding, this might be profanely styled a big thing on foot. Ex pede Herculem is an old phrase, whose modern form is likely to be ex pede Secesh -- you may know a rebel from his foot!

abstract: We had thought to have done forever with the Falstaffian HOLLINS, but the conflagration which his exploit has lit up in the journals of the Crescent City forbids our losing sight of the valiant "pepperer." HOLLINS is happy. HOLLINS is a hero. Republics are proverbially ungrateful, but the Southern Confederacy gushes towards HOLLINS. To be sure "the noble veteran" brought back his "little Confederate mosquito fleet," with the sting taken out of it -- the fire ships having stranded and fizzled completely and the ram having broken his nose against the Richmond. Nevertheless HOLLINS, who is a good deal of an artist in his line, and, like another "battered old veteran," knows the effect of a "lie well told," got off a splendid bulletin, and the Orleanese made a Sardanapalism of their lean supply of grease in his honor. In fact, HOLLINS has had an apotheosis. And, as it is a relief to think we have had the last of him, we append, with deep emotion, the scene in which the hero goes up in a blaze of tallow oil. We copy from the New-Orleans Crescent;

abstract: As a general thing, the rank and file of the Democratic Party have come up nobly to the support of the Government in its contest with rebellion. Thousands upon thousands of them have rallied to the defence of the country, and are now in the field to defend the Constitution and the Union against their deadly foes.
lead_paragraph: As a general thing, the rank and file of the Democratic Party have come up nobly to the support of the Government in its contest with rebellion. Thousands upon thousands of them have rallied to the defence of the country, and are now in the field to defend the Constitution and the Union against their deadly foes. From the moment the first blow was struck, -- when the first shot was fired at Fort Sumter, -- they have done everything in their power to sustain the honor of the Stars and Stripes, and to protect the institutions and the Government of the country. In our Legislature last Winter, the great body of the Democratic members threw aside all party considerations, and voted freely men and money to suppress the rebellion. And nothing did more to startle the rebels and to check their progress than this noble and resolute unanimity among men of all parties in the Empire State, and especially in this City, in favor of a vigorous and effective prosecution of the war against rebellion.

abstract: The easterly storm of Saturday [???] severest which has been experienced for many years, and caused one of the most terrible shipwrecks which has occurred on the Atlantic Coast for years. The ship Maritana was driven on the rocks near Boston Light, and totally lost, involving the destruction of twenty-seven lives. Considerable damage was done in this City, particularly along the river fronts, where the tide inundated the cellars, and even overflowed the piers, destroying considerable quantities of goods and rendering the places untenable. The parks in the City suffered in their trees and foliage, the grounds were gullied by the heavy rain floods, and some of the Railroads leading into the City had extensive damage done to their tracks. The Sound steamers were compelled to make a harbor and wait for the subsidence of the gale. They mostly arrived yesterday afternoon, and report two or three vessels ashore in the Sound. The pilot-boats report the gale as very severe outside, and some of them lost sails and spars. The grounds of the Greenwood Cemetery were also considerably damaged. Our telegrapic reports indicate that the storm has been unusually severe elsewhere, especially in the Chesapeake Bay.

abstract: Yesterday, the detectives, FARLEY and TIEMAN, succeeded in recovering $260 of the money which Mrs. MARKS had received for diamonds, and she had deposited for safe keeping with a Mr. SCHAMMEL. On Saturday night the movements of Mr. FELLNER's watch, and his gold spectacles were procured. The gold cases of the watch had been detached and sold. A photographic likeness of Radelsky, the alleged principal in the murder, who is still at large, may be seen at Police headquarters. Mrs. MARKS having signified her inclination to die, is kept under a close watch, to prevent her following the example of her sister, ALBERTINA FLAUM.

abstract: The General arrived in this City on Saturday evening, accompanied by the gentlemen of his Staff, and also by Secretary CAMERON, Maj.-Gen. BUTLER, Brig.-Gen. MCCALL, Col. CULLOM and others. On account of the severity of the storm, it was supposed that the party would remain over in Harrisburgh. This circumstance, together with the heavy rain, prevented the assemblage of the people who, under other circumstances, would have turned out to do honor to the retiring General. To those who were present to welcome him Gen. SCOTT gave a cordial grasp of the hand and a hearty benediction, expressing a wish, however, that no attempt at a reception should be made. When the crowd about the car cheered him, he said, good naturedly, "Oh, go home, friend, and don't make a noise." He was assisted to his carriage and was driven to his son's residence in Twelfth-street. Adjutant-Gen. THOMAS escorted him to his home.

abstract: There was great rejoicing all through Chili over the Anniversary of the National Independence, and at the conciliatory tone exhibited toward all parties and factions by the new President Senor JOAQUIN PERIZ.
lead_paragraph: There was great rejoicing all through Chili over the Anniversary of the National Independence, and at the conciliatory tone exhibited toward all parties and factions by the new President Senor JOAQUIN PERIZ. "Forgiveness, reconciliation, and the cooperation of all in the prosperity of the Republic, -- such is Senor PEREZ's simple programme," -- says the Mercurio. Balls, dinners, and other fetes, had been given in his honor, both at Santiago and Valparaiso, in which friends and old foes vied in paying him honors. At the ball given at Santiago "in the centre of the pit, floored over for dancing, there was an elegant fountain of sparkling waters, crowned by inscriptions in letters of fire. The whole interior of the theatre was covered with brilliant hangings, flowers and ornaments."

abstract: The elections for Judges, &c., for the approaching election for President of Peru, in the place of Gen. CASTILLA, took place throughout the country on the 13th, with what result has not yet been ascertained. The candidates for President are Dr. MAR Gen. SAN ROMAN and Gen. ECHENIQUE. Riots occurred on the day of election between the different clubs, and some pistol shooting, but order was restored by the military.
lead_paragraph: The elections for Judges, &c., for the approaching election for President of Peru, in the place of Gen. abstract: It is easier to make a dyke that shall be invulnerable to the water on one side and to vermin on the other than to maintain a perfect blockade.
lead_paragraph: It is easier to make a dyke that shall be invulnerable to the water on one side and to vermin on the other than to maintain a perfect blockade. Three thousand miles of coast cannot be so walled in by ships that nothing can be thrown on the shore and nothing carried off. It was not an improved coastguard but a reduced tariff that suppressed the smuggling of French goods across the British Channel. It was not the force of our armies but the irresistible devices of commerce that broke down NAPOLEON's Berlin decrees. So we may be sure that, however legally effective may be the Federal blockade of the Southern ports, there will be always cotton ships crossing the Atlantic if the planters are willing to sell; and we may be sure that they will be the more willing the higher that prices rise through the rigor of the prohibition. But there is another fact no less certain, namely, that the quantity thus brought off will be quite insufficient for our wants, and at a rate far above our means. The world cannot afford to buy of us cloth, the raw material of which we have ransomed rather than purchased. Illicit supplies will help to keep us in work till the four quarters of the earth are teeming with the plant for which we have offered a reward. But if we try to make American cotton serve us as heretofore, we shall find the Indian weaver underselling us, by working up in his rude loom the fibres we have caused to be grown. We must have free trade in cotton and free trade in bread, in time of war as in time of peace, if ever again we are to be at ease touching food and labor. In place of idly speculating upon the supplies that may reach us in driblets, or madly threatening the belligerents with European intervention, our politicians and manufacturers should address themselves in earnest to an amendment of the law of nations. Seeing that all the great Powers are, more or less, concerned in the relaxation of the American blockade, why should they not address to the United States Government a proposal based upon its own language in 1856 and 1857? Why should they not invite its assent to a general agreement, exempting all private property not of a warlike nature from blockading and privateering? Such an agreement would afford no special advantage to the Confederates -- for it would leave exposed to confiscation all cotton consigned to their Government. It would, therefore, do no injustice to the Federalists -- reopeningto them, indeed, a lucrative trade, from which they are now shut out. It would involve no presumption on the part of the European Powers -- and no humiliation, save to the Government by whom such proposals were scouted when they came from Washington. Our Chambers of Commerce then urged their acceptance. Let the same and other Mercantile Associations unite now to press the matter upon the attention of our statesmen. Let the French manufacturers be invited to join with those of England in addresses to their respective Governments for this just and beneficent object. The success of such a movement would do far more than relieve the severity of a present exigency. It would establish as a principle the liberation of peaceful commerce from the bonds of war, and secure at least one great benefit to mankind from a war of uncertain though unfolding issues.

abstract: Mayor WOOD, in his speech at Cooper Institute, on Friday night, in support of JAMES LYNCH for Sheriff, said it was "difficult to see what connection there is between the election of a Coroner or Sheriff and the saving of the Union." That difficulty has been considerably diminished by the proceedings of the meeting referred to.
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD, in his speech at Cooper Institute, on Friday night, in support of JAMES LYNCH for Sheriff, said it was "difficult to see what connection there is between the election of a Coroner or Sheriff and the saving of the Union." That difficulty has been considerably diminished by the proceedings of the meeting referred to. The speeches made on that occasion, and the specific claims of the candidate whose election it was designed to aid, leave very little to be learned upon that subject. If we were to hear that the City of New-Orleans had elected for Sheriff a man who refused to fight against the Union, -- who had quit the field of battle on the eve of an engagement, -- who had left the ground just as the action commenced, and who had been branded in the official report of the commanding General as having "marched to the rear to the sound of the enemy's cannon," -- we should have no difficulty whatever in coming to the conclusion that the City of New-Orleans had very strong sympathies with the Union, and was only half in earnest in its pretended support of the Union cause. And this belief would be immensely strengthened, if the speeches made in support of such a candidate were filled with bitter denunciations of the rebel Government, and exultant predictions of its utter failure.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent telegraphs positively that the order transferring the command of the Western Military Department from Gen. FREMONT to Gen. HUNTER, has been sent to the former, and has probably reached him. The order is stated to be absolute and unconditional, and based upon a thorough conviction of FREMONT'S incapacity as a General, and of his profligacy in the expenditure of the public money.

abstract: -- The election in this District is distinguished by the fact that the only genuine relic of the Buchanan and Breckinridge Democracy is running for the State Assembly. Mr. AUG. SCHELL, who was Collector of this Port during the last Administration -- who had bolted from Tammany Hall in 1853 -- who attended the Charleston Convention, and acted with YANCEY & Co. in breaking it up, and who finally, alone we believe of the New-York delegates, bolted from the Baltimore Convention because it nominated STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, and who supported JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, now in the rebel army, for President, -- is the candidate whom the Democrats have seen fit to nominate. It is the boldest political movement of the season. It is said that Mr. SCHELL moved into that District quite lately, as the only one in which he could secure a nomination from the Democracy. Whether this is so or not, it would be very extraordinary if, at this late day, after all the disastrous experience we have had of the Buchanan Administration and of the flagrant treason of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, any District in this City could be found willing to indorse them, by electing a man so thoroughly identified with both, and so bitterly hostile to DOUGLAS, as Mr. SCHELL. It may possibly be done, -- but we shall not believe it until after the votes are counted.

abstract: There is really much less confusion in the leading nominations for office at the election to-day than at first sight one is apt to suppose. There have been a great many separate organizations of parties, but the candidates of all those among them which are entitled to special notice are substantially the same. There are really but two parties,--one repre-...
lead_paragraph: There is really much less confusion in the leading nominations for office at the election to-day than at first sight one is apt to suppose. There have been a great many separate organizations of parties, but the candidates of all those among them which are entitled to special notice are substantially the same. There are really but two parties, -- one representing the Government, and pledged to stand by it steadily and heartily in its contest with rebellion, -- and the other seeking, as directly and openly as they dare, to cripple its efforts and destroy its chances of success.

abstract: The main interest of the election to-day, so far as the County canvass is concerned, turns on the election of Sheriff. One wing of the Democratic Party has nominated JAMES LYNCH for that office, -- and he is supported, as is evident from the speech of Hon. LEVI S. CHATFIELD, which we quoted yesterday, on grounds equivalent to open and flagrant sympathy with Secession. Under ordinary circumstances there would be little fear of his election; -- but his supporters have been artful enough to enlist nearly the whole Irish vote in his behalf, in spite of the fact that, from lack of sympathy with the Union cause, or from some other motive, he left the field on the eve of the Battle of Bull Run, and "moved to the rear to the sound of the enemy's cannon." His election, instead of conferring honor upon our Irish fellow-citizens, would be really a most serious impeachment of their patriotism, and would be quoted everywhere as an evidence of their sympathy with secession.

abstract: vestigation in the case of the two men, JOHN GALLIGAN and JAMES ENGLISH, the victims of the tragedy at Marcellus last Monday night, resulted last evening in the rendering of a verdict that they were killed by ALBERT BESSY and JOHN ENGLISH, all the parties being under the influence of liquor at the time. A warrant for the arrest of the implicated parties was immediately issued by Coroner DIDAMA, and Deputy-Sheriff GILBERT, aided by Chief MULHOLLAND, immediately arrested BESSY and ENGLISH. BESSY and his wife had been before the Coroner's Jury, and they were still at Alvord's Hotel, in Marcellus, where the investigation was held, when he was taken in custody. ENGLISH was at his father's house, three-quarters of a mile from Marcellus, and was greatly surprised when the officer called for him. His father and mother were much distressed that their youngest boy should be charged with his own brother's murder. The arrests were made at about 8 o'clock, and the prisoners were brought to this city and lodged in the watch-house at 10 o'clock. They were taken before Coroner DIDAMA this morning. CORNELL CRYSLER and CHARLES ANDREWS, Esqs., appeared in their behalf, and waived an examination for a few days. They were then committed to the Penitentiary.

abstract: At about 7 o'clock on Sunday evening last, the body of PHILIP AUGUSTUS EMBURY was found at Fishkill, N.Y., a few rods from the railroad depot, and on the road leading back from the river passing Meyers' Hotel. An examination was made, when it was ascertained that he had been murdered, having received a fatal stab in the back with some long, sharp instrument, which passed nearly through the body, and must have caused instant death.
lead_paragraph: At about 7 o'clock on Sunday evening last, the body of PHILIP AUGUSTUS EMBURY was found at Fishkill, N.Y., a few rods from the railroad depot, and on the road leading back from the river passing Meyers' Hotel. An examination was made, when it was ascertained that he had been murdered, having received a fatal stab in the back with some long, sharp instrument, which passed nearly through the body, and must have caused instant death.

abstract: A private letter from the United States Consul, at Nassau, N.P., dated Oct. 28, states that there have been several arrivals from the blockaded (?) ports, one of which brought a nephew of Gen. HARDEE. "I am under the impression," says the writer, "that he was on the lookout for arms and powder, which, I am officially informed, were to be shipped from England. Last week, the armed steamer Theodora, alias Gordon, Capt. LOCKWOOD, direct from Charleston, chased the New-York Underwriter's steamer Johnston into the very mouth of the harbor, but as Capt. HOYT was near the light-house, she stood off for Havana, as the Captain of the Gordon told the Conchs who boarded her, that he had a lot of passengers for England, via Havana." Among them were Messrs. MASON, SLIDELL and company. She was heavily armed.

abstract: On Sunday afternoon, at about one o'clock, the Twenty-seventh Massachusetts Regiment, Col. LEE, arrived in Jersey City, on its way to Perryville, Md. On Saturday morning, camp was broken at Springfield, and the regiment took the cars for the city of Hudson, at which place it embarked on the steamer...
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, at about one o'clock, the Twenty-seventh Massachusetts Regiment, Col. LEE, arrived in Jersey City, on its way to Perryville, Md. On Saturday morning, camp was broken at Springfield, and the regiment took the cars for the city of Hudson, at which place it embarked on the steamer Connecticut, and was carried to the Jersey City railroad depot. The numerical strength of the regiment is about 050, all of whom are fully uniformed, armed and equipped. The weapons supplied the men is the Enfield rifle. Accompanying the regiment is a full band and drum corps. All the necessary camp equip age, ambulances, wagons, horses, and everything needful for the comfort and well-being of a regiment is carried with them. The Sons of Massachusetts turned out in great force to welcome the Twenty-seventh, and bid them God-speed on their mission The following is a list of the officers:

lead_paragraph: Fighting has been renewed in Western Virginia, the rebels this time being the attacking party. A dispatch to the Cincinnati Gazette from Gallipolis, dated on Saturday, states that on the morning of the day previous, FLOYD attacked Gen. ROSECRANS at two points -- opposite Gauley Bridge and at Camp Tompkins. FLOYD is represented to have had heavy guns and a large force of infantry -- at least four thousand attacking Camp Tompkins. The number at Gauley Bridge was not known. Another dispatch to the Cincinnati Commercial, dated Saturday evening, states that the firing continued all day Friday, but with no effect of consequence upon the national forces who replied with spirit and silenced two of the enemy's batteries. The tiring had not been renewed on Saturday, and it was believed that such a disposition had been made of the National forces that FLOYD and his whole army would be captured. This intelligence is verified by a dispatch from Maysville, Ky.

abstract: The British schooner Dashaway, of Halifax, reports that on the 20th inst., in Crooked Island passage, was chased by a hermaphrodite brig, which continued in pursuit for two days, when she hauled her wind and stood to the north and eastward. She carried four staysails and royal, looked very rakish, and was painted black, and sailed very fast. On the 25th in lat. 35°, lon. 74°, saw a pilot-boat rigged schooner,' painted black, carrying a large flying staysail, and supposed her to be a privateer.

abstract: OF SPURIOUS BALLOTS. -- Justices WOODRUFF and HOFFMAN are nominated for the SUPERIOR COURT by all the organizations except Tammany. Some of the Mozart tickets are, by a fraud, printed with MONELL and BARBOUR, Tammany, substituted for WOODRUFF and HOFFMAN. Other ballots have WOODRUFF and HOFFMAN for the Supreme Courts instead of SUPERIOR. This unworthy trick will vitiate  the ballot. The ticket should read -- "FOR JUSTICES OF THE SUPERIOR COURT, LEWIS B WOODRUFF, MURRAY HOFFMAN."

abstract: The steamship Jura, from Liverpool on the 24th via Londonderry on the 25th of October, arrived at Father Point at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. She brings one day's later news. The sales in the Liverpool cotton market for the week were put down at 146,000 bales, at a general advance of d.@1d., the market closing unsettled. The speculators took 82,000 bales, and the exporters 13,000.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Jura, from Liverpool on the 24th via Londonderry on the 25th of October, arrived at Father Point at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. She brings one day's later news. The sales in the Liverpool cotton market for the week were put down at 146,000 bales, at a general advance of d.@1d., the market closing unsettled. The speculators took 82,000 bales, and the exporters 13,000. The stock on hand was estimated at 614,000 bales, of which 321,500 were American Trade prices in Manchester were advancing. Breadstuffs had a declining tendency, and provisions were still quiet. The bullion in the Bank of England had increased to L211,500, and Consols were quoted at 92 3/4@92 7/8 for money. The drain of specie from France still continued, and it was expected that the Bank of France would speedily adopt some new measure to better the condition of money affairs. The political intelligence by this arrival is unimportant.

abstract: The jury in the case of Rev. Thomas J. Williams, who has been on trial in Newark charged with conduct unbecoming a clergyman, after being out all Thursday night, failed to agree, and were yesterday morning discharged. The defendant was held to bail on his own recognizances for his appearance at the January term. The Judge ruled out the main points in the indictment, there being no evidence to sustain them, and directed the jury to consider the simple question of "Assault." On this the jury disagreed -- 8for acquittal and 4 for conviction. It is understood that the prosecution will be abandoned.

abstract: The charge of Judge NELSON to the Grand Jury in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, which is given in our columns elsewhere, will attract attention from several considerations. The first part of it, relating to the Slave-trade, would in ordinary times have been the chief subject of interest, but in these days of treason the Slave-trade does not so much interest the public. Their thoughts are turned another way, and the latter part of this charge will attract most attention.

abstract: -- We learn from the officers of the steamer Liberty, which reached here yesterday afternoon, that on Wednesday last the steamer Igo, Capt. SAM. PRICE, exploded at Hill's Landing, about six miles below Parkersburgh, killing one man and scalding fifteen, some slightly, and others seriously. The steamer was badly blown up. The Igo was a stern-wheel steamer, which has been running for some time between Gallipolis and Parkersburgh. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, Nov. 2.

abstract: Yesterday morning, Mrs. MARKS, who had been apprehended upon suspicion of having been concerned in the murder of FELLNER, attempted to commit suicide in the Eighth Ward Station-house. She had been confined there since Saturday last. Previous to her entering the cell, a search was made by a matron to see that she had no instruments or means of self-destruction.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, Mrs. MARKS, who had been apprehended upon suspicion of having been concerned in the murder of FELLNER, attempted to commit suicide in the Eighth Ward Station-house. She had been confined there since Saturday last. Previous to her entering the cell, a search was made by a matron to see that she had no instruments or means of self-destruction. Notwithstanding this precaution, it appears that she had secreted about her a penknife, with which she attempted to end her existence. The female in charge of her was in the room at the time, and so well was her plan of self-destruction put into execution that she did not suspect her purpose. Mrs. MARKS was sitting on a lounge, with a shawl around her, and her right arm thrown over the back of her seat, and her left hand she used for the purpose of taking from her secret pocket the penknife, and thrusting it into the main artery of her right arm. She was careful to hold her wounded arm so far over the back of the lounge that her keeper could not discover the blood as it flowed from the wounds, especially as it was covered by her shawl. It happened, however, that very shortly after she had inflicted the wound, the female guard had occasion to go out for a few minutes, and during her absence an officer took her place. He at once discovered that his prisoner looked very pale and languid, and went to Capt. HELME, telling him his suspicions that all was not right. Upon the Captain's arrival, he immediately removed her shawl, and discovered the blood running in a stream from the wounded arm. The prisoner fast becoming insensible, a surgeon was called forthwith, the artery closed, and the wound dressed, but last evening the unfortunate woman was so low that little hopes were entertained of her recovery by the surgeon. When asked by the officers why she had attempted to end her existence at this time, she replied that she felt sad on account of the death of her sister, Miss FLAUME, and that she had a fear that she herself would be convicted of the murder of FELLNER unless she died before they had a chance to try her.
headline: {'main': 'THE FELLNER MURDER.; Attempted Suicide of Mrs. Marks--Confession, &c.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE FELLNER MURDER.; Attempted Suicide of Mrs. Marks--Confession, &c.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Although the critical condition of our National affairs, the ravages of the great storm of Saturday last, and the apprehensions awakened thereby, for the safety of the Naval Expedition which left Hampton Roads, southward-bound, on the 29th have somewhat overborne the political excitement usually predominant in Gotham, on the eve of an election, yesterday still was, by no means, unmarked by many of the peculiar agitations and movements which precede and accompany the exercise of popular suffrage.

lead_paragraph: On Sunday this regiment, Col. W.B. HEYWARD, which has been encamped at Camp Wheeler, near Ogdensburgh, for the past seven weeks, arrived in this City in route for the seat of war. It was the original intention to quarter the men on landing at the Park Barracks. Owing, however, to some difficulty among them, they were not disembarked, but remained on board the steamer, which was anchored opposite Thirtieth-street, North River, all night.

abstract: THE WRECKED VESSELS. -- The ship Maritana, Capt. G.W. Williams, which was wrecked near Boston Light, was 991 tons register; built in Quincy, Mass., in 1857, and rated as an A 1 ship. She belonged to Providence, and was owned by S. Mauran, and others. The bark Nathaniel Coggswell, wrecked at Scituate Beach, Boston harbor, was 308 tons register; built in Charleston, S.C., in 1855; belonged in Boston, and was owned by the captain and others.

abstract: Col. FEATHERSTONE, who commanded one of the Mississippi regiments in the late battle at Leesburgh, has made a statement, giving the result of the action, and some additional circumstances adding to the lustre of our victory. He states that we took 77.6 prisoners, four pieces of artillery, 1,600 muskets, and a quantity of clothing. Our forces engaged in the action did not exceed 1,500 men. The enemy had from seven to twelve regiments. Our loss was not more than 150 killed and wounded. The enemy's loss in killed, wounded, drowned and prisoners, is stated to have not been less than 1,900 men.

abstract: Sound, about five miles east of Eaton Neck Light between Fresh Pond and Smithton Landing, on Sunday morning, Nov. 3, the body of a man, apparently about thirty years of age, height 5 feet 10 inches, dark brown hair, whiskers full and slightly sandy, one upper front tooth gone, one front side tooth with large cavity filled with gold. Had on red flannel undershirt, unbleached muslin shirt, two pair pants, (under ones snuff brown color, outer ones small black and white stripe), vest of figured cotton or worsted, with rolling collar of black satin, loose pea-jacket or sailor's coat, heavy goods, fine black and white stripe, black silk neck tie, no collar, low-quartered patent-leather shoes. The body evidently had not been in the water many hours. There were no marks of violence on it, except scratches evidently produced by the action of the water against the shore. There was also found near the same place a small skiff, about 12 feet long and 4 feet wide, planking cedar, and clear pine gun-wales, painted yellow, with blue stripe around top, white stern, no name or mark. Coroner SHEPARD held an inquest on the body, and will have it suitably buried in the Huntington cemetery, if not claimed. The clothing can be seen, or further information obtained by calling on. G.H. SHEPARD,

lead_paragraph: very sharp contest among the three candidates for this important office. It is the only office on the County ticket in regard to which the nominations of the Republicans and the People's Union differ -- the former having nominated A. OAKEY HALL, and the latter Mr. LAWRENCE. Mr. HALL has the advantage over Mr. LWARENCE of the support of the regular Republican organization, together with that of one of the wings of the Democracy, and of several of the other organizations of the day. It is not at all impossible that Mr. LAWRENCE may withdraw from Mr. HALL votes enough to secure Mr. WATERBURY's election -- but he cannot receive enough to secure his own.

abstract: There have been no novelties at the theatres during the past week, the pieces now before the public seeming to answer all the requirements of the managers and abundanly satisfying the lieges. Nor does it seem probable that any important change will be made in the various programmes until Monday next, when the Winter Garden will have to substitute annother "star" for Mr. J.S. CLARKE, the present luminary.
lead_paragraph: There have been no novelties at the theatres during the past week, the pieces now before the public seeming to answer all the requirements of the managers and abundanly satisfying the lieges. Nor does it seem probable that any important change will be made in the various programmes until Monday next, when the Winter Garden will have to substitute annother "star" for Mr. J.S. CLARKE, the present luminary. This excellent comedian has been drawing fine houses, and the "Octoroon" if it could be continued, would, from present appearances surpass its first career in profitableness and duration. But Mr. CLARKE's other engagements interfere fatally with this desirable result, and the piece must be withdrawn on Saturday next. The few opportunities that remain will undoubtedly be seized by the public to witness a play in which incident, action, pathos and effect are so wonderfully blended.

abstract: In the Supreme Court yesterday afternoon-- Justices CLERKE, SUTHERLAND and BARNARD presiding-- the distinguished British Member of Parliament and Queen's counsel, Mr. EDWIN JAMES, was admitted to the New-York Bar. It is understood that he intends to make this City his home, and that he will enter at once upon the practice of the profession in which he has won such conspicuous honors abroad.
lead_paragraph: In the Supreme Court yesterday afternoon -- Justices CLERKE, SUTHERLAND and BARNARD presiding -- the distinguished British Member of Parliament and Queen's counsel, Mr. EDWIN JAMES, was admitted to the New-York Bar. It is understood that he intends to make this City his home, and that he will enter at once upon the practice of the profession in which he has won such conspicuous honors abroad. In spite of the barriers that oppose the progress of mere talent, however great, to high success in England, Mr. JAMES had achieved, without the slightest aid from aristocratic connections, the very high distinction of standing among the foremost members of the British Bar. Since the elevation of Sir FREDERICK THESIGER to the chancelorship and that of Sir ARTHUR COCKBURN to the Chief Justiceship of the Queen's Bench, he has been almost without a rival, in some branches of the profession. As a parliamentary counsel, even previous to their elevation, he held the highest position No member or petitioner believed his chances secure until Mr. JAMES had been retained, and the statute book of England is indebted to him for the new bankruptcy act, and many of the wisest measures which have marked the course of legal reform in the past few years. In all the "causes celebres" which have awakened interest here, he has figured as leading counsel either for the prosecution or defence. The conduct of the case against PALMER, in the celebrated Rugeley poisoning, was committed to him. In the prosecution of BERNARD for conspiracy against the life of LOUIS NAPOLEON, he led for the defence, and his eloquent vindication is almost as familiar among us as it is over Europe. But recently, in the case of Col. DICKSON against the Earl of Wilton, he did battle for the soldier's rights and honor against the whole power of the Court and Horseguards, and obtained a verdict of twenty thousand dollars.

abstract: Yesterday, the members of the Union Defence Committee held a meeting, Comptroller HAWS in the Chair, for the purpose of expressing proper sentiments of esteem and respect for Gen. SCOTT on his retirement from the command of the army. Mr. A.A. LOW and Mr. SIMEON DRAPER submitted a series of resolutions, all of them eulogizing the high worth and genius of Gen. SCOTT. The matter, however, was deemed to be of too much importance to be dismissed with the adoption of a series of resolutions. Judge PIERREPONT proposed that a Committee be appointed to take into consideration the best manner of expressing to Gen. SCOTT the high regard and veneration in which he was held. Judge PIERREPONT's proposal was approved of and adopted, and the following gentlemen were appointed the Committee -- EDWARD PIERREPONT, A. A. LOW, A.T. STEWART, DAVID RITTENHOUSE, and R.H. MCCURDY. Messrs. DRAPER and LOW's resolutions were then referred to the Committee, and the meeting adjourned subject to their call.

abstract: The rebels by this time, must pretty fully appreciate the magnitude of the contest they have in hand, and the peril in which they are placed. Assuming the Ohio River for their Northern boundary, which is the line they are seeking to establish, they are exposed on three sides to attacks by water, against which they can oppose no naval force whatever, nor any ...
lead_paragraph: The rebels by this time, must pretty fully appreciate the magnitude of the contest they have in hand, and the peril in which they are placed. Assuming the Ohio River for their Northern boundary, which is the line they are seeking to establish, they are exposed on three sides to attacks by water, against which they can oppose no naval force whatever, nor any land works of the least value; for, with the command of the sea and the great navy, any point at which slight fortifications may have been raised, can be turned with the greatest ease. To maintain their Northern line, they have accumulated all their forces in Virginia, Kentucky and Missouri -- very probably 250,000 men -- an immense army for five millions of people to raise. Secession is not fully accomplished unless it carries off every Slave State. To leave Missouri, Kentucky and Western Virginia behind, would be such an unequal division of the country and its population, as to leave the South so inferior in all the elements of strength as to threaten its existence in any contest that might arise with the North. It is in these States that the cause of secession is to be decided. The rebels, even here, must act on the offensive, and drive us from them. We hold nearly one-half of Virginia, shall soon have the whole of Missouri, and; probably, Kentucky. When this is accomplished the rebellion is so dwarfed in its proportions, and so mutilated in its geographical boundaries, that it must speedily prove an entire failure, even were it to be acknowledged and a truce patched up between the seceded and loyal States.

abstract: The magnitude of the force either under arms or shortly to be raised is almost incredible. After all the abatements demanded by the exaggerations of the American journals, the residue of the probable truth, as computed by our special correspondent, is enough to astound us. None of the regular armies of Europe make any approach to the scale of these levies, all of which, be it observed, are for active and immediate service.

abstract: The New-York Detectives have received a dispatch from Baltimore to the effect that a man answering the description of RADETSKI, the supposed murderer of FELLNER, is in that city, and asking if he should be arrested and hold until an officer from New-York could arrive. A dispatch was once returned, desiring the Baltimore Police to hold him, and Detective DUSENBURY left by the afternoon train yesterday, quite certain that he will be able to secure the principal actor in the murder before he returns.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Detectives have received a dispatch from Baltimore to the effect that a man answering the description of RADETSKI, the supposed murderer of FELLNER, is in that city, and asking if he should be arrested and hold until an officer from New-York could arrive. A dispatch was once returned, desiring the Baltimore Police to hold him, and Detective DUSENBURY left by the afternoon train yesterday, quite certain that he will be able to secure the principal actor in the murder before he returns.

abstract: We have sufficiently definite information from the great fleet to assure us of its safety, and to render it certain that it is intended primarily for operations on the South Carolina coast the point of descent being either at Bull's Bay or Port Royal, at the entrance of Beaufort Harbor.
lead_paragraph: We have sufficiently definite information from the great fleet to assure us of its safety, and to render it certain that it is intended primarily for operations on the South Carolina coast -- the point of descent being either at Bull's Bay or Port Royal, at the entrance of Beaufort Harbor. The former is only about twenty-five miles above Charleston, while the latter is about fifty-five miles below -- the coast line running northeast and southwest. The steamer Monticello, from the blockading fleet off Savannah, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Monday, and reports that she passed the fleet on Saturday night, opposite Cape Roman, within thirty miles of Bull's Bay, moving along in fine style. The officers of the Monticello express the belief that the landing was made in Bull's Bay, where there were no fortifications of consequence. On the other hand, a Norfolk paper of Monday, received at Fortress Monroe, asserts that the destination of the fleet was known to be Port Royal, though no information had been received there relative to its movements. There are various reasons in favor of the supposition that Port Royal is the place aimed at. Beaufort, the harbor of which it commands, is about equidistant between Savannah and Charleston, and it is a good point from which to conduct operations against either of these cities, should such a course be contemplated. It is situated on the west bank of the Port Royal River, a narrow arm of the sea, and contains about nine hundred inhabitants. The harbor, which is sixteen miles from the main ocean, is spacious, but a bar prevents the entrance of vessels drawing more than eleven feet of water -- consequently the larger vessels of the fleet cannot pass in.

abstract: It is scarcely more than a month ago that we had occasion to speak in terms of merited compliment of the trial trip of the City of New-York, belonging to the Liverpool, New-York, and Philadelphia Steamship Company. In a few hours' run down the Bay, she displayed qualities of speed which seemed to place her at the head of the screw steam fleet belonging to the commercial world.
lead_paragraph: It is scarcely more than a month ago that we had occasion to speak in terms of merited compliment of the trial trip of the City of New-York, belonging to the Liverpool, New-York, and Philadelphia Steamship Company. In a few hours' run down the Bay, she displayed qualities of speed which seemed to place her at the head of the screw steam fleet belonging to the commercial world. In every other respectshe seemed to be the equal of any vessel that leaves our port to cross the Atlantic. Since then the City of New-York has made an eastern and a western passage, both of so remarkable a character that the best expectations excited on the occasion we have referred to were more than realized. She left her dock at Pier No. 44 North River on the 5th of August, and after being detained several hours by the tide, crossed the bar at 4 1/2 o'clock, P.M. Nine days and fourteen hours afterwards she was in the harbor of Queenstown, beating the Persia, which followed three days later, by several hours. During this passage, and the one just completed, the vessel was not allowed to run at her full pressure of steam, owing to the newness of the engines, which might easily have become heated. Hence it is reasonable to expect that in a more favorable period of the year, and when the motive power can be used to its fullest capacity, the vessel will exceed her best running this season. And yet it will be seen by the following extract from the log that the western trip was one of the most remarkable ever made, having been accomplished in the space of nine days and four hours. The storm prevented the vessel from reaching her dock on Saturday, and, indeed, she was compelled to put to sea during the most violent portion of it. The following is the official account of the run westward:

abstract: The death of Sir JAMES GRAHAM is reported by the last steamer as having occurred at Netherby, on the 25th of October. Sir JAMES is chiefly distinguished as having been the chosen lieutenant of PEEL, and of late the chief of the Peelites. If he was not a great statesman, he was certainly a powerful Minister, and his support was always considered of immense advantage to a Government.
lead_paragraph: The death of Sir JAMES GRAHAM is reported by the last steamer as having occurred at Netherby, on the 25th of October. Sir JAMES is chiefly distinguished as having been the chosen lieutenant of PEEL, and of late the chief of the Peelites. If he was not a great statesman, he was certainly a powerful Minister, and his support was always considered of immense advantage to a Government. He was too timid to take the first place in politics, and perhaps he was too unsettled ever to be a safe guide. On the other hand, his administrative ability was of a high order, and his eloquence, his noble presence and his fine voice were extremely effective, and made him at once a formidable opponent in Parliament and a valuable member of any Cabinet.

abstract: We are not able to give the exact numer of troops with which Gen. ROSECRANS has been able to repulse FLOLD; but, as nearly as can be ascertained, he must have had under his immediate command from ten to twelve thousand men. According to our latest advices, previous to the battle, the General was about effecting a junction with the officer in command at Gauley Bridge. This latter brigade consisted of the First Kentucky Volunteers, Col. WOODRUFF; the Second Kentucky Volunteers, Col. W.G. TERRELL; the Seventh Ohio, Col. TYLER; the Eighth Ohio, Col. DUPUY and the Eleventh Ohio, Col. HARRISON; and these regiments, some weeks ago, at Gauley Bridge, were considered to number at least 3,500 effective men. The force under Gen. ROSECRANS' immediate command, consisted, when last heard from, of the Ninth Ohio, Col. MCCOOK; Tenth Ohio, Col. LYTLE; Twelfth Ohio, Col. LOWE, and the Thirteenth Ohio. Col. PIATT; also the Twenty-third, Twenty-eighth, Thirty-sixth and Forty-seventh volunteer regiments from the same State, besides some detached bodies, supposed altogether to amount to 8,000 men. A union of the two forces would have made a respectable corps d'armee of 11,000 -- quite sufficient to manage FLOYD, whose army cannot be very superior in numbers.

abstract: It is not very likely that any part of the great armada which is now on its way to the South is to be employed in the repossession of the seceded State of Florida. At the same time, we think that if a few of the men-ofwar and some thousands of the troops were to be sent to the northeastern coast of that State, and if that success were to attend their ...
lead_paragraph: It is not very likely that any part of the great armada which is now on its way to the South is to be employed in the repossession of the seceded State of Florida. At the same time, we think that if a few of the men-ofwar and some thousands of the troops were to be sent to the northeastern coast of that State, and if that success were to attend their arms, which, under proper guidance, might be confidently anticipated, it would shed a ray of light on the present hour of National gloom and misfortune, which would be as cheering to the people as it would be novel. Already we have a foothold off the southern coast of the State, in the Tortugas, which not all the navy and army of Davisdom can ever dispossess us of; and in the western part of the State, at Fort Pickens, our position may now certainly be considered impregnable.

lead_paragraph: The remarkable quietness which characterized the election in this City and vicinity yesterday has left but little opportunity for the pencil of the paragraphist. From every quarter of the Metropolis and its sister cities, there was, all day long, but one unvarying report of listlessness and light voting. In some of the up-town Wards, there was comparative activity on the part of the Germans, who rallied, in some force, for their chosen candidates, and the friends of JAMES LYNCH, in the Districts controlled by the Mozart organization, made a considerable show of interest and industry.

abstract: An exhibition of a very interesting character is Capt. WILLIAMS' Panorama of a Whaling Voyage at Hope Chapel. In a graphic narrative, or, more properly speaking, yarn, the Captain tells us of his adventures in the South Seas, and explains with remarkable force the secret of taking whales.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition of a very interesting character is Capt. WILLIAMS' Panorama of a Whaling Voyage at Hope Chapel. In a graphic narrative, or, more properly speaking, yarn, the Captain tells us of his adventures in the South Seas, and explains with remarkable force the secret of taking whales. The pictures convey some of the most perilous scenes to our mind's eye, and the old salt, in fighting his battles over again, succeeds, by the heartiness of his enthusiasm, in warming an audience of landsmen into an agrecable state of excitement. The theme is a new one in the lecture-room, and it is treated as it ought to be, in an unpretentious and purely unconventional way. We advise our readers by all means to spend an hour or two with Capt. WILLIAMS, in the lower hall of Hope Chapel.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN, in his admirable reply to the Philadelphia Committee, asked, as Commander of the armies of the United States, at the hands of the people, "forbearance, patience and confidence." He has a right to them all, and he enjoys them all at the hands of those to whom the appeal is made. Undoubtedly there have not been wanting at ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. MCCLELLAN, in his admirable reply to the Philadelphia Committee, asked, as Commander of the armies of the United States, at the hands of the people, "forbearance, patience and confidence." He has a right to them all, and he enjoys them all at the hands of those to whom the appeal is made. Undoubtedly there have not been wanting at times indications of an opposite temper. Our people are unused to war, and to the necessities which it creates. It was natural that they should sometimes fail to appreciate the obstacles which obstruct its progress, -- that they should become impatient of results, relentless in their criticism of faults or misfortunes on the part of the responsible leaders, and disposed to rely far more on their own impulsive and patriotic courage than on the slow and calculated movements of the Government. These distrusts always attend the beginnings of every great enterprise. It is by War alone that the people can be educated to the duties of war, -- just as it is by fighting alone that soldiers can learn to fight.

abstract: Our dispatches, it will be seen, do not decisively settle whether the great naval expedition made a landing on the shores of Bull's Bay or pushed on to Port Royal entrance.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches, it will be seen, do not decisively settle whether the great naval expedition made a landing on the shores of Bull's Bay or pushed on to Port Royal entrance. The Monticello, returning from the blockading fleet off Savannah, reports having passed the whole fleet moving finely along, on Saturday night, within thirty miles of Bull's Bay, which her officers were of the opinion the fleet entered early Sunday morning and effected a landing. The fact that the fleet was seen off Bull's Bay does not at all make it certain that Commodore DUPONT and Gen. SHERMAN have made a landing there, and indeed, a Norfolk paper of Monday positively announces the destination of the fleet to be Port Royal.

abstract: The intelligence which has just reached us from Europe, partakes of the animated and encouraging hues, which seem just now to color the entire political horizon. Whereas three months since a conflict with England appeared so nearly inevitable, that statesmen on both sides of the water had almost abandoned the hope of uninterrupted peace; and, ...
lead_paragraph: The intelligence which has just reached us from Europe, partakes of the animated and encouraging hues, which seem just now to color the entire political horizon. Whereas three months since a conflict with England appeared so nearly inevitable, that statesmen on both sides of the water had almost abandoned the hope of uninterrupted peace; and, whereas, only four weeks ago, the rebel agents at London and Paris seemed to have everything their own way; we have now the most satisfactory proof of the ascendency which the cause and success of this Government have acquired with the Governments of France and England. The London Post, an official exponent of the British policy, announces to the persons who have been actively agitating for a forcible rupture of the blockade, that the hope of such intervention may be dismissed once for all. The English Government will, in no event, interfere in the American quarrel. So long as a blockade is maintained, British shipmasters must run it at their own risk; nothing will lead the Government to desert its position of neutrality in order to protect them. And while the suffering and disturbance which the manufacturing interests must undergo, in the absence of the usual supplies of cotton, are apprehended at their full value, the unalterable resolution of the Government to resist firmly the temptation to relieve the agony of its subjects, at the cost of a violation of international law and the risk of a foreign war, is placed beyond the possibility of a doubt. A correspondence which recently passed between the British Foreign Office and a wealthy shipowner of Liverpool, and which we reproduce elsewhere, goes to strengthen these declarations.

abstract: FIRE IN A GROCERY-STORE. About 2 o'clock, yesterday (Tuesday) morning, a fire broke out in a grocery-store, No 120 West Nineteenth-street, and before it could be extinguished extended to Nos. 118, 122 and 124, which, being frame-buildings, were entirely destroyed. The grocery where the fire originated was owned by Mr. WATERS, and was damaged about $800.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN A GROCERY-STORE. -- About 2 o'clock, yesterday (Tuesday) morning, a fire broke out in a grocery-store, No 120 West Nineteenth-street, and before it could be extinguished extended to Nos. 118, 122 and 124, which, being frame-buildings, were entirely destroyed. The grocery where the fire originated was owned by Mr. WATERS, and was damaged about $800. Insured. WATERS has been arrested upon the complaint of BRIDGET SULLIVAN and SUSAN RYAN, who resided in the building, upon the charge of setting fire to the house. Fire Marshal BAKER is investigating the cause of the fire.

abstract: This afternoon the Times has some particulars of the late fight at Gauley Bridge. The engagement was not a general battle, but a rather warm skirmish, in which the enemy were repulsed with great loss. The action was commenced by the rebels, who opened two batteries on our lines near Ganley Bridge, but, though the firing continued all day, little or no damage was done, not a man being killed.

abstract: The New-York State Election took place yesterday, and resulted, undoubtedly, in the success of the People's Union ticket. The returns which have reached us at the time of going to press are meagre and confused, but the general result can hardly admit of a doubt.
lead_paragraph: The New-York State Election took place yesterday, and resulted, undoubtedly, in the success of the People's Union ticket. The returns which have reached us at the time of going to press are meagre and confused, but the general result can hardly admit of a doubt. The election in this City passed off very quietly, and the vote is probably about one-half what it was last year. The local candidates known to be elected in this City are Geo. Loutrell, Juo. J. Bradley, Christian B. Woodruff and R.B. Connolly, for the Senate; John Callahan, Daniel Leamy and Henry J. Raymond, for the Assembly, and probably A. Oakey Hall for District-Attorney, and H.W. Genet for County Clerk.

abstract: Troops are concentrating here, in order to sail South as soon as the steamers which composed the Federal fleet shall return from South Carolina. abstract: The Day Book says that a rumor existed in that city on Sunday that Gen. BEAUREGARD had resigned, but does not credit it. A dispatch from Richmond also says that a similar rumor exists there, and for several days the question has been asked on the street, but the reporter is unable to say whether there is any truth in it or not, but gives it as a current rumor of the day. [A gentleman was in Baltimore on Tuesday, who stated that he saw Gen. BEAUREGARD at Gordonsville, Va., on Monday, en route, for Charleston.]

abstract: The Herald displays great ingenuity in its efforts to aid the cause of rebellion, while making  clamorous demonstrations in favor of the Union. The trick of looking in one direction, while rowing in the opposite, is played with dexterity but while  it may deceive the great mass of its readers, it cannot impose its impudent counterfeits upon any man who is accustomed to analyze what he reads.

abstract: Nothing further has been heard from the Naval Expedition. All we know of it is that on Saturday evening it had escaped the fury of the storm that created so much alarm, and had passed Bull's Bay twenty-five miles north of Charleston, and was still on its way Southward. The report that it had landed part of  its forces at Bull's Bay is not confirmed, and
lead_paragraph: Nothing further has been heard from the Naval Expedition. All we know of it is that on Saturday evening it had escaped the fury of the storm that created so much alarm, and had passed Bull's Bay twenty-five miles north of Charleston, and was still on its way Southward. The report that it had landed part of its forces at Bull's Bay is not confirmed, and the opinion gains ground that this was not its point of destination. We believe that at the outset it was fixed upon as one of the points to be taken and held by the National troops, --but that circumstances afterwards led to a change of plans, and the real destination of the fleet was fixed further South.

abstract: The election on Tuesday passed off very quietly, and a respectable vote -- nearly 22,000 -- was polled. All of the candidates on the People's Ticket were elected, except in the cases of two candidates for Assembly -- in the Fourth and Sixth Districts -- who were defeated by local causes. Mr. STEWART, the People's candidate in the Fourth District, was defeated by Mr. DARCY, Democrat, undoubtedly because of his alleged hostility to the Metropolitan Police law. In the Sixth District, Mr. STEARNS, the People's candidate, doubtless owes his defeat to the fact that he is understood to be an ardent Abolitionist, and sympathized strongly with the John Brown raid upon the "sacred soil" of Virginia. The successful candidate was put up by the Republicans. The names of the officers elected are as follows:

abstract: There is no longer any doubt about the fact of Gen. FREMONT'S removal. He received the order relieving him of his command on Saturday, and when the truth became known it created the most intense excitement throughout his command.
lead_paragraph: There is no longer any doubt about the fact of Gen. FREMONT'S removal. He received the order relieving him of his command on Saturday, and when the truth became known it created the most intense excitement throughout his command. Great numbers of the officers, it is stated, signified their intention to resign at once, and many companies laid down their arms, declaring their disinclination to fight under my other leader. Gen. FREMONT did his best to counteract this feeling, and urged upon officers and men the duty of obedience to the behests of the Government. He also issued a farewell order to the army, in which he expressed his regret at being obliged to leave upon the eve of a battle. On Sunday morning he left with his Staff and body guard for St. Louis -- the command devolving upon Gen. POPE until Gen. HUNTER's arrival. Gen. FELMOST's removal, it will be seen by our dispatches, has been effected literally in sight of the enemy, who at last accounts were encamped upon the old Wilson's Creek battle-ground. Small bodies of them came within twelve miles of Springfield on Saturday, and it was ascertained that their advance, 2,800 strong, was approaching. PRICE was reported to be at Cassville on Thursday last, with 25,000 men, and BEN MCCULLOCH ten miles nearer Springfield with 10,000 more, while still another 10,000 were expected from Arkansas, and accessions were being made from the rebel residents of Green, Jasper and other adjoining counties. The entire army of PRICE is estimated as high as 60,000 men. It appears certain that a great battle must soon be fought, and probably on the same ground made memorable by the death of the gallant LYON. The successor of Gen. FREMONT, we learn from Washington, is likely to be Gen. HALLECK or Gen. BUEL.

abstract: The returns, slowly accumulating through the day, very conclusively proving that the leading candidates on the People's Union ticket had no chance of election, that organization did not think it worth while assembling last evening, and their headquarters were shut up at a very early hour. There was disappointment, even, about Mr. MANIERRE, whom they had hopes of on Tuesday night; and, without cause for mutual gratulation, it was evidently thought useless to incur exposure to the inclemency of the weather.

abstract: COMMUTATION OF SENTENCE.--The United States Marshall yesterday received, from the State Department, a commutation of the sentence of death passed by the Judge of the Circuit Court of this District, in April last, upon SAMUEL COLLINS, LEWIS FEATUERSTONE, and JOHN DUNLEAVY, convicted of the murder of GEO.
lead_paragraph: COMMUTATION OF SENTENCE. -- The United States Marshall yesterday received, from the State Department, a commutation of the sentence of death passed by the Judge of the Circuit Court of this District, in April last, upon SAMUEL COLLINS, LEWIS FEATUERSTONE, and JOHN DUNLEAVY, convicted of the murder of GEO. W. PYKE, Captain of the American ship General Parkhill, on the high seas, June 3, 1861. The convict were seamen on board of the above vessel, and were sentenced to be executed on Friday, the 15th of July last, but the time was subsequently extended to the 29th inst. Owing to the contradictory character of the evidence on which they were convicted, together with the petition of many respectable citizens for Executive clemency, the President has commuted the sentence to imprisonment at hard labor for fifteen years, in the State Prison at Sing Sing.

abstract: Capt. LIBBY, formerly of the ship Gondar, of Charleston, and now of the privateer Sallie, is known to me as a man of desperate character and revengeful feelings. He it was who tampered with the rope that a man was about to be hung with in Charleston last Spring, and the consequence was the man was tortured to death. The criminal was formerly second officer with LIBBY, and having obtained an advantage over him, he took the above method of gaining revenge. When I was in Charleston Jail, recently, Capt. LIBBY called on me, and I asked him to assist me to get out. He replied I had no business to be there, and that I would be out next day, but the next day or Capt. LIBBEY did not come. On the occasion of his tampering with the rope at the execution, he was shot by the Sheriff through the neck, which, when I saw him in Charleston, was not yet well. When last I saw him he was recruiting for the privateer Beauregard. W.E. WELCH,

abstract: From the annual report of the Comptroller-General of the State of Georgia, we learn that she has now in the held thirty-four full regiments (some more that full) and four partially filled regiments, together with three battalions, and other independent companies in Virginia and Georgia, amounting in all to about forty regiments in the Confederate Government service. And besides this, three regiments now in the State service are to be increased at once to six regiments for the defence of her sea-coast.

abstract: Our summary of news from the North is of more interest to-day than usual. The sailing orders of the great Naval Expedition will attract especial attention. Speculation will now soon be at an end; and perhaps before these lines shall be printed the telegraph will tell us where the blow has fallen. After reading these orders, however, we cannot join in the opinion which to same extent prevails, that
lead_paragraph: Our summary of news from the North is of more interest to-day than usual. The sailing orders of the great Naval Expedition will attract especial attention. Speculation will now soon be at an end; and perhaps before these lines shall be printed the telegraph will tell us where the blow has fallen. After reading these orders, however, we cannot join in the opinion which to same extent prevails, that the contemplated landing is intended on any comparatively secluded and undefended spot. If this giant force is to take possession of some sand bar or marshy island, or sea-coast village, why such strict injunction that the expedition should sail in a body, and the soldiers land in such heavy array, and with the admonition that their courage will probably be tested? If we judge these orders by the ordinary rules, and in connection with the Northern boasts that a terrible blow is to be struck, and at our very vitals, we cannot but conclude that it is expected to debark either in the vicinity of a strong Confederate army or of a large Confederate city. Applying these tests, Pensacola, and Charleston, and Savannah, and New-Orleans, are the points which present themselves to our mind. There is something so absurd in the injunction to keep the expedition close together, and to land in a long line of boats, and with elaborate preparations, for the purpose of capturing Sand Point or Mosquito Bar, or Alligator Inlet, that it is difficult to conceive that the Northern Generals would thus make themselves ridiculous.

abstract: One of your correspondents has called attention to the propriety of abolishing in our army the distinction between volunteers and regulars. I see no good reason for maintaining this distinction. At the termination of the war there will be material enough out of which to form a standing army as large as would be required by the necessities of the country, or would receive the sanction of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 4, 1861.

abstract: The petty achievements of Spain in the Morocco war have rekindled her ambition, She was once a great European Power, and would fain figure as one again. So the mediation of the French Emperor was solicited, and the coveted honor would have been obtained for her, had it not been for the opposition of England.
lead_paragraph: The petty achievements of Spain in the Morocco war have rekindled her ambition, She was once a great European Power, and would fain figure as one again. So the mediation of the French Emperor was solicited, and the coveted honor would have been obtained for her, had it not been for the opposition of England. To recompense herself, however, for this disappointment, Spain presently determined to take advantage of the divided state of San Domingo, and to seize once more on that Republic. Having carried out this scheme, and overturned liberty in Eastern Hispaniola, she next directs her attention to the anarchical condition of Mexico, and to the sufferings of her subjects resident therein. Her Government, which had witnessed so much confusion and sanguinary strife on Spanish soil, affected to be horrified at the disorders and licentiousness prevalent in Mexico! Her Government, which had plundered the Catholic Church at home, affected indignation because of the wrongs sustained by that Church in her ancient colony! Her Government, which never paid its own debts, could not endure the idea of Spaniards being thus defrauded by Mexicans! Therefore, it was decided that Spain should forthwith send a naval and military expedition to the country of MONTEZUMA, for the ostensible purpose of redressing all these evils and grievances, but in reality to effect, if possible, the reoccupation and reconquest of this lost dependency.
headline: {'main': 'Growing Insolence of Spain.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Growing Insolence of Spain.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Washington Sun, of Friday evening, says: "We mentioned a day or two since that Sergeants FRANKLIN COOK, T.D. FARKER and R.E. ELLINWOOD have been appointed Second Lieutenants in the army. They reached Washington to-day. These gentlemen have recently escaped from San Antonio, Texas, where they were held as prisoners by the rebels. Their adventures in making their escape would fill a volume. They escaped from their guards at San Antonio at night, and made their way, guided by a compass, through the terrible chapparel country to Laredo, on the Rio Grande. They were pursued by the rebel cavalry, which at one time was within a few rods of where they were secreting themselves among the Spanish bayonet bushes and prickly pear. They had determined not to be recapturedalive. On reaching Laredo, they proceeded to Monterey, Mexico, and from there to Tampico. From the latter place they sailed to Havana, and from there to New-York. Our Consul at Havana was most kind to them, advancing them means to reach New-York, &c. They state that our Consul at Tampico would do nothing for them, but they got along without his assistance. Until they reached Laredo, they subsisted upon a few crackers they had supplied themselves with. Three finer looking men we have never seen, and our Government shows again in these cases that it knows how to reward faithful men and good soldiers. These gentlemen have all filled honorable and high positions as non-commissioned officers in their regiments, and will be welcomed by the army in their new positions."

abstract: The return to Savannah of the Theodora, the vessel which bore SLIDELL and MASON to Cuba, illustrates what is probably the cardinal defect of the blockade. The South, blessed in so many particulars beside the advantages of the peculiar institution, is gifted in this, that it possesses a three-fold, and indeed often a four fold coast. What with "sea-Islands" formed in the alluvium of the shore by arms of the sea, and the deltoid accretions at the mouths of her many rivers, there are countless passages which he beyond the reach of our smallest war-vessels; and which are nevertheless easily penetrable by small commercial craft, -- the schooners and shallops of coast-wise traffic. On the Atlantic side, a vessel of light draft can traverse nearly the entire coast from Norfolk to Cape Sable, without danger of molestation from the blockading fleet; and throughout that distance may select any outlet to the sea, which it finds to be momentarily released from the guardianship of a national ship-of-war.

abstract: A petition to the Legislature is being circulated in Panola County, Tenn., praying that body to pass a law for the purchase of the cotton crop of the State, and that payment in whole or in part be made by Treasury notes; that the cotton be pledged for the redemption of the notes. The petitioners further ask that if this cannot be done for the State at large, that it be done for the Count of Panola.

abstract: The recent promotion of a number of non-commissioned officers to Second Lieutenants has caused many of the Sergeants on duty at depots, as drill instructors, to apply for transfers to regiments, as they have no chance of being promoted unless they are attached to a regiment. Col. LOOMIS, commanding on Governor's Island, has intimated that he cannot entertain any more applications for transfers, as he must retain a sufficient number of men competent to drill recruits and attend to the ordinary duties of non-commissioned officers at a principal depot.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. J.S. CLARKE will take his benefit at this establishment to-night, the last for many months to come. An artist, who has so firmly established himself in the public regard, scarcely needs a word of recommendation from the Press. It is pleasant, however, to say that Mr. CLARKE's engagement so far has been a perfect success, and to express the hope that to-night, when he appeals directly to his friends and admirers, there will be something more than an ordinary recognition. The "Octoroon" will be played, and the "Toodles." A better bill cannot be found in the City of New-York.

abstract: The United States vs. Nathaniel Gordon. -- The prisoner was the master of the ship Erie, which was captured by the Mohican with a cargo of slaves on board, and was indicted for being engaged in the Slave-trade. He was tried once before, but the jury failed to agree. Judge Dean and Mr. Joachimssen appeared as his counsel. The testimony of Lieut Todd' of the Mohican, who was put in charge of the Eric, was taken, and was nearly the same as on the formed trial. Evidence was also given to show that Gordon was an American, born in Maine.

abstract: GEORGE B. McCLELLAN is Commander-in-Chief of the Armies of the United States! This important step was taken, to-day, in Cabinet Council. The young General finds himself at the head of a force as numerous as that of Rome in her palmiest days, and not since equaled except by a monarch of the last century--LOUIS XIV.--until we descend to the wars of NAPOLEON. What changes have nine centuries introduced in the mode of warfare.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday, Nov. 1, 1861.

abstract: Parson BROWNLOW has been compelled to suspend the publication of the Knoxville Whig, and to yield an unwilling obedience to the Confederate laws. But he does it defiantly, and under compulsion. His address to his subscribers, which we publish in another column, proclaims afresh, and with emphasis, his loyalty to the Union, and his denunciation of the men who are seeking its overthrow. No man in the country has shown more true courage in his adhesion to the Constitution during this rebellion, than Parson BROWNLOW.
