abstract: On Saturday last a Sergeant, named DAVENPORT, belonging to the McClelland lifes was stand by Capt. FITZ JAMES O'BRIEN, of the same regiment. It appears that DAVENPORT, who is said to be the most desperate and unruly man in the regiment was met outside the limits of the camp by Capt. O'BRIEN, who asked him for his pass, as in the rule. DAVENPORT made some impertinent answer, Capt. O'BRIEN said not another word, but passed on, intending to report the Sergeant at headquarters for inscience to his superior officer. DAVENPORT followed him, still using insulting language. At this Capt. O'BRIEN drew his pistol and commanded the man to full back. To this DAVENPORT paid no attention, but still closed on the Captain. Over seven times he was told not to come nearer, but he still advanced upon O'BRIEN, who was retreating. Finally he made a rush upon the Captain, whose pistol went off accidentally. Feeling overpowered, O'BRIEN again cooked the pistol, and shot the man in the abdomen. DAVENPORT, who is now rapidly recovering, has served under the British Government in India, such being the case, he must have known that it was against all military discipline to insult, much less strike, a superior officer, and by so doing he placed himself in a position to be shot any moment.

abstract: Our news from Kentucky is highly important. A telegram from Cairo states that an expedition left there on Thursday evening with the intention, as was supposed, of attacking Columbus. Heavy and continuous cannonading was heard in that direction yesterday, and the expedition was believed to be having a warm time.

abstract: We have no news whatever from the Naval Expedition in addition to what has already been published. It must be borne in mind that there are but two channels through which information concerning the fleet can come-- one is by returning vessels which would make Fortress Monroe their first stopping place, and the other is through rebel sources by the overland route. By the latter route we as yet hear nothing.
lead_paragraph: We have no news whatever from the Naval Expedition in addition to what has already been published. It must be borne in mind that there are but two channels through which information concerning the fleet can come -- one is by returning vessels which would make Fortress Monroe their first stopping place, and the other is through rebel sources by the overland route. By the latter route we as yet hear nothing. The steamboat of the regular line to Baltimore, leaving Fortress Monroe on Tuesday evening, reached Baltimore yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock, having been detained by the way. Our latest advices from the Fortress, therefore, are to Tuesday night, and at that time there had been no fresh intelligence from the fleet.

abstract: It seems quite certain that the Naval Expedition, from which the whole country awaits intelligence with so much anxiety, is intended to operate upon the coasts of South Carolina and Georgia,--with a view primarily of establishing depots for receiving stores and reinforcements, and also of moving upon Charleston or Savannah and opening a port for the exit of cotton.
lead_paragraph: It seems quite certain that the Naval Expedition, from which the whole country awaits intelligence with so much anxiety, is intended to operate upon the coasts of South Carolina and Georgia, -- with a view primarily of establishing depots for receiving stores and reinforcements, and also of moving upon Charleston or Savannah and opening a port for the exit of cotton. It is more than probable that PORT ROYAL is one of the points selected for landing: -- whether the other is Bull's Bay, north of Charleston or Brunswick, south of Savannah, is as yet unknown: -- and will depend on which of the two cities is to be first assailed.

abstract: The District-Attorney of Monmouth County, N.J., yesterday visited this City, for the purpose of giving our detectives some additional facts relative to the actors in this terrible homicide, and also for the further purpose of conveying Mrs. MARKS to New-Jersey, where it is believed the murder was committed. Since the attempt of this woman to commit suicide in the Eighth Ward Station-house on Monday last, she has been very low, and at times has appeared to be dying. On Wednesday her condition seemed so critical that additional medical aid was called in, and it was only after much effort on the part of the physicians that she was restored to consciousness. Yesterday she was in a state of delirium most of the time, constantly bewailing her fate, and imploring the officers not to put her to death for the crime of her brother. It was with much difficulty that the New-Jersey officials succeeded in setting her into the carriage, and she only ceased resistance when told that a requisition from the Governor of New-Jersey had been obtained for her removal from the City. For the last three days several New-York lawyers have been engaged in trying to ascertain the exact condition and whereabouts of the prisoner, with a view of obtaining a habeas corpus, hoping thereby to secure her liberty, and to place her beyond the reach of the officers of justice. RADETSKY had not, at last accounts, been arrested.

abstract: There was a very large meeting, of unusually high in elligence and respectability, at the Cooper Institute last evening. It was held on behalf of the impoverished Union natives of the North Carolina shore, Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT presided, and spoke at length. The other speakers were Mr. TAYLOR, Pastor of the church at Hatteras Inlet; Rev. Mr. CONWAY, Chaplain of HAWKINS' Zouaves; Gen. BURNSIDE, of Rhode Island Brigade fame; Dr. ADAMS, Prof. HITCHCOCK, and Dr. TYNG. We give a full report on another page.

abstract: GENTLEMEN: Your favor of the 7th is received to-day. Most gladly would I comply with the request of your Club if I could, but the professional engagement that has brought and will detain me here for some days, and others that I cannot without a breach of duty postpone, make it impossible.

abstract: The determination of the rebels to resort to privateering excited perhaps as much indignation in this community as any step which they have taken. We were not surprised that they did so, for though civilization in its progress towards the improvement of the race, by striking off one after another those practices which prevailed in earlier and ruder times, had set its influence strongly against privateering, yet those who had gone into such an uncalled for rebellion to sustain the "twin relic of barbarism," Slavery, were naturally attracted towards barbarous practices, and having stolen all that they could reach on land, naturally took to robbery at sea. But though this was natural on their part, it none the less excited indignation on ours, and the steps which the Government took to meet the emergency, and the proclamation of its intention to treat it as it deserved, met with the warm approval of all who were engaged in commerce.

abstract: Gen. CAMERON, in his speech at the Astor House the other night, said that New-York had contributed 35,000 men to the war. The number already in the field is 85,000. He also stated that Pennsylvania had contributed 1,500 more than New-York. This may be true, if those only are counted who are already in the field: -- but if those who are ready to go are included, New-York is very largely ahead.
lead_paragraph: Gen. CAMERON, in his speech at the Astor House the other night, said that New-York had contributed 35,000 men to the war. The number already in the field is 85,000. abstract: We regret to announce the death of Mr. HARRY NEIL, the dramatic critic of the New-York Tribune. The sad event occurred yesterday afternoon, after a short sickness. Some few days since Mr. NEIL was seized with what seemed to be an attack of fever and ague, and was compelled to take to his bed. The disease subsequently assumed a typhoidical character, and resulted fatally.
lead_paragraph: We regret to announce the death of Mr. HARRY NEIL, the dramatic critic of the New-York Tribune. The sad event occurred yesterday afternoon, after a short sickness. abstract: The Twenty-third Massachusetts Regiment, Col. KURTZ, will arrive in this City on Saturday morning. They will be received at Pier No. 3 North River, by the Sons of Massachusetts, who are requested to meet there at 9 o'clock. The regiment will he escorted to the Park Barracks, where they will breakfast. The officers will partake of a dejeuner at the Astor House, provided by the Sons, at which many of our distinguished citizens will be present. Rev. Dr. TYNG will make the welcoming address. The following gentlemen have been selected by Col. FRANK E. HOWE as Marshals: Capt. SAMUEL HATHAWAY, Col. O.D. ASHLEY, Maj. J.W. CURRIER, Dr. F. WILLIS FISHER, and Capt. W.H.L. BARNES. Badges can be obtained of either of these gentlemen, and tickets to the "welcoming breakfast" at the Astor House, or at No. 203 Broadway.

abstract: BOLD ROBBERY. -- Some time yesterday afternoon, during the absence of the family, the house No. 196 Little Montgomery-street, Jersey City, occupied by HENRY FISH, was broken open by thieves and completely ransacked from the basement to the upper floor, and a quantity of jewelry, silver ware and other articles were taken. The entrance was effected by forcing open the basement door with a "jimmy." L.B. LYONS' liquor-store, corner of York and Hudson streets, was entered on Wednesday night and robbed of a few dollars in change.

abstract: This regiment, which has been encamped for some time past at Turtle Bay, left on Thursday for the seat of war. Its numerical strength is 900, exclusive of officers. All the men are fine, healthy-looking young fellows, and are armed with the Enfield rifle. Attached to the regiment is a fine band. The Fifty-eighth is composed of Italians, Germans. Poles, French, Danes and Russians. They left by the Camden and Amboy line. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: Simon Banks vs. The Steamboat Metropolis.  NELSON, C.J. The libel is filed in this case to recover damages against the Metropolis for a collision with the sloop Golden Rule, on the night of the 12th August, 1858, on Long Island Sound, some five or six miles off Falkland's Island, and nearly midway between that and Long Island shore. The sloop was laden with corn and feed, and bound for Providence.
lead_paragraph: Simon Banks vs. The Steamboat Metropolis. -- NELSON, C.J. -- The libel is filed in this case to recover damages against the Metropolis for a collision with the sloop Golden Rule, on the night of the 12th August, 1858, on Long Island Sound, some five or six miles off Falkland's Island, and nearly midway between that and Long Island shore. The sloop was laden with corn and feed, and bound for Providence. R.I. The metropolis was on her usual trip from Fall River to the City of New-York. The night was not very dark, the wind light, east-southeast or southeast, the sloop going but one or two miles an hour, close hauled; she saw the lights of the steamer severally miles off, and, when within some two or three miles, coming on a course apparently towards her, a bright light was hoisted by a hand standing on the deck; and afterwards, the steamer still continuing her course, he stood upon top of the cabin, holding the light as high as he could with his arm.

abstract: The telegraph brings an unsatisfactory report of an engagement which occurred on Thursday at Belmont, a spot on the right bank of the Mississippi, a short distance above Columbus. There was a rebel encampment at this place, where have been lodged some seven thousand men, under the command of Gen. CHEATEM, of Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph brings an unsatisfactory report of an engagement which occurred on Thursday at Belmont, a spot on the right bank of the Mississippi, a short distance above Columbus. There was a rebel encampment at this place, where have been lodged some seven thousand men, under the command of Gen. CHEATEM, of Tennessee. To the task of recovering possession of the river, it was an essential preliminary that this force should be dispersed; and Gen. GRANT, the Commander at Cairo, organized an expedition for the purpose. There were four steamers, upon which were transported five regiments of infantry, two squadrons of cavalry, and a battery of field pieces; while two gunboats were in attendance to protect the landing. The landing was effected on Thursday morning; and hardly were the troops drawn up in line of battle when the action commenced. Notwithstanding the inferiority of numbers, the National force seems to have had all the earlier honors of the fight, driving the rebels back to their camp, and then beyond it; and with the National flag replacing the emblem of secession over CHEATEM'S headquarters. There were twelve guns also captured, of which two were brought away.

abstract: No changes of importance at the Brooklyn Navy-yard during the last day or two. The Santiago de Cuba, which was to have left on Thursday, did not get away until yesterday. There was some little trouble in getting her out. Two or three vessels fitting out had to be removed to make way for her, and she fouled the Fernandina and Connecticut without doing any damage worth recording. She will steam down the bay to try her engine, and will then anchor off the Battery to receive her powder.
lead_paragraph: No changes of importance at the Brooklyn Navy-yard during the last day or two. The Santiago de Cuba, which was to have left on Thursday, did not get away until yesterday. abstract: Intelligence has been received from the Great Expedition, which, considering that it comes from a rebel source, may be looked upon as highly encouraging. A flag of truce arrived at Fortress Monroe from Norfolk on Thursday, and the only person who came by it was under parole not to reveal particulars; but he was allowed to communicate the fact that the fleet had arrived at Port Royal Entrance, and was at last accounts engaged in bombarding the rebel batteries on Hilton Head, with a prospect of their speedy reduction. One of our gunboats had been disabled, and another was ashore, and it was understood that Commodore TATTNALL, who commanded the rebels, was about to attempt the capture of the latter with a small steamer. It is not stated whether our troops had made any effort to land, but it is not likely they would do so before the rebel batteries were silenced, which would not be a difficult matter with the rifled cannon of long range carried by our war vessels. During the severe gale which prevailed while the fleet was passing down the coast, the steamer Union and a small sailing vessel were lost -- the former on Kill Devil Shoal, and the latter on Rogue's Beach, on the coast of North Carolina, and their crews, numbering between seventy and eighty, were taken prisoners. The Union had horses on board, all but fifteen of which were lost, and the other vessel was loaded with ordnance stores.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence has been received from the Great Expedition, which, considering that it comes from a rebel source, may be looked upon as highly encouraging. abstract: A BEAR AND BULL FIGHT. -- Some scoundrels, of a so-called sporting turn, threaten to scandalize the good people of Jersey, by inaugurating among them conflicts between savage beasts, upon the Spanish and Californian plans. These fellows, whoever they are, have made arrangements for a fight between a bull and a bear, both of which pugnacious brutes are said to be already in training. East Newark, where the fight is to come off, is in a state of tremendous excitement and indignation upon the subject, and there is no doubt the projectors of the shameful exhibition will have their little speculation nipped in the bud.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, Judge MCCUNN presiding, Erastus B. Roberts, 36 years, native of Utica, N.Y., late clerk in the Overland Mall Company, was tried for embezzling $4,000 from his employers, in November of last year. The jury returned a verdict of guilty and the prisoner was remanded for sentence. The case occupied nearly the whole day, and at its close the Court adjourned till Monday next, at 10 A.M.

abstract: The art of statesmanship consists in first knowing all the elements and condition of a nation, and then applying legislation or policy, so as to bring out the most beneficial results from those elements. Modern nations have not been remarkable for this art. I doubt whether we have this art in as much perfection as the old Roman statesmen.
lead_paragraph: THE BEECHES, October, 1861.

abstract: A correspondent calls attention to the conspicuous part the letter B is playing in our national troubles. Big Bethel, Bull Run, Ball's Bluff, the two Beauforts, Brunswick, Bolivar, Belmont, seem to justify the idea of its frequency in topography. While he alleges "that the Blair family on the Union side are as influential in the making and unmaking of Generals and the management of the war generally, as are Secretary at War BENJAMIN, and Gens. BEAUREGARD and BRAGG, on the side of the enemy." Had our curious correspondent pushed his case further by reminding us how all our troubles began with these abominable B's, BUCHANAN and BRECKINRIDGE, it would have been more complete.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent calls attention to the conspicuous part the letter B is playing in our national troubles. abstract: The report reaches us, by way of Louisville, that the notorious privateer Sumter has been captured to the leeward (or the North) of Barbados. It is not the first time that such a report has gained currency, and it is only some few weeks ago that we received graphic particulars of the pirate's total destruction in the Bocas of Trinidad. There is, however, this in favor of the truth of the present story -- that it comes through Southern sources where it would not he believed until authenticated beyond all peradventure, Under these circumstances some account of the Sumter's eventful and adventurous career will be both interesting and pertinent.

abstract: The reports as to the extent of the disaster to the steamer Union, one of the vessels composing the expedition, must be very much exaggerated. The only steamer by that name, which went South, was the ferry-boat Union, belonging to the Union Ferry Company, an old boat which has for some time been out of active service, and which was purchased and sent down to be used in landing and transferring the troops. She had no horses on board, and no men except, probably, ten or fifteen persons who constituted her crew. She carried no ammunition, and had nothing on board except the coal necessary for the voyage. Those who know the boat will wonder that she ever got so far on her passage as the coast of North Carolina. The chief part of the ammunition went on another steamer.
lead_paragraph: The reports as to the extent of the disaster to the steamer Union, one of the vessels composing the expedition, must be very much exaggerated. abstract: The first concert (twentieth season) of the New-York Philharmonic Society will take place to-night at Irving Hall, Mr. CAHL BERGMANN conducting BEETHOVEN's symphony No. 5, in C minor; BERLIOZ's overture to "Le Carnival Romaine," and WAGNER's overture to "Rienzi" are the principal instrumental features. abstract: GORDON OF THE SLAVER "ERIE." When, in 1820, the Congress of the United States declared the Slave-trade piracy, the act was recorded as reflecting lasting honor on the American name. Four years afterward, the Parliament of Great Britain followed our example.
lead_paragraph: GORDON OF THE SLAVER "ERIE." -- When, in 1820, the Congress of the United States declared the Slave-trade piracy, the act was recorded as reflecting lasting honor on the American name. Four years afterward, the Parliament of Great Britain followed our example. But the glory of this legislation has for years been tarnished by the lamentable failure of prosecuting officers and juries in executing the law. Some years ago, a conviction was secured, but by inattention to certain technical requirements, the verdict was set aside by consent. Nothing further was heard of the case.

abstract: The whole country will breathe more freely in consequence of the news from the great armada. The first tidings we get, and they through rebel sources, assure us of the safe arrival of the fleet at Port Royal Entrance. Though the winds and waves did buffet our ships for three days, they nobly rode out the storm, and a couple of insignificant vessels stranded off the coast of North Carolina is the cheap rate at which we purchase the grand success. The intelligence breaks off in the middle of the bombardment of the batteries that guard the entrance to Port Royal harbor -- the reduction of the fortifications being imminent. Through the confused statements of the affair, we gather the premonitions of a successful assault: considering the avenue through which the tidings come, we may conclude we have heard all the disasters, and may safely look forward to a brilliant bulletin.
lead_paragraph: The whole country will breathe more freely in consequence of the news from the great armada. abstract: THE PAULSEN CHESS CLUB. -- This is the name of a chess association recently organized among the German chess-players of this City, who have named their club after the noted chess champion PAULSEN, now in Europe. The first meeting of the club was held at their rooms, which are located at No. 189 Bowery, last evening. Quite a number of our leading players were present on the occasion, and a very agreeable evening was spent in trying their skill in chess strategy. The officers of the club are as follows: President, E. BORCH; Vice-President, M. SPINDLES; Secretary, E. BRENZINGER; and Treasurer, C. FEHRER, The evenings of meeting during the week are Wednesdays and Fridays. Among the prominent players present last evening, who are members of the club, we noticed Messrs. Droege, Charnier, Hallerbach, Beneke, Bausing and Walthisins. On Saturday evening next our young New-York champion, Mr. JAMES LEONARD, will undertake the difficult task of playing ten games of chess against first-class players, without seeing the boards or men. This interesting mental feat will take place at the Morphy Rooms, Broadway, commencing at 7 P.M.

abstract: How to deal with slaves in the Southern States must speedily become a practical question, and the sooner the better. Hitherto it has been mainly a theme for speculation. Every man has had his theory about it, and has been urgent for its immediate adoption.
lead_paragraph: How to deal with slaves in the Southern States must speedily become a practical question, and the sooner the better. Hitherto it has been mainly a theme for speculation. Every man has had his theory about it, and has been urgent for its immediate adoption. The Government has shown a disposition, very natural and proper, to postpone the subject as long as possible, and especially to leave it to the control of Congress. The landing of troops upon the Southern coast, however, in the very midst of the densest slave population, and in the heart of the Cotton region, where the treatment of slaves is the most severe, and their desire to escape the strongest, will compel prompt and decisive action on the subject. Beaufort District, at the head of Port Royal harbor, contains 38,805 inhabitants, of whom 32,279 are slaves, the slaves thus outnumbering the whites in the proportion of more than five to one. They are mainly employed upon large cotton plantations, are severely worked, given to insurrectionary schemes, and more intelligent than the corresponding class in Alabama and Mississippi. There can be no doubt that thousands of them will flock into the National camp, with the expectation of protection under the National flag.

abstract: I closed my last letter to the TIMES at Fort's Station, a point 12 miles above this on the Overland Road, and 46 miles from Springfield. Night before last, Gen. abstract: As the mail train from Greenport was leaving the Cutchogue station yesterday, and was under full headway, the engineer discovered a child's carriage on the track. The breaks were applied by a signal from the engineer, and the motion of the train was nearly arrested when the cow-catcher canght the little carriage and tossed it from the track. A little boy rolled out of the tiny vehicle, and was picked up without having received a scratch. The child had gone out with his little carriage, and seating himself unconcernedly in it, was playing ride on the railroad.

abstract: After the plucky little fight at Wild Cat, "Your Own" concluded that things in the mountains were beginning to warm up, and that he had better be in to see the sport. Accordingly he started and reached Nicholasville, the terminus of the Covington and Lexington Railroad without let or hindrance. But once there his troubles began, nor do they seem disposed to come to an end.

abstract: The remains of the late Col. BAKER arrived in Philadelphia on Thursday afternoon. When the train rolled into the depot, the City Guard were drawn up in line upon the platform. The Mayor of the city formally received the coffin containing the body, and  then a squad of soldiers belonging to the California regiment received it in their turn, and bore it upon a bier to the hearse provided for it.
lead_paragraph: The remains of the late Col. BAKER arrived in Philadelphia on Thursday afternoon. When the train rolled into the depot, the City Guard were drawn up in line upon the platform. The Mayor of the city formally received the coffin containing the body, and then a squad of soldiers belonging to the California regiment received it in their turn, and bore it upon a bier to the hearse provided for it. The coffin was then covered with the splendid silk American flag sent by the Californians to the Mayor of Philadelphia. The hearse was a beautiful open vehicle, drawn by six jet black horses, whose heads were decked with nodding plumes of white, corresponding with others on the top of the vehicle. A groom, in deep mourning, accompanied each horse. With BIRGFELD's brass band at its head, playing the Dead March in Saul, the procession then got in motion. It passed through dense crowds of people along the entire route.

abstract: In nearly every militarydepartment, and in almost every column of the army, the commanding officers have been superseded or transferred since the opening of this brief war. In Baltimore, Butler gave place to Cadwallader, and he in turn to Banks, and Banks again to Dix. In St. Louis, when Harney made his incongruous treaty, the Government removed him, and gave Lyon command; Lyon was soon subordinated to Fremont, who now, in turn, gives place to Hunter. On the Upper Potomac, Patterson was superseded by Banks; at Fortress Monroe. Butler was superseded by Wool; in Kentucky, Anderson was followed by Sherman, who now gives up his command to Buel. A Cairo, Grant, took the place of Prentiss in Western Virginia, Rosecrans succeeded McClellan. At Washington, McDowell, or account of Bull Run, was superseded by McClellan; and now Scott himself gives place to the last named General. Some of these officers have been displaced for incompetency or blundering; others have been transferred to more responsible posts, or posts more adapted to their genius; intrigue may have had something to do with the removal of others; while some not named have been removed for drunkenness and immorality. When a General fails of success, we want him out of the road at once. In this we but follow the example of other nations in great crises. In the days of the first French revolution, unsuccessful or blundering Generals were speedily put out of the way by decapitation, and the quick guillotine performed the work now accomplished in a milder but equally effective manner. This was done in numerous instances until the military bunglers were all weeded out, and then the Republican army brought forth a list of great Generals unparalleled in the history of any other people. In the Crimean war, again, St. Arnaud died, and Canrobert was superseded, and Pelissier proved to be the man for the the emergency. In our Revolution also, and in the war of 1812, we had the same experience with our Generals in many cases that we are having now. Doubtless, in the present war, we will finally find the path to victory, and find, too, the men to lead us thither. But it takes time and labor to discover them.

abstract: It needs no special inspiration to discover that Spain, having renewed her youth, has entered upon a new and troublesome stage of her career. As well in the Old World as in the New, she has undertaken the laborious ...
lead_paragraph: It needs no special inspiration to discover that Spain, having renewed her youth, has entered upon a new and troublesome stage of her career. As well in the Old World as in the New, she has undertaken the laborious role of a first-rate Power. Having dispersed the Carlists, and expelled CRISTINA, the Government of ISABELLA has succeeded in courting the presence of foreign capital and enterprise, a transfusion which has given life to her dying industrial energies, and some revenue and more credit to the national exchequer. To create a navy and an army would naturally be the first use a military Prime Minister would make of his new resources; and Marshal O'DONNELL has created both, and by the war in Morocco, and participation in the attack upon Cochin China, has sought to afford both the practical drill and experience which the French military establishment has acquired in the finishing schools of Algeria, Crimea and Italy. Now it is observable that all those who bear about them maiden swords, are not usually free from a certain swagger and provocative bluster, which often impels them to flesh their maiden weapons rashly and indiscriminately. Spain, in resuming her youth, has not dispensed with these youthful attributes. Having seduced Dominica, and, wrenching as it were the very knocker from the gate of Portau-Prince, bullied and insulted the Haytian Republic, she turns to Liberia, that other and only remaining negro Republic on the map, and picks a quarrel with its sable Government. And as if practice upon the African races. Moorish and Hametic, had strengthened her arm for strife of a higher order, we find her also aiming a blow at Mexico, with a view of restoring, if not a Spanish viceroy, at least a decided Spanish influence, over the affairs of that country. By such demonstrations we are constrained to recognize the resolute purpose of the Spaniard to recover the place in affairs of the world, which he once conquered, and has so long lost.

abstract: As further but still imperfect details touching the encounter at Belmont come to hand, they lose something of their first ill-coloring. While the losses upon the National side were severe, there is reason to believe they were greatly exceeded by those of the rebels; and if it be true that the latter have abandoned Belmont, the object of Gen. GRANT is certainly accomplished. To have attained it with less risk and loss would have been so much to the credit of that officer, that we can only hope the numbers of the enemy were exaggerated, or material facts in the business suppressed to suit telegraphic convenience. It will be judicious, therefore, to suspend opinion until official accounts are received.

abstract: "We may notice a rumor which gained extensive circulation yesterday evening throughout the city, to the effect that orders had gone forward for a countermarch of the whole Southwestern army, and that upon its arrival in this city it would go into Winter quarters. We have such information as leads us to the belief that the design of pursuing the rebels into Arkansas has been abandoned by the War Department, for the alleged reason that a campaign in that distant and barren locality during the Winter months is impracticable; but we are also certain that so long as there is a chance of giving the rebels a drubbing with or near the borders of our State, our army will be continued in the Southwest. The news this morning indicates that that chance is not at all improbable or remote. There will be no retrograde movement yet awile; and if one is ordered, the cities of Springfield, Rolla, Jefferson City and Lexington will not be left defenceless.

abstract: The market rules very quiet for both sorts, although there is but little, if any, demand at present. Holders are very firm. The stock of medium and low fleeces is very light, a large portion of the clip being already consumed or in the hands of manufacturers; and if the demand for army goods should continue through the Winter, manufacturers will have to resort to fine grades, which, by being mixed with lower foreign Wools, may be found to answer a good purpose. Of these last we shall probably have fair supplies, but, judging by the readiness with which lots now on the way are taken to arrive, there will not be for some time much accumulation on the market; and as by last advices prices are rapidly advancing in the European markets we cannot look for much variation from our present market rates. -- Evening Journal, Nov. 6.

abstract: We have agreeable evidences of a new life in the publishing trade. Mighty presses, that for many months have lain idle in silent vaults, have shaken off the enforced torpor, and are now whirling their long firms with renewed vigor, like ...
lead_paragraph: We have agreeable evidences of a new life in the publishing trade. Mighty presses, that for many months have lain idle in silent vaults, have shaken off the enforced torpor, and are now whirling their long firms with renewed vigor, like giants refreshed by slumber. The HARPERS, who seem to make a special pet of Africa, favor us with The Okovanger River, the adventures in Southwestern Africa of CHARLES JOHN ANDERSSON. Necessarily there is a certain sameness about all African adventure; DU CHAILLU introduced a new feature in his story in the way of the gorilla; but he was a fortunate and exceptional mortal. Every one cannot light on a new species of ape. Like his predecessors, Mr. ANDERSSON seems to have found a peculiar pleasure in "bagging" beasts of the desert and jungle. Whether elephant or giraffe, graceful antelope or plain and practical rhinoceros, all was game that came before his rifle. Now Mr. ANDERSSON breakfasted on an elephant cutlet, anon he supped from stewed lion. And about this latter meal the halo of a poetical justice hovers. Even the sentimentalist who enters a sad protest against slaughter, cannot think it wrong to eat the animal that would feel no hesitation, be troubled by no delicate scruples as to eating you. In thus heaping live coals upon the juicy steaks of his enemies, Mr. ANDERSSON must have enjoyed a species of savage Sardanapalism that can only occur to a man once or twice in a lifetime, and then in Africa.

abstract: We give below the result of the "little leaven" embodied in a small circle of fifty sixty patriotic women, who, on the 25th of April last, held an in formal meeting at the New-York Infirmary for Women, having for its object the concentration of the ...
lead_paragraph: We give below the result of the "little leaven" embodied in a small circle of fifty sixty patriotic women, who, on the 25th of April last, held an in formal meeting at the New-York Infirmary for Women, having for its object the concentration of the wide-spread benevolence of societies and sewing circles, which were organizing throughout the length and breadth of our land to meet the soldier's need. The establishment of a central depot succeeded this movement; and Mr. COOPER having kindly given for an indefinite period the free use of one of his Institute apartments, the society gradually assumed more important dimensions, and become organized under the title of "The Woman's Central Association," which, of account of its indefatigable efficiency in its various departments, was, on the 10th of September last, incorporated with for rather as an auxillary branch of) the U.S. Sanitary Commission at Washington. The whole receipts of the Financial Committee from their commencement to the present time have been $7,215 93.

abstract: The taciturnity of the Norfolk newsmongers, about the doings of the National fleet off Beaufort, is naturally accepted as evidence of its success. The rebels have not hitherto been diffident about the proclamation of their victories. To have met that vast flotilla; to ...
lead_paragraph: The taciturnity of the Norfolk newsmongers, about the doings of the National fleet off Beaufort, is naturally accepted as evidence of its success. The rebels have not hitherto been diffident about the proclamation of their victories. To have met that vast flotilla; to have prevented the landing of the army it carried, and to have beaten it off the coast, would be achievements too splendid to be passed without glorification and a reasonable amount of boasting; and it is hard to believe that policy could have prevented the transmission to the North of intelligence so gratifying to their vanity. When, therefore, we are told that Secretary WELLES has confidently assured a correspondent that the absence of news is accepted as proof that no bad news need be expected, we can only say the assurance is creditable to the sagacity of that statesman, having, as it has, a proverbial sanction, and embodying, as it does, a very general popular conviction.

Many poor widows as well as the wives of volunteers, and very destitute laboring people sent their children there, and depend on the simple [???] the [???] assistance of shoes and everything to carry them, [???] Winter, Without [???] would be driven out upon the [???] to [???] they best [???]. abstract: A NOTED CONFIDENCE MAN CAUGHT. JAMES McMANUS, alias JAMES BRADY, was arrested by officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinet, on Friday night, charged with grand larceny upon several occasions. The prisoner is a man of some note, and some time ...
lead_paragraph: A NOTED CONFIDENCE MAN CAUGHT. -- JAMES McMANUS, alias JAMES BRADY, was arrested by officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinet, on Friday night, charged with grand larceny upon several occasions. The prisoner is a man of some note, and some time ago figured in the papers as the person who robbed a lady of money and diamonds, to the value of between $4,000 and $5,000, while on a steamboat passing down the Mississippi River. About 18 months ago, he made the acquaintance of Mr. GEO. HARRISON, a wealthy gentleman, residing at No. 146 Thompson-street, in this City, and by his superior address and line, manly appearance, so won the confidence of HARRISON that he loaned him money to quite a large amount, and upon one occasion bought two silk dresses for MCMANUS' wife. About the time the dresses, were bought, MCMANUS went to HARRISON's house at an early hour one morning, and by false representations forced his way into Mr. HARRISON's chamber while he was asleep, took from a dressing-table a watch and chain, valued at $200, and some other articles, and with them made his escape. The next we hear of him is in New-Orleans, where he represented himself as a Methodist minister, dressed as such and preached as he had opportunity. Some time in March last he made the acquaintance of Mr. MCCLUSKY, at the Park House, in this City. The meeting was apparently a casual one, and soon Mr. MCCLUSKY became so enamored with the learning and fine social qualities of MCMANUS, that at the conclusion of an evening's conversation he invited him to remain at the hotel with him during the night. MCMANUS represented to MCCLUSKY that he was at that time a Professor at Princeton College, N.J. During the night Prof. MCMANUS stole the gold watch of his friend, and also three gold chains and some other articles, valued in all at about $650, and made his escape. Mr. MCCLUSKY, who resides in Boston, at once made known to the police the loss he had sustained, and from that time Officer GOLDEN has had the matter in charge, and been on the lookout for the prisoner. When arrested, he at first denied the charge, but subsequently admitted that he was the person who robbed MCCLUSKY, and stated that he should plead guilty if a charge was made by him. Justice CONNOLLY held the prisoner for examination in default of bail. MCCLUSKY's watch and chains were recovered yesterday from a pawn-shop in Walker-street. MCMANUS is about thirty-five years of age, of fine personal appearance, converses very well, and is apparently a well-educated man. He says he is a native of Philadelphia. Mr. MCCLUSKY has been telegraphed to come on, and enter a complaint against the prisoner.

abstract: EXCITING CATASTROPHE -- Two LAKE SCOWS OVER THE FALLS. -- An exciting disaster occurred at Chippewa on Monday afternoon. The scows Hotspur and Atlantic, which had been locked into Chippewa Creek, from the Wetland Canal, on their way to this city, were rendered unmanageable by the freshet, and breaking loose from the tug Whip, which was endeavoring to check the velocity of their approach toward the liver, were swept at terrific speed through the village. They sheered against the docks and cables were thrown out and fastened to the posts, but the force of the current was so great that these finally broke, when both vessels rushed toward the mouth of the Creek, tearing away the bridge and bumping violently against the wharves. Nearly all aboard had previously managed to escape to the dock, but the wife of the Captain of the Atlantic remained unrescued when the craft reacted the river. A small boat was immediately manned and sent out to save her, he was taken off when nearing the rapids, One of the scows was carried over the Falls with its entire cargo. The Hotspur was loaded with flour and barley, and the Atlantic with lumber -- all consigned to parties in this city. -- Buffalo Commercial, Nov. 6.

abstract: Gen. GRANT telegraphs from Cairo to headquarters here that our victory at Belmont, Mo., was complete. We captured 130 prisoners, and all of the rebel artillery, but were obliged to leave part of the guns behind for the want of horses to haul them.

abstract: Attention has recently been directed to the incongruous and unconstitutional nature of the late important legislation of Congress for raising revenue by internal taxation. It seems to be incontestibly true that a gross blunder has been committed, and the very first days of the regular session, which meets in December, should be devoted to a revision and amendment of the hasty and ill-advised work of the extra session.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: Gen. SCOTT took his departure for Europe yesterday afternoon in the steamer Arago, accompanied by his son-in-law, Col. SCOTT, and family. He goes direct to Havre, thence to Paris, and, if his health permits, will continue his journey to Rome, where he intends to spend the Winter. Many of our most prominent citizens visited him on board the steamer to bid him farewell, and as the Arago left the dock, the crowd upon the wharf gave the old hero three parting cheers.

abstract: The United States store ship Nightingale, Capt. D.B. HORN, from the Southwest Pass, in ten days, has just arrived at this port. Oct. 31, she spoke and boarded the schooner, Sally Gay, of Norwich, Capt. CRESSE, hence for Tampico. She left at Southwest Pass the United States flag ship Niagara and the United States steamer Huntsville; also, the store ships Pampero and J.C. Kuhn. The following is her list of officers: Capt. DAVID B. HORN; First Officer, W.A. Cline; Second Officer, W.H. De Wolf; Third Officer, John Harrington; Acting Assistant Surgeon, Arthur Ricketson; Paymaster, H.D. Kinsley; Prize-Masters, Kempton, S.R. Hudson.

abstract: SIR: Arriving at Washington with my regiment in the month of May, and being inspected by you and your Staff, you uttered to me the most flattering words, "Colonel, your regiment to the finest of all I saw parade through Washington." These encouraging words acted upon me, upon my officers, upon my men, like the spur of good after upon a good horse. I went ahead, proud of the expression of the satisfaction of a man who is the greatest military leader on this Continent. My regiment grew up to a Brigade, my Brigade to a Division, which I hope will be in the vanguard for attack quite as brave as my Brigade was in the rear guard.

abstract: CRANBERRIES ON HIGH LAND.?For several years past, we have been attempting to raise cranberries on high land, that had been allowed to mature the seeds of a variety of weeds indefinitely before the land came into our possession. The plants grew well enough on this soil,
lead_paragraph: CRANBERRIES ON HIGH LAND. -- For several years past, we have been attempting to raise cranberries on high land, that had been allowed to mature the seeds of a variety of weeds indefinitely before the land came into our possession. The plants grew well enough on this soil, but the incessant pulling of weeds so often disturbed the young "runners," that they did not have time to get a fair hold of the soil, and of course did not succeed well. This experiment was continued two or three years, and then abandoned. The next attempt was upon a piece of underdrained "swale" land; that is, land such as we have all over New-England, bordering meadows, or the low "runs" among the uplands. The piece we selected was of the latter description, where the surplus water found its way out from a series of gently swelling hills. It would have been good corn land in a moderately dry season. The water, however, before it was drained remained in it late enough in the Spring to cause it to send up rushes, in some places, flags, and a variety of rank meadow grasses. This was its condition when selected for cranberries. Six months later it was thoroughly drained by the use of tile laid four feet deep, which resulted in bringing in timothy and red top, without the aid of plowing or adding seed -- on three sides of the piece there being a stout growth of both these grasses. The process was to cover the rushes and meadow grass with coarse gravel, so that none of it could be seen. A little fine meadow muck, say fifteen bushels to the rod, was spread over the gravel, and the plants set about one foot apart in each direction. The plants were taken from a common cranberry meadow, and set from the middle to the last of April. The only thing done to them since has been to keep out all weeds and grass that have made their appearance; and this must be done with care, so as not to disturb the sod or plant, which was originally set, or the "runners" which have started out from it. On the single rod where the plants have been set three years, in the first week of September, we gathered one bushel of cranberries, and we have seen but a single lot in market that will compare with them in size. On a rod set two years eight quarts were gathered. There amounts were in clean, sound cranberries, with probably not an imperfect one amongst them, as they were gathered by hand. A cranberry patch has a value beside that found in its fruit, as there is scarcely anything more ornamental in the vicinity of the dwelling. The plants have a dark, but brilliant green in the Spring and early Summer, and when in blossom, at a little distance, present the appearance of a slight fall of snow upon them; and on a nearer approach, the delicate line of pink on the blossom gives then a very beautiful appearance. They remain in this condition for more than two weeks. In the Autumn, when the leaves have matured, they present various shades of red, and thus remain pleasant and inviting to the eye until snow covers them for the Winter. From observation and careful inquiry through several years, we are satisfied that not more than one family in ten in Massachusetts ever have a cranberry in the house. They are only common with a comparatively few. In our opinion this ought not to be so, because we are convinced that their usefulness does not cease with the mere gratification of the taste. Physicians inform us that they possess valuable medicinal qualities, which give tone and healthy action to the liver and kidneys, and favor the removal of vitiated matters which have become useless and injurious to the system. The preparation of the cranberry for the table, requires a good deal of sugar, to be sure -- but sugar is an exceedingly nutritions and healthy article when taken as a portion of the meal, and is undoubtedly, so far as economy is concerned, cheaper than meat. We hope others will try the experiment of raising the cranberry on high land, so as to establish the fuel that such culture is feasible, and that all our people may have cranberries at hand for their [???] and [???], and as a condiment for their roasted [???] on Thanksgiving Day, or for their roasted motion, when they are so fortunate as to have it. -- N.E. Farmer.

abstract: We have no additional news from the Great Expedition which, under the circumstances, may be considered a favorable indication of its success. Our dispatch from Fortress Monroe states that on Friday a flag of truce passed between the flag-ships at that station and Norfolk, but that no ...
lead_paragraph: We have no additional news from the Great Expedition -- which, under the circumstances, may be considered a favorable indication of its success. Our dispatch from Fortress Monroe states that on Friday a flag of truce passed between the flag-ships at that station and Norfolk, but that no intelligence whatever relative to the Expedition could be gained from the rebels who were encountered. It was expected, however, that news would soon be received direct by a dispatch boat. The dispatch also conveys indirectly the important information that a second expedition is about to sail -- naval officers, it is stated, having been ordered to report to the commanding General, and the troops destined for the service being congregated at Annapolis. A statement to the same effect has already been published in the TIMES, copied from a Baltimore paper.

abstract: Under the heading of "The Church and Christian Society in 1861," M. GUIZOT has just published a book which cannot fail to impress public opinion, wherever the name of this distinguished writer and statesman is known.
lead_paragraph: Under the heading of "The Church and Christian Society in 1861," M. GUIZOT has just published a book which cannot fail to impress public opinion, wherever the name of this distinguished writer and statesman is known. The singularity of this hook consists in the fact that, though a Protestant by birth and convictions, an efficient and zealous member of several Protestant associations, and a devoted advocate of his faith. M. GUIZOT forgets in it his personal opinions as well as his antecedents, and pleads the cause of the temporal power of the Papacy. Leaving aside all differences existing in the religious world, he seen in the Churches which divide the faid, of the people between themselves, but meaning of the same family, whose Head is Jesus Christ. He does not think that the reunion of belief in a universal faith be either in our nature or in our destiny. He says that whatever may be our faith, we have all been brought up in certain religious sentiments common to all, that modern civilization is essentially christian, and that we all bear the name of Christianity. There is in this fact a moral and social unity capable of resisting all diversities of [???] of surviving all struggles, and of binding all the Christians together.

abstract: The approach of the season for the customary annual Thanksgiving Day calls out proclamations from the Governors of the various States. We have before us a dozen of these documents from different heads of States. The present crisis of course lends these papers an interest which they do not possess in the calm times of peace, and the occasion is seized by the Governors to express their views of the situation. To us there is something very grand in the high tone of patriotism that characterizes all these utterances -- a symphony of many voices coming from the East and from the West, affirming for the States represented an unfaltering devotion to the Union, and an immovable determination to subdue those who would seek its destruction.

abstract: In the whirl of political excitement attendant upon the State election last week, the fact was entirely overlooked by the great mass of voters that the Maine law question was involved in the issues of the election. It will ...
lead_paragraph: In the whirl of political excitement attendant upon the State election last week, the fact was entirely overlooked by the great mass of voters that the Maine law question was involved in the issues of the election. It will be remembered that a concurrent resolution was passed at the last session of the Legislature providing that the Constitution of the State be so amended as to prohibit the sale of intoxicating liquors as a beverage, and that this amendment is this Winter to be referred to the Legislature just chosen. In hardly a single District of the State was the question mooted, and even the teetotal organs advised their readers, in view of the immediate and pressing perils of the nation, to hold in abeyance the minor object of liquor prohibition. The liquor dealers, however, who are thoroughly organized throughout the State, pledged themselves, at their meeting at Syracuse last month, not to vote for any man who favored the proposed constitutional amendment, and who was not directly in favor of repealing the present excise law, and allowing all citizens "to sell strong and spirituous liquors and wines in any quantity." The probability s that the amendment will be voted down by the Legislature. Even if adopted by that body, however, it has yet to be submitted to the popular vote of the State before it becomes a law."

abstract: A letter written on board the brig Wm. Creery, a vessel owned partly in Philadelphia and partly in New-Orleans, to E.H. SHAW, of this city, contains a statement to the following effect: "On the 24th of September we passed a fort called Terriffa, at the mouth of Gibraltar, one of the Spanish forts, and was signalized by a blank cartridge from one of their guns to hoist our ensign, (flag,) and while so doing they fired into us with an 18-pound shot, striking the top rail and bulwarks about four feet forward of the fore-rigging on the port side, passing through the forecastle, (men's house,) then through the bulkhead and beams, and from there into the cook's house, and lodged on the starboard side of the vessel's between decks, starting two deck planks. The men were on deck forward, not two feet from where the ball struck. The cook had left the galley only a few seconds before the ball struck us. Two men were injured -- not seriously -- by the splinters that came from the rail. It seems that it is a custom for vessels to hoist their ensigns when passing a fort; but we were not aware of it, and they fired into us before we could get our colors hoisted. They could not help seeing the men forward, and to shoot the way they did looks as if they meant to kill some one."

abstract: "I am a 'supporter of the Government,' and 'a hearty supporter of the honest efforts of the Administration.' I consider the existence of this war as a very sad fact, but while it does exist, I am for having it waged with the utmost energy. I never thought, I never said, that the Administration was 'thoroughly incapable,' or 'thoroughly abolitionized.' It was a perfectly legitimate object in you to defeat the election of a political opponent, and so far as your article contributed to my defeat, I feel personally obliged to you for it; but you are aware that to hold up a man, at this time, and in this community, as no supporter of the Government, is tantamount to calling a dog a mad dog, and should you not have paused before you made such wounding charges against me, on the strength of loose, flying reports of my speech?"

abstract: Mr. Job Collamer, Assistant Superintendent of the Central Railroad, who died in Buffallo, on Thursday last, was born near Ballston Springs, in 1816. He was conductor of the first train that entered the Rochester Depot in 1840. In 1841, he was appointed Superintendent of the Watertown and Rome Railroad, which position he resigned to go into the grain business in Buffalo. In 1857, he was elected Superintendent of the Western Division of the New-York Central Railroad. His death was the termination of an illness which first exhibited itself last August.

abstract: The United States steam sloop-of-war Powhatan, D.D. PORTER commander, from Key West in 6 days, arrived at this port yesterday. On the 6th inst. she encountered a heavy gale from NW., when south of Hatteras, which lasted 36 hours, and broke the delivery-pipe, placing the ship in great danger, as she could not be kept head to the sea by her steam. She comes home for repairs and new boilers.

abstract: -- Many new educational, medical and literary institutions are in progress. Among the most prominent of these we may refer to one peculiarly our own, and one that the older residents have watched with great interest -- the Graefenberg Institute, No. 2 Bond-street. Originated by our own citizens, who exhibited their Knickerbocker feelings by the quaint old German title, the founders of this excellent medical institution obtained for it the legislative sanction of the State, and have gradually grown in popular esteem, until their buildings, No. 2 Bond-street, bear solid evidence of their prosperity and the respect in which they are held. The medical theory and practice of this now world-renowned institution may be spoken of with great favor. The advertisements, pamphlets and almanacs published by the Board of Directors are unassuming, modest, but bearing indubitable evidence of intrinsic worth. Differing from other establishments, addressing themselves to popular favor, all of their medicines are prepared and dispensed by educated physicians, and as disease is no respecter of dull times, we advise those afflicted to investigate the principles inculcated in this treatment, when they can judge of it for themselves. Many of our most distinguished citizens have given it the sanction of their names, and, as New-Yorkers, we may rejoice in the prosperity of the institution. -- New-York Daily News, Aug. 19.
lead_paragraph: -- Many new educational, medical and literary institutions are in progress. Among the most prominent of these we may refer to one peculiarly our own, and one that the older residents have watched with great interest -- the Graefenberg Institute, No. 2 Bond-street. Originated by our own citizens, who exhibited their Knickerbocker feelings by the quaint old German title, the founders of this excellent medical institution obtained for it the legislative sanction of the State, and have gradually grown in popular esteem, until their buildings, No. 2 Bond-street, bear solid evidence of their prosperity and the respect in which they are held. The medical theory and practice of this now world-renowned institution may be spoken of with great favor. The advertisements, pamphlets and almanacs published by the Board of Directors are unassuming, modest, but bearing indubitable evidence of intrinsic worth. Differing from other establishments, addressing themselves to popular favor, all of their medicines are prepared and dispensed by educated physicians, and as disease is no respecter of dull times, we advise those afflicted to investigate the principles inculcated in this treatment, when they can judge of it for themselves. Many of our most distinguished citizens have given it the sanction of their names, and, as New-Yorkers, we may rejoice in the prosperity of the institution. -- New-York Daily News, Aug. 19.

abstract: Last evening the lower part of the city was in a flurry of excitement growing out of the late supersession of Gen. FREMONT in the command of the army of the Mississippi. The German citizens seemed to be particularly exasperated at the removal, and certainly took no pains to conceal their sentiments on
lead_paragraph: Last evening the lower part of the city was in a flurry of excitement growing out of the late supersession of Gen. FREMONT in the command of the army of the Mississippi. The German citizens seemed to be particularly exasperated at the removal, and certainly took no pains to conceal their sentiments on the subject. The lager beer saloons and other public resorts were thronged with indignant crowds, who huzzaed lustily for FREMONT, and gave frequent groans for FRANK BLAIR, whom they regarded as chiefly responsible for the recent change of commanders in the Western Department. Probably no man was ever more heartily condemned and vituperated than our Congressional Representative, Col. BLAIR, and by men, too, who have heretofore been only too proud to be reckoned amongst his most ardent friends and supporters.

abstract: The inhabitants of St. Catharines were thrown into a feverish state of excitement on Monday, in consequence of a serious break-down occurrence to CHAS. S. STRATTON (known as Gen. Tom Thumb) and his suite. They were proceeding to Niagara town, being advertised to appear there that day. They had scarcely left the Wetland House five minutes when the axle of their conveyance broke; the horses, high-spirited ones, immediately became uncontrollable, and started. After carrying away the hind part of a buggy standing by the road-side, the fore-wheel came off. They then made for the sidewalk, which is an embankment twenty feet high. One of the horses went over the bank, but fortunately at this juncture the pole broke, freeing the animals, and, part of the debris becoming entangled in the fence, luckily saved them from a bath in the Welland Canal. The General was thrown out with great violence, alighting on his back. He was instantly picked up by Mr. TOMLIN, (who was much cut and bruised,) and carried into a store, where fortunately no bones were found to be broken, but he was much bruised and shaken. Mr. PIERCE, being seated near the driver, was enabled to take a spring and escaped unharmed. Messrs. WELLS and DE VERE were badly bruised, as also was the valet. Mr. CASWELL, the pianist, took a flying leap and alighted on his face, much to the derangement of his nasal organ. The little footman was much alarmed, and his smart livery was in a pretty pickle from rolling in the mud. The remainder of the party were more or less bruised. The General bore the mishap with great coolness and composure, and appeared much gratified when he learned that none of his retinue were seriously injured. After a short delay they again started, rejoicing that no worse misfortunes had befallen them. The General was advised to rest himself for the day, but he resisted all solicitations, being determined that the Niagara public should not be disappointed. -- Toronto Globe, Nov. 7.

abstract: In the early part of the week, U.S. Inspector IVES seized a trunk going South, with its owner, Mr. RUTSON MAURY, which on examination was found to contain seventy-nine letters from foreign countries to different parties in the South. These letters were secreted among the clothing and some in the "pocket" of the trunk.

abstract: We have had stirring times here yesterday and today. Late on Saturday night, one of three messengers sent forward by Col. LEONARD SWETT, from St. Louis, succeeded in eluding the vigilance of the guards stationed to prevent access to Gen. FREMONT'S Headquarters, and served on the General personally the orders from Washington turning over the command of the Western Department to Maj.-Gen. DAVID HUNTER.

abstract: The vigorous measures set on foot by the new Administration, for the suppression of the slave-trade, have already succeeded in reducing that infamous traffic to its last extremity. It was one of the first points to which Mr. LINCOLN and Mr. SEWARD gave their attention, and they have followed it up with vigor and success. The meeting of the United States Marshals, some weeks since, did a great deal to infuse vigor and harmony into their action, and the conviction last week of the captain of the Gordon, will satisfy the parties who have hitherto grown rich on the profits of this nefarious trade, that the law is no longer to be a dead letter.

abstract: MORTALITY. During the last week there were  103 deaths in this city, classified as follows: Men, 12; Women, 18; Boys, 49; Girls, 24; Adults, 30; Children, 73; Males, 61; Females, 42. Diseases Bright's
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- During the last week there were 103 deaths in this city, classified as follows: Men, 12; Women, 18; Boys, 49; Girls, 24; Adults, 30; Children, 73; Males, 61; Females, 42. Diseases -- Bright's disease of kidneys, asthma, compression of the brain, convulsions, (adult,) debility, (adult,) dropsy, dysentery, puerperal fever, typhus fever, disease of heart, inflammation of bladder, inflammation of bowels, inflammation of stomach, inflammation of throat, intemperance, lockjaw, palsy, rupture, scrofula, disease of spine, unknown, one each. Apoplexy, congestion of the brain, congestion of the lungs, croup, diarrhoea, drowned, hydrocephalus -- two each. Debility, (infantile,) typhoid fever, old age, teething -- three each. Cholera infantum, diphtheria -- four each, inflammation of the lungs, 5; marasmus, (infantile,) and premature birth, 6 each; scarlet fever, 7; convulsions, (infantile,) 9; consumption, 15. Sixty-four of those who died were 5 years of age and under, and 84 were natives of the United States. The deaths occurred in the several Wards, as follows; First Ward, 5; Second Ward, 6; Third Ward, 2; Fourth Ward, 3; Fifth Ward, 2; Sixth Ward, 8; Seventh Ward, 6; Eighth Ward, 6; Ninth Ward, 7; Tenth Ward, 7; Eleventh Ward, 14; Twelfth Ward, 3; Thirteenth Ward,. 5; Fourteenth Ward, 5; Fifteenth Ward, 3; Sixteenth Ward, 11; Seventeenth Ward, 6; Eighteenth Ward, 1; Nineteenth Ward, 3.

abstract: Scandal-mon  gers are busy with the motives which have taken THURLOW WEED, Archbishop HUGHES, and other distinguished gentlemen holding no official positions, abroad just at the present moment. As usual in such cases, the worst and most malicious motives are those which find the widest circulation and the most prompt credence.
lead_paragraph: Scandal-mongers are busy with the motives which have taken THURLOW WEED, Archbishop HUGHES, and other distinguished gentlemen holding no official positions, abroad just at the present moment. As usual in such cases, the worst and most malicious motives are those which find the widest circulation and the most prompt credence. While the disposition to credit attacks upon personal character seems so general as it is now, protests against their injustice may be of little value. But we do not believe for a moment, that Mr. WEED has gone to Europe for any of the reasons assigned by his enemies. We presume that he and the other eminent gentlemen concerned have gone, either upon their own motion or at the suggestion of the Secretary of State, to render to our Government in other countries the same kind of unofficial service which half-a-dozen leading Secessionists have been rendering their Government, vigorously and effectively, for the last six months.

abstract: A correspondent"respectfully requests" us to publish the address of the rebel BRECKINRIDGE to the people of Kentucky. We cannot oblige him. We have better use for the space at our command than to fill it with arguments in defence of treason concocted by a ringleader among the traitors. The address referred to is one of the most venomous assaults upon the Government which has yet been issued. Our correspondent, who has so sympathizing an admiration for such literature, will find it in the Herald.

abstract: COUNTRY. It seems that Gen. MIRAMON, the defeated leader of the reactionary party in Mexico, is taking active measures to aid the invasion and conquest of his country.
lead_paragraph: COUNTRY. -- It seems that Gen. MIRAMON, the defeated leader of the reactionary party in Mexico, is taking active measures to aid the invasion and conquest of his country. He has been for some time past sojourning in Madrid, and we have been assured that his visit to that city had merely private business for its object, which is just as likely as that should the arch-rebel JEFF. DAVIS take a trip to London, at present, the traitor's going thither would be solely occasioned by the pressure of personal interests. Our Washington correspondent, however, in his communication of the 7th, removes all doubts as to the real business of MIRAMON in the Spanish capital, by announcing that the Mexican Chief has been appointed a Lieutenant-General in the service of Spain, and that he is to be second in command of the military force destined to invade, within a few weeks, his ill-fated country. His acceptance of a commission in the army of ISABELLA, his consenting to be a leader of the very expedition which is about to assail his native Republic, only too plainly demonstrate the object of his visit to Spain. The instances are rare in which an aspirant for political honors seeks revenge by leading foreign enemies against his own country.

abstract: Gen. SCOTT took his departure for Europe on Saturday afternoon in the steamer Arago, accompanied by his son-in-law, Col. SCOTT, and family. He goes direct to Havre, thence to Paris, and, if his health permits, will continue his journey to Rome, where he intends to spend the Winter. Many of our most prominent citizens visited him on board the steamer to bid him farewell, and as the Arago left the dock, the crowd upon the wharf gave the old hero three parting cheers.

abstract: On what purports to be the official Drawings of the Delaware State Lotteries, under the management of JOHN A. MORRIS  CO., I find my name is used as a Commissioner having superintended these drawings.
lead_paragraph: On what purports to be the official Drawings of the Delaware State Lotteries, under the management of JOHN A. MORRIS CO., I find my name is used as a Commissioner having superintended these drawings. I feel it due to myself and the public, to say that I have never superintended a drawing of any lottery in Delaware, under the management of JOHN A. MORRIS & Co., and at the same time to assign the reasons of the publication of this card. The grant from which I presume these parties assume to derive their power was passed at Dover, in January, 1859, and gave to R. FRANCE, for the purpose of raising money for internal improvements, the right to prepare Schemes, Draw Lotteries, &c., in Delaware for twenty years, upon condition of the payment of $36,000 annually, payably $18,000 on or before the 1st days of January and July of each year, and upon failure to pay any one of these several payments within thirty days after the same became due, all the privileges under that grant ceased.

abstract: MATHEW F. MAURY, whose arrest in Cleveland, Ohio, was noticed on Saturday, under the head of telegraphic news, arrived here yesterday morning in charge of a Government officer, and was at once sent to port Lafayette.
lead_paragraph: MATHEW F. MAURY, whose arrest in Cleveland, Ohio, was noticed on Saturday, under the head of telegraphic news, arrived here yesterday morning in charge of a Government officer, and was at once sent to port Lafayette. Mr. MAURY has been quite extensively engaged in the business of conveying letters and dispatches between the North and South, and when he arrived in this City, about three weeks ago, he had 600 letters in his possession, which he subsequently delivered to various parties throughout the North, to whom they were addressed. They were written at the South, and though some of them were of a commercial character, others related to the war movements, and tended to implicate some of our most prominent public men as being sympathizers and coworkers with the rebels. But Mr. MAURY's motive in acting as mail carrier was evidently one of a pecuniary nature, for the compensation he received for conveying the 600 letters was at the rate of $2 50 per ounce, and some of the letters weighed from four to five ounces.

abstract: Thirteen of the sixteen volumes of which the New American Cyclopadia is to consist, have already appeared, and the three concluding volumes, ws understand, are in rapid progress toward completion.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen of the sixteen volumes of which the New American Cyclopadia is to consist, have already appeared, and the three concluding volumes, ws understand, are in rapid progress toward completion. We have, therefore, the means of forming a full and accurate judgment of a work which, from its magnitude, and from the eminence of the writers who have contributed to its pages, if for no other reasons, must long occupy a conspicuous position in American literature. Of its magnitude some idea may be formed, when we state that the total number of pages will be not far from twelve thousand, and that each of these pages contains as many words as four pages of the common run of books. The sixteen volumes of the Cyclopaedia, therefore, will equal, in bulk of matter, about two hundred ordinary duodecimos.

abstract: Notwithstanding the threatening aspect of European affairs, and the occupation of France in military preparations, the Emperor is prosecuting steadily and vigorously three of the greatest enterprises of modern times any one of which, successfully completed, will constitute an enduring monument of his statesmanship. These three undertakings are: the Submarine Telegraph between Europe and Africa, the cutting through of the Alps, and the opening of the Isthmus of Suez.

abstract: The correspondent of the London Times, who was the historian of the war in the Crimea, and the reporter of the Indian campaign, has become to European ears the great chronicler of a mightier event the American Rebellion. As a popular historian, he is himself a public, if not a historic character.
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of the London Times, who was the historian of the war in the Crimea, and the reporter of the Indian campaign, has become to European ears the great chronicler of a mightier event -- the American Rebellion. As a popular historian, he is himself a public, if not a historic character. The importance of the position he now occupies can hardly be exaggerated. For the present time, he conveys, not only to the readers of the Times, but to all the English weekly Press and the most of the Continental journals, the latest and the most trustworthy information of the whole tremendous movement on our soil. One can scarcely take up a paper of Europe which does not either quote or assimilate the ideas and statements of Mr. RUSSELL. He is, at this time, the people's historian for Europe. Public opinion is probably more affected by him, as it respects the character of our struggle and the materiel of our armies, than by any other living man. And when one reflects what vast and far-reaching interests are involved in this contest, affecting the formation of States and the fortunes of nations centuries hence, determining production and commerce on which millions must live, settling the liberties of a whole race and the condition of a continent, we may conceive what must be the responsibility of that man who is especially forming the opinion of the whole civilized world on this war. For it should be remembered that in this day of the world's history it is opinion, not force, which determines great struggles.

abstract: In accordance with the notice given to the public during the past week, and repeated yesterday morning in all the daily papers, the doors of City Hall were thrown open at 11 o'clock A.M. yesterday, and all corners were admitted, under certain regulations and precautions, to view the remains of Col. E.D. BAKER, of Oregon, who, having exchanged his Senatorial robes for the military tunic, fell while gallantly advancing at the head of his regiment, the First California Volunteers, in the late disastrous affair with the enemy at Ball's Bluff, Virginia.

abstract: We are still without news direct from the Great Expedition, no dispatch boat having arrived, either at Fortress Monroe or at Annapolis, at the date of our latest advices from those points.
lead_paragraph: We are still without news direct from the Great Expedition, no dispatch boat having arrived, either at Fortress Monroe or at Annapolis, at the date of our latest advices from those points. Another flag of truce passed between Fortress Monroe and Norfolk, on Saturday, however, and though the rebels were still extremely uncommunicative, enough was learned to give sufficient assurance that the success of the expedition is all that could have been desired. The rebel officers accompanying the flag of truce refused to give any information, but one of the hands or board the steamer is stated to have admitted that Beaufort was in possession of the National forces, and that the National flag was waving from the Court-house. Persons who have arrived in Baltimore from Old Point state that the Richmond Enquirer, of Friday, contains a dispatch from Charleston, dated Wednesday, announcing simply that the National troops had landed at two points, and were marching inland. Another rumor is that the National troops stormed and captured two forts -- this news having been telegraphed to Norfolk on Saturday morning. Another, vessel of the expedition the steamer Commodore Perry -- has returned to Fortress Monroe in a disabled condition, and the steamer Governor has probably been lost, though we receive no confirmation of the rebel statement that two vessels had been wrecked on the North Carolina coast.

abstract: The Richmond papers are enforcing, with irresistible appeals, the importance of reinforcing Gen. ZOLLICOFFER's command in Kentucky, and thus effectually protecting Eastern Tennessee and Western Virginia against the threatened incursions of a strong column of the enemy. Although for the present, Gen. ZOLLICOFFER's may be sure against any successful effort to dislodge him, yet if all we hear be true about the heavy masses that the enemy are bringing forward to meet him, he will soon have need of a much larger body to defend the important section of country which relies on him for protection. We all know that Gen. ZOLLICOFFER and his brave army will do all that heroism, energy, and daring can to repel the invader. But we cannot afford to risk the loss of so important a position as he holds, as long as an additional regiment can be spared for his relief. The Examiner very forcibly says:

abstract: There is but one important change in theatrical announcements for to-night: this is at the Winter Garden, where Miss JULIA DALY who has recently achieved a very enviable success in England will make her rentree in the "Female American Cousin."
lead_paragraph: There is but one important change in theatrical announcements for to-night: this is at the Winter Garden, where Miss JULIA DALY -- who has recently achieved a very enviable success in England -- will make her rentree in the "Female American Cousin." The "Octoroon" is the afterpiece. At all the other Broadway establishments the bills are the same, viz.: At Laura Keene's, the "Seven Sons;" at Wallack's, the "King of the Mountains;" at Barnum's, the "Angel of Midnight." The business at all these places continues good. Miss KEENE was honored, on Thursday night, by a visit from Mrs. President LINCOLN. We have not yet heard what effect it has had on the policy of the Administration.
