abstract: Our news from the great Naval Expedition is still of the vaguest and most unsatisfactory kind. Nearly all that we have of any importance comes through rebel sources, and so far as it goes, it betokens success. The Richmond Enquirer is given as authority for the report that reaches us by way of Baltimore, that the fleet had landed its troops, who were marching inland. The landing referred to was doubtless at Beaufort, -- as seems still more probable from the further rumor, from other sources, that Beaufort had been taken after two forts at the entrance of the harbor had been silenced.

abstract: We are still without direct and authentic tidings of the naval expedition. No dispatch vessel has yet been sent back, or none at least had arrived at the date of our latest advices. But we have instead a flood of rumors, all coming through rebel sources, and all agreeing on one point--that of reporting the substantial success of the expedition.
lead_paragraph: We are still without direct and authentic tidings of the naval expedition. No dispatch vessel has yet been sent back, or none at least had arrived at the date of our latest advices. But we have instead a flood of rumors, all coming through rebel sources, and all agreeing on one point -- that of reporting the substantial success of the expedition. Some of the most ingenious of our croakers yesterday evinced a good deal of ingenuity in giving a very strained construction to the news, and in reading in it exactly the reverse of what everybody else understood to be its purport. They were quite confident that these rumors are intended to deceive -- that our forces, after effecting a landing, had actually been bagged by the rebels, and their retreat to the fleet cut off, and that the favorable reports permitted to leak out through the "wheelsman," the "intelligent deserter," and the Richmond Examiner, were but parts of a Confederate plot to elate the public mind, preoccupy the attention of the authorities, and prevent the sending of reinforcements.

abstract: The first Legislatures of the two now Territories of Nevada and Colorado are now in session. The Legislature of Nevada meets at Carson, a town situated at the eastern base of the Sierra Nevada mountains, and the Legislature of Colorado sits at the City of Denver, located at the eastern base of the Rocky Mountains. Both bodies are in good working order, and are busily engaged in getting into shape the necessary bills, and in enacting a code of laws such as is adapted to their condition and wants. Both of the Territories are now in a fair way to enjoy that measure of order and justice which is secured by a full code properly enforced.

abstract: ALLEGED THEFT OF ARMY CLOTHING. Mr. MAHLON KINNEY, a detective in the employ of the Provost-Marshal at Washington, arrived in this City on Saturday in quest of a lot of army clothing which was sent to the Seventy-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., soon after the battle of Bull Run, but which they never received, and which, as now alleged, was taken by the sutler of the regiment, J.M. REYNOLDS
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED THEFT OF ARMY CLOTHING. -- Mr. MAHLON KINNEY, a detective in the employ of the Provost-Marshal at Washington, arrived in this City on Saturday in quest of a lot of army clothing which was sent to the Seventy-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., soon after the battle of Bull Run, but which they never received, and which, as now alleged, was taken by the sutler of the regiment, J.M. REYNOLDS. On learning the facts, Marshal MURRAY sent Deputy-Marshals HUNT and MCKAY to the pier of the Camden and Amboy Railroad, where they found fourteen cases of clothing marked J.M.R., and containing 1,000 army jackets and 334 overcoats. They were informed that REYNOLDS had been to the railroad office and told the clerks that if anyone inquired for the clothing to tell them it had not arrived. Detective KINNEY immediately procured the arrest of REYNOLDS, whom he found at his residence in Brooklyn, and also of the Quartermaster to the regiment, Mr. W.A.L. OSTRANDER, who was found at his home in Leroy-street. OSTRANDER was supposed to be implicated in the matter, from the fact that the arrival of the clothing at Washington was said to be only known to himself, the sutler and Col. LEARY, who was at that time sick in this City, and [???] since died. The Quarter-master, however, claims to be innocent in the matter, and shows a receipt for the clothing from the sailer, who agreed to deliver the same to the regiment at Fort Monroe. The goods are said to have been sold by the sutler to the State of Michigan. Both of the accused were committed to the Tombs, and for examination will probably or bad to-day.

lead_paragraph: It has been the fashion of very foolish people to speak disrespectfully of the military suggestions of newspapers. It has rather come to be considered the thing to warn the Government against listening to the mere wild and unskillful speculation of writers, whose knowledge must necessarily spring from other sources than the lessons of experience; and invite it to throw itself wholly upon that sounder understanding of martial affairs, which comes from active and successful [???] on flood and field. Clamor of this description, which, unhappily, had an apparent warrant in the disaster upon which undue precipitancy urged the army on the 21st of July, has served to silence a criticism, which might at all times have proved wholesome, and to suppress suggestions dictated by practical common sense -- in the present instance a better adviser than an experience which has no application to the anomalies of civil war, and an attachment to routine, slow to abandon the inadequate machinery of a peace establishment.

abstract: We are still without news direct from the Great Expedition, though driblets continue to reach us through indirect channels enough to indicate that the success of the enterprise has been commensurate with the anticipations of the Government, and all that its friends could desire.
lead_paragraph: We are still without news direct from the Great Expedition, though driblets continue to reach us through indirect channels -- enough to indicate that the success of the enterprise has been commensurate with the anticipations of the Government, and all that its friends could desire. The intelligence which we publish to-day comes by way of Hatteras Inlet, brought to Fortress Monroe by the steamer Spaulding, and by way of Cairo, through Memphis papers received there. A person has arrived at the Inlet from the main land in a small boat, and communicated the information that two forts at Port Royal entrance had been captured; that a large National force had been landed; that Beaufort had been occupied after a portion of the town had been burned, and that our troops had advanced and taken possession of the railroad connecting Charleston and Savannah -- probably at Coosahatchie -- capturing a large quantity of stores. No dates are given, and nothing whatever is said of the character of the fighting which must have taken place before so much could be accomplished. Deserters from the rebels, who have reached Newport's News, from up the James River, state that the utmost consternation exists in the rebel army, and that a number of regiments have been sent South to meet this new danger to the bogus Confederacy. The news by way of Cairo is more explicit in some respects. The Memphis papers received there contain dispatches from Savannah fully confirming the landing of our forces and the capture of three forts, -- this is the number known to have been erected by the rebels, -- at Port Royal, Hilton Head and Bay Point. The excellent map, which we publish this morning, will enable our readers to determine the location of these forts. The statement that the National forces had possession of the town of Beaufort is also confirmed, and the losses of the rebels are admitted to be heavy. The report of the wreck of the steamer Union is confirmed by the gunboat Albatross, which has arrived at Fortress Monroe from the blockade on the North Carolina coast. She went ashore on the 6th inst. about eight miles to the eastward of Bogue Inlet. The steamer Winfield Scott is said to have been in company with her, and it is conjectured that she also may have been lost, but there is no certainty about it. The rumor of the loss of the steamer Ocean Express is not confirmed.

abstract: A large number of merchants, and others in favor of the passage of a National Bankrupt Law, met at the fifth-avenue Hotel last evening for the purpose of exchanging views on the subject, and adopting some measures by which the object in question could be attained. Mr. ROYAL PHELPS was called to the chair, and Mr. N. SULLIVAN acted as Secretary.
lead_paragraph: A large number of merchants, and others in favor of the passage of a National Bankrupt Law, met at the fifth-avenue Hotel last evening for the purpose of exchanging views on the subject, and adopting some measures by which the object in question could be attained. Mr. ROYAL PHELPS was called to the chair, and Mr. N. SULLIVAN acted as Secretary. The Chairman stated that a similar meeting was held last October by a number of gentlemen, at the request of W.E. DODGE, A.R. WETMORE, W.E. SMITH, and other prominent merchants. At that time a resolution was passed, by which a Special Committee of five was appointed to obtain information in regard to the system of the bankrupt laws, and report the same to the meeting. The ostensible object of the merchants was to induce Congress to pass a bill by which some fair compromise might be made between debtor and creditor, and the honest man protected. The Chairman further intimated that, if any persons were present with a view to seeure the benefit of a bankrupt law, that was not the place for him.

abstract: During the storm, which recently prevailed with such violence on the North Carolina coast, two French vessels of war are supposed to have been lost. One -- the Prona -- is known to have gone ashore on Ocracoke Beach, and to have been blown up by order of her commanding officer; and the other -- the Cantilabria -- is believed to have suffered the same fate near Beaufort, N.C. They are understood to have repelled all intercourse with the vessels of our blockading fleet, and their movements may be regarded as having been somewhat suspicious.

abstract: The ceremony of presenting the colors to the Ira Harris Cavalry, which had been postponed from Saturday, on account of the weather, took place yesterday afternoon, at Camp Scott, where the regiment is encamped, in the presence of some five hundred spectators, a considerable proportion of whom were ladies.
lead_paragraph: The ceremony of presenting the colors to the Ira Harris Cavalry, which had been postponed from Saturday, on account of the weather, took place yesterday afternoon, at Camp Scott, where the regiment is encamped, in the presence of some five hundred spectators, a considerable proportion of whom were ladies. Hon. IRA HARRIS, United States Senator from the State of New-York, whose name has been taken by the regiment, and who was requested to present the flags, invited the Collector of the port, the Surveyor, and others, to accompany him to Staten Island, to participate in the ceremony. Mr. ANDREWS accordingly placed the revenue steamer Tiger at the service of the party, who proceeded to Vanderbilt Landing, where carriages were in waiting to convey them to the encampment. Judge HARRIS, the Surveyor, Deputy Surveyors ISAACS and GRAHAM, and several other Cnstom-house officials, with their ladies, were on board. While waiting for the arrival of the party, the regiment was marched in companies to the parade-ground, where they were drawn up in line, each company carrying its guide-colors of red and white, on which was inscribed the company letter. Upon the arrival of the guests, a review of the regiment took place, which was concluded by paying the honors of a marching salute to the honored Senator, who occupied the stand, and stood uncovered as they marched by. The regiment was then drawn up in front of the stand, which was near the centre of the plain, in form of a hollow square, the officers, some thirty in number, in full dress uniforms, advancing to the front, Col. DE FOREST occupying the centre of the group. The colors were then unfurled, when Senator HARRIS spoke as follows:

abstract: This regiment left Boston at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and will arrive at Pier No. 3, North River, at 9 o'clock this morning. The Sons of Massachusetts, resident in New-York and vicinity, are requested to meet at the Pier at 8 1/2 o'clock, A.M., where Marshals will be in attendance to furnish badges and to join in the escort. The officers of the regiment, by invitation of the Sons, will partake of a dejeuner at the Astor House, at which not only the sons, but their wives, the daughters of the Old Bay State, will be present. Rev. Dr. TYNG will make the welcoming address, and brief and interesting speeches from other distinguished personages are expected, including Col. BROWN, Private Secretary of the Governor of Massachusetts; PARKEGODWIN, Esq., of the Evening Post, and others. Tickets can be obtained at the Astor House, and No. 203 Broadway. Ample and excellent provision has been made for the men at the Park Barracks. On departing, the regiment will awaken the echoes of Broadway, with the New-England "Glory, Hallelujah" chorus.

abstract: The walls of the new theatre in this city are now up and ready for the skill of the carpenter. abstract: Capt. DOWELL, of the Twentieth Indiana Regiment, which returned to Fortress Monroe from Hatteras, says that he found it almost impossible to remain longer on that narrow neck of land on account of the loss of camp equipage and stores. Although the men have suffered severe privations, the number on the sick-list is very small. All are now comfortably quartered near Fortress Monroe.

abstract: This Regiment, Col. PAUL FRANK, which has been encamped for some time past on Staten Island, left yesterday for the seat of war. It numbers nearly 1,000 men, all of whom are fully uniformed, equipped and armed. The regiment did not land-in this City, but proceeded direct to Amboy, from which place the ears were taken for Philadelphia, en route for Washington. A list of the officers has already been given; the following are the field officers:

abstract: It is understood that the Commission authorized to report upon the Stevens Battery is now in session. The Stevens Battery is a shot-proof ship-of-war, of unusual power, size and weight of armament, designed for coast and harbor defence, upon which work was commenced in 1854, and stopped in 1856, when the vessel was more than half completed, for want of appropriations, after Mr. STEVENS had spent $200,000 upon it from his private purse.
lead_paragraph: It is understood that the Commission authorized to report upon the Stevens Battery is now in session. The Stevens Battery is a shot-proof ship-of-war, of unusual power, size and weight of armament, designed for coast and harbor defence, upon which work was commenced in 1854, and stopped in 1856, when the vessel was more than half completed, for want of appropriations, after Mr. STEVENS had spent $200,000 upon it from his private purse. It is important to know, after Congress has so persistently neglected this means of defence, while European Governments have hurried them forward, that the responsibility of completing the master-design of the father of American marine steam-engineering, or of abandoning a work of which all works of like character in Europe are but imperfect copies, is intrusted to a Commission from whom the public will expect a strictly professional verdict, due to the magnitude of the subject. There is no reason, at present, to suppose that the distinguished gentlemen who have undertaken this task will dissatisfy any candid and intelligent person.

abstract: In the references of this paper to events in Mexico, we have repeatedly directed attention to the European intrigues of the Miramon party.
lead_paragraph: In the references of this paper to events in Mexico, we have repeatedly directed attention to the European intrigues of the Miramon party. The Mon-Almonte treaty gave the first palpable evidence of the course in which the clergy and reactionists were drifting, and since the celebration of that agreement, one fact after another has offered itself to prove the growing intimacy established by them with the Court of ISABELLA II. Messrs. GABRIAC and PACHECO, the French and Spanish envoys, went home to their respective Governments with the avowed intention of promoting a joint intervention. They left behind them the relics of an insurrectionary army, which Spanish officers soon presented themselves to discipline and recruit, and which already spreads the Spanish flag in the sierras of the Republic. They were followed closely by MIRAMON himself, the most obsequious instrument the Church in Mexico ever used for its political objects, who proceeded to Paris, the centre of intrigue, and, when the Spanish expedition was ready to sail, reported himself at Madrid, where his business, according to official journals, was "strictly private."
headline: {'main': 'The Future Viceroy of Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Future Viceroy of Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Nova Scotian passed Father Point yesterday on her way to Quebec, with advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 31st ult. and Londonderry on the 1st inst. She brings no political intelligence of interest, but the commercial news is important. The Liverpool cotton market appears at last to have taken a turn downward, and the market is quoted dull at a decline of 1/4d. Breadstuffs were firm, though prices generally were unchanged. Provisions were dull.

abstract: THE SICI  LIAN VESPERS OF THE NINETEENTH CENTURY.  The additional particulars received of the affair at Guyandotte on Sunday evening give a frightfully tragic interest to the story.
lead_paragraph: -- THE SICILIAN VESPERS OF THE NINETEENTH CENTURY. -- The additional particulars received of the affair at Guyandotte on Sunday evening give a frightfully tragic interest to the story. There were, it seems, stationed as a guard in the town something less than three hundred Union troops, all Virginians. The most of these the rebel inhabitants, by dint of delusive demonstrations of kindly feeling and anxious hospitality, beguiled to their houses on the evening in question, and then by a display of signals, announced to the guerilla cavalry of Ex-Congressman JENKINS, lurking in the neighborhood, that the unconscious victims were garlanded for the slaughter. The butchers, five hundred in number, dashed into the town, fell upon the unarmed National soldiers, and after killing a number, as yet unascertained, made captives of the remainder, those only who had declined the hospitality of the conspirators escaping. While the fight was proceeding, the rebel population, male and female, assisted the destruction by firing from the windows upon their betrayed guests.

abstract: There is no intelligence as yet from the great fleet.  A flag of truce brought down to-day the crew of the French corvette Pronna, wrecked last Tuesday night near Ocracoke Inlet, N.C. She had no pilot and went ashore during heavy weather. The crew, 100 in number, were all saved and reached Norforlk via Charleston. They also bring the report of two rebel batteries having been taken by our troops, but nothing more.
lead_paragraph: There is no intelligence as yet from the great fleet.

abstract: It is a great pity that domestic dissensions should be so prevalent amongst our officers, and that they should be carried to so bitter an extent. The Ball Bluff affair is pregnant with trouble, and Courts-martial innumerable may be discerned in the distance. The Tammany Regiment having deemed it wise to publish Gen. STONE's order rebuking Col. HINKS, of the Massachusetts Nineteenth, for his report of affairs at Harrison's Island, the Colonel has considered it due to his friends that his action in the matter should also be made public. Feeling himself aggrieved by Gen. STONE's order, Col. HINKS addressed him the following communication, demanding a Court of Inquiry.

abstract: THE GREAT EXPEDITION. abstract: The news this morning from every quarter gives some idea of the vast power which the Government have for months been accumulating. We are now beginning to see the difference between abundant means consciousness of a just cause business ...
lead_paragraph: The news this morning from every quarter gives some idea of the vast power which the Government have for months been accumulating. We are now beginning to see the difference between abundant means -- consciousness of a just cause -- business method -- habits of order and subordination and a mechanical training, on one side, and a wild frenzy, unsupported by a single quality we have named, on the other. The first successes are usually on the side of the latter, as a mob may be able to burn down a city, while the next day no trace of its organization may be found. We have waited till every arm we possess could be brought into action; when the blows we strike are irresistible, because they cannot be opposed by equal preparation and resources. We are rewarded for our patience and sacrifices by the unmistakable proofs that, this morning, we can see the beginning of the end.

abstract: The splendid success that has attended the naval expedition at Port Royal, and the tidings of which, still through rebel sources, we publish this morning, will carry the public mind to the climax of satisfaction. The painful suspense, now so happily relieved, that has held the country spell-bound over the fate of the fleet for two weeks but adds intensity to the delight with which the grand coup will be hailed.
lead_paragraph: The splendid success that has attended the naval expedition at Port Royal, and the tidings of which, still through rebel sources, we publish this morning, will carry the public mind to the climax of satisfaction. The painful suspense, now so happily relieved, that has held the country spell-bound over the fate of the fleet for two weeks but adds intensity to the delight with which the grand coup will be hailed. This is not merely the successful execution of a part of the warlike programme, but the prologue of a drama, which is to open with the illuminated initial of the capture of the rebellious city by the sea. The novelty of the arm employed, the poetic justice of the punishment inflicted, and the vast train of consequences that must come out of this fact, all conspire to make it the most brilliant, if not the most important event of the contest.

abstract: The pirate-ship Sumter has undoubtedly been nabbed at last. After a brief and inglorious career of less than half a year, the vessel, says the telegram tersely, "has been caught in her own trap." She thought she had a galleon, and suddenly discovered that one of Uncle Sam's sea-dogs had her. So she gently resigned her soul, body and crew into the hands of her captors; and the latter, doubtless well ornamented with iron jewelry, are now on their way to this port, -- here to receive a like fate with the pirates of the Savannah, who were tried but not convicted, last week. The Sumter was commissined by JEFF. DAVIS to "burn, sink and destroy" every ship which had the Stars and Stripes flying at its peak; and when first she slipped to sea from New-Orleans, the Yankees were given to understand that, in a very short time, their shipping and their flag would be clean swept from the five great oceans of the world. But, alas for great expectations! She captured, all by fraud, one ship, two brigantines, three brigs, two barks, and one schooner; but every one of these is now in the hands of its rightful owners, with the old flag flying, excepting only the one ship, which the Sumter fulfilled her commission by burning at sea. With the Sumter's venture and capture, fails the great and terrible system of Southern privateering, of which we and the world heard so much half a year ago. As for the Captain, who until lately commanded her, he has fled to England, and now, it is reported, is about to deliver a course of shilling lectures upon the American crisis.
lead_paragraph: The pirate-ship Sumter has undoubtedly been nabbed at last. abstract: The regulation ordering that one-half of the pay of all recruits at depots shall be retained until they  are assigned to and join some regiment, has been revived, and will, no doubt, cause some dissatisfaction among unassigned recruits on Governor's Island and elsewhere. This regulation has been in abeyance for the last two years or more, and though the men may not like its revival, it will in reality be advantageous ...
lead_paragraph: The regulation ordering that one-half of the pay of all recruits at depots shall be retained until they are assigned to and join some regiment, has been revived, and will, no doubt, cause some dissatisfaction among unassigned recruits on Governor's Island and elsewhere. This regulation has been in abeyance for the last two years or more, and though the men may not like its revival, it will in reality be advantageous to them, as they will not have so much ready money to spend in bad liquor, which, notwithstanding stringent orders to the contrary, finds its way to Governor's Island every pay-day, and fills the guard-house with obstreperous inmates.

abstract: On Monday night, THEODORE MARTIN (colored) became involved in a quarrel with a carman named VALENTINE COON, in a grocery-store on the southeast corner of Thomas-street and West Broadway, and during the altercation, COON caught up a cleaver from a block and struck MARTIN a heavy blow on his head, which had the effect to fracture his skull. COON then caught him by the arm and struck him a second blow with the cleaver upon the head, and was about to seize a saw to inflict further injuries when the proprietor of the grocery interfered, and at this moment Officer CARMAN, of the Fifth Precinct, entered and took both parties to the station-house. Dr. KENNEDY was called in, and after an examination of the wounds of the injured man, pronounced them such as must necessarily prove fatal. MARTIN was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, and COON committed by Justice BRENNAN to await the result of the injuries.

Dr. KENNEDY was called in, and after an examination of the wounds of the injured man, pronounced them such as must necessarily prove fatal. MARTIN was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, and COON committed by Justice BRENNAN to await the result of the injuries.

lead_paragraph: The Twenty-third Regiment Massachusetts State Volunteers, Col. JOHN KURTZ commanding, whose arrival has been announced for different days during the past week, having been detained by various obstacles, among them the fact that a large portion of the equipments provided for them were condemned by Adjutant-Gen. SCHOULER, left their camp at Lynnfield, Mass., on Monday morning, and, passing through Boston, departed from the latter City at 3 o'clock on the same day, amid the applause of the populace. They took the Fall River route, and arrived in this City about 11 o'clock yesterday morning, on board of the steamers State of Maine and Metropolis, the latter of which had grounded during the night, that mischance still further retarding the journey.

abstract: They tell a story of the commander of one of our vessels, which have so vigorously maintained the blockade, which, if true, will help to explain how such magnificent results have been arrived at, as our blockade has shown. They say that, on a certain day a sail made its appearance, heading for the blockaded port, whereupon this vessel was signaled from the flag-ship to chase. After some delay the anchor was raised, and the vessel stalled to intercept the approaching sail, but it soon became manifest that she was too near the bar to be cut off. As she was within gun-shot, however, the Lieutenant asked leave to throw a shot that way, thinking that the shot might reach her, if the vessel could not. But the commander refused to allow him to fire, saying that his "orders were to chase, not to fire." So the chase went over the bar in triumph, and the National vessel returned to her anchorage.

abstract: The intelligence from the Great Expedition which we publish this morning, although no later than that given in the TIMES yesterday, is much fuller in detail, and of the highest importance. It is obtained from rebel sources, no dispatch-boat having yet arrived direct from the fleet.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from the Great Expedition which we publish this morning, although no later than that given in the TIMES yesterday, is much fuller in detail, and of the highest importance. It is obtained from rebel sources, no dispatch-boat having yet arrived direct from the fleet. The expedition approached Port Royal Entrance on Thursday last, at 9 o'clock in the morning, and engaged Forts Walker and Beauregard, on Hilton Head and Bay Point, and during the hottest of the fire several vessels of the fleet passed in and took possession of the mouths of the inlets leading to Beaufort, Savannah and Charleston, which they immediately blockaded, apparently according to a preconcerted plan. Four other vessels made directly for Beaufort, and at last advices were within sight of the city. Meantime, the forts at the entrance, mounting some thirty to thirty-six guns, had been reduced and were taken possession of by our forces and preparations were being made to land on Port Royal Island and attack Beaufort. Only one of the National gunboats is known to have been lost, and she was burnt. Some accounts say that several others were disabled, but there is no certainty about this. The rebels complain that the guns in their batteries were very badly served, while those of the fleet were served with the greatest precision. Commodore TATNALL, as before announced, was in command of the rebel "fleet." consisting principally of tug-boats, but when the National vessels entered Broad River his vessels scattered, and he landed to assist in saving the shore guns. The Charleston Mercury, from which a great portion of our news is obtained, is evidently afraid that Charleston will soon be in possession of the National forces.

abstract: A meeting of delegates of the above-named organization, some ninety in number, met last evening at No. 534 Broadway, the purpose being to exchange views on the subject of the Mayoralty. After the preliminary business of the evening had been disposed of, a Committee of Conference, empowered to meet with similar Committees from other organizations, was appointed, and the meeting was then called upon to name candidates for the office of Mayor, to be submitted to a future meeting, and subject to approval after consultation with the other Committees. Among the prominent names mentioned, and referred to the Committee of Conference, were; Gen. HIRAM WALBRIDGE, Brig.-Gen. JOHN A. DIX, SAM. A. HOTALING, ISAAC BELL, Jr., JAS. T. BRADY, C. SWACKHAMMER, JOHN A. KERR and FERNANDO WOOD. The meeting was purely preliminary, and will meet again on the call of the Executive Committee, which meets this day at 4 P.M., at the rooms of the Convention, and continue in session daily. Dr. BRADFORD, in an earnest speech, declared himself in favor of uniting all the elements of opposition upon some one candidate for whom every man of every party could vote.

abstract: Orders have been received by Col. SACKETT relative to the payment of those soldiers who have been taken prisoners. Pay may be drawn by a person having the written authority of the prisoner, or by his wife, guardian of his minor children, or by his widowed mother. Application for payment to be made to the senior paymaster of the district where the regiment is serving. It must be accompanied by a certificate approved by a United States Judge, District-Attorney, or Judge of a Court of Record, stating the relation of the applicant to the prisoner. When the soldier has been killed the auditor has been directed to place the $100 bounty allowed by Government to this credit.

abstract: The Bermuda a British steamship, which a few weeks ago carried arms to rebel hands, and joy to rebel hearts, by running the blockade at Savannah, has repeated the attempt, with equal success, carrying out to England a cargo of cotton. The method was probably simple. The tug which subsequently dragged her beyond the bar, had, previously reconnoitering, ascertained the absence of the coastguard, so that there was nothing to impede escape. For, on the theory that any guard was at that point of the coast, it is impossible to account for the escape of a first-class merchant steamer, openly towed out to sea, without assuming connivance on the part of the National officers. We must rather suppose the blockading squadron assigned to Savannah had been called to share in the operations at Port Royal; and that the Bermuda profited by its absence.

abstract: A copy of the Norfolk Day Book, of Nov. 11, which has fallen into good hands, has the following items in relation to the Fleet, taken from the Charleston Mercury, of Friday, Nov. 8: Forty-two vessels appeared before the batteries at the entrance of Broad River between 9 and 10 o'clock Thursday morning. Under cover of a tremendous fire, seven steamers (one account says fifteen) passed the batteries, and gained a point out of range of the guns at Bay Point and Hilton Head. One gunboat was burned and several steamers crippled. Twelve men wounded in the batteries The steamers once passed closed the creeks running into Broad River, driving up the streams Commodore TATNALL's "Mosquito Fleet" towards Savannah, and cutting off water communication with Charleston. The forces had not landed.

abstract: Col. MULLIGAN, of the Irish Brigade, which so valiantly defended Lexington some weeks ago, returned to Chicago on Friday last. A dense crowd hronged the railroad depot, and great enthusiasm was displayed. Father BUTLER, the Chaplain of the Irish Brigade, who was present at the siege of Lexington, forced his way through the crowd, sprang upon the platform, and threw his arms around the Colonel. The latter returned the embrace. Neither could speak, but their tearful eyes manifested the heartiness and cordiality of the greeting. Two herculean privates elevated the Colonel on their shoulders and tried to carry him through the crowd, but stumbled and pitched him headlong. Finally he succeeded in getting an opportunity to respond to a speech of welcome by Mr. E. VAN BUREN. He said:

abstract: Gen. WILLIAMS, the rebel commander, who has just been defeated by Gen. NELSON, was originally by profession a lawyer. In 1846 he raised an independent company and went to Mexico. His first service was upon the line of the Rio Grande. When a large portion of Gen. TAYLOR's troops were transferred to Gen. SCOTT's line of operations, his company went with them. It participated gallantly in the battle of Cerro Gordo. Its term of service expired immediately afterwards, and he returned home.

abstract: MARY ANN WEBBER, who was so dreadfully injured by her husband striking her with a hatchet, on the 4th inst., died at the New-York Hospital, yesterday, from the injuries then received. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest, and the evidence of the surgeon who made the post-mortem, is to the effect that her skull was fractured in several places, and that one of the blows from the hatchet penetrated through the brain. Deceased was about 35 years of age, and a native of Ireland. Her husband, who was arrested at the time of the occurrence, is a German by birth, and has been committed to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: While the naval success at Beaufort does splendid credit to one arm of the service, we must not lose sight of the victory achieved by the other in Kentucky. For the latter, in its immediate consequences, is perhaps of greater value than the former.
lead_paragraph: While the naval success at Beaufort does splendid credit to one arm of the service, we must not lose sight of the victory achieved by the other in Kentucky. For the latter, in its immediate consequences, is perhaps of greater value than the former. It so happens that simultaneous with the advance of Gen. ANELSON and his army to Piketon, the Union men of Tennessee had commenced the only species of warfare against their oppressors for which they possessed weapons. The East Tennessee Railroad is the main, because the direct thoroughfare between Richmond and New-Orleans, and the only one entirely secure from destruction at the hands of maritime expeditions. It might be easy for an enemy coming from the sea to cut off the coastline, by destroying the bridge at Weldon, in North Carolina, or that at Petersburgs Virginia; but the inland route has been regarded as secure, because, by nothing short of a general and successful advance of the National army into the southernmost Border States, has it been deemed possible to interfere with intercourse in that quarter. Nine-tenths of the food which feeds the rebel troops in Virginia, and a majority of the munitions of war -- the gunpowder, the caps, the cannon-balls, the shoes, the grain and the pork, upon which they are dependent, pass over the East Tennessee Railroad to Lynchburgh and Richmond. The Atlantic States do very little in supplying aught but men; the great valley of the Mississippi is looked to for the rest. The Tennessee Unionists have proved to the insurgent Government how hugely its confidence is misplaced. If the accounts received of their doings be correct -- and they come from rebel authorities who would be interested in withholding the report of such disasters from the Northern public, -- nearly all the principal bridges on the road between Knoxville and the Virginia line have been destroyed; bridges, two or three of which it is probably beyond the reach of rebel resources and enginery to replace. This is a victory hardly less important than that of NELSON. In conjunction with that, it will very certainly oblige ZOLLICOFFER to return into East Tennessee, whither he will be followed by a Union army about which the thousands of that quarter of the State who have stedfastly voted against, and to the last opposed the treason of Gov. HARRIS, and his fellow-plotters, will rapidly congregate. A strong National army once established in this all-important locality, the back of rebellion will be broken.

abstract: Tuesday evening, Dr. HAYES received a cordial welcome at the Kane Lodge of Masons, corner of Thirteenth-street and Broadway. Besides the members of the Lodge, many visitors were present. THOMAS S. SOMMERS, W.M., made a very neat and appropriate welcoming address, to which Dr. HAYES replied by saying that it gave him great satisfaction to be welcomed back to civilization.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday evening, Dr. HAYES received a cordial welcome at the Kane Lodge of Masons, corner of Thirteenth-street and Broadway. Besides the members of the Lodge, many visitors were present. THOMAS S. SOMMERS, W.M., made a very neat and appropriate welcoming address, to which Dr. HAYES replied by saying that it gave him great satisfaction to be welcomed back to civilization. He felt grateful for this mark of their confidence. His thoughts had been with them continually during his absence. He had carried the Masonic emblems which they had placed in his hands to the furthest North, and placed them upon land nearer the Pole than had ever before been reached. Those emblems had reminded him of duties which he owed to his fellow-creatures.

abstract: The leading topic now among sporting men is the great "international match" now on the topis between HEENAN and MACE, the American and English champions. HEENAN's challenge has already appeared in these columns, wherein he offered to allow MACE a liberal per centage to fight in the United States or Canada. The Sporting Life, an English publication, on behalf of MACE, accepts HEENAN's challenge, whether MACE is victorious or not in his forthcoming fight with KING in January next. The match with HEENAN and MACE is to be for $10,000, MACE to be allowed $2,500 for traveling expenses to this country and HEENAN is to enter into a bond for $7,500 as a guard against all outside interference. The terms have been accepted by HEENAN, and the articles will at once be drawn up and signed. All sporting men here are willing to bet their "pile" on HEENAN, and one of the most prominent says he will back him to his last dollar. Many imagine that MACE will not prove the conqueror in his fight with KING, as the latter is a tall, powerfully built young fellow, only 25 years of age, and standing six feet two and a half inches high. Any way that is of no consequence, as win or lose, MACE declares himself willing to fight HEENAN.

abstract: Among the large number of regiments now congregating at Annapolis, and soon to embark under command of Gen. BURNSIDE, are the D'Epineuil Zouaves, one of the most thoroughly equipped and drilled corps which have entered the service. Some of the latest regiments from Massachusetts and New-Hampshire, and the Ira Harris Cavalry regiments, now complete, are to swell the command of the gallant BURNSIDE. From Boston, Gen. BUTLER will soon be ready to embark with between three and four thousand chosen troops on board of the steamship Constitution, besides an unknown number on board of other transports. The Constitution leaves New-York on Saturday, and will proceed to Boston, under a charter from the Government, which has been negotiated here through Mr. C.K. GARRISON, the agent of Gen. BUTLER.

abstract: linians who, according to Gov. PICKENS, are "born insensible to fear," behaved precisely as we should have expected them to. They all ran away! The rich plantations on the alluvial bottoms that flank the Broad and Beaufort Rivers were seen to be all abandoned as the National fleet sailed up, the town of Beaufort was found completely deserted, and the two or three thousand South Carolina troops took leg bail. In fact, they behaved just as such conceited cockerels and braggadocio Bobadils naturally would. It has always been a boastful threat of the Palmettese -- there were some at the North even fools enough to believe it -- that, sooner than submit, they would die in the last ditch, and all that sort of stuff and nonsense! But they did better than that -- they ran away, remembering that

abstract: The officers and crew of the French steam corvette Prony, wrecked on the morning of the 5th inst. at the mouth of Ocracoke Inlet, on the coast of North--arolina, arrived here yesterday from Norfolk. The officers are quartered at MAILLARD'S an Broadway, amd at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, and the crew in the houses of the Canard Company at their dock in Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: The officers and crew of the French steam corvette Prony, wrecked on the morning of the 5th inst. at the mouth of Ocracoke Inlet, on the coast of North--arolina, arrived here yesterday from Norfolk. The officers are quartered at MAILLARD'S an Broadway, amd at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, and the crew in the houses of the Canard Company at their dock in Jersey City. It is rumored that the United States Government, at the request of M. DE MONTHOLON, French Consul at this port, will offer the wrecked mariners suitable accommodation on Governor's Island until they shall receive the orders of their Admiral at Halifax, to which point telegraphic dispatches have been sent to his address. We give full particulars of the wreck in another column.

abstract: The officers, marines and sailors of the French corvette, Prony, arrived at the Cunard Dock yesterday morning, at three o'clock, by the New-Jersey trains, having left Baltimore Monday morning. abstract: Every vessel engaged in the action was more or less cut up, although none was injured so badly as to make it necessary to return home for repairs. The Wabash, the largest vessel in the fleet, was singled out as the special target of the enemy's fire. Thirty-four shots struck her. Her most serious injury was to her mainmast, which was very badly wounded, a ball passing through it. It, however, can be fished and made as serviceable as before. She was also struck in the starboard counter, causing her to leak somewhat. Her rigging, bulwarks, ports and spare spars, which were triced up outside, were considerably damaged, and the end of the spanker-boom was shot away.
lead_paragraph: Every vessel engaged in the action was more or less cut up, although none was injured so badly as to make it necessary to return home for repairs. abstract: of discontent prevails in the Fire Department, in consequence of the Comptroller declining to sanction payments of rent to such fire companies as suffered their houses to be used as polling places at the late election. It has been the practice heretofore to make such payments, and the firemen conceive that, as they subject themselves to great inconvenience, and are obliged to pay for the gas consumed by the Inspectors, they are fairly entitled to have their fund indemnified in this trifling way. This view seems reasonable. At all events, it would be much more gratifying to see payments taking such a direction than dropping into the till of small groceries and beer shops, which usually receive such patronage.

abstract: THE THEFT OF ARMY CLOTHING.--W.A.L. OsTRANDER AND J.M. REYNOLDS, the Quartermaster and Sutler of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, who were arrested on Monday charged with appropriating to themselves a large amount of clothing sent to their regiment at Washington, were yesterday sent on to...
lead_paragraph: THE THEFT OF ARMY CLOTHING. -- W.A.L. OSTRANDER AND J.M. REYNOLDS, the Quartermaster and Sutler of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, who were arrested on Monday charged with appropriating to themselves a large amount of clothing sent to their regiment at Washington, were yesterday sent on to Washington in charge of Deputy Marshals HUNT and MCKAY, to be delivered to the Provost-Marshal. They were to have had an examination here, but it was finally decided that the investigation and disposition of the case properly belonged to the military authorities.

abstract: Daylight this morning found us in full view of the inhospitable coast of South Carolina. We steamed slowly towards tlhe land--which loomed indistinctly through the haze of a morning which, in year latitude, is only seen in midsummer--preceded by the Wabash, a few lengths ahead of us, and with not more than half a dozen of the fleet in sight.

abstract: Gen. STONE is greatly annoyed by residents of the village of Poolesville, who sell villainous liquor to the troops. abstract: The First and Fourth Regiments of the Irish Brigade proceed to Washington on Monday next. It has been so determined by the Governor of the State, in accordance with the earnest desire of the President and Secretary of War.
lead_paragraph: The First and Fourth Regiments of the Irish Brigade proceed to Washington on Monday next. It has been so determined by the Governor of the State, in accordance with the earnest desire of the President and Secretary of War. Gen. MCCLELLAN also has expressed an ardent wish to have the soldiers of the Irish Brigade in his command as soon as possible. Nothing, therefore, will prevent the regiments above mentioned from marching on Monday, the 18th. The regiments will leave Fort Schuyler at 7 o'clock, on board one of the largest river steamers. Disembarking at the foot of Thirty-fourth-street, the troops will proceed to Madison-avenue, and halt in front of Archbishop HUGHES' residence. They will here be presented with their colors. After which, marching through Fifth-avenue, and thence into Broadway by Fourteenth-street, they will proceed to the Jersey ferry, en route for the Philadelphia cars.

abstract: a pang to the illness of Gen. HENRY A. WISE, to learn that Accomac has escaped the secession epidemic. An expedition from Baltimore has ascertained that the Union sentiment isomnipotent in that county, insomuch that "Only, near Onancock," is as faithful to the National, colors as if it had never been the seat and shrine of the inspired Ex-Governor. The circumstance only verifies a somewhat musty proverb. The adjoining county of Northampton, occupying the extreme point of the Pan Handle, is reported as less free from contamination. But the detachment of Col. DURYER's Zouaves, which, our Baltimore correspondent informs us, has been sent into that Ultima Thule, will doubtless show the jolly oystermen of the region pointed and substantial reasons why they should emulate their neighbors in Accomac.

abstract: It is related that as the National fleet passed up the bay to Beaufort, our soldiers saw no white men, who everywhere fled at sight of the Star-Spangled banner: but "the negroes came down to the banks, with bundles in their hands, evidently expecting to be taken off." This is certainly a fulfillment, though under different circumstances, of JOHN RANDOLPH's famous prophecy, that are long, instead of the blacks running away from the whites, the whites would be compelled to run away from the blacks. It is also a spontaneous solution of one terrible problem in a manner far more favorable than any one could have augured. Servile insurrections are entirely prevented, and rendered impossible. What would have happened had the whites remained, is another thing. But, thank Heaven, the door of that chamber of horrors is left unopened!

abstract: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, PELATIAH PERIT in the Chair. abstract: Almost every day, in these times of civil and social upheaval, there is some new and embarrassing question demanding immediate solution: there are questions of constitutional law, of civil law, of citizens' rights, of military policy, and of the proper way of putting down the great rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Almost every day, in these times of civil and social upheaval, there is some new and embarrassing question demanding immediate solution: there are questions of constitutional law, of civil law, of citizens' rights, of military policy, and of the proper way of putting down the great rebellion. We know not at first how to deal with such large and difficult problems, for the simple reason that there are no historical precedents to guide us, and we cannot foresee to what results any given solution may lead. But American common sense soon unravels the intricacies, gets at the essential justice in the case, and inaugurates a corresponding policy. We have a score of very remarkable examples of this since the breaking out of the rebellion. The question now on hand is how to circumvent the secession repudiators of debts due in the North.

abstract: The arrival of the United States gunboat Bienville at this port, from Port Royal, S.C., via Fortress Monroe, enables us to lay before the renders of the TIMES a full and authentic account, from our own correspondents, of the movements of the Great Expedition, from its departure, up to and including the attack upon and capture of the rebel batteries at Hilton Head and Bay Point, at the entrance of Port Royal harbor, and the landing of our troops. The expedition arrived off Port Royal on Sunday, Nov. 3 -- a portion of the fleet, however, being detained by the gale. The steamers Vixen and Mercury were sent on Monday morning to sound the channel, and were soon followed by several of the gunboats, which were fired upon by the batteries of Fort Beauregard. The rebel Commodore TATNALL also attacked them with his gunboats, but darkness put an end to the contest for that day. On Tuesday morning, the 4th, the whole fleet entered the harbor, and Gens. SHERMAN, WRIGHT and STEVENS made a reconnoissance, to ascertain the location of the rebel batteries, by drawing their fire. At 7 o'clock A.M. the enemy opened fire from their batteries and gunboats, the National fleet responding with promptitude and telling effect. Our gunboats withdrew about 9 o'clock, having gained a full knowledge of the location and strength of the enemy's batteries. In the afternoon the heavy men-of-war moved inward to get into position, but the Wabash grounded, where she remained for an hour and a half. This circumstance postponed the general engagement. On Wednesday, the 5th, the day was stormy and unfavorable, and a council of war decided to "wait a little longer." On Thursday, at 9 o'clock A.M., the fleet got underway, and at a few minutes past 10 o'clock the rebels opened fire again. The Wabash gave one broadside to Fort Walker, on Hilton Head, and another to Fort Beauregard, on Bay Point. The rebel navy also opened fire but kept at a prudent distance from the big guns of Uncle Sam's ships. The Wabash, Susquehannah and Bienville swept down in line, and delivered their compliments at Hilton Head in the shape of 10-second shells, while the lively gunboats put in the punctuation points for the benefit of the rebel Commodore, at the same time enfilading the two batteries. The firing was now incessant, and a perfect shower of shot and shell fell inside the rebel forts. At noon, the three ships above-named came down, and poured full broadsides into the two forts, the gunboats keeping their positions, and doing excellent service. The flag-ship, the Susquehannah and Bienville, went within six hundred yards, and made terrible havoc with their 5-second shells, silencing several of the enemy's guns. This fire was continued for four hours, during which the National fleet delivered over two thousand rounds. The rebels fought with desperation and inflicted considerable damage on our vessels' nearly all of which were hit by shots. At 3 o'clock P.M. the guns of the enemy had been dismounted or silenced, and Commander JOHN ROGERS went on shore at Fort Walker and found it vacated, and hoisted the Stars and Stripes. A considerable number of killed and wounded were discovered, and it was estimated that the enemy must have suffered a loss of at least one hundred men killed and an equal number severely wounded. Bay Point battery was taken possession of on Friday at sunrise. The rebels fled in the greatest confusion, leaving everything in their tents, even to their swords, watches, private papers and clothing. The loss on board of the National fleet was eight killed, and six severely and seventeen slightly wounded. The troops landed and took possession on Thursday evening, and next day the Bienville left with dispatches for the Government. It will be noticed that the accounts which have previously reached us through rebel sources have been wonderfully correct, considering their origin -- only a few trifling disasters to our vessels having been thrown in by way of offset to their humiliating reverse. These disasters, however, prove to have been pleasant rebel fictions, invented to smooth off the rough edges of defeat. Not one of the National vessels was disabled or destroyed, as reported, though several of them were badly cut up.

SHERMAN, WRIGHT and STEVENS made a reconnoissance, to ascertain the location of the rebel batteries, by drawing their fire. At 7 o'clock A.M. the enemy opened fire from their batteries and gunboats, the National fleet responding with promptitude and telling effect. Our gunboats withdrew about 9 o'clock, having gained a full knowledge of the location and strength of the enemy's batteries. In the afternoon the heavy men-of-war moved inward to get into position, but the Wabash grounded, where she remained for an hour and a half. This circumstance postponed the general engagement. On Wednesday, the 5th, the day was stormy and unfavorable, and a council of war decided to "wait a little longer." On Thursday, at 9 o'clock A.M., the fleet got underway, and at a few minutes past 10 o'clock the rebels opened fire again. The Wabash gave one broadside to Fort Walker, on Hilton Head, and another to Fort Beauregard, on Bay Point. The rebel navy also opened fire but kept at a prudent distance from the big guns of Uncle Sam's ships. The Wabash, Susquehannah and Bienville swept down in line, and delivered their compliments at Hilton Head in the shape of 10-second shells, while the lively gunboats put in the punctuation points for the benefit of the rebel Commodore, at the same time enfilading the two batteries. The firing was now incessant, and a perfect shower of shot and shell fell inside the rebel forts. At noon, the three ships above-named came down, and poured full broadsides into the two forts, the gunboats keeping their positions, and doing excellent service. The flag-ship, the Susquehannah and Bienville, went within six hundred yards, and made terrible havoc with their 5-second shells, silencing several of the enemy's guns. This fire was continued for four hours, during which the National fleet delivered over two thousand rounds. The rebels fought with desperation and inflicted considerable damage on our vessels' nearly all of which were hit by shots. At 3 o'clock P.M. the guns of the enemy had been dismounted or silenced, and Commander JOHN ROGERS went on shore at Fort Walker and found it vacated, and hoisted the Stars and Stripes. A considerable number of killed and wounded were discovered, and it was estimated that the enemy must have suffered a loss of at least one hundred men killed and an equal number severely wounded. Bay Point battery was taken possession of on Friday at sunrise. The rebels fled in the greatest confusion, leaving everything in their tents, even to their swords, watches, private papers and clothing. The loss on board of the National fleet was eight killed, and six severely and seventeen slightly wounded. The troops landed and took possession on Thursday evening, and next day the Bienville left with dispatches for the Government. It will be noticed that the accounts which have previously reached us through rebel sources have been wonderfully correct, considering their origin -- only a few trifling disasters to our vessels having been thrown in by way of offset to their humiliating reverse. These disasters, however, prove to have been pleasant rebel fictions, invented to smooth off the rough edges of defeat. Not one of the National vessels was disabled or destroyed, as reported, though several of them were badly cut up.

abstract: One of the worst effects of our want of military experience in America is, that we only learn our lack of preparations after some cruel disaster.
lead_paragraph: One of the worst effects of our want of military experience in America is, that we only learn our lack of preparations after some cruel disaster. The Yankee ingenuity and practical talent, which have done such wonders in the arts of peace, have been applied comparatively little to the business of a campaign, and they certainly have not, thus far, produced the results we might have expected in the present war. How, for instance, ten or fifteen thousand men of New-England could encamp for months on the banks of a river, which they knew must ultimately be crossed with artillery and with masses of men, and never prepare any boats or materials for a bridge, of attach to their camps any pontoon-train, is something utterly incomprehensible to any European army, though composed of men with not half the invention or business patent. Suddenly, after our most gallant and heroic men are caught on the further bank, between an overwhelming force in front and the torrent in the rear, the commanding officer is heard inquiring whether there are any means of transport, in case of retreat! Now, after the calamity, after a defeat which, but for the heroic bravery shown by the men, would be most discouraging and painful, the whole army and country wake to the discovery that "we have no pontoon-train" anywhere on the line of the Potomac! It seems as if nothing but disaster and defeat will ever teach us the simplest rules of military preparation.

abstract: Private letters from Fort Craig, New-Mexico, under date of Oct. 16, state that there were one thousand soldiers, regulars and volunteers, intrenched there, and that they expected to more into Texas.
lead_paragraph: Private letters from Fort Craig, New-Mexico, under date of Oct. 16, state that there were one thousand soldiers, regulars and volunteers, intrenched there, and that they expected to more into Texas. The regulars consisted chiefly of the Seventh Infantry. Several cases of small-pox had appeared among the troops, but they were not considered serious, and the health of the troops was generally good. Company F of the Seventh has been stationed at Fort Craig for about twelve months.

abstract: The elite of South Carolina, congregated at Beaufort watering-place, behaved most unceremoniously toward the Union pleasure-seekers, having all beat a precipitate flight. A single whiteman, and he drunk, was left to welcome the coming, speed the parting guests! We would like to have his name. It would pain us to think that he should sink into the general blank oblivion -- the tipsy Marius ruminating in maudlin meditation amid the ruins of Beaufort. For he has a high moral meaning, has he. He is a typical man. What is the whole rebellion but a gigantic "drunk?" For thirty years the South has been intoxicating itself with the wildest schemes -- schemes of infinite Slavery expansion, of an all-conquering Cottondom. They began with the drunkenness of secession, and ended in the tremendous delirium of civil war. But they are getting rapidly sobered, and will come out of it wiser and better men, though with a terrible headache as the effect of their dissipation.

abstract: -- The injurious reference made to Capt. F.G. YOUNG, Quartermaster of the brigade of the late Col. BAKER, in the letter of a correspondent in yesterday's TIMES, appears to have been made under a total misapprehension of the facts. Capt. YOUNG, who is now in this City, and stopping at the Brevoort House, has shown us a fifteen days' furlough from his command, signed by the proper officer of Gen. MCCLELLAN's Staff, and approved by the President. The Captain is here on important business connected with his brigade, and there is no foundation whatever for the false statement touching his arrest.

abstract: The U.S. gunboat Bienville, Commander CHAS. STEEDMAN, and A.E.R. BENHAM, Executive Officer, arrived at this port at 6 1/2 o'clock last evening, from the Great Naval Expedition, via Fortress Monroe, where she left dispatches for Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH, and whence Capt. STEEDMAN proceeded to Washington with dispatches for the Army and Navy Departments. These dispatches, from Capt. DUPONT, who commanded the naval portion of the Expedition and from Gen. SHERMAN, who commanded the military branch, will be found below, together with a detailed narrative of the operations of the Expedition since it left Hampton Roads.

abstract: At a meeting of the Taxpayers Union Convention, held at the Everett House, ROBERT B. MINTURN was unanimously nominated for Mayor, and a Committee of Twenty-five appointed to wait upon him and announce that fact. A Committee of Three was also appointed to report names for Aldermen. Councilmen and School Commissioners, as candidates at the ensuing Charter election, and another Committee of Seven, to confer with other organizations. The meeting was mainly composed of merchants of the highest respectability. On Friday the Executive Committee has a meeting of importance at the office of the Chairman of the Union Convention, JOHN LIVINGSTON, Esq.

abstract: -- The new steamer Constitution, of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, made an engineers' trial trip yesterday, leaving Canal-street dock at 9 o'clock A.M., and returning to her anchorage, opposite Canal-street, about 4 o'clock P.M. The party on board consisted chiefly of the officers of the Company and practical engineers. The ship ran about five miles beyond the light-ship, the engine making from twelve to fifteen revolutions with a moderate head of steam, being equal to an average of fourteen knots an hour. She steers with great case. The entire trip was most satisfactory. Capt. SKIDDY, who noted the results of the trial, will give them to the Press on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: -- The new steamer Constitution, of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, made an engineers' trial trip yesterday, leaving Canal-street dock at 9 o'clock A.M., and returning to her anchorage, opposite Canal-street, about 4 o'clock P.M. abstract: If a canard of unusual feather is to be let fly at Paris, its flight always takes the direction of Brussels.
lead_paragraph: If a canard of unusual feather is to be let fly at Paris, its flight always takes the direction of Brussels. To the Brussels Independance and Nord are sent the sensational stories which the censorship of the press at Paris restrains from publication, or which, if circulated at the French capital, would simply meet with ridicule. Of this sort is a story brought us by the Niagara -- a story derived in the first instance from the Herald of this City. France and England, we are told, have complex designs in the Mexican Gulf. Their joint expedition will be something more than a monster dun at the door of impecunious Mexico. The end of the year will see that matter happily concluded, and in January a business of more momentous import will be attended to, namely, the rupture of the blockade at the Gulf ports, and the release of cotton to supply the starving millions of Britain and France. In other words, the two Powers in question propose to relieve their cotton famine by a war with the United States.

abstract: From Washington we have the continued report of quiet along the National lines. The rebels do not show themselves much since the news of the success of the Great Expedition reached them. A person who reached Washington yesterday, only a day or two from Richmond, reports that the full extent of their disaster was known to the rebels, and that it had created among them the greatest consternation.
lead_paragraph: From Washington we have the continued report of quiet along the National lines. The rebels do not show themselves much since the news of the success of the Great Expedition reached them. A person who reached Washington yesterday, only a day or two from Richmond, reports that the full extent of their disaster was known to the rebels, and that it had created among them the greatest consternation. The recent reconnoissance of the Fifth Regiment of the Excelsior Brigade, under command of Col. GRAHAM, to Mathias Point, and about four miles back into Virginia, appears to have been a most successful one. We give a detailed account of it this morning from the pen of our special correspondent with the Brigade.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, a Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations, in the loyal States, assembled in the Bible House building, to consider the subject of the "United States Army a a Field of Christian Usefulness," and to arrange, as far as practicable, some system of operations by which that field may be most efficiently and economically cultivated.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, a Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations, in the loyal States, assembled in the Bible House building, to consider the subject of the "United States Army a a Field of Christian Usefulness," and to arrange, as far as practicable, some system of operations by which that field may be most efficiently and economically cultivated. The Convention was organized by choosing G.H. STEWART, of Philadelphia, President; E.S. TOBY, of Boston, Vice President, and CEPHAS BRAINARD, of New-York, and WILLIAM BALLINGTON, of Washington, Secretaries. A Business Committee of five was then appointed, and the delegates proceeded to the Tabernacle Baptist Church, corner of Tenth-street and Second-avenue, where they were formally received and welcomed, in behalf of the New-York Association, by Rev. S.H. TYNG. The exercises at the Church were opened with singing and prayer, after which P. HARWOOD VERNON, President of the New-York Association, made a brief introductory address. Dr. TYNG, in an appropriate address then welcomed the delegates. He alluded to the great amount of good that had been accomplished by the Associations in attending to the spiritual and bodily wants of our soldiers, and there were grand results in war, as well as painful ones. He held that slavery of man was a thousand fold worse than any warfare that could be waged to overturn and destroy it. In speaking of JOHN C. FREMONT, he said that he would yet prove the pathfinder of humanity. He also spoke in glowing terms of Commodore DUPONT, and justly eulogized the irreproachable character of Gen. SCOTT. He urged that the occasion should be made fragrant and fruitful with glorious results for Christianity, for the Church, for the nation, and for humanity, in all its hopes and joys.

abstract: Our special correspondent, on board the Mantic, brought from Port Royal late numbers of the Charleston Mercury and Courier. The latter journal retains much of its aristocratic appearance, but the Mercury is printed on paper utterly innocent of bleaching powders, and so rotten that it is a wonder it should have hung together long enough to pass through the press. More than this, its portly dimensions have been very seriously curtailed, until it is hardly half its former size. From these journals we make the following interesting extracts:

abstract: On last Sunday morning, Rev. Mr. NEWLIN, Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Bloomfield, N.J., delivered a discourse commemorative of WILLIAM S. PIERSON, late Corporal of Company B, First Minnesota Regiment. Corporal PIERSON, who was a native and resident of Bloomfield, chanced to be in Minnesota at the time the first call for volunteers was issued, and at once [???] for three months, but subsequently was [???] in for three years with the rest of the First Minnesota. In the battle of Manassas he did his share to secure this regiment the high reputation which it gained, but received two Minie balls in his thigh, fracturing the hip-bone badly. Abandoned with the rest of the wounded, he dragged himself two or three miles from battle field during the Sunday night succeeding the panic, and on Monday was picked up by a passing ambulance and taken to the Junction. It was Tuesday morning, however, before he received any food or attendance. As soon as his condition warranted it, he was transferred to Richmond and placed in the General Hospital, where his friends have every reason to believe that he received the most faithful attention and rare. Amputation of the wounded limb was finally found necessary, and was performed by the ablest practical surgeon in Richmond, but his strength had been too much exhausted by the previous suffering, and on Aug. 18, Corporal PIERSON died, in the 20th year of his age. A letter written to his parents by the surgeon who attended him while in the hospital, although dated Aug. 23, did not reach them until two or three weeks ago. Mr. NEWLIN's funeral discourse was founded on the text. "Fight the good fight of faith." It was a forcible vindication of the justice of the cause in which Corporal PIERSON lost his life, and a touching and eloquent tribute to the deceased.

abstract: The Charleston Mercury threatens that the proud city by the sea shall be "laid in ashes" rasher than that it shall fall into the hands of the cursed "Hessians," and tells us that black flags are hoisted, indicating that no quarter will be taken from the "invaders."
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Mercury threatens that the proud city by the sea shall be "laid in ashes" rasher than that it shall fall into the hands of the cursed "Hessians," and tells us that black flags are hoisted, indicating that no quarter will be taken from the "invaders." We may form some idea of what they are likely to do from what they did on the occasion of an invasion of another sort of Hessians about a hundred years ago. An officer of distinction in the British service, giving an account of the operations of His Majesty's army in South Carolina, says:

abstract: The steamship Niagara, which left Liverpool on the 2d inst. and Queenstown on the 3d, arrived at Halifax yesterday. Her advices are two days later than were received by the Nora Scotian.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Niagara, which left Liverpool on the 2d inst. and Queenstown on the 3d, arrived at Halifax yesterday. Her advices are two days later than were received by the Nora Scotian. In the Liverpool Cotton market there had been a decline during the week of 1/8@1/4d. Breadstuffs were firm and an advance in Corn is noted. Provisions were quiet. The steamship City of Washington, from New-York, while going from Queenstown to Liverpool broke her main shaft, and proceeded under canvas as far as Holyhead, whence she was towed to Liverpool. The Bank of France, it is announced, has succeeded in effecting a loan of two and a quarter millions sterling from the Bank of Prussia. We have a reiteration of the report that France has opened negotiations with Austria for a cession of Venitia, and it is reported that the Duke of Magenta has been intrusted with the conduct of the affair. The Valley of the Dappen in Switzerland had been occupied by French troops, and the Swiss Government had sent Commissioners to the spot, resolved to demand satisfaction from the French Government. Trouble also seems to be brewing in Russia. The collision of the students with the soldiery, on the occasion of the reopening of the University at Moscow, appears to have been quite a serious affair, in which some blood was shed. Two hundred and fifty students were arrested.

abstract: One of the most extraordinary enterprises ever recorded in the history of counterfeiting has, within the last two or three days, been brought to light. Bills -- to an, as yet, unascertained amount -- are in circulation, forged on the Shoe and Leather Bank of this City, one of the wealthiest and most reliable of all our metropolitan financial institutions. The bankitself will sustain no material injury in the affair it is true; but the skillful way in which its officers have been deceived, in the matter of their own paper issue, proves that it has had a narrow escape. The spurious issue is in $160 bills, and it is said that quite a number of them are known to have been thrown upon the market. Several City banks have taken them, and unless able to trace them to customers, will stand in for a considerable loss.

abstract: The genius of the North in the present contest has never had a better illustration than the announcement that the merchant-ship, freighted with every variety of Yankee notion, is following fast in the wake of the manof-war.
lead_paragraph: The genius of the North in the present contest has never had a better illustration than the announcement that the merchant-ship, freighted with every variety of Yankee notion, is following fast in the wake of the man-of-war. This would seem consistent with the great object in view, which was a restoration, first, of the geographical integrity of the country, and next, of those peaceful arts which political amity alone renders possible. We at present waive the question as to whether a step is either politic or legal in reference to the trade of other countries. It is certainly agreeable to the trading genius of Yankeedom The North never willingly destroys, but always seeks to create and conserve. In a month's time every Union man in South Carolina, that has a mind to trade, can have any want supplied from a water-pail to a piano-forte or a steam engine. We calculate that they will not be backward in moderately helping themselves to such things as they need.

abstract: "A little after 2 o'clock this morning, the explosion of a migety gun from the enemy's side announced the approach of a new sail -- daylight revealed a huge steamer at anchor near Fort Pickens. Three guns were fired, which shook the very city, and caused for the moment some little anxiety. I give it as a report from below that several vessels were in the vicinity of Pickens last night, and under darkness of the hour landed troops on the Island, it was thought. I give this simply as I hear it. Certain it is, that there are seldom any vessels seen now in the daytime near the fort. By these movements, no doubt, they intend for the future to keep a secret.

I give this simply as I hear it. Certain it is, that there are seldom any vessels seen now in the daytime near the fort. By these movements, no doubt, they intend for the future to keep a secret.

abstract: A FATAL ACCIDENT IN BROOKLYN. A sad calamity occurred in the family of Dr. LUCIUS HYDE, who resides at the corner of Clark and Henry streets, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, in the sudden death of his interesting little neice, a child of seven years of age, who met her death from falling from the upper floor of the stable attached to the residence, in which she was playing with a young brother.
lead_paragraph: A FATAL ACCIDENT IN BROOKLYN. -- A sad calamity occurred in the family of Dr. LUCIUS HYDE, who resides at the corner of Clark and Henry streets, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, in the sudden death of his interesting little neice, a child of seven years of age, who met her death from falling from the upper floor of the stable attached to the residence, in which she was playing with a young brother. While there together in the afternoon, it appears, her brother suddenly heard a fall, and proceeding down the stairway saw his little sister lying on the floor apparently lifeless, she having fallen from the upper floor through a trap door, which was used to ventilate the loft of the stable. Lustily calling for assistance, the family promptly came to his aid, and the little sufferer was taken into the house and medical aid immediately sent for. Dr. HYDE, being an invalid and a sufferer, from a severe nervous disease, was not notified of the sad occurrence, but Drs. HURD, LANDON and KISSAM were soon in attendance, and restoratives were at once applied. For the time being hopes were entertained of her recovery, as she rallied a little, but after that her pulse rapidly declined, and congestion of the brain having set in, she expired before 5 P.M. This terrible blow deeply affects a large circle of the Doctor's relatives and friends, as the child was an exceedingly bright and interesting girl. This is but one of many similar accidents that have occurred of late in Brooklyn, but none have terminated so fatally as this, and it should warn parents to forbid their children from playing in such dangerous places.

abstract: pendent enters into explanations of the way in which it was made last week to say that Secretary SEWARD and THURLOW WEED believed the war with rebellion hopeless, and had conspired to terminate it by a sudden peace. The offensive paragraph came, it seems, from an unauthorized contributor, who, when the paper was in the act of "going to press," arrested the irresponsible people in charge with the astounding announcement, and induced them to give it publicity. The editors disclaim all accountability for the faux pas -- a disclaimer which those who know their prudence and sense will freely accept It will be a judicious precautionary measure, however, considering the world of readers the Independent reaches, and the authority of itsstatements and opinions, to surround the critical period of its weekly issue with a well-armed and courageous guard against the peril of similar interpolations.
