abstract: The trial of MINTHORNE WESTERVELT, the  third mate of the Nightingale, for partici- pation in the slave trade, was closed yesterday by a disagreement of the jury.
lead_paragraph: The trial of MINTHORNE WESTERVELT, the third mate of the Nightingale, for partici- pation in the slave trade, was closed yesterday by a disagreement of the jury. This is not, perhaps, a matter of surprise, although it seems as though the facts testified to by the witnesses for the prosecution were sufficient to warrant a verdict against him. If those witnesses were to be believed, and there was no reason why they should not have been, beyond the fact that they were engaged on the same vessel, there could be no doubt that WESTERVELT kept count of the negroes as they were shipped, helped to rig the stagings by which they came up the ship's side, and performed his duties as third Mate up to the period of the capture of the vessel, during all the time of her lying in the Congo River while the preparations for the voyage were going on and during all the time she was dodging about to avoid the English and American cruisers -- now out to sea for a day or a week, and now back to the coast again, watching her chance to take in her cargo without detection. It is possible that the jury may not have believed the witnesses, even in the total absence of any explanation from the accused, but it is more likely that the four jurors who were for acquittal hung upon the point in the Judge's charge, that he might have been "under compulsion, physical or moral," that he might have been "beguiled into it by the arts or power of others until too late to extricate himself," although no shadow of compulsion was proved and he had repeated opportunities to get away from the vessel if he had desired, as she was boarded five or six times by English and American cruisers, while she was waiting for a cargo. To us it rather seems that it would have been better if there had been more men on the jury like the German juryman, who was rejected at the commencement of the trial, because he had "read the articles in the Tribune, and the impression produced on his mind was that, if the evidence was clear, the jury ought to give in a verdict."

abstract: One unacquainted with the extraordinary and fantastical notions prevalent in South Carolina about the outside world and the people of the North, cannot conceive the horror-haunted condition in which the whole State must now be plunged.
lead_paragraph: One unacquainted with the extraordinary and fantastical notions prevalent in South Carolina about the outside world and the people of the North, cannot conceive the horror-haunted condition in which the whole State must now be plunged. The designs of the North have, for ten years past, been set forth as so atrocious, so unutterably demoniacal, that the mere thought of them has kept the people in a condition bordering on insanity. In painting the people of the North, only two colors have been used, red and black; bloodthirsty and fiendish were they all. The colors have been put on with a prodigiously big brush, and very thick. All Northerners were Abolitionists, and all Abolitionists were -- well, for what they were, see, passim, the Southern Quarterly, DE BOW's Review, the Charlston Mercury, the Carolina Times, and every dingy gazette that saw the light from King's Mountain to Beaufort; listen to RHETT, to KFITT, to Gov. ADAMS, to Gen. QUATTLEBAUM, to Rev. Dr. THORNWILL, to MAXCY GREGG, and to all the heady orators of the bar-room; look at the statutes of the State, and see what penalties wait upon the detected Abolitionist; go to the plantations, and see how he is guarded against, as fire would be guarded against in a powder-magazine. It was the design of the North to make a San Domingo of the South; and San Domingo means a black man's revelry in white men's blood, in rapine and in ruin, such as history has but one solitary example on its pages.
headline: {'main': 'South Carolina in a Ferment.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'South Carolina in a Ferment.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: About 9 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the extensive saw-mill of C. & R. POLLON, Nos. 446, 448 and 450 Water-street. Nos. 446 and 448 were five story brick buildings, and were totally destroyed; No. 450 was a four-story building, and was only a partial loss. Messrs. POLLON's loss is estimated at about $50,000. They are insured for $35,000. The second, third and fourth floors of No. 446 were occupied by GEORGE VAUGHN as a picture frame manufactory. His loss is about $1,500; insured for about the same amount. The fire originated, in No. 446, in the vicinity of the boiler.
lead_paragraph: About 9 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in the extensive saw-mill of C. & R. POLLON, Nos. 446, 448 and 450 Water-street. abstract: About 8 o'clock yesterday morning, a German named SAMUEL HOFFMAN was stabbed to the heart with a dirk in the hands of Dr. MOSES LOWENBERG. The parties resided in the same house, at No. 141 First-avenue; Dr. LOWENBERG occupied the front basement as an office, and the murdered man, with his family, lived in the rear basement room. It seems that, yesterday morning, an altercation took place between the parties about the hall-door. Mr. HOFFMAN wished to have it shut, and the Doctor insisted that it should remain open. After the door had been opened and shut twice by the respective parties, Dr. LOWENBERG opened it a third time, and declared he would put it out of the power of HOFFMAN to shut it again, and immediately approached him as he was standing in the hallway, and, without further provocation, plunged a dirk into his breast four times, inflicting wounds so serious that he died in about five minutes afterwards. The only words that HOFFMAN uttered, after he received the stabs, were -- " I am stabbed," and staggering into his room, he fell down on alounge, and soon expired. Dr. LOWENBERG was immediately arrested, and taken to the Seventh Precinct Station-house, where he is now detained to await the result of the Coroner's inquest. Coroner SCRIRMERwill hold an inquest at 8 1/2 o'clock this morning. The deceased was about thirty-five years of age, and has left a wife and two children in destitute circumstances. He was a carpenter by trade, and had been a resident of New-York about ten year. For the last eleven months he has been out of employment the most of the time. He has the reputation of being a quiet, inoffensive man, of industrious habits. The dirk used in the commission of the murder is 14 1/2 inches in length, from the point to the brass ferule near the handle, and had evidently belonged to a cane; but the officers, after diligent search, were unable to find the other portion. After the prisoner had been taken to the Station-house, he desired to send a messenger to Collector BARNEY, at the Custom-house, saying that he stood well there, and could get any amount of bail necessary. He is a politician of some note among the Germans of the Seventeenth Ward, and has hitherto taken an active part in the election of City officers.

abstract: An immense audience assembled last evening, at the Cooper Institute, to hear Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER deliver his new lecture, entitled "The Camp and Country," before the New-York Young Men's Christian Association. By 8 o'clock the spacious Hall was crowded, a large proportion of the audience consisting of ladies. The platform was occupied by a throng of notable personages from this and other cities; among whom were noticed PETER COOPER, Esq., and the newly elected officers of the Convention of Young Men's Christian Associations now in session here, viz.: GEORGE H. STUART, of Philadelphia, President; E.S. TORY, of Boston, Vice-President, and CEPHAS BRAINERD, of New-York, and WM. BALLANTINE, of Washington, Secretaries. A number of delegates to the same Convention, accompanied by their wives and daughters, were also furnished with seats in the same vicinity.

abstract: About 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, a disturbance occurred in the apartments of BLACKMAN  ABELL, No. 1 Ann-street, occupied as a gambling house, in which a man named ALBERT OATMAN, was was severely beaten, and had an arm broken by the proprietors of the establishment.
lead_paragraph: About 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, a disturbance occurred in the apartments of BLACKMAN ABELL, No. 1 Ann-street, occupied as a gambling house, in which a man named ALBERT OATMAN, was was severely beaten, and had an arm broken by the proprietors of the establishment. The question in dispute between the parties, which led to the quarrel, has not transpired, but OATMAN, on leaving the place immediately procured the arrest of FREDERICK BLACKMAN and AUGUSTUS ABELL, who were taken by officer WATERS to the Second Precinct Station-house. About 8 o'clock in the evening the officers having the prisoners in custody were served with a writ of habeas corpus, signed by City Judge MCCUNN, directing them to produce the bodies of BLACKMAN and ABELL, before him at his office, No. 29 Wall-street, yesterday morning, at 9 o'clock. The complainant not appearing promptly at the time specified, and Judge MCCUNN having duties to attend to in Court, the hearing of the case was postponed to 3 P.M. Meantime an examination of the writ by the complainant's counsel, CHAS. A. SPENCER, had discovered it to be a forgery, and under these circumstances the Assistant District-Attorney, Mr. ANTHON, was requested to be present at the examination. The complainant and the prisoners were promptly in attendance at the hour named, and Ex-Judge STUART appeared for the defence. Mr. WALLACE, of the County Clerk's Office, was asked to examine the writ and immediately pronounced the name of JOHN CLANCY signed thereto, a forgery. He further testified that the County Clerk's name was never signed to writs of habeus corpus except during office hours -- from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. The writ was obtained by a lawyer named JAMES G. GUMBLETON. Judge MCCUNN was charitable enough to suggest that the person, whoever he might be, that signed the County Clerk's name did it through ignorance, supposing that he had a right so to do, as in the case of executions; and Judge STUART even contended that the County Clerk's signature was not necessary. The writ also lacked the attestation of a Judge of the Supreme Court, and on the whole, the counsel for the defence admitted that it was defective in law and therefore null and void. Judge MCCUNN said that he indorsed the writ without particularly examining it, supposing it to be all right, but it was now evident that it was either a forgery or a blunder, and in either case was null and void, and he should therefore dismiss it and remand the prisoners to the custody of the officers. BLACKMAN and ABELL were then removed to the Tombs, where they spent last night, and will have an examination on a charge of assault and battery at the Jefferson Market Police Court this morning. At the request of Mr. ANTHON, Judge MCCUNN agreed to deposit the forged writ in the hands of Mr. VANDERVOORT, Clerk of the Court of Sessions, where it may hereafter form the basis of an indictment against somebody for forgery in the first degree.

abstract: A recruiting office for the Eighth Infantry, United States Army, has been opened at the corner of Sixteenth-street and First-avenue, Capt. WILLIAM McE. DYE in charge.
lead_paragraph: A recruiting office for the Eighth Infantry, United States Army, has been opened at the corner of Sixteenth-street and First-avenue, Capt. WILLIAM McE. DYE in charge. This regiment, the headquarters of which have been removed to Fort Hamilton, will be recruited to its full strength as soon as possible. Col. PITCAIRN MORRISON, late Lieutenant-Colonel of the Seventh Infantry, has been appointed Colonel of the Eighth, via Brevet-Brig.-Gen. JOHN GARLAND deceased.

abstract: The Republican Mayoralty Convention, consisting of five delegates from each Ward of the City, met at the Headquarters, corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for the officer of Mayor of New-York at the ensuing election. GEORGE R. JAQUES, of the Sixteenth Ward, was chosen to preside, and Messrs. H. HEWLETT, of the Fourth Ward, and G. ELLERY, of the Thirteenth Ward, appointed Secretaries. The contestants from the First Ward occupied about one hour of the time of the Convention, but the delegation, headed by HENRY SMITH, was finally admitted, and the other delegates withdrew. Mr. QUIGLY introduced a resolution to appoint a Committee of twenty-two for the purpose of conferring with any organizations opposed to the election of FERNANDO WOOD.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Mayoralty Convention, consisting of five delegates from each Ward of the City, met at the Headquarters, corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for the officer of Mayor of New-York at the ensuing election. abstract: This regiemnt left Augusta in the neighborhood of which town, and of Bangor, it has been chiefly recruited on Wednesday evening, arriving here yesterday morning. That is, four companies our of ten arrived, coming aboard of the steamboat Metropolis, of the Fall River line; the balance were announced to ...
lead_paragraph: This regiemnt left Augusta -- in the neighborhood of which town, and of Bangor, it has been chiefly recruited -- on Wednesday evening, arriving here yesterday morning. That is, four companies our of ten arrived, coming aboard of the steamboat Metropolis, of the Fall River line; the balance were announced to come on afterward by the steamer Male of Name. These four companies were marched from Pier No. 3 vp Broadway to to the Park barracks, have to await the arrival of their comrades. They had been previously dined in Boston, where "covers" were laid for them in Fanneil Hall.

abstract: The Duke of Argyle was entertained at a banquet by his tenantry, in Inverary, on the night of the 25th ult. In responding to the toast of his health, the Duke alluded to the American war. I see, he said, that there has been some fear expressed lately that the inconvenience which is likely to arise in this country from the contest in America is so great that there will be a pressure put upon the Government to interference in that contest, or at least to take some steps which may ultimately involve us in it. I have too high an opinion of the good sense and of the public principle of the people of this country to believe that any such pressure will be put upon the Government; and I must add, that I have too great confidence in the firmness and the public principle of the Government and Parliament of this country, to believe that they will be willing to submit to such pressure, if it were put upon them. It is our absolute duty, I need hardly tell you, to remain entirely neutral in that contest, [applause,] and not only is it our duty to remain neutral, as regards action, but I think it is to a very great extent our duty to abstain even from offering advice, though it might be conceived in a kind and friendly spirit. No good whatever can arise from offering such advice as that, for example, which was lately offered (I have no doubt with the best intentions) by the Emperor of Russia to the contending parties in America. The answer which the Americans will infallibly give to any such interference, will, however civilly expressed, virtually amount to this: "We are very much obliged to you for your kind advice; we have no doubt that it is conceived in the best spirit and with the bust intentions; but there is a general rule in this world that every man should attend to his own affair; and there is this additional reason for doing so in the present case, that it is quite evident that you don't understand ours." That is the answer which virtually the American they unworthy, or at least [???] and unimportant, Now, even we may think of that [???] in [???] to our American [???] we ought to [???].that no more tremendous issues were ever submitted to the dread arbitrament of war than those which are now submitted to it upon the American Continent. I do not cure whether we look at it from the Northern or from the Southern point of view. Take the mere question of what is called the right of secession. I know of no Government which has ever existed in the world which could possibly have admitted the right of secession from its own allegiance. There is a curious animal in Lochfyne, which I have sometimes dredged up from the bottom of the sea, and which performs the most extraordinary and unaccountable acts of suicide and self-destruction. It is a peculiar kind of star fish, which, when brought up from the bottom of the water, and when any attempt is made to take hold of it, immediately throws off all its arms -- its very centre breaks up, and nothing remains of one of the most beautiful forms in nature but a thousand wriggling fragments. Such undoubtedly would have been the fate of the American Union, if its Government had admitted what is called the right of secession. Gentlemen, I think we ought to admit, in fairness to the Americans, that there are some things worth fighting for, and that national existence is one of these. [Cheers] And then, gentlemen, if we go to the South -- If we look at the matter from the Southern point of view, difficult as it may be for us to do so -- I must say that I am not surprised at their conduet. If they believe -- as they loudly proclaim that they do believe -- that Slavery is not an evil which is to be tolerated only, and brought to an end as soon as possible, but a divine institution for the benefit of mankind, to be maintained, and, if possible, extended, and which, if it is assailed even in a single outpost, must be defended to the death, then, even though the citadel be not assailed, but only an important outwork -- then it is but natural that the South should rise in its defence, But of course, in this as in all other revolutions, those who take part in them must be judged finally by the moral verdict of mankind upon the justice of the cause which they have risen to assert. But whatever may be' our private sympathies, we, as a nation, must take no part whatever in this contest. Most earnestly do we trust and pray that it may be brought to a speedy end, and yet I confess that there is another wish which I think, in our mind, ought to stand even before this one -- and that is the wish that the end of this war, whenever it does come, be it soon or late, may be such as shall be worth the sacrifice and the cost -- such as shall tend to the civilization of the world, and promote the cause of human freedom. [Loud cheers.]

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday, by Coroner SCHIRMER, at the Seventeenth Precinct Station-house, upon the body of SAMUEL HOFFMAN, who was murdered on Thursday morning by Dr. MOSES LOWENBERG, at their residence, No. 141 First-avenue. The evidence taken substantiated the account which was given of the affair in yesterday's TIMES. Mrs. ELIZABETH HOFFMAN, wife of deceased, was the only person who witnessed the murder. She stated that Dr. LOWENBERG was in the habit of harboring females in his office, and that they often remained there the most of the night; that this was the case on the night previous to the murder. On Thursday morning, about 7 o'clock, witness went out on an errand, and when she returned she closed the front basement door. Dr. LOWENBERG immediately opened it, using great violence in so doing. Witness then remarked to her husband that the draft through the hall was very great; that it made their room -- which was the rear basement -- uncomfortably cold, and that she intended to close the door again. She did so, but the Doctor immediately reopened it with a violent jerk. Deceased then remarked that as the Doctor did this to tantalize them, he would reclose the door himself. He accordingly closed it, immediately after which the Doctor came out of his office in the front basement and stabbed deceased. He died almost immediately afterwards. The post-mortem examination revealed the fact that three stabs had been inflicted in the breast, one of which passed through the pericardium, terminating at the spinal column, and that this wound was the cause of his immediate death. The jury rendered a verdict of "Death by a stab wound at the hands of MOSES LOWENBERG, Nov. 14, 1861, and that said wound was inflicted without provocation."

She did so, but the Doctor immediately reopened it with a violent jerk. Deceased then remarked that as the Doctor did this to tantalize them, he would reclose the door himself. He accordingly closed it, immediately after which the Doctor came out of his office in the front basement and stabbed deceased. He died almost immediately afterwards. The post-mortem examination revealed the fact that three stabs had been inflicted in the breast, one of which passed through the pericardium, terminating at the spinal column, and that this wound was the cause of his immediate death. The jury rendered a verdict of "Death by a stab wound at the hands of MOSES LOWENBERG, Nov. 14, 1861, and that said wound was inflicted without provocation."

abstract: The merchants of this City are moving for the restoration of that clause in the old warehousing law which allows merchandise to remain in bond three years before it was required to be withdrawn, either for consumption or reexportation. The new law, which reduces the time to three months, strikes a fatal blow at the system and at the commercial prosperity of this City. We trust that a people who have contributed so liberally to the support of the Government, and without whose aid it could not have been sustained, will, by an amendment of the odious features of the new law, have some return made them by Government for the benefits it has received. Elsewhere we give a communication from the merchants to Mr. BARNEY, the Collector of this port, and his letter forwarding the same to the Secretary of the Treasury.

abstract: The steamer Champion, from Aspinwall on Nov. [???], arrived at this port yesterday. She brings as prisoners of State Ex-Senators GWIN and BRENT, of California, and CALHOUN BENHAM, Attorney-General of the State under Mr. BUCHANAN. These gentlemen took passage for Panama in the Orizaba, on which, unluckily for them, were Brig.-Gen. SUMNER, with a force of United States soldiers. Before arriving at their destination they were placed under arrest by order of the General, and carried across the Isthmus under guard of the National forces, in spite of the protest of the New-Granadian authorities, who had not military strength at hand sufficient to resist this procedure or to arrest Gen. SUMNER, as they tried to do. The prisoners contrived to destroy some documents which might have furnished valuable evidence against them.

abstract: The arrest of Messrs. GWIN, BENHAM and BRENT, by order of Gen. SUMNER, is one of those incidents which is striking and startling, simply because all the facts of the present anomalous period in the national career are so necessarily. Of the immediate reasons which prompted the action of Gen. SUMNER, we are of course not advised. He doubtless proceeded upon something beyond a general impression as to the culpability of those gentlemen.
lead_paragraph: The arrest of Messrs. GWIN, BENHAM and BRENT, by order of Gen. SUMNER, is one of those incidents which is striking and startling, simply because all the facts of the present anomalous period in the national career are so necessarily. Of the immediate reasons which prompted the action of Gen. SUMNER, we are of course not advised. He doubtless proceeded upon something beyond a general impression as to the culpability of those gentlemen. Yet that impression might well have warranted the step merely as a precautionary measure. The three prisoners were open and declared sympathizers with secession. The Breckinridge interest in California had the three for its nucleus. Dr. GWIN, when in the United States Senate, lent himself to all the plots and plans of the men who have since precipitated the Union into the abyss of revolution; went home to California in order at once to procure his reelection to the Senate, and to secure the State to the Disunionists; and when defeated, returned to Washington to act as advocate, negotiator, go-between, of his Southern friends. His son, it will be remembered, he instantly removed from West Point, when the rebellion broke out, and sent him to join the rebel army. It has been currently stated in California, that all three gentlemen had gone to the Isthmus, not to proceed to the Atlantic coast, but indirectly to the Confederate States, there to join their fortunes with those of the insurrection. The circumstance of none of the three having procured "through tickets" seems to lend color to this theory; though indeed the fact may have suggested the theory. Our correspondent at Aspinwall states a circumstance, which, if verified, certainly creates suspicious it will be difficult for the prisoners -- if they are indeed prisoners, who have the liberty of the city unrestrained -- to thoroughly remove. Gen. SUMNER, with less of the detective than was essential to his new avocation, omitted to seize and search their baggage, when the arrest was made. It is stated that the three gentlemen took advantage of the omission to throw their papers overboard; and that these, with a carpet-bag of Dr. GWIN, were seen scattered in the wake of the ship. When the search was subsequently made, not a document, or letter, or scrap of paper, could be found in the luggage of either. The fact, if it be one, invites explanation.

abstract: The Convention continued its sittings yesterday, GEORGE H. STEWART, Esq., presiding. A series of resolutions were presented for the consideration of the Convention, asserting the duty of Christians, and particularly of the Association, to promote the spiritual and temporal welfare of the soldiers in the army, and of the sailors and marines in the navy, in cooperation with their respective Chaplains. It recommended the appointment of a Christian Commission of twelve members, to serve gratuitously, with power to fill vacancies and appoint secretaries and agents. The progress of reform, and of the organization of prayer-meetings and Christian Associations among soldiers wore the subject of congratulation. The Government is to be memorialized to furnish tents in which to hold religious and reformatory meetings in the army. Messrs. THOMPSON, TOBY, BALLARD, ALVORD, STODART, DESMOND, BALLANTYNE, and others, took part in the discussion. The following persons were appointed members of the Central Commission:

abstract: The United States transport steamer Coalzacoalcos, Commander D.S. BABCOCK, arrived at this port late Thursday night from Port Royal, S.C. which port she left at 2 P.M. on Wednesday. She brings nothing further of importance from the fleet than the advices brought by the Bienville, except that the troops had all landed, and the stores and ordnance were then being rapidly discharged. A number of the transports would be ready to leave soon.

abstract: The history of States and communities affords sometimes strange coincidences, which would almost make one believe in astrology and in the influence of stars upon names. Take, for instance, Port Royal, and you will find that this name has, since its foundation, been coupled with heresies of some kind, as if to show that the word royal is not a protection against the emancipation of the mind and the progress of freedom in the world.

abstract: The Confederates had 20,000 men in the field. Buenos Ayres, it is said, has less, and in a demoralized condition. A battle took place on the 18th of September, between URQUIZA, of the Confederates, and Gen. MITRE, of the Buenos Ayrean forces. It appears to have been a drawn battle, but reports vary. It is reported that MITRE occupies Rosario.

abstract: As the contest with the rebellion proceeds; we begin to see more clearly the mighty difference between a people complete in whatever can give strength -- education; the application to the creation of wealth of the best contrivances of ingenuity, and skill, and patient industry, which well knows that values are always in ratio to cost. The people most addicted to the arts of peace, are, when fully roused, the most terrible in arms, from the skill and cunning they acquire in engines of destruction. A mechanic at the North,quietly constructing a steam-engine -- neither himself nor his work ever seen -- exerts a greater influence over the contest than a Southern regiment, with all its vaunting and bravado. The Port Royal Forts could not have been taken by any force that the North could put into the field, marching it all the way by land. A few ships demolish them, scattering, in a few hours, their defenders, panic-stricken. Our skill multiplies the power of our soldiers a thousand fold; the moment they can be brought into action, the disparity between the combatants is at once seen to be almost infinite.

abstract: Doubt has been expressed in several quarters as to the right of the National Government to raise the blockade at Beaufort, while maintaining it elsewhere. The impression is conveyed that the whole cordon is invalidated by the dropping of this single loop; and that European Powers, patient heretofore, will never permit such capricious relaxations. It is sufficient to say in answer, that the proclamation of the blockade closed rebel ports. Any port passing from the possession of the rebels is by the very fact reopened, and trade resumes its flow thither as a matter of course, insomuch that it would require fresh Executive action to close it to shipping, whether foreign or domestic. Collector BARNEY only awaits the appointment of a Collector at Beaufort to grant buy clearance demanded. Such an appointment Secretary CHASE engages to make forthwith.

abstract: The Conference Committee, appointed by the Tammany General Committee to confer with organizations opposed to the election of Mr. WOOD, met yesterday (Friday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock. There was a full attendance, among whom were several Republican Ward politicians. Delegations from the Liquor-dealers and rival German organizations, were invited to occupy seats, but no action was taken towards settling their claims to precedence. A discussion of the merits of the different candidates took place, and the names of GODFREY GUNTHER, HIRAM WALBRIDGE, ELIJAH F. PURDY, and others were mentioned, Mr. GUNTHER evidently being uppermost in the minds of delegates. Mr. PURDY was appointed to confer with the Liquor-dealers Associations, and the Convention adjourned to meet at the call of the Executive Committee.

abstract: John H. Foot vs. The Noryh Western Insurance Company. -- A verdict was recovered in February, against the defendants, upon a renewal policy, to which they interposed the defence that they did not receive or indorse on the new policy, notice of other insurances on the property at the time of the renewal. The original policy, however, contained a note of the other insurances, and there was testimony that the Company was again notified, and requested to indorse the other insurances on the renewal policy when they issued it, and took the premium, but it was not done. The Clerk entered judgment upon the verdict, it appears that a judgment had been recovered in December, 1857, against the Company on this policy, which was opened so far as to let the Company come in and defend, upon giving a bond with surities, and permitting the judgment and execution to stand to secure the plaintiff. The plaintiff moved to set aside the second judgment, as irregular and a nullity, and claims that his remedy was upon the original judgment, from which it was new too late for the Company to appeal. The Court sustained the second judgment, in so far that the Company might appeal from it. No case having been filed, the General Term dismissed the appeal in September and declared it abandoned. The defendants moved at Special Term for relief; a question was raised as to the jurisdiction of the Special Term to modify the order of the General Term, which was to-day heard by the General Term, who held that it was within the jurisdiction of the Special Term to hear and determine the application.

The original policy, however, contained a note of the other insurances, and there was testimony that the Company was again notified, and requested to indorse the other insurances on the renewal policy when they issued it, and took the premium, but it was not done. The Clerk entered judgment upon the verdict, it appears that a judgment had been recovered in December, 1857, against the Company on this policy, which was opened so far as to let the Company come in and defend, upon giving a bond with surities, and permitting the judgment and execution to stand to secure the plaintiff. The plaintiff moved to set aside the second judgment, as irregular and a nullity, and claims that his remedy was upon the original judgment, from which it was new too late for the Company to appeal. The Court sustained the second judgment, in so far that the Company might appeal from it. No case having been filed, the General Term dismissed the appeal in September and declared it abandoned. The defendants moved at Special Term for relief; a question was raised as to the jurisdiction of the Special Term to modify the order of the General Term, which was to-day heard by the General Term, who held that it was within the jurisdiction of the Special Term to hear and determine the application.

abstract: Of the intention of the English Government to permit no pressure for cotton, however urgent, to prompt interference with the blockade of the Southern ports, there is no room for rational doubt. Not only does the semi-official Press seize every occasion to convey this impression, but conspicuous parliamentary supporters of the Ministry go down to their constituents, apparently with no other object than to make the statement, and Cabinet Ministers repeat it, wherever they can obtain an audience. Earl RUSSELL, Earl DE GRAY, theDuke of ARGYLE, Mr. GLADSTONE, have all said so, and that in the part of England where distress is likely to be the severest, and the unpopularity of such rigid regard to international faith the most probable. Notwithstanding the pinch is already felt in Lancashire, and half-time has become the rule in almost every factory town, it appears now to be the conviction that the storm must be weathered, without swelling it with the possibilities of war.

abstract: We took this fort, mounting twenty-one guns, after a four-hours' fight. It was nobly done. The Wabash, which led, was carried along the shore by the soundings as close as possible. The soundings were given regularly, as upon an ordinary occasion; signals were made continually without a single mistake, while the rain of fire from this ship (the Wabash) fell upon the fort with all the cold precision of target practice.

abstract: David Ogden vs. Samuel A. Rollo. This was an action to make the defendant liable for a loss suffered by the plaintiff in consequence of the insolvency of an insurance company, of which the defendant was a trustee, the complaint alleging that it was by reason of certain wrongful acts committed or allowed by the defendant, that the corporation became insolvent and irresponsible.
lead_paragraph: David Ogden vs. Samuel A. Rollo. -- This was an action to make the defendant liable for a loss suffered by the plaintiff in consequence of the insolvency of an insurance company, of which the defendant was a trustee, the complaint alleging that it was by reason of certain wrongful acts committed or allowed by the defendant, that the corporation became insolvent and irresponsible. The complaint did not allege that the plaintiff was a creditor of the corporation at the time the wrongful acts complained of were committed, but that he became a creditor subsequently thereto.

abstract: The new ocean steamship constitution, which has just been completed for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and intended for the passenger traffic between Panama and San Francisco, leaves to-day at noon, for Boston, from her anchorage opposite Canal-street. She has been chartered by Gen. BUTLER to convey a portion of his Division from Boston to some, as yet, unknown point on the Southern Coast. Her great capacity and, at the same time, her moderate draft of water when loaded, render her one of the most desirable steamers afloat for transport service. She will probably accommodate comfortably more passengers than any ship of equal tonnage which has ever been constructed in this country. By the use of her Sewell's condenser -- a patent arrangement -- over 30,000 gallons of fresh water daily can be made from salt water while lying in port. Besides her wheel condenser, site has a Normanby apparatus of large condensing capacity. Her tanks hold over 20,000 gallons. The ship is 350 feet in length, over all, 45 feet breadth of beam, not including paddle-boxes; 32 feet depth of hold and 40 feet deep from upper deck. Her engines were put in at the Novelty Works, under the supervision of Mr. EVERETT, and is a master-piece of work. The walking-beam weighs 30 tons. The cylinder is 105 inches in diameter, and stroke of piston 12 feet. Diameter of air-pump 4 feet 10 inches. Stroke, 6 feet. Diameter of circulating pump 4 feet 2 inches, stroke 4 feet 9 inches. She has 4 main boilers of 32 feet length and 13 feet 3 inches in diameter. There are also 4 single return boilers of 40 inches diameter, and one auxiliary boiler to drive the donkey-engine, giving her very great boiler capacity. The diameter of shaft is 23 inches, and diameter of paddle-wheels 40 feet out-side of buckets. She is in command of Capt. FLETCHER, one of the most experienced and popular of commanders, her engineer being Mr. VANDERBILT, long and favorably known in ocean steamship service. During the trial trip on Thursday the machinery worked with the greatest case, and gave entire satisfaction. She attained 14 revolutions with 20 pounds of steam. The Constitution was built by WM. H. WEBB. from models and plans by Capt. SKIDDY, who superintended her construction from the laying of the keel to her launching, assisted by Capt. ALLEN MCLANE.

By the use of her Sewell's condenser -- a patent arrangement -- over 30,000 gallons of fresh water daily can be made from salt water while lying in port. Besides her wheel condenser, site has a Normanby apparatus of large condensing capacity. Her tanks hold over 20,000 gallons. The ship is 350 feet in length, over all, 45 feet breadth of beam, not including paddle-boxes; 32 feet depth of hold and 40 feet deep from upper deck. Her engines were put in at the Novelty Works, under the supervision of Mr. EVERETT, and is a master-piece of work. The walking-beam weighs 30 tons. The cylinder is 105 inches in diameter, and stroke of piston 12 feet. Diameter of air-pump 4 feet 10 inches. Stroke, 6 feet. Diameter of circulating pump 4 feet 2 inches, stroke 4 feet 9 inches. She has 4 main boilers of 32 feet length and 13 feet 3 inches in diameter. There are also 4 single return boilers of 40 inches diameter, and one auxiliary boiler to drive the donkey-engine, giving her very great boiler capacity. The diameter of shaft is 23 inches, and diameter of paddle-wheels 40 feet out-side of buckets. She is in command of Capt. FLETCHER, one of the most experienced and popular of commanders, her engineer being Mr. VANDERBILT, long and favorably known in ocean steamship service. During the trial trip on Thursday the machinery worked with the greatest case, and gave entire satisfaction. She attained 14 revolutions with 20 pounds of steam. The Constitution was built by WM. H. WEBB. from models and plans by Capt. SKIDDY, who superintended her construction from the laying of the keel to her launching, assisted by Capt. ALLEN MCLANE.

abstract: In ordinary times, it would be perfectly disgraceful for the United States, a nation which not only boasts overmuch of its excellence in all things, but which really excels in many things, to be as poorly represented at London next year as it was in 1851. But now, our people are excusing themselves from an adequate attempt in this direction on the basis of the war. We think this is all wrong, for two most excellent reasons.

abstract: We have a military foothold now in half of the States over which DAVIS claims to be sovereign ruler, and are likely very soon to have a foothold in three or four more, if not the whole of them. Of Virginia, we have full command of that third which lies west of the mountains, not to speak of the region opposite Washington and the possession of Fortress Monroe. In North Carolina we hold Hatteras; in South Carolina Port Royal; in Florida, the Tortugas and Fort Pickens, in Mississippi, Ship and other islands. In all these States the flag of the union flaunts defiance in the face of traitors. Beside these, we are likely ere long to get hold of Brunswick, in Georgia. By the capture of Pensacola a large part of Alabama will be at our mercy. The Balize, in Louisiana, is open to us. We can occupy Galveston Island, in Texas, at our convenience. On the Northern line, Gen. NELSON, the victor of Piketon, is hovering on the verge of Tennessee, and the rebels of Cumberland Gap are likely to find themselves [???] one of these [???] mornings when they wake up. The National army is within a stone's throw of Arkansas, and our Western lads are roused from their slumbers to the music of its alligators. This completes the circle of the so-called sovereign Confederate States. On the other hand, not a single rebel soldier has yet set foot on the sacred soil of any one of the Free States of the Union.

abstract: Business at the Brooklyn Navy-yard was extremely brisk yesterday. Orders were received from Washington to send several storeships, with stores and provisions, to Beaufort. A quantity of lumber will also be sent there, as mentioned yesterday in our Washington dispatches. The storeship Supply, which had filed up with stores and was on the eve of departure for Pensacola, has been ordered to Beaufort. She at once hauled out to the buoy, and will sail today.
lead_paragraph: Business at the Brooklyn Navy-yard was extremely brisk yesterday. Orders were received from Washington to send several storeships, with stores and provisions, to Beaufort. A quantity of lumber will also be sent there, as mentioned yesterday in our Washington dispatches. The storeship Supply, which had filed up with stores and was on the eve of departure for Pensacola, has been ordered to Beaufort. She at once hauled out to the buoy, and will sail today. The storeship Relief took the berth vacated by the Supply, and will probably fill up with stores and lumber. The steamer De Soto left the Navy-yard and anchored off the Battery, and the Bienville hauled into her berth to take in stores and undergo some necessary repairs. The carpenters are already plugging up the shot-holes she received in the Port Royal engagement. The Nightingale transferred her crew to the receiving-ship North Carolina, and went down to the Atlantic Dock to discharge her cargo. The steamer Crusader has been completely overhauled, and will shortly be ready for commission. New boilers have been put in her, and she has also been recoppered. She was yesterday floated out of the dry dock, to make room for the Sumter, which requires similar repairs.

abstract: Mr. CHARLES H. SEAMAN, long and favorably known as one of our most efficient Hell Gate Pilots, died on Friday at his residence in this City. abstract: eral of our journals take great exceptions to Gen. SHERMAN'S proclamation to the people of South Carolina, without any reason whatever that we can see. All proclamations of the kind are usually little more than ver-...
lead_paragraph: eral of our journals take great exceptions to Gen. SHERMAN'S proclamation to the people of South Carolina, without any reason whatever that we can see. All proclamations of the kind are usually little more than verbiage, having about as much effect and significance as those issued by the redoubtable WOUTER VON TWILLER in the veritable and early history of Manhattan. A speech is the part of the ceremony of every General in assuming command. That of Gen. SHERMAN clearly copies the position of Government, which probably does not intend to arm the slave or disturb the domestic relations of the South, unless such arming and interference becomes necessary to put down the rebellion. That such arming will be resorted to is clearly inferrible from the General's speech. In fact, he affirms this in language as clear as an officer in his position ought to use. His proclamation could hardly be couched in terms more offensive to South Carolina. Instead of being unmeaning to her, it will incite her rage and animosity to the utmost, and very speedily bring about that state of things in which the extra muskets Mr. CAMERON tells us he put aboard the fleet will be speedily used. The language of the chief of the War Department, who controls not only the speeches but the action of Gen. SHERMAN, has no ambiguity whatever. We presume the General's conduct will only reflect that of the Secretary. We see no discrepancy between them. It might have been well for Gen. SHERMAN to have made no proclamation whatever. But such is the custom. If he made one, it is certainly the better way to deal in platitudes, and act his intentions, instead of bragging about them. Successful men seldom tell us what they are going to do. They first see whether success is possible. To go quietly at work arming a few regiments of slaves, will strike the rebels with tenfold more terror than threats of this purpose. This is unquestionably Gen. SHERMAN's plan. He is not only in harmony with the Administration, but with the sentiments of those who now seem so eager to censure him.

lead_paragraph: The name of Capt. CHARLES WILKES, who so neatly nabbed SLIDELL and MASON, is a name known both in navigation and in science. He was born in this State in 1805, and originally entered the naval service of his country in 1818, at the carly age of 13 years. In 1838, having previously distinguished himself by his scientific ability, he received from the American Government the command of a naval expedition intended to explore the countries bordering on the Pacific and Southern Oceans. His command consisted of two sloops-of-war, a brig and two tenders, and he himself had the grade of Captain. Leaving here shortly after his appointment, he doubled Cape Horn, crossed over to Polynesia, Van Dieman's Land and Australia, advancing as high as the 61st degree of south latitude; he then visited the Feejee Islands and Borneo, and returned to New-York in 1842, after having visited Singapore and the Cape of Good Hope. This memorable expedition of four years was fertile in useful observations, which Capt. WILKES recounted in a very able work in five octavo volumes, entitled A Narrative of the United States Exploring Expedition. In 1848 the Geographical Society of London presented him with a gold medal, as a token of their appreciation of his labors. He has also, since then, published a work entitled Western America, which contains valuable statistical details and geographical facts and maps relating to California and Oregon. Commodore WILKES received his present commission in 1855. He has been in the service altogether forty-three years. Ten of these years he has been on sea service; twenty-six engaged on shore or other duty, and seven years unemployed. For some years, latterly, he has been assigned to special duty near Washington. He is now returning from the Coast of Africa with the United States steamer San Jacinto. On his way home he found orders to cruise around the coast of the West Indies to look out for privateers or vessels attempting to run the blockade, which duty he has been performing for the past six weeks. While engaged in this business he fell in with the vessel containing the two rebel Plenipos. The whole country now rings with applause of his bold action.

abstract: lodgment at Beaufort is likely to produce an issue between the pugnacious Governor of Palmettodom and the cautious President of the Confederation. The vengeful feelings of his people, Gov. PICKENS discovers, can only find adequate vent in the tomfoolery of running up of black flags in certain select neighborhoods, indicative of the chivalry at the insult which the Yankees have visited upon their fiery soil. This President DAVIS declines to permit; possibly because the sable emblem in question belongs appropriately to the naval service of the rebellion -- a service the world persists in regarding as piracy. But we are given to understand that the State of South Carolina, standing in this matter upon her reserved rights, will certainty give to the winds the mortal token of "no quarter." Such contumacy it is scarcely probable the Confederate authorities can permit to pass without punishment. If, for this object, the rebel President propose to send troops he can spare with so much difficulty to curb the insubordinates, we beg to suggest he will make use of the National force already in the State, as it has nothing to do at present but to wait for an enemy who "would be wooed and not unsought be won," and for whom the waiting may therefore have to be protracted.

abstract: We do not believe the American heart ever thrilled with more genuine delight than it did yesterday, at the intelligence of the capture of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON, recently of the Senate of the United States, the most prominent and influential actors in the rebellion, and on their way to England and France, to represent the rebels at the Courts of these countries.
lead_paragraph: We do not believe the American heart ever thrilled with more genuine delight than it did yesterday, at the intelligence of the capture of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON, recently of the Senate of the United States, the most prominent and influential actors in the rebellion, and on their way to England and France, to represent the rebels at the Courts of these countries. The capture of Beaufort may have created a deeper and more lasting impression, from a consciousness of the important results accomplished, but really no satisfaction is equal to that experienced when base and treacherous knaves meet their deserts. If we were to search the whole of Rebeldom, no persons so justly obnoxious to the North, could have been found as those just caught. DAVIS himself has some redeeming qualities; MASON and SLIDELL, none. The former is arrogant imperious and ignorant, treating, when in the Senate, his associates with unmeasured scorn, contempt, and constantly heaping contumely upon the free labor and social system of the North. In personal bearing, he was an Eastern satrap, by some curious anomaly transferred into the Senate of a Republic. A thorough enemy of the Union, he used his position simply for its destruction. SLIDELL is a far abler man, and would be a much more dangerous one, did not a reputation for almost every species of dishonesty greatly weaken his influence. His sobriquet, even at home, among his own constituents, is Baron Plaquemine, from the origination by him of the notorious frauds in that parish which, in 1844, gave the vote of the State to Mr. POLK instead of Mr. CLAY. For almost the entire Administration of Mr. BUCHANAN he was one of its ruling spirits, and the bosom friend of the President, and, more than any other man, the promoter of the rebellion. The two rogues fell out, however, near the close of Mr. BUCHANAN's term. Mr. SLIDELL was as implacable as Mr. BUCHANAN, and a very fierce quarrel grew up between them. He was of the clique of those infamous characters which so long controlled the Government of this country, and whose ruin he sought by associating with it his own infamy, as the snake covers his victim with his own nauseous slime as the necessary condition of swallowing it. Both are sworn enemies of order and law -- of constitutional Government -- of free labor -- of human progress. They belong to an age in which the basest of passions and motives bore sway. For seeking to restore such an age they fled their country, and are now happily the prisoners of the very Government they sought to overthrow.

abstract: -- The Independance Belge has revelations, not only as regards the intentions of France and England to recognize the Southern Confederacy, but relative to the position the Government of the United States has assumed towards the Mexican expedition. According to that journal, the Washington Cabinet has not only declined to take part in the measure, but has protested formally against it, and intimates that nothing but the urgent preoccupation of domestic questions prevents an immediate alliance, offensive and defensive, with Mexico. The story, if not true, is well invented. It is just such an answer as the proposition should have received, for it places in a clear light the cowardly advantage those Powers are taking of our internal difficulties, and leaves it to be so distinctly inferred that upon the settlement of this family quarrel, the case of Mexico will be attended to.
lead_paragraph: -- The Independance Belge has revelations, not only as regards the intentions of France and England to recognize the Southern Confederacy, but relative to the position the Government of the United States has assumed towards the Mexican expedition. abstract: No nation ever yet had any just idea of its idiosyncracies. Few persons in any nation arrive at a rational comprehension of the peculiarities of foreigners.
lead_paragraph: No nation ever yet had any just idea of its idiosyncracies. Few persons in any nation arrive at a rational comprehension of the peculiarities of foreigners. The closer the relationship between the peoples of two countries, the more apparent is that ignorance of each other, which, thinking it knows all, learns nothing. Never was this more clearly demonstrated than in the case of England and the United States. Of a common origin and tongue, separated by scarce a century of independent organization, almost identical in variety of race, and of social, political and religious aspiration, students in the same schools of philosophy and literature; exchanging residence, correspondence, news; eternally shaking hands across the ocean; saluting, mingling, amalgamating; yet still seemingly as utter strangers at least so far as English insight into our real nature and disposition is concerned -- as if no more intimate bonds of community existed between them than between the Esquimaux and Chinese. The mischief of the matter is, that coming as it were of the same household, they imagine they have an intuitive perception of our character and genius, and that they are the legitimate exponents to the people of other countries of what about us and our institutions stands in need of elucidation.

abstract: The accounts given in the Canadian papers regarding the loss of the North Briton, are exceedingly meagre. The following is the substance of the details given: From the time that the vessel left Quebec until she ran ashore, the weather was extremely rough, strong easterly gales prevailing.
lead_paragraph: The accounts given in the Canadian papers regarding the loss of the North Briton, are exceedingly meagre. The following is the substance of the details given: From the time that the vessel left Quebec until she ran ashore, the weather was extremely rough, strong easterly gales prevailing. When the ship grounded it was pitch dark, with a strong wind blowing; and she labored so that fears were entertained that she would go to pieces every minute. The boats were got out as soon as possible, and this is all that is said concerning the wreck. Sixteen of the officers and crew were in two boats, which went adrift shortly after the North Briton struck. Both boats were knocked about in a fearful sea for two days, when one of them, to which the eight men on board the other had been transferred, was picked up, on the 7th instant, by the J.G. Deshler, a brigantine bound from Liverpool to Cleveland. This was 350 miles below Quebec. The only additional fact concerning the wreck is that the North Briton ran straight on the rocks at Mingan, and is grounded by the bow in twelve feet of water.

abstract: The latest news from England touching the indispensable staple, is extremely contradictory; touching the state of business and the condition of the people in the cotton manufacturing districts, it is decidedly bad.
lead_paragraph: The latest news from England touching the indispensable staple, is extremely contradictory; touching the state of business and the condition of the people in the cotton manufacturing districts, it is decidedly bad. The London Times and the Calcutta Englishman are diametrically opposed to each other as to the probability of an adequate supply of cotton being obtainable from India. The Thunderer asserts that "India, which, properly stimulated, can produce all things, is bestirring herself to supply" England's "necessities in the article of cotton. What has been long certain in theory is now about to be shown in practice -- that with American seed and European supervision, we may obtain any quantity of cotton from India that Manchester will pay for." It would certainly be hazardous to assign limits to India's cotton-growing capacity, had she American seed, European supervision and European capital; but that is not now the question. The question now is, whether India is at present "bestirring herself to supply" England's "necessities in the article of cotton," as the Thunderer maintains. The Englishman, which is published in the metropolis of India, not at ten thousand miles distance from the country of which it speaks, boldly affirms that she is not doing so to the extent supposed and needed. The manifesto issued by Manchester and her Cotton Supply Association, says our Anglo-Indian authority, has inspired little confidence in the cotton-growing districts. The zemindars, planters and ryots, who were almost ruined by American competition, and whose screw and cleaning-houses are now dilapidated, are very unwilling to extend the cultivation of the required crop without receiving a guarantee that a similar disaster shall not again occur, their reluctance to make the venture being enhanced by the fact that 50,000 bales of Cotton are at present rotting in the depots of the Ganges for want of purchasers! Such, in substance, is the statement of the Englishman, and few, we think who really desire to know the truth will hesitate to prefer it to the vague and rhetorical assertion of the British, journal. But how could England have the effrontery to give to the Indian agriculturist a guarantee which she would be constrained to violate the moment our civil war had ended? The Manchester manufacturer would surely not tolerate a discriminative duty on American Cotton in order to secure a remunerative price to the grower of the Oriental article. The Manchester manufacturer would surely not consent to pay an exorbitant price for Indian Cotton, if an article equally good and much cheaper were at hand. Should the adequate extension, then, of the cultivation of the Cotton plant in India depend on the granting of the guarantee alluded to, we may safely conclude that the extended cultivation will not take place; and this, in despite of the reckless and rhetorical assertions of the Times, seems to be the prevalent opinion in England -- for the panic spreads and business becomes more stagnant, and the interests of both capitalists and operatives grow more and more paralyzed. The accounts from the manufacturing districts are, indeed, very disheartening. The short-time and total-suspension movement is now in operation everywhere. Those mill owners who have not closed altogether, have put their hands off with half work. In the Manchester district alone there are nearly 100,000 people already out of employment, while one-fourth more are receiving relief from the Union than at the corresponding period of last year. Winter too approaches with his attendant hardships to aggravate the sufferings of the distressed and destitute. Such is the gloomy intelligence last brought from England. But there is balm in Gilead. As we write there is news on its way to England which will calm her fears and allay her sorrows. The success of our Naval Expedition will enable the American Government to do more toward supplying England's want, and alleviating the sufferings of Eng. land's people, than all the zemindars of India could effect. What neither the arts nor the arms of England or Englishmen could accomplish, we will presently achieve for them. What neither Asia, nor Africa, nor distant Australia could yield to them, we will presently provide them with. Northern troops now garrison Southern fortresses, are now encamped, on Southern soil, have now possession of a Southern port, whither Britons will soon be invited to come for the purchase and shipment of that material which will again make busy the mills of their manufacturers, and gladden, with the prospect of returning work and plenty, the hearts of their toilers. This is the cheering and unlooked-for intelligence which America has sent to England. Its announcement will banish anxiety, apprehension and panic from the minds of her people. Let us hope that it will also bring Englishmen to a sense of their erroneous opinions, and convince them, even at the eleventh hour, that their own true interests, and those of their country, are inseparably bound up with the speedy and complete triumph of the North in the pending war.

abstract: This arch-conspirator is a native of the State of New-York, to which he now returns loaded with eternal infamy. He was born in the year 1793, and as soon as he reached manhood, he went to New-Orleans, to seek his fortune. He arrived there "poor, friendless and alone;" but, as he had received a good education in his native State, he shortly undertook the practice of law in that city. His skill and adroitness soon won for him a high place at the New-Orleans bar. His success as a lawyer was unparalleled even in that city of suddensuccesses; and he was retained on one side or the other, in almost every important lawsuit which arose. After fifteen or twenty years' toll at the bar of New-Orleans, he accumulated a princely fortune and a wide reputation. His first public service appears to have been as United States District Attorney at New-Orleans, to which office he was appointed by Gen. JACKSON. He was frequently sent to the State Legislature of Louisiana, and was afterwards chosen one of the Louisiana delegation to Congress. In the House he was remarked for his tact and skill as a manager, and his shrewdness and coolness in debate. At times, under provocation, he would become excited, and the words would flow from his lips in a torrent; but this rarely happened. His temper was generally thoroughly under command.

abstract: The D'Epineuil Zouaves, who have been encamped for some time past at Camp Leslie, Staten Island, left yesterday for Annapolis, at which place it will be attached to Gen. BURNSIDE's Brigade. The D'Epineuil Zouaves is organized on the French plan, and will consist, when completed, of two battalions, numbering 1,732 men. It was the first battalion that left yesterday; the other, for which there are already four hundred men enrolled, will leave as soon as the full complement is obtained.

abstract: JAMES MURRAY MASON is a native of Virginia, and springs from one of the very first of its families. He was born in 1797, in what was at that time a part of Fairfax County, on Anadostan Island, which is encircled by the Potomac River, just above the present metropolis of the Union. His first ancestor in Virginia was GEORGE MASON, who was a member of the English Parliament in the reign of CHARLES I. He was a strong upholder of the King, and resisted the measures adopted against him by the Parliament. Subsequently he became an officer in the army of CHARLES II., and commanded a regiment of cavalry in the campaign against the "Roundhead" troops of OLIVER CROMWELL. After the defeat of the royal forces at Worcester, in 1651, he made his escape disguised as a peasant, and, embarking for America, landed at Norfolk. Soon afterward he established a plantation in Westmoreland County, on the Potomac, on which river he and his lineal descendants have lived for more than two hundred years.

After the defeat of the royal forces at Worcester, in 1651, he made his escape disguised as a peasant, and, embarking for America, landed at Norfolk. abstract: -- Beaufort now in our hands, and a portion of the Territory of the United States, is a port of entry. The Collector turned rebel, and the office is consequently vacant. A new one is to he appointed. There will be a plenty of candidates, but we can name one in whom qualities and desert are both combined -- JOHN N. MERIMAN, formerly, and still, legally Collector of Georgetown, South Carolina. He remained faithful to the last, and for the discharge of his duties after the rebellion broke out, was cast into a loathsome prison at Georgetown, where we presume he still lies, as we have heard of no steps taken for his release. Here is the man for the office named. Why should not Government release him by main force, if necessary, and compliment in a fitting manner his devotion to the Constitution? What a splendid piece of retributive justice this would be. It would be such a proud testimony, not only to individual loyalty, but to the power and justice of the Government, as to endear it to the hearts of every citizen, and add more to its real strength than a dozen victories. Let us have some successes like this, and there will be no bounds to the gratitude and spirit of our people.

abstract: We publish this morning the gratifying news of the arrest of the rebel Commissioners, Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, who recently succeeded in eluding the vigilance of the blockading fleet, and escaped to Gardenas on board the steamer Theodora. They were captured by a party from on board the United States steam-frigate San Jacinto, Capt.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the gratifying news of the arrest of the rebel Commissioners, Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, who recently succeeded in eluding the vigilance of the blockading fleet, and escaped to Gardenas on board the steamer Theodora. They were captured by a party from on board the United States steam-frigate San Jacinto, Capt. WILKES, recently from the coast of Africa, but which for six weeks past has been cruising among the West India Islands. Capt. WILKES, it appears, received intelligence that the two rebels had embarked on board the English mail-steamer at Bermuda, and determined to capture them. He accordingly overhauled the steamer in the Bermuda Channel, and sent a messenger on board to demand their surrender. This was refused, with the intimation that there was not force enough to take them. Capt. WILKES accordingly sent an additional force, and at the same time put the San Jacinto into a position to enforce his demands, when the surrender was made. The two Commissioners, with their secretaries, were then transferred to the San Jacinto, together with all their papers, and they reached Fortress Monroe on Friday, when it was determined to bring them to New-York. The name of the British steamer from which they were taken is given as the Trent. Another account, received by way of Halifax, states that she was the Fingal which had transferred her cargo of munitions of war to the Nashville, taking in exchange the rebel Commissioners. This statement is disproved, however, by the announcement that the Fingal has arrived at Savannah with the cargo shipped at Greenock.

abstract: A few days ago a dug-out, containing six slaves came from Charleston off to the Susquehanna. They are worth about $1,200 or $1,500 each. Greasy, fat and well posted they are; they said they "heard" that they could get protection on board, and they claimed it. They gave much valuable information about Charleston, and they said that the schooner Evelyn went into Bull's Bay the day after Capt. MARSTON forced us to release her.

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT. -- On Friday morning, a man named JAMES CURLEY, employed in one of the grain stores at the Atlantic Basin, was suffocated under the following circumstances, he was engaged in drawing off grain from an upper to a lower loft, and was sucked through the grain pipe by the immense volume of grain. A fellow-workman succeeded in getting hold of the hands of the unfortunate man and attempted to rescue him, but in vain. When taken out he was quite dead. The deceased was a widower, but leaves a young daughter residing in New-York.

abstract: -- There were 102 deaths in the city last week, classified as follows: Males, 63; females, 39. Diseases: Abscess, angina, apoplexy, asthma, bleeding of the lungs, burns, cancer, casualties, compression of the brain, congestion of the heart, constipation of the bowels, diarrhoea, diplheria, dropsy in the head, [???], typhoid fever, disease of the heart, disease of the liver, measles, old age, smallpox, softening of stomach, suffocation, one each; drowned, premature birth, intemperance, scrofula, 2 each; bronchitis, congestion of brain, croup, dropsy, marasmus, (infantile,) palsy, 3 each; debility, (infantile,) 5; inflammation of the lungs, 7; convulsions, (infantile,) 11; scarlet fever, 12; consumption, 18. Forty-nine of those who died were 5 years old and under.

abstract: One of the most significant movements of the United States troops, is that planned by MajorGen. DIX, and directed toward the occupation of Accomac and Northampton Counties, Va. Particulars of which were given exclusively given in yesterday's TIMES.
lead_paragraph: One of the most significant movements of the United States troops, is that planned by MajorGen. DIX, and directed toward the occupation of Accomac and Northampton Counties, Va. Particulars of which were given exclusively given in yesterday's TIMES. These counties form what is known as the Eastern Shore of Virginia, and are in what was formerly WISE's Congressional District. The inhabitants, as a mass, have refrained from active participation in the rebellion, though very many young men have entered the Confederate army. Accomae is understood to be prepared to array herself for the Union, but Northampton is hostile.

abstract: There has been no change in recruiting since our last report, but the recruiting parties are anticipating a revival of business as soon as the cold weather sets in. In ordinary times this anticipation might be fulfilled, even to the extent of causing the suspension of recruiting altogether, on account of more men being enlisted than the service required, but at present there are so many offices open for general service, and for different regular regiments, as well as for the volunteers, that a moderate influx of recruits would make very little difference in the returns from any one office. It is reported that recruiting for general service will be suspended, and that each regiment will be left to provide its own recruits, instead of drawing them from a general depot like Governor's Island. The establishment of recruiting offices for the First, Third and Eighth Regiments of Infantry has doubtless given rise to this report.

abstract: The steamship City of Manchester passed Cape Race on Saturday evening, with advices from Europe four days later than were received by the Niagara. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Queenstown on the 7th inst. The Liverpool Cotton Market is reported dull, with an advanced tendency in prices, although no change had taken place of consequence. This condition of the Cotton market had a corresponding effect on trade prices in Manchester. The market for Breadstuffs was generally quiet and steady, except for Wheat, which had an upward tendency. Provisions continued dull.

abstract: Dispatches received from Cincinnati discredit the first report of the conflict at Piketon, Ky., and represent the affair as one of much smaller proportions. There were not a thousand rebel prisoners, and not four hundred killed; nor were Gens. WILLIAMS and HOWES captured.
lead_paragraph: Dispatches received from Cincinnati discredit the first report of the conflict at Piketon, Ky., and represent the affair as one of much smaller proportions. There were not a thousand rebel prisoners, and not four hundred killed; nor were Gens. WILLIAMS and HOWES captured. The entire force of the enemy only amounted to a thousand, while his losses were about fifty. The great body of the insurgents broke and dispersed. This is the latest story, and may therefore stand until we get a better; but we should not be at all surprised to learn that the first bulletin coming, as it purported to do, from Gen. NELSON, was the true one; and this latter the device of rebel sympathizers to mitigate the moral effect of the defeat.

abstract: The Convention for the Fourth District, representing the above party, met Saturday evening at No. 561 Broome-street, and organized by the appointment of W.B. HATCH, President, and W.C. HURD, Secretary. On motion, a Conference Committee of One from each Ward was appointed to confer with other organizations for the selection of candidates for the Councilmanic District. It being suggested that the Tammany Party would not join in such conference, Mr. HURD made a proposition that, in such case, the People's Union should join with the Mozart Republican, Hotel-proprietors' Union Club, and the National Union Committee, which would be amply sufficient to carry the District. The proposition was assented to. The Convention then adjourned, to meet at the same place on Friday evening, the 22d inst.

abstract: The People's Union Nominating Convention met Saturday night, pursuant to a call from its Chairman, WM. TUCKER, and Messrs. WILLIAM C. CONNER and ROBERT BEATTY, Secretaries. In the absence of the regular Chairman, CHARLES FOX, Esq., of the Seventh Ward, was called to the Chair. After canvassing the mayoralty question, the roll of the wards was called for nominations. Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE was the only candidate named, whereupon he was declared to be the nominee of the Convention by acclamation. Messrs. Charles Fox, Elbert Robinson, A.M. Bininger, A.W. Canfield, Frederick C. Wagner, James W. Booth and Robert Beatty were appointed a Committee to tender the nomination to Mr. OPDYKE.

abstract: The battle of Port Royal will be remembered as one of the best fought and best conducted battles which have signalized the war in which we are engaged. If Gen. RIPLEY had been appointed a General in command two months sooner everything would have been in a better state of preparation. But these two previous months were wasted in doing nothing for our defence. Within the time left for him, Gen. RIPLEY did all that untiring energy and skill could accomplish, to put our coast in a state of preparation. The two islands of Hilton Head and Bay Point, with their extreme limits, constitute the two points which guard the entrance to Port Royal Sound, about three miles in width. On these two points forts were erected -- Fort Walker on Hilton Head, and Fort Beauregard on Bay Point. The time we possessed, enabled us to make them only earthworks, without any protection from shells or bombs.

abstract: Gen. Dix sends five thousand men to take possession of Accomao and Northampton Counties, in Virginia, on the eastern side of Chesapeake Bay. We published yesterday and reprint todaythe proclamation which Gen. DIX has ordered to be issued to the inhabitants. It assures them against any interference with their private property and personal rights, and gives the most explicit assurances against any attempt to interfere with their slaves. It is evident that Gen. Dix is not acting under instructions from Col. JOHN COCHRANE, of the Seventeenth Ward.

abstract: his eyes on the most magnificent carriage that has ever been built in this country, by stopping as we did, at the carriage repository No. 620 Broadway. abstract: A misapprehension of some importance exists, we fear, in the public mind as to the effect of our having taken Port Royal harbor upon commerce with the South. It seems to be assumed that this commerce is at once to be resumed through that port,--that English and French vessels may proceed thither for cotton, and that an active trade will instantly spring up with all the world for the supply of Southern wants.
lead_paragraph: A misapprehension of some importance exists, we fear, in the public mind as to the effect of our having taken Port Royal harbor upon commerce with the South. It seems to be assumed that this commerce is at once to be resumed through that port, -- that English and French vessels may proceed thither for cotton, and that an active trade will instantly spring up with all the world for the supply of Southern wants. This impression is probably due partly to a misquotation of the terms in which the blockade was proclaimed by the President. It has been said that inasmuch as it is only a blockade of "rebel ports," the blockade ceases the moment the ports are held by the National forces. The language used is much more explicit than this. The Proclamation declares that --

abstract: We have reliable information that, when the news of the capture of Port Royal reached the Confederate camp at Manassas, three South Carolina regiments demanded permission, and declared their intention to return at once to the protection of their own State. Orders were issued from headquarters to prevent their departure at all hazards. The doctrine of State sovereignty and of the right of secession does not seem to find as much favor with the Confederate authorities as it did at the outset of the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: We have reliable information that, when the news of the capture of Port Royal reached the Confederate camp at Manassas, three South Carolina regiments demanded permission, and declared their intention to return at once to the protection of their own State. abstract: From Lieut. C. H. COLBURN, of the Eleventh Massachusetts Regiment, Company H, attached to Gen. HOOKER's Brigade, on the Maryland shore of the Potomac, and who arrived in this city this evening, I have the following interesting particulars of a rebel attack upon the schooner Maryland. The schooner was loaded with wood, and yesterday, while passing the rebel battery off Pig Point, and directly off the encampment of the Massachusetts Eleventh, became becalmed.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Friday, Nov. 15, 1861.
