abstract: We published yesterday morning the announcement of the capture of the rebel Commissioners, Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, who recently succeeded in eluding the vigilance of the blockading fleet, and escaped to Cardenas on board the steamer Theodora.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday morning the announcement of the capture of the rebel Commissioners, Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, who recently succeeded in eluding the vigilance of the blockading fleet, and escaped to Cardenas on board the steamer Theodora. They were captured by a party from on board the United States steam-frigate San Jacinto, Capt. WILKES, recently from the coast of Africa, but which, for six weeks past has been cruising among the West India Islands. Capt. WILKES, it appears, while coaling at Havana, learned that the rebel Commissioners were to leave on the 7th, on board the English mail steamer Trent, and determined to capture them. He accordingly overhauled the steamer in the Bahama Channel, and sent a messenger on board to demand their surrender. After some demur on their part, the Commissioners, with their Secretaries, were transferred to the San Jacinto, together with their papers, which are understood to be very voluminous. Capt. WILKES offered also to take on board the ladies and children accompanying the party, but they preferred to proceed to England on board the Trent. The San Jacinto then proceeded to Fortress Monroe, whence it was determined, after consultation between Capt. WILKES and Gen. WOOL, to bring the distinguished prisoners to New-York, while dispatches announcing the capture were forwarded to Washington. An account of the arrest, received in Halifax by the English mail steamer from Bermuda, stated that the steamer on board which the arrest was made was the Fingal, which had transferred her cargo of munitions of war to the Nashville, taking in exchange the rebel Commissioners. This statement is disproved, however, by the announcement that the Fingal has arrived at Savannah with the cargo shipped at Greenock.

abstract: The capture of MASON and SLIDELL comes in good time to remind our amiable friends of the Charleston Mercury that the less they say about hanging prisoners, giving no quarter &c., the better. They are undoubtedly very much excited and even unusually wrathy, -- for which we do not blame them. But there is no special necessity just now for their drawing lots to see whom of our prisoners they shall first hang, nor was it worth while for them to terrify the President and his Cabinet, as well as creation at large, by fulminating their fearful threats about extermination. Hanging prisoners, as well as giving no quarter, is a game which two can play at, -- and which no one can be permitted to play alone. We happen to have in our hands, moreover, quite a number of hostages of considerable value when questions of exchange or retaliation come up for decision. Possibly the Southern Confederacy may think SLIDELL as great a loss to them as the gallant CORCORAN would be to us; -- and if they should insist on hanging Mr. ELY, who is a member of Congress, we can offset him with MASON, who is not only a Senator but an Ambassador to boot.

abstract: Although there are some who suppose the Confederates will retire, as they are pushed, until they take up a position behind Manassas, and that they will not fight better than they did in the action of the 21st of July, there is no sound reason for believing that they will not risk another battle, or that they will not contest it with at least as much spirit.

abstract: We think that Mr. LINCOLN and Mr. SEWARD are providing against a danger which can hardly be said to exist, and that in doing so they are wasting upon useless objects at once men, money, and materiel, which it should be their aim to concentrate upon their real and immediate enemies.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon, Superintendent KENNEDY, in accordance with instructions received from the Secretary of State, rearrested Ex-Senator GWIN, J. CALHOUN BENHAM and J.L. BRENT, the trio who had been arrested by Gen. SUMNER. Dr. GYNI's arrest was effected at the New-York Hotel during the after noon, and that of the other two in the evening. They were all taken to Fort Lafayette, to await the arrival of traitors MASON and SLIDELL by the San Jacinto, when the whole party will be conveyed to Fort Warren, Boston Bay.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, Superintendent KENNEDY, in accordance with instructions received from the Secretary of State, rearrested Ex-Senator GWIN, J. CALHOUN BENHAM and J.L. abstract: Mr. Secretary CHASE, when in this City the past week, was waited upon at his quarters at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, by a large body of Government contractors, for the purpose of making arrangements for payments, which were somewhat in arrears, of their claims. As the Department has now ample means, from the negotiation just completed with the Banks, claims to the amount of $1,500,000 will be immediately paid out in this City, through the Quartermaster, for supplies of one kind or another, furnished to the Army. An equal sum, or $3,000,000 in the aggregate, is to be paid out by the Agent for supplies and ships to the Navy. So large an amount immediately disbursed, cannot fail to give a decided impulse to business, oven in so large a city as New-York. The money will, in a few days, return to the banks in the regular course of business, leaving them nearly as strong as before. It is a somewhat surprising fact that, notwithstanding the Government loans taken by the banks, their ability to accommodate their customers is in no degree impaired. No stringency has been created, while the vast expenditures which have been going on, and the immense amount of money put in circulation, have greatly improved the condition of the commercial and manufacturing interests. The Loan, so far, has been in every point of view a great advantage to the Banks, giving all the paper they wanted at high rates of interest, and greatly strengthening their customers.

abstract: AND EUROPE. -- The submersion of the cable between Africa and France has solved the question as to the great obstacle to be met in this kind of enterprise, and has set the scientific world at work in the research of means to overcome it. This obstacle resides in the weight of the cable, and its want of elasticity. It has been ascertained that at a depth of between two and three thousand yards the wires would break by their own weight. If to this we add the tossing and pulling produced by the motion of the ship on the sea, we must come to the conclusion that a far lesser depth can cause the rupture of the cable, and defeat, in a second, the whole operation.
lead_paragraph: AND EUROPE. -- The submersion of the cable between Africa and France has solved the question as to the great obstacle to be met in this kind of enterprise, and has set the scientific world at work in the research of means to overcome it. abstract: The people of South Carolina commenced their revolutionary proceedings just about twelve months prior to the capture of Beaufort Harbor. The anniversary was celebrated in a way little to their liking. The year of secession was opened amid general rejoicing, and with great confidence real or affected, in the brilliancy of the future that was before them.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: BILLS OF EXCHANGE. -- GEORGE CROMER, who has a number of other names, is now on trial, charged with forgery -- the bill before the jury charging the forgery of a bill of exchange, with intent to swindle Messrs. BOWEN & FOX, brokers, of this city. The case developed the fact that a number of persons throughout the United States had been approachedby letters, with a view to swindle, and the mode adopted by the defendant proved him to be a most accomplished banker, understanding all the details of the business. He would forward to the parties selected, letters embracing the first and second of bills of exchange, and request them to call at their post-offices and secure a letter containing the third of the bills, which would be sent by a party whose name would be given. Sometimes three or four letters, upon the same subject, would be received from persons of a different name, and in different cities, and yet a comparison of the writing of these letters now collected together in Court, experts have sworn that they are written by the same party, that party being the defendant, whose handwriting was established by papers found on his person at the time of his arrest. Many of his letters purported to come from St. Thomas, and were marked "ship" letters, and in order to secure this post-mark the accused would present to the Postmaster a letter, apparently from a foreign country, and professing that he had just learned that it was unlawful to deliver it, except through the mail, deposits it and has it marked "shipletter."

abstract: THE PASSPORT SYSTEM.--Pursuant to orders from Superintendent KENNELY, the police, under Capts. MOUNT and DIXON, took charge on Saturday morning of the two steamers Borussia and City of New York, which were to sail for Europe. About 10 o'clock  Inspectors DILKS and LEONARD repaired to the docks, and took command of the police arrangements. They had charge of the gates, and admitted no one without a passport.
lead_paragraph: THE PASSPORT SYSTEM. -- Pursuant to orders from Superintendent KENNELY, the police, under Capts. MOUNT and DIXON, took charge on Saturday morning of the two steamers Borussia and City of New York, which were to sail for Europe. About 10 o'clock Inspectors DILKS and LEONARD repaired to the docks, and took command of the police arrangements. They had charge of the gates, and admitted no one without a passport. The City of New-York sailed at her appointed hour, but the Borussia was detained three hours later, owing to the fact that about twenty passengers were unprovided with passports. Superintendent KENNEDY telegraphed to Washington, and soon received permission from the State Department for their leaving.

abstract: When Capt. WILKES determined to arrest MASON and SLIDELL on board a British vessel, against the protest of the Captain, he is said to have remarked that he should do it, right or wrong--and that at the worst he could only be cashiered.
lead_paragraph: When Capt. WILKES determined to arrest MASON and SLIDELL on board a British vessel, against the protest of the Captain, he is said to have remarked that he should do it, right or wrong -- and that at the worst he could only be cashiered. This remark would imply that he acted without instructions, and that he was willing to run the risk of whatever personal consequences the act might involve, for the sake of rendering the country a marked and memorable service. He need have no misgivings on the subject. His action was prompt, energetic and patriotic; -- and what is still more to the point, it will be found to have been in strict conformity with the principles of international law, with the practice of all nations in time of war, with the decisions of English courts, the opinions of English authorities, and the declarations and the action of the British Government. If Capt. WILKES erred at all, it was in not seizing the English ship which was found conveying these rebel agents and their dispatches, in flagrant violation of the neutrality enjoined upon her by the English Government, and bringing her in for confiscation as lawful prize. In view, however, of the great service which he has rendered the country, and of the fact that he acted without instructions, we presume that both the Government and the country will overlook this neglect on his part, and will award him the highest possible praise for what he did.

abstract: The theatres were well attended during the past week, and in consequence there were but few changes in the bills. Miss JULTA DALY brought her engagement to a close at the Winter Garden on Saturday evening, having played in the "Female American Cousin" with success during the short period of her stay here. She is a fair impersonator of the purely conventional Yankee "gal," but lacks finish for the other and politer phase of Mr. GAYLOR's creation. The "Octoroon" was, we suspect, the principal attraction. To-night, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS commence an engagement, appearing in three pieces -- the "Fairy Circle," the "Magic Joke," and the "Irish Tiger."

abstract: Since I led you to expect (some months ago,) that the French army would evacuate Rome in the course of the Autumn, the "Italian question" has, I am sorry to say, gone several steps backward. The opinion which I then expressed, was, as you cannot have failed to observe, subsequently confirmed by the universal impression of the principal journals of Europe.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: Tammany Hall nominated, last night, JAMES T. BRADY for Mayor, and he was indorsed by the Germans and one of the multitudinous Union parties of the day.
lead_paragraph: Tammany Hall nominated, last night, JAMES T. BRADY for Mayor, and he was indorsed by the Germans and one of the multitudinous Union parties of the day. GEORGE OPDYKE has beennominated by the Republicans. Thus, we have two strong candidates in the field. We presume that Mayor WOOD will soon be put in nomination, and that thus the campaign will be fairly opened with a triangular contest. There have been one or two other nominations made, but they will amount to nothing, and are scarcely intended to be serious.

abstract: The eternal fitness of things is consulted in the consignment of JAMES M. MASON to a prison in Boston Harbor, with unquestionable Yankees for his keepers. What has always tended to make MASON especially obnoxious to those who suffered his society, has been his exceeding shallow capacity, presumption and affectation of contempt for Northern people and institutions. It was Mr. R.C. WINTHROP, of Boston, who, a few months ago, asked the Virginia Senator when he would visit Boston. The reply was: "Not till I come as an Ambassador." This official visit is now to be paid. How the Envoy will like the palace prepared for his Legation, and the State with which Yankee hospitality will surround him, remains to be seen. He may at least be able to anticipate TOOMBS in the determination to call the roll of his slaves in the shadow of the Bunker Hill Monument; for if the fugitive from his Excellency, the Ambassador's, plantation be not at Boston, it would be hard to say where they are. Whether they will come at his call as readily as of old may be somewhat doubtful.

abstract: FIRE IN AN OIL MANUFACTORY. -- Between 6 and 7 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in the Lubricating Oil Manufactory of C.F. DE FOREST on Eighteenth-street, near Avenue A. The flames spread rapidly, and soon destroyed the adjoining building, and communicated to the lumber-yard of NASH & WHITE. It was nearly two hours before the firemen succeeded in subduing the flames. Mr. DE FOREST estimates his loss at $3,000, upon which there is no insurance. Messrs NASH & WHITE say their loss is at least $5,000, upon which there is an insurance of $3,000 in the Pacific and St. Mark's Insurance Companies. The fire is thought to have been caused by the carelessness of a workman.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN AN OIL MANUFACTORY. -- Between 6 and 7 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in the Lubricating Oil Manufactory of C.F. DE FOREST on Eighteenth-street, near Avenue A. abstract: The San Jacinto, with Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL on board, was telegraphed at 3 P.M., yesterday, when off Squan. Mr. ROBERT MURRAY, United States Marshal, embarked on board the steam-tug Achillis, and intercepted her, and in pursuance of orders received from Washington, she was ordered to Boston; no communication from the shore to be allowed with her, until after the delivery of her prisoners at Port Warren.

abstract: The steamship Norwegian, arrived at Portland last evening, with one day later news from Europe. She left Liverpool on the 7th, and Londonderry on the 8th inst.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Norwegian, arrived at Portland last evening, with one day later news from Europe. She left Liverpool on the 7th, and Londonderry on the 8th inst. The sales of cotton in the Liverpool market during the week has been 60,000 bales, and the market closed buoyant at the prices reported by the Niagara. The sales to speculators were 36,000 bales, and those to exporters 7,000. Breadstuffs were quiet but steady, and provisions drooping. No change had taken place in American securities. Consols were quoted at 93 3/8@93 1/2. The English Government, it is stated, had ordered a large shipment of ball-cartridges to Canada, though a previous order to send out Armstrong guns had been rescinded. The most important intelligence from the Continent, is the announcement that the Emperor of Austria had addressed an autograph letter to the Chancelor of Hungary, directing a suspension of the civil offices.

abstract: THE BATTLE OF PIKETON NOT A HOAX.  A dispatch from Cincinnati states that the rereported battle at Piketon was a hoax. If a hoax, it was one which resulted in the capture of twenty-seven hundred prisoners. The misapprehension arose from the fact of two battles having been fought.

abstract: We have advices from the City of Mexico to the 26th ult., and from Vera Cruz to 1st inst., via Havana, per steamer Cosmopolitan. The Mexican news by this arrival does not appear to be of striking interest. The principal item is the defeat of MARQUEZ, with 3,000 troops, near Pachuca, by the Government forces under Gen. TEPIA.
lead_paragraph: We have advices from the City of Mexico to the 26th ult., and from Vera Cruz to 1st inst., via Havana, per steamer Cosmopolitan. The Mexican news by this arrival does not appear to be of striking interest. The principal item is the defeat of MARQUEZ, with 3,000 troops, near Pachuca, by the Government forces under Gen. TEPIA. The battle was hotly contested, and the slaughter of the reactionary forces is said to have been very great. MARQUEZ, with MEJIA, ZULOAGA and other of his officers fled to the mountains.

abstract: The authorities of the Southern Confederacy have actually set on foot the attempt to force our Government to recognize their right of privateering, by retaliating upon their prisoners of war the treatment which we extend to their privateers. It will be seen that Col. CORCORAN has been "confined in a cell appropriatted to convicted felons," and is to be treated in all respects as such a felon, and as if held for execution like the pirate, SMITH, recently convicted in Philadelphia. Thirteen other officers have also been selected to be confined in cells reserved for persons accused of infamous crimes, as a retaliation for the treatment of men held for trial in this City, on charge of having been engaged in privateering.
lead_paragraph: The authorities of the Southern Confederacy have actually set on foot the attempt to force our Government to recognize their right of privateering, by retaliating upon their prisoners of war the treatment which we extend to their privateers. abstract: Several officers recently appointed from civil life have reported to Col. LOOMIS, on Governor's Island, making the total number of officers on the rolls upwards of forty. abstract: The Governor of this State having, in accordance with a time-honored custom, appointed Thursday, the 28th day of November inst., as a day of public thanksgiving, 1, FERNANDO WOOD, Mayor of the City of New-York, do hereby recommend all good citizens to unite on the day thus set apart, in ascriptions of praise to the source of all good, for His manifold mercies and blessings.

abstract: The notorious prisoner, FELIX SANCHEZ, who for the last three or four years has been confined in the Tombs, attempted, on Sunday afternoon, to take the life of JACOB TRUEHEART, alias MYERA, who acts as one of the tier boys in the City Prison. It will be remembered that SANCHEZ was arrested, between three and four years ago, for the murder of his father-in-law. He was subsequently tried upon the charge, and convicted. The case was appealed, and after much delay a new trial was ordered by the appellate Court, but for some reason the alleged murderer has never been a second time brought to trial. During all this time he has been confined in the Tombs, and the keepers of the prison have hitherto been, enabled to treat him generally with the same degree of lenity which is extended to other prisoners. It seems that Sunday morning, about 10 o'clock. SANCHEZ called to this tier-boy, TRUEHEART, and desired him to bring him a ladder, that he might open the ventilator of his cell. TRUEHEART replied he must wait until Mr. BROWN, the deputy-keeper, returned, as he could not furnish the ladder in his absence. SANCHEZ made some tough reply to this, but nothing further passed between them till about 3 o'clock P.M., when the doors of the cells were unbarred for the prisoners to receive their meals. When SANCHEZ's cell-door was opened, he at once rushed out upon TRUEHEART, making a deadly thrust at his heart with one of the blades of a pair of tailor's, shears, which was sharp pointed, and had a rag wound round the handle, to enable him to hold and wield it with effect. TRUEHEART had the presence of mind to throw the weapon upwards as it approached his breast, but it struck his right arm, and inflicted a serious wound. SANCHEZ then raised the weapon for another blow, and but for the timely interference of the prisoners, JAMES SHEPHERD, TRUEHEART would doubtless have been murdered upon the spot. Deputy Keeper BROWN came to the rescue, and took SANCHEZ in charge. Mr. SUTTON, the Warden, was informed of the affair, and ordered the offender to be placed in a dark cell on the ground floor, where he is now confined.
lead_paragraph: The notorious prisoner, FELIX SANCHEZ, who for the last three or four years has been confined in the Tombs, attempted, on Sunday afternoon, to take the life of JACOB TRUEHEART, alias MYERA, who acts as one of the tier boys in the City Prison. SANCHEZ then raised the weapon for another blow, and but for the timely interference of the prisoners, JAMES SHEPHERD, TRUEHEART would doubtless have been murdered upon the spot. Deputy Keeper BROWN came to the rescue, and took SANCHEZ in charge. Mr. SUTTON, the Warden, was informed of the affair, and ordered the offender to be placed in a dark cell on the ground floor, where he is now confined.

abstract: RECRUITING MEETINGS. -- Rev. H.P. GROZIER will speak at the following places in Suffolk County, in behalf of the Union, on the evening of the days named, Nov. 19, Tuesday, at Mount Etna, Nov. 20, Wednesday, at Wading River, Nov. 21, Thursday, at Bating Hollow; Nov. 25, Monday, at Mattiluck; Nov. 26, Tuesday, at Northville; Nov. 27, Wednesday, at Comac; Nov. 29, Friday, at Synwelt Free Church. During the last thirty days Mr. CROZIER has spoken 22 times, to over 5,000 people, enlisted 150 volunteers, organized 10 sewing leagues with from 30 to 50 members cash, and raised $200 for hospital garments -- all in Suffolk County.

abstract: The Memphis Appeal has the particulars of two destructive fires which occurred there on Thursday, the 31st ult. The first destroyed CHURCHILL & WINSTON's furniture establishment, of which the Appeal says: "The stock of furniture being owned by M.L. DUNCAN, a resident of Cincinnati, it had come under the notice of Mr. JACKSON, the Receiver of the Confederate States, who had caused the account of stock to be taken. At once the suspicion was expressed among the crowd, which rapidly collected, that the owner had caused the place to be set on fire for his own ends. This opinion was strengthened when positive assertions were made that the stock was insured in Cincinnati, and that if it passed into the hands of the Confederate States the owner would lose everything; whereas, if it was burned, he would recover its value from the Cincinnati insurers."

abstract: RE-ARREST OF CHAS. M. JEFFERDS. -- CHAS. M. JEFFERDS, the young man who was tried in June last for the murder of JOHN WALTON and acquitted, was re-arrested on Saturday evening on a bench-warrant issued by the District Attorney. There were two indictments against him -- one for the murder of WALTON and the other for the murder of JOHN W. MATTHEWS, (the former of which only has been tried,) who, it will be recollected, was shot in attempting to arrest the murderer of WALTON. The conduct of young JEFFERDS since his acquittal has been very indiscreet, and, on the supposition of his innocence, very remarkable. His manoeuvres during the Summer would furnish material for a very lengthy and curiously-interesting story, but their publication at the present time would, for obvious reasons, be improper. Suffice it to say that the District Attorney has in his possession evidence which it is thought will insure his conviction on the second indictment beyond peradventure.

abstract: Mr. SAVAGE, U.S. Vice-Consul at Havana, who had been to Key West on business, and who returned to Havana on the 10th inst., reports that 1,500 rebel troops had been discovered by the Union patrol, some twenty miles from the fort, on Santa Rosa Island, The patrol immediately informed the commander of the fleet, who sent a force and shelled them off the island with great loss. It is supposed the object was to get together some 5,000 or more rebels, and by a forced march to Col. WILSON's camp make another night attack upon them. The greatest vigilance is exercised by the commander of the Zouaves.

abstract: "Democracy has been on its trial in America, and has failed," declared the Earl of Shrewsbury, in his speech at a recent gathering in Worcester, England. "Separation," continued the noble lord, "is inevitable; and the establishment of some sort of aristocracy in America is inevitable, also!" It is worth remembering that the nobleman who speaks so oracularly about America is the self-same sagacious gentleman who, some thirty years ago, when the noted quack doctor, ST. JOHN LONG, was tried and convicted for the manslaughter of one of his patients, actually swore, as a witness for the prisoner, that, when afflicted with a chronic headache, he rubbed one of the quack doctor's lotions upon his forehead, and it removed the ailment, by drawing a lump of lead from his (the noble's) cranium! What a lump of lead must have remained behind to have come out in the Saturnine stupidities of his lordship's Worcester oration!

abstract: We present above a minute and faithful map of the eastern shore of Virginia, the destination of an expedition which Major-Gen. DIX has dispatched from his command at Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: We present above a minute and faithful map of the eastern shore of Virginia, the destination of an expedition which Major-Gen. DIX has dispatched from his command at Baltimore. The counties of Accomac and Northampton occupy the lower extremity of the peninsula, of which Delaware is the base, the Atlantic and Chesapeake Bay washing the two sides. The seaboard exhibits the common characteristics of the Atlantic coast, in its numerous islands of sand, with inlets and interior sounds; the principal of these being Chincotague Island, inlet, and sound, famous for oysters, the favorites of epicures. It is from the Atlantic side of Accomac and Northampton that the Northern supplies of the bivalves are chiefly drawn. The Chesapeake shore is closely indented with bays and inlets, often the estuaries of small inland streams. From Cape Charles, the Southern extremity, to Cape Henry, the opposite gate-post of the Chesapeake waters, the distance is about fifteen miles. To Old Point Comfort it is nearly thirty.

abstract: The bark W.R. Kibby, which has heretofore figured somewhat conspicuously as a slaver, has now turned up in a new light. It will be recollected that the Kibby was condemned as a slaver, and sold by the United States Marshal of this District. She was purchased by a firm in South-street, and fitted out for a trading-voyage to St. Thomas, whither she sailed with a cargo. She there took out papers from the British Consul and went to Key West, whence she proceeded to Texas, successfully running the blockade. At Brazos and Metamoras she took in a cargo of hides, and $20,000 in specie, with which she started for Halifax. Falling short of provisions on the way, she put into this port on Sunday to get a fresh supply. She was immediately seized by the United States Marshal, the Captain arrested and sent to Fort Lafayette, and the vessel detained as a prize.

abstract: The Moniteur, alluding to the Valley of the Deppes affair, affirms that the French Government never entertained an idea of determining by force or military occupation the territorial question pending between France and Switzerland. abstract: Early Monday morning a serious affray took place in a lager beer saloon in the basement of No. 54 Greene-street. The saloon was kept by FREDERICK M. POWELL, and it appears that soon after 12 o'clock Sunday night two men, named JOSEPH BASSMORE and JOHN F. EAGAN, entered and called for drinks. Soon after this, POWELL and EAGAN got into a quarrel about some girls who were employed in the saloon, and finally they came to blows. BASSMORE, who was standing by, seeing that his friend EAGAN was being severely beaten, drew a large dirk knife and stabbed POWELL in the left side, inflicting wounds which are said to be serious. BASSMORE then was put and threw he dirk into the street. Officer STILLWELL, of the Eighth Precinct, soon after arrested the offender, and yesterday he was committed to the Tombs to await the result of POWELL's injuries. Officer REGAN, soon after the affray, found the dirk which was used upon the occasion, and then conveyed the injured man to the New-York Hospital.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS made their reappearance at this establishment last evening, and attracted an overflowing audience. They are deservedly regarded as the best artists in their peculiar line of business now before the public, and never play in the Metropolis without creating a sort of revival for the "Irish Boy and Yankee Gal" style of thing. Three popular pieces were given last night, the "Fairy Circle," the "Magic Joke," and the " Irish Tiger." Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS were received with great favor by the audience.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS made their reappearance at this establishment last evening, and attracted an overflowing audience. They are deservedly regarded as the best artists in their peculiar line of business now before the public, and never play in the Metropolis without creating a sort of revival for the "Irish Boy and Yankee Gal" style of thing. Three popular pieces were given last night, the "Fairy Circle," the "Magic Joke," and the " Irish Tiger." Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS were received with great favor by the audience.

abstract: The U.S. steam-frigate San Jacinto, with the rebel Commissioners, SLIDELL and MASON, on board, arrived off this port yesterday afternoon, but was boarded by United States Marshal MURRAY, who, in accordance with instructions from Washington, ordered her to proceed to Boston, where she will transfer her prisoners to Fort Warren. Strict orders were also given to hold no communication with the shore until after the transfer is made.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. steam-frigate San Jacinto, with the rebel Commissioners, SLIDELL and MASON, on board, arrived off this port yesterday afternoon, but was boarded by United States Marshal MURRAY, who, in accordance with instructions from Washington, ordered her to proceed to Boston, where she will transfer her prisoners to Fort Warren. Strict orders were also given to hold no communication with the shore until after the transfer is made.

abstract: We mentioned, a few days since, that charges had been made by the Government against Quartermaster A.L. OSTRANDER and Sutler J.M. REYNOLDS, of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, of embezzling goods belonging to the United States. We learn that they have been fully investigated at Washington, and the implicated parties honorably discharged from custody. The charge arose in consequence of an irregularity in the transfer of Government stores. The arrest shows great vigilance on the part of the Government, and commendable promptness in dealing with those to whom even suspicion attaches. There was enough to excite suspicion in this case, but the evidence showed clearly that there was no criminal intent on the part of the accused.

abstract: That mythical character, the unknownauthor of Rutledge, whose mask no one has yet succeeded in peeping behind, and whose personality is us mysterious as that ot "Junius," the Stat Nominis Umbra of all time, has, we learn, a new novel ready for the press, entitled The Sutherlands, which will be published by Messrs. RUDD & CARLETON, of New-York. If the success of an author's first book be a criterion for a second, The Sutherlands will reach a circulation of more than twenty thousand copies, and still fall short of that attained by Rutledge.

abstract: The members of the First City Troop, of Philadelphia, on Saturday, commemorated the formation of the Company in 1774, by a supper at the Continental.
lead_paragraph: The members of the First City Troop, of Philadelphia, on Saturday, commemorated the formation of the Company in 1774, by a supper at the Continental. Gen. PATTERSON was present, and, in response to a toast and three cheers, made a forcible speech explaining his reasons for not intercepting Gen. JOHNSTON previous to the battle of Manassas Junction He returned thanks for the compliment paid him, and for the manner in which it had been received. He said that he was not in the habit of giving reasons for anything he did or did not do, but in the presence of men of so much intelligence as the members of the First City Troop, a part of his command in the short campaign in the valley of Virginia, he considered it due to them as well as to himself to give a short statement of facts.

abstract: The map we lay before the readers of the TIMES, this morning, is especially intended to represent those portions of Tennessee and Kentucky where military operations are active, and where the population in sympathy with the cause of the Union are promoting it, by destroying important railroad bridges upon the rebel lines of communication.
lead_paragraph: The map we lay before the readers of the TIMES, this morning, is especially intended to represent those portions of Tennessee and Kentucky where military operations are active, and where the population in sympathy with the cause of the Union are promoting it, by destroying important railroad bridges upon the rebel lines of communication. The latest intelligence from Kentucky, leaves Gen. NELSON, after winning the splendid engagement at Piketon, pausing at that point, without affording any indication whether he proposed to proceed southward through Pound Gap or Cumberland Gap, or to remain, in order to keep the Secessionists of Eastern Kentucky in check, while Gen. THOMAS, now in strong force at London, advances toward Cumberland Gap, and attacks LEE, who is said to hold that pass at the head of 25,000 rebels. Our Ohio correspondent suggests that the mountains of that district afford other entrances into Tennessee beside those held by the enemy, naming especially Wheeler's Gap, some thirty-five miles westward of the Cumberland Gap. It is not impossible that Gen. THOMAS contemplates turning the flnak of LEE, by availing himself of these undefended passes. In the meantime, Gen. BUCKNER, at the head of 30,000 rebels, holds Bowling Green, throwing forward his advance guard as far as Green River, the bridge over which has been destroyed by his orders. The headquarters of the Union army, which at present contents itself with barring BUCKNER's march northward, remains at Elizabethtown, with the advance at Nolin.

abstract: The United States steam-transport Atlantic arrived here yesterday from Beaufort, having on board Dr. BLUDGARD, U.S.N., who brought dispatches for Commodore PAULDING, commanding at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and was also in charge of five seamen, who were transferred to the hospital as soon as they arrived.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam-transport Atlantic arrived here yesterday from Beaufort, having on board Dr. BLUDGARD, U.S.N., who brought dispatches for Commodore PAULDING, commanding at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and was also in charge of five seamen, who were transferred to the hospital as soon as they arrived. The corpse of a marine, who died on the passage, was landed at the Navy-yard, and will be interred in the burial-ground attached to the Naval Hospital.

abstract: The Grand Jury yesterday found an indictment against CHARLES M. JEFFERDS for murder in the first degree, in killing JOHN W. MATTHEWS, June 30, 1860. The old indictment was for murder in the second degree, which was yesterday quashed by the Court on motion of the District-Attorney, having been superseded by the new indictment. The Grand Jury also found an indictment against JEFFERDS for assault and battery with intent to kill WM. T. WALTON, a brother of the deceased JOHN WALTON, the assault having been committed on the 16th inst., at his place of business, No. 32 New-Bowery. JEFFERDS was yesterday arraigned on both indictments, and pleaded not guilty. He was attended in Court by his counsel, JAS. T. BRADY, Esq., who asked that the trial be set down for an early day. The Court, after consultation with the District-Attorney, designated Wednesday, the 4th of December prox., for the trial.
lead_paragraph: The Grand Jury yesterday found an indictment against CHARLES M. JEFFERDS for murder in the first degree, in killing JOHN W. MATTHEWS, June 30, 1860. JEFFERDS was yesterday arraigned on both indictments, and pleaded not guilty. He was attended in Court by his counsel, JAS. T. BRADY, Esq., who asked that the trial be set down for an early day. abstract: The United States steam transport Atlantic Capt. ELDREDGE, arrived at this port at about 11 o'clock yesterday morning from Port Royal, S.C., which place she left on the 16th at 3 P.M. She brings no news of interest, nothing of importance having transpired since our last advices. She has on board a number of passengers, and invalids from the army and navy, also six prisoners.

abstract: Amid hubbub and confusion I shall say a few unimportant words more because something may be expected, than anything I have to say. Gen. abstract: Troops in considerable numbers, of various arms, yet remain on Staten island, at Camp Scott and elsewhere. Their blue overcoats, so comfortable in the clear, bracing weather of the past week, are seen at all points along the shore. Among the men on leave Sunday, more or less stragglers wore noticed, who, as night came on, exhibited symptoms of succumbing to the enemy which surrounds the camp in peace or war, Gen. Whisky. At Fort Tompkins, one of the works under the supervision of Col. DELAFIELD, the Officer of Engineers having charge of the defences of New-York, CHARLES HASKINS, Esq., has recently been appointed Resident Superintendent. Mr. HASKINS is an architect and civil engineer of good repute, whose selection for this post is an excellent one. This fortification, directly opposite Forts Lafayett and Hamilton, is, in its plan, one of the most complete and extensive in the country. Some years will be required for finishing it, but, meantime, heavy batteries are mounted on the shore side with guns of large calibre, which would not fail to give a good report of themselves in case of an enemy approaching the City by way of the Narrow -- the narrowest portion of which, here not a mile wide, is commanded by the three forts above mentioned.

abstract: We have advices from Port Royal to the afternoon of Saturday last, at which time Beaufort had not been permanently occupied by the National forces, although it continued deserted by the inhabitants, and occasionally visits were made to it by single regiments of our troops. The intelligence brought by a previous arrival, that our pickets on the further side of Hilton.
lead_paragraph: Head Island had been attacked by the rebels, is not confirmed. The stores and ordnance belonging to the army had nearly all been landed, and several of the transports were expected to leave soon. The dispatch from Savannah, published a day or two ago, announcing that the great fleet had passed Fernandina on the way South, is disproved by the statement that the fleet on Saturday was still at anchor in the harbor of Port Royal. By the United States steam transport Atlantic, which brings the above intelligence, we have received a number of letters from our correspondents with Gen. SHERMAN's command, which give a detailed account of the occurrences which have taken place since the capture of the fortifications.

abstract: The success of the French  floating batteries, La Devastation, La Tonnante and La Lave, at Kinburn, Crimea, has been the signal of a revolution in the great navies of Europe which does not seem to stop short of a complete transformation.
lead_paragraph: -- The success of the French floating batteries, La Devastation, La Tonnante and La Lave, at Kinburn, Crimea, has been the signal of a revolution in the great navies of Europe which does not seem to stop short of a complete transformation. No sooner was La Gloire built, by order of the Emperor of the French, than England, seeing her superiority over wooden vessels, immediately set herself to work and tried to outvie her powerful rival. The result of that competition produced the Defiance, the Resistance, the Warrior and the Black Prince, four steel-clad vessels, now afloat. Eleven vessels of that description are said to have been ordered by the Admiralty within the last sixty days, and an amount of twelve and a half millions of dollars has been voted by the English Parliament for that purpose. But as every one of these vessels cost above two millions, and as the amount voted is merely sufficient for the construction of five of them, an additional appropriation of about fifteen millions to necessary for the six remaining vessels.

abstract: The Twelfth Regiment Maine Volunteers are to be of Gen. BUTLER'S Expedition. They are to sail hence in your magnificent new steamer the Constitution, which is expected here on Wednesday to take them on board. This regiment is commanded by Col. GEO. F. abstract: This place has now been in the hands of the Federal forces for three days, and although only the troops are landed, the change produced is remarkable. In the first hurry and confusion, amid which I wrote an account of the events of Thursday, I had no opportunity to do more than note the more salient of those events and the merest outside of circumstances.

abstract: MORRIS MEYER, a man of high social position, about twenty-three years of age, was arrested in this City yesterday by direction of Superintendent KENNEDY. Mr. KENNEDY received a telegram from the State Department in the early part of the day, requesting him to arrest the young man, and convey him at once to Fort Lafayette. Pursuant to these orders, he sent officers immediately to the store of Mr. MEYER, in the upper part of Broadway, where he was found, and conveyed to Police Headquarters. For a little while,great excitement prevailed about the Superintendent's Office, among the friends of the accused. Several gentlemen from Fifth-avenue called for the purpose of interposing in his behalf, and all his friends insisted that he was a true Union man and should be released. But the Superintendent believed the evidence before him was strong enough to hold the prisoner, and he therefore sent him in charge of officer to Fort Lafayette. Mr. MEYER is a Mississippian by birth, his parents being among the most wealthy in the State. He has been for several years engaged in carrying on a fashionable boot and shoe store on Broadway, and has done a flourishing business. From letters and papers found in the possession of the accused, it is believed that he has been conducting a treasonable correspondence with parties in Mississippi for a long time.

abstract: The rebels have undertaken to coerce our Government into an acknowledgment of their belligerent rights, by threatening to hang our prisoners in their hands unless those rights are conceded. They make the first test on the privateers whom we have captured.
lead_paragraph: The rebels have undertaken to coerce our Government into an acknowledgment of their belligerent rights, by threatening to hang our prisoners in their hands unless those rights are conceded. They make the first test on the privateers whom we have captured. We claim that these men have violated certain laws of the United States, knowing perfectly well what those laws are, and in deliberate contempt of their authority. We propose to give them the benefit of a fair jury trial, -- of a full defence by counsel of their own selection, and every advantage which parties accused of crime ever enjoy. If they are convicted we propose to inflict upon them the penalty which the law prescribes. We cannot do less than this without acknowledging the right of somebody other than the Government of the United States to nullify those laws, -- to declare them void and of no effect.

abstract: The telegraph reports, this morning, the seizure of a Spanish bark off Charleston, and that she was put in charge of a prize crew. This is the Spanish bark Providencia, Capt. VEINCH, which sailed from Havana for New-York, Oct. 5. in ballast. On her voyage she was brought too by the U.S. gunboat Monticello, when the mate of the bark was sent on board the gunboat with her papers for the inspection of the officers. During his stay on board, a violent blow came on, so that it was Impossible for him to return to the bark, and he was taken into Hampton Roads, and so came on to the consignee of the vessel in this City, where he is now anxiously awaiting the arrival of his vessel. He has her papers in his possession.

abstract: The Nominating Committee of the "Tax-Payers' and Citizens' Union," met at the Everett House Monday evening. FRANCIS R. TILLOU was Chairman, and Messrs. GEORGE GRISWOLD, WM.B. WEDGEWOOD and WM.D. WADDINGTON, were the Secretaries. Among other gentlemen present were Jas. Bogardus, Jacob L. Dodge, Alexander Arnold, Charles Abernethy, R.L. Schieffillin, H.S. Maynard, George D. Phelps, J.W. Meeks, Noah Worrall, Z.N. Ely, and others of equal prominence in the monetary world. Of the $300,000,000 represented by the Association, at least $30,000,000 were represented on this occasion. The Committee appointed at a previous meeting to make a nomination for Mayor, asked further time, which was granted. The Committee adjourned until Wednesday evening, when the Mayoralty and other charter nominations are positively to be made. It is understood that if Mr. BRADY accepts the nomination of Tammany Hall, this Convention will unanimously indorse him.

abstract: Plymouth Church was crowded on Tuesday evening with people eager to hear Rev. J.S. INSKIP, Chaplain of the Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M.,...
lead_paragraph: Plymouth Church was crowded on Tuesday evening with people eager to hear Rev. J.S. INSKIP, Chaplain of the Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M., and a liberal collection was taken up to furnish some necessary articles for the comfort of the men. Mr, INSKIP glanced at the carcer of the regiment from the time it left Brooklyn in May last, up to the present - at the advance post in Virginia. He claimed, what no one ever doubted, that the regiment had done its whole duty, and the audience might rest assured they would remain in the held until the close of the war. The statements made were for the most part interesting, and gave those present a better idea of camp life than they had before entertained. The Fourteenth, with their military duties, mingle the following exercises: Sunday morning and evening, preaching in "Fowler Chapel" - a tent; and in the afternoon a prayer meeting is held at the same place. The church is under the management of twenty trustees - composed of men of all professions, and no profession of faith, and the arrangement if, such that every, thing works harmoniously, and a great deal of good has already been accomplished, partially through this means, and we presume also from the fact that Mr. INSKIP, when the regiment first wont into the field, took upon himself the urduous duty of doing all the necessary swearing that was to be done. On Monday evening a temperance meeting is held in the tent. The society new numbers about 160, including about 20 whe, when they entered the regiment, were drunkards. Tuesday evening a literary and debating society meets at the same place. Wednesday and Thursday evenings prayer - meetings are held. Friday evening a concert is given, and on Saturday evening the "Chaplain's Levee" is held, when there is singing, instrumental music, declamation, and the affair winds up with a smoke - the only occasion on which smoking is allowed in the tent. An admission fee of one stick of wood for the chaplain is sometimes charged for admission to this entertainment. As may well be imagined, the men of the regiment are pretty much all of the time occupied between drill, singing, praying and speaking, and accordingly in good spirits. The men, however, are sadly in need of many little comforts which they cannot obtain for themselves, such as flannels, stockings, mittens, &c.; and to urge the furnishing of them is the special mission of Mr. INSKIP at this time. Contributions can be sent to WM. M. BURNET, No. 19 Henry-street, and they will be forwarded immediately.

abstract: The captain of the bark Wm. R. Kibby, seized on Tuesday for an alleged violation of the blockade, was arrested yesterday and taken to Police Headquarters, in Broome-street. The vessel was towed up to the City in the early part of the day, and upon its arrival, the first and second mates were also taken in charge by the police, and after having been conveyed to headquarters, and an examination had been made by the Superintendent, they were sent to the House of Detention as witnesses in the case. One of the mates has prepared a statement, consisting of a detailed account of the cruise of the bark, the discharge of her cargo at Brazos, and the shipping of a return cargo from the Rio Grande. It is believed that the evidence which the two mates can give relative to the voyage, the cargo, &c., will be sufficient to warrant a confiscation of the vessel and the freight contained in her.

abstract: We are a nation young in years, and still younger in experience, if the causeless panics to which we are constantly subject are to be taken as proof.
lead_paragraph: We are a nation young in years, and still younger in experience, if the causeless panics to which we are constantly subject are to be taken as proof. Like an untrained, but spirited horse, we shy, and perhaps throw our load into the ditch, at everything unusual that accident, or malevolence, or improvidence may have thrown in our path, though it may be nothing more than a tattered rag flaunting by the wayside. Our sensitiveness is in part owing to our social and political organization. In other countries the solution of grave international, and even domestic questions, is regarded as belonging exclusively to Governments which exist per se, and whose own safety and welfare are to be considered, as well as that of the people. The latter, consequently, quietly pursue their wonted avocations, while their rulers are tortured with anxiety, and the difficulties which beset them, but which never, or only slowly, reach the public eye. Not so in the United States. All questions that arise are instantly before an impressible audience, consisting of the whole nation, and are magnified in one direction or the other according to the caprice or conclusions of the moment. The Share market, that barometer of public sentiment, dances up and down in such rapid oscillations that it is barely possible to register anything like a correct mean.
headline: {'main': 'Our Causeless Panics.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Causeless Panics.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In an article, which we elsewhere reprint from the Paris Presse, we have a significant disclosure of the part England and France propose to themselves in the expedition to Mexico.
lead_paragraph: In an article, which we elsewhere reprint from the Paris Presse, we have a significant disclosure of the part England and France propose to themselves in the expedition to Mexico. They go, it seems, as "tutrices," -- traveling "governors," or "tutors," -- "mentors" of Spain, who, left to herself, would be likely, in the excess of juvenile strength and spirits, to commit we know not what extravagancies. The least that was to be expected from the original Spanish programme, which the Madrid Ministry was so long obstinate in the resolve to execute independently, was the forcible restoration of Spanish rule in Mexico. This purpose has been curbed by the joint convention. Neither of the Powers is to acquire territorial or other advantages not common to the rest; and, should the Mexican people, promoted by European bayonets, select monarchical institutions for their future government, no European bayonet shall point out the man to wear the crown. The treaty itself is a defeat of the purpose which induced the Spanish Government to begin its preparations for war. The expedition is so nicely balanced between the three parties, that anything like unity between two will give direction to its conduct and results; so that the moderate designs which the English and French Governments entertain in common, must control the entire transaction.
headline: {'main': 'The Joint Expedition to Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Joint Expedition to Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Arrange  ments have been made between the Heads of Departments in Washington and the representatives of the New-York Press, by which,...
lead_paragraph: Arrange ments have been made between the Heads of Departments in Washington and the representatives of the New-York Press, by which, it is hoped, much of the inconvenience and dissatisfaction hitherto connected with the publication of official documents may be avoided. Up to the present time, there has been nothing like system introduced into this matter; it has been left to take care of itself. Every leading newspaper has kept three or four reporters in Washington, mainly to watch the Departments, and get hold first of such official documents as might be in their possession. The business thus became a mere scramble, entailing infinite annoyance upon the Secretaries and Heads of Bureaus, and leading to practices in the highest degre derogatory to the character and position of the Press. It became dangerous to leave a public document upon any Secretary's desk, lest it should mysteriously disappear and make its first appearance in the columns of some enterprising newspaper. Some journals, much more zealous for news than for the preservation of their self-respect, devoted themselves to the purchase of special favors in this way, by filling their columns with fulsome flattery of special members of the Government who had them to bestow, and unscruplous abuse of others who might decline thus to traffic for their own advantage in documents belonging to the Government and the people at large. The whole thing was becoming a nuisance to the Secretaries, fatal to the independence and self-respect of the Press, and degrading to the gentlemen employed as reporters at Washington.

abstract: On motion of Mr. BOOLF, the Board of Aldermen on Monday last adopted resolutions relative to a public rejoicing for the victory gained by our navy at Port Royal.
lead_paragraph: On motion of Mr. BOOLF, the Board of Aldermen on Monday last adopted resolutions relative to a public rejoicing for the victory gained by our navy at Port Royal. National salutes were to be fired from our public parks, flags were to be hoisted, and the various City bells were to ring out joyous peals. Yesterday was the day appointed for the jubilee. Owing, however, to the board of Councilman referring the matter to the Committee on National Affairs, to report on Thursday, Mr. BOOLE'S resolutions could not be full carried out yesterday. A portion of the programme, though, was gone through. Mr. JAMES E. AYLIFFE, the well-known bell-ringer of Trinity Church, played the following tunes upon the bells of Trinity: "Hail Columbia," "Yankee Doodle," airs from "Child of the Regiment," "Home, Sweet Home," "Last Rose of Summer," "Evening Bells," "Star-Spangled Banner," airs by DE BERIOT, airs from "Fra Diavalo," and "Columbia, the Gem of the Ocean." Flags were also displayed from the City Hall and other public buildings in the City. The original programme will be officially issued at an early day, when out citizens willh ave an opportunity to participate in the generals rejoicings.

abstract: Stephen V. Moers vs. Augustus Mond and [???] others, -- The plaintiff alleged that by a conspiracy between the defendants, one of whom is now dead, he was defrauded of over three hundred bales of tobacco. It was alleged that one of the defendants acted as broker, purchasing the goods for Mond, who gave $6,000 costs and the rest in notes, which were to be immediately discounted by the other defendants -- but they were not; and when the notes matured they were protested for non-payment. This suit was then brought to recover the value of the tobacco. The defendants denied the charge of conspiracy and attempted to show that it was false; but in the minds of the jury, they failed to do so, and the consequence was a verdict against all of them for the sum of $22,583 65. An allowance on the verdict was made of $400.

abstract: The bark Teresa, Capt. FOSTER, from Maracalbo, Oct. 22, with coffee, hides, &c., to MAITLAND, PHELPS & Co., reports that on Nov. 12, in lat. 30 10, long. 72, spoke schooner Winthrop, from Wilmington, N.C., for Nassan, N.P. She had run the blockade, in company with another schooner, four days previously. On the 17th inst., lat 38 05, lon. 71 30, fell in with brig Judge Whitman, Capt. BRAY, from Boston to Fortress Monroe, with granite. in a sinking condition. After considerable trouble, succeeded in taking off the Captain and crew, and brought them to this port. Left at Maracalbo bark Ilva Durie, from St. Thomas, just arrived.

abstract: The crew of the supposed slaver Augusta were yesterday brought before Judge INGRAHAM, on a writ of habeas corpus, but the United States District-Attorney having meantime issued a warrant for their arrest on the charge of aiding and abetting the slave-trade, the Judge dismissed the writ and remanded the prisoners to the custody of the United States Marshal, who recommitted them to the Tombs. The Augusta was taken into Greenport after her capture, whence she will be brought to this port. Her owner, APPLETON OAKSMITH, who is now in Fort Lafayette, claims that she was destined for a legitimate voyage; but the nature of her cargo, and the manner of her fitting up, will probably demonstrate the real character of the vessel.

abstract: "When Secretary WELLES contracted for the new gunboats, a hue and cry rang through the country disparaging them, and predicting their failure.
lead_paragraph: It arose from the disappointments of parties seeking contracts to construct something else in their stead. Seven of them have been fairly tested in Commodore DUPONT's late brilliant action. They have proved the most valuable for the particular service required on the Southern coast now afloat -- so valuable as that orders have doubtless been sent out to hasten the construction of the rest of the twenty-five as fast as possible."

abstract: Lieut. EVARTS, of WILSON'S regiment of Zouaves, has returned to New-York from Fort Pickens, and brings a few more such interesting detail, about the fight at Santa Rosa Island as can only be derived from the experience of an eye-witness and participant. He puts down the number of the attacking force at 1,800 men, with 1,000 more in reserve, and asserts that the whole effective force of the Zouaves was 203, part of the regiment doing garrison duty at Tortugas and Key West, and a considerable proportion of those remaining on the Island being in hospital. The attack of the rebels was a complete surprise, the Zouaves receiving their first warning from the discharge of rebel musketry in their very midst. They retreated on the sudden shook of alarm, but most of them speedily rallied under command of Lieut.-Col. CREIGHTON, and charged their assullauts, driving them back, and effectually frustrating their prearranged designs. It was after the Zouaves had done this much that the regulars arrived from Fort Pickens, and completed the total defeat of the enemy.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. EVARTS, of WILSON'S regiment of Zouaves, has returned to New-York from Fort Pickens, and brings a few more such interesting detail, about the fight at Santa Rosa Island as can only be derived from the experience of an eye-witness and participant. The attack of the rebels was a complete surprise, the Zouaves receiving their first warning from the discharge of rebel musketry in their very midst. They retreated on the sudden shook of alarm, but most of them speedily rallied under command of Lieut.-Col. abstract: It is a common experience of lawyers, that it is hard to find adjudged cases which go upon all-fours with any case in controversy.
lead_paragraph: It is a common experience of lawyers, that it is hard to find adjudged cases which go upon all-fours with any case in controversy. And this seems to be so in the instance of MASON and SLIDELL. Many cases have been cited in the discussions upon it, but few of them really hit the point at issue exactly. Most of them are decisions of the Courts in proceedings to condemn vessels as prizes, which would be pertinent if Capt. WILKES had seized the Trent and brought her into this port to be condemned and sold. But that is not exactly the case. Capt. WILKES did not capture the Trent, and no proceedings are to be had against her. He has stopped her, searched her, and taken from her two men with their baggage, among which, as we understand, were dispatches from the rebels to to their emissaries abroad. Was he authorized to take them, or has Great Britain a ground of complaint against us because of his act?

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION SUPPORT OF THE QUARANTINE HOSPITALS. The regular meeting was held yesterday, Mr. CURTIS, Vice-President, in the Chair.
lead_paragraph: COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION SUPPORT OF THE QUARANTINE HOSPITALS. The regular meeting was held yesterday, Mr. CURTIS, Vice-President, in the Chair. A communication was received from the Quarantine Commissioners, asking for an additional loan of $1,000 for the support of the Quarantine Hospital. This caused some debate, but was finally granted. The money received from the sale of the Richmond County bonds is now expended, except a small balance of $500. From the weekly statement, it appears that 62,793 emigrants have arrived up to date, against 96,651 last year. The amount received for commutation of passengers, and other sources, is $182,240 80. Expenses during the same period is $172,565 69. Balance in bank, $9,675 11.

abstract: THE CANVASS FOR  MAYOR. The contest for Mayor begins to clear up a little. JAMES T. BRADY declines the nomination of Tammany Hall, and Mr. GUNTERR has been nominated in his place.
lead_paragraph: THE CANVASS FOR MAYOR. -- The contest for Mayor begins to clear up a little. JAMES T. BRADY declines the nomination of Tammany Hall, and Mr. GUNTERR has been nominated in his place. He is a popular candidate, and will poll a highly respectable vote. He will divide the Democracy very fairly with WOOD and thus greatly improve the chances of OPDYKE's success, if he should decide to run. We doubt whether WOOD will poll as heavy a vote as LYNCH did. Aside from the general opposition which he has always encountered, there are many who think he has been Mayor long enough, and and that a little rotation in that office may be desirable. Indeed, it is not certain that he is to be a candidate. Possibly he may make up his mind that he has held this office long enough to satisfy his ambition, and that he may as well be looking forward to something else. Still the understanding among his friends is that he intends to be a candidate.

abstract: Napoleon B. Kukuck vs. W.A. Mills, C.H. Sand et al. - In this case the defendant, Sand, was the owner of a mortgage for $10,000, made by the defendant, Mills, He assigned the mortgage, as alleged, to one John Anderson, to secure a loan of $3,000, to be made by Anderson to a third party, with a condition that if the $3,000 was repaid at the end of one year, the mortgage should be reassigned to C.H. Sand; otherwise title thereto was to vest in Anderson. The borrower failed to pay, and Anderson, assuming to have full title, assigned the mortgage to the plaintiff, who instituted proceedings in foreclosure, making Sand a party, serving upon him no notice of a personal claim, with the summons. By inadvertence, Sand permitied himself to be in default, and the plaintiff obtained judgment of foreclosure, and the matter passed into the Sheriff's hands.

abstract: The grand review of almost the entire army of the Potomac by Gen. McCLELLAN, for which preparations have for some time been making, took...
lead_paragraph: The grand review of almost the entire army of the Potomac by Gen. McCLELLAN, for which preparations have for some time been making, took place yesterday, and passed off with the greatest success. During the progress of the review the precaution was taken to double the picket guards at all points, to prevent a surprise by the enemy, and still further to guard against any such accident, the different divisions, as soon as their parts of the programme had been respectively executed, filed off to their quarters. The restriction regarding passes to cross the Potomac, was, for the time, suspended, and all had the liberty of witnessing the display. It is estimated that some thirty thousand persons availed themselves of this liberty. Gen. MCCLELLAN was accompanied by the President and Secretaries SEWARD and CAMERON, on horseback, and wherever they appeared the young commander and his distinguished companions were received with the greatest enthusiasm. The line, which was formed in a semi-circle, occupied an extent of four miles.

abstract: The Royal Mail steamship Asia arrived at this port yesterday, with advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 9th, and Queenstown on the 10th inst. The Liverpool Cotton market was firmer, but prices continued unchanged. The Breadstuffs market was steady, and Provisions were dull. Trade at Manchester was restricted, but there was greater firmness in prices, and a further advance was demanded. The English funds were firm and higher -- Consols being quoted at 935/8@933/4. An improvement had also taken place in the French Money market.

abstract: The Albany Atlas and Argus discusses the case of MASON and SLIDELL at some length, and, as perhaps is not to be wondered at, comes to the conclusion that the adjudged cases which have been cited in support of our view of the case, do not cover it, because the
lead_paragraph: The Albany Atlas and Argus discusses the case of MASON and SLIDELL at some length, and, as perhaps is not to be wondered at, comes to the conclusion that the adjudged cases which have been cited in support of our view of the case, do not cover it, because the Trent had neither left nor was bound to a port of the rebel States, and that "the law which placed on a parallel with articles of contraband the dispatches and person of an envoy, is not applicable to either, when conveyed from one neutral port to another." It cites the declaration of the English Government in the Crimean war, which, it thinks, "relates to articles of contraband going to an enemy's port and dispatches from an enemy's port," and it adds, that "any other view would break up the maritime commerce and mail service of the whole world."

abstract: Henry Curtis, alias William Willetts, was placed on trial in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge EMOTT and Justices STILWELL and HOYT. yesterday, on an indictment charging him with the murder of Policeman David II. Martin, of the Second Precinct Police. Messrs. Britton and Jenks
lead_paragraph: Henry Curtis, alias William Willetts, was placed on trial in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge EMOTT and Justices STILWELL and HOYT. yesterday, on an indictment charging him with the murder of Policeman David II. Martin, of the Second Precinct Police. Messrs. Britton and Jenks appeared as counsel for the prisoner, and District-Attorney Winslow conducted the prosecution. A jury was obtained before the panel of eighty, which had been drawn for the Court, was exhausted, and the trial was proceeded with without any vexatious delay. The facts elicited from witnesses placed on the stand by the people, were substantially as follows: On the night of the 5th of August last, the prisoner attempted to break into house No. 130 Adams-street, occupied by Mr. Sanxay; several residents in the neighborhood, and among others, Mr. Anderson, witnessed his proceedings and made an attempt to arrest him; when Curtis found that he was discovered, he ran from Adams into High-street, through High to Washington-street, and through the latter street as far as Prospect-street, when his further progress was stopped by Officer David H. Martin, of the Second Precinct Police; the citizens who had followed the fugitive, crying, "stop thief," soon came and found the prisoner and the officer clinched and upon the ground. Upon raising and seperating them, it was found that Martin had received a mortal wound in the right side of his neck, from the effects of which he died within a very few minutes. Several persons were near enough to see that Curtis made the stab before the officer used his club. On the person of accused was found a complete set of burglars' tools, skeleton keys, false whiskers, &c. The testimony was nearly all introduced yesterday, and counsel will sum up this morning.

abstract: INSTALLATION. Last evening the Second U.P. Presbytery of New-York installed Rev. G. CAMPBEL Pastor of the West Forty-fourth-street United Presbyterian Church. Rev. HUGH H. BLAIR preached the sermon and presided. Rev. D. PATTERSON addressed the Pastor, and Rev. Mr. BRUSH the people. The exercises were very interesting and appropriate. The attendance was large. The prospect of this Church is now very encouraging.
lead_paragraph: INSTALLATION. Last evening the Second U.P. Presbytery of New-York installed Rev. G. CAMPBEL Pastor of the West Forty-fourth-street United Presbyterian Church. Rev. HUGH H. BLAIR preached the sermon and presided. Rev. D. PATTERSON addressed the Pastor, and Rev. Mr. BRUSH the people. The exercises were very interesting and appropriate. The attendance was large. The prospect of this Church is now very encouraging.

abstract: We beg leave to favor the gentlemen of President LINCOLN'S Cabinet with a little fatherly, and of course friendly, advice. We do it partly for their own good, but mainly for the good of the country, which is of more importance than all of them put together. We ...
lead_paragraph: We beg leave to favor the gentlemen of President LINCOLN'S Cabinet with a little fatherly, and of course friendly, advice. We do it partly for their own good, but mainly for the good of the country, which is of more importance than all of them put together. We beg them not to start topics of public discussion concerning which they differ among themselves, -- especially as it is not essential to the public good that they should be canvassed just now, -- but to lend all their thoughts and all their efforts to the prosecution of the War, in which they have a common interest, and in regard to which they are all agreed. We are prompted to these suggestions by the following paragraph from our Washington dispatches of yesterday morning:

abstract: The grand canvass for Mayor is fairly opened at last. We have a clear view of the whole field, and can form some reasonable estimate of the probable result. The Mozart Convention met last night and nominated Mayor WOOD for relection, as the special champion of Municipal Reform and of the War for the Union. There's nothing like cool ...
lead_paragraph: The grand canvass for Mayor is fairly opened at last. We have a clear view of the whole field, and can form some reasonable estimate of the probable result. The Mozart Convention met last night and nominated Mayor WOOD for relection, as the special champion of Municipal Reform and of the War for the Union. There's nothing like cool courage, even if it does verge on arrogance, in a political canvass. FERNANDO takes the bull by the horns, and demands an election to reform the very abuses for which he, far beyond any other man, is generally held responsible.

abstract: By the Asia we have a brief synopsis of the speeches of the American Minister and Lord PALMERSTON, at the Lord Mayor's Banquet, which is an occasion for ventilating opinions by persons in high official positions. Mr. ADAMS, our Minister, in response to the toast ...
lead_paragraph: By the Asia we have a brief synopsis of the speeches of the American Minister and Lord PALMERSTON, at the Lord Mayor's Banquet, which is an occasion for ventilating opinions by persons in high official positions. Mr. ADAMS, our Minister, in response to the toast to the Diplomatic Corps, said he was there to cement the friendship and good feeling between the two countries. Lord PALMERSTON volunteered a reply, in which he assured Mr. ADAMS that his Government had his Lordship's sympathies; that he hoped soon to see peace restored to our country; and that England would, in the end, be greatly advantaged by the war, in securing for her supplies of cotton from other sources than the United States -- a very sensible view of the case. The speech of Lord PALMERSTON was in the most conciliatory and friendly tone.
headline: {'main': 'Lord Palmerston on American Affairs.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Lord Palmerston on American Affairs.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Washington papers announce the death of this talented young officer, after a short illness from typhoid fever. Lieut, SNYDER graduated at West Point with distinguished honor at the head of the class of 1856, and was appointed to the Enneers, in which corps he proved himself a most
lead_paragraph: The Washington papers announce the death of this talented young officer, after a short illness from typhoid fever. Lieut, SNYDER graduated at West Point with distinguished honor at the head of the class of 1856, and was appointed to the Enneers, in which corps he proved himself a most efficient officer. In August 1860, he was assigned as assistant to Capt. JOHN G. FOSTER, then in charge of the defences of Charleston harbor. He was one of that heroic band who defended Fort Sumter so gallantly against the fearful odds arrayed against them, and when the flag-staff was shot down, he was the officer who planted it on the ramparts.

abstract: The steamship Baltic arrived at this port yesterday from Port Royal, but she brought no news of consequence additional to that brought by the Atlantic. The mails brought by these two vessels are very heavy. The Post-Office Department ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Baltic arrived at this port yesterday from Port Royal, but she brought no news of consequence additional to that brought by the Atlantic. The mails brought by these two vessels are very heavy. The Post-Office Department yesterday received notice that fifteen thousand letters were received by the Atlantic alone. They were forwarded from Hilton Head without the prepayment of postage, and the Department has ordered that they shall be sent to their destination, the postage to be collected when delivered. A Post-Office is to be established at Port Royal immediately, a blank commission for the Postmaster, to be filled by Gen. SHERMAN, having already been sent out. In the course of a week, it is expected, the Treasury Department will also take steps regarding the collection of the customs there.

abstract: FAVORABLE CHARACTER OF THE EUROPEAN ADVICES. Advices from France indicate that the feeling on the part of that Government is more cordial towards the United States than ever.

abstract: The Fort Smith Times says the telegraph wire has been cut several times between Van Buren and Fayetteville, Ark., by some Lincolnite. The citizens of Van Buren have offered reward for the villain, and we hope he may be arrested and get his reward. It is also stated that some Abolition scoundrel has been attaching wire to the telegraph line between Van Buren and Fayetteville, running one end, and Maj. CLARKE and MONTGOMERY'S messages into the ground, thus destroying all communication between the two termini.

abstract: Three non-commissioned officers lately serving on Governor's Island are among the eleven just promoted to Second Lieutenancies in the regular army. Their names are CHARLES BENZONI, OSCAR HAGEN and SAUL S. CULBERTSON. Lieut. BENZONI served in the British German Legion, and enlisted in the United States Army about three years ago. On the organization of the Eleventh Infantry he was transferred to it, and has been acting as Quartermaster-Sergeant. Lieut. HAGEN was First Sergeant of company A, permanent party on Governor's Island, and has seen a good deal of service on the frontiers. Lieut. CULBERTSON has served in the British Army, and was with his regiment (the Twenty-fourth Infantry) through the whole of the late Indian campaign. This regiment had more fighting and suffered more than any other. Lieut. CULBERTSON was also in the battle of Bull Run, and was the last man to leave the field, spiking the gun he had been working, and cutting the traces before he did so.

abstract: The Jackson correspondent of the Vicksburgh Sun says he has seen a letter from Gen. JOHNSTON to Gov. PETTUS, declining to receive more troops under the late requisition, having already more soldiers than he can dispose of. The Governor is requested to disband all companies organized under said requisition, unless they go armed and equipped for the war. The Sun says that the volunteers who had been recently mustered into the service at that city were very indignant on being disbanded, and their officers had left for Jackson, to lay their case before Gov. PETTUS.

abstract: The delegation from Mozart Hall, appointed to apprize the Mayor of his renomination, performed their duty yesterday noon, at the Mayor's office. The Mayor made a speech in response, in which he assigned many private reasons why he did not desire a reelection.
lead_paragraph: The delegation from Mozart Hall, appointed to apprize the Mayor of his renomination, performed their duty yesterday noon, at the Mayor's office. The Mayor made a speech in response, in which he assigned many private reasons why he did not desire a reelection. He had, however, finally determined to gratify his friends, and, as he said, perform his duty to the best interests of the City, by accepting the nomination.
