abstract: The TIMES gave, a few days since, from documents of the period, a statement of the circumtances of the capture, in the Revolutionary War, of HENRY LAURENS, who had been the President of Congress, and who was crossing the Atlantic on his way as an ambassador to Holland.
lead_paragraph: The TIMES gave, a few days since, from documents of the period, a statement of the circumtances of the capture, in the Revolutionary War, of HENRY LAURENS, who had been the President of Congress, and who was crossing the Atlantic on his way as an ambassador to Holland. Although that it is not in all respects a parallel case to the more recent one of MASON and SLIDELL, the two are nearly enough alike to render the story of LAURENS' capture interesting and, perhaps, important, as a precedent in international jurisprudence.

abstract: The New-Orleans Crescent has the following: "Unfortunately the abettors and resources of the Hessian Government of LINCOLN have been underrated. It is now nearly six months since a vessel entered the port of New-Orleans from a distant country. The same remarks will apply to Mobile and other ports on the Gulf. Where a vessel with a cargo of merchandise has passed the Lincoln blockade, twenty have passed the blockade in the war of 1812. Flour from Spain can be delivered, via Havana, at our Levee, at $8 to $10 per barrel, such as we ourselves paid yesterday $18 for. Will the non-expectationts say that we should be inhibited from encouraging shipments of this necessary article, to be paid for in cotton."

abstract: From parties who left Columbus on Wednesday, and who are in a position to know fully [???] they state, we learn that Gen. POLK was still suffering from the injury he received on the occasion of the bursting of the cannon there, and Gen. PILLOW was in command. A force was at work cutting down the timber on the Missouri side, opposite Columbus, so as to leave no ambush for the enemy in any event. The people on the Missouri side are in utter consternation, and are flying from their houses. While the Kentucky was up the river, on Wednesday, her captain kindly ferried over five families to this side, with their teams and household articles. Fugitives say there is a large amount of corn and hogs in the country, all of which they expect to fall into the hands of the enemy. It has been forcibly kept there by the blockade. The people were destroying or removing all flats, landing-boats and ferry-boats that were along the shore. The ferry-boat that crossed near Point Pleasant has been destroyed. A soldier who had been taken prisoner, but who escaped from Cairo, reported that soldiers were coming into that place in great numbers, and that the day before he left, Wednesday, nine regiments arrived. There was a general expectation at Columbus that there will soon be an invasion of a more serious character than the late one at Belmont.

abstract: That a British vessel was stopped  and searched on the high seas. Can our Government justify that act? It is scarcely conceivable that England should question it; for it is one of the clearest and most indisputable maxims of international law that neutral vessels may be visited and searched.
lead_paragraph: That a British vessel was stopped and searched on the high seas. Can our Government justify that act? It is scarcely conceivable that England should question it; for it is one of the clearest and most indisputable maxims of international law that neutral vessels may be visited and searched in time of war, if suspected of carrying articles contraband of war and thus engaged in aiding the cause of either belligerent. It is frequently said that the United States has denied the right of search, -- that we went to war with England in 1812 to resist it, -- and that we have denounced it ever since. This is a mistake, -- growing out of the confounding of two things which are entirely distinct. We have denied the right of search in time of peace for the enforcement of any municipal or treaty regulation. We have denied the right of England to search our ships to see whether we had English sailors on board, or whether they were going after a cargo of slaves, in time of peace. But we have never denied the right of search for contraband in time of war. All our writers on law, -- all our statesmen and diplomatists, have expressly admitted that right. Chief-Justice MARSHALL styled it "a belligerent right which cannot be called in question." Even Mr. CASS, while contending in 1859 against the right of search in time of peace, said there was "no right of visit except from the belligerent claim."

abstract: After Change hours, yesterday, we were shown a document of an official character, issued at Columbus on Friday last, authorizing the party to whom it was issued, a gentleman of this city, "to transfer from Kentucky, on the Memphis and Ohio Railroad to Memphis, flour and other subsistence;" and there is no orders at any time prohibiting any one from doing the some.
lead_paragraph: After Change hours, yesterday, we were shown a document of an official character, issued at Columbus on Friday last, authorizing the party to whom it was issued, a gentleman of this city, "to transfer from Kentucky, on the Memphis and Ohio Railroad to Memphis, flour and other subsistence;" and there is no orders at any time prohibiting any one from doing the some. We may presume that we may regard this as a virtual abandonment of the blockade. We therefore look for liberal arrivals by the Ohio Railroad, which, added to the increased arrivals by the Charleston Railroad, will certainly effect the market.

abstract: Our kinsfolks across the water have seen but one issue to the rebellion the breaking down of the North from its want of the sinews of war.
lead_paragraph: Our kinsfolks across the water have seen but one issue to the rebellion the breaking down of the North from its want of the sinews of war. This is a staple argument with Mr. RUSSELL, the correspondent of the London Times, who tells his principals that the South can afford to play the waiting game much better than the North. When a particular result is desired, a conclusion that favors it is very apt to be adopted with very little examination or reason. The wish to have it so supplies the place of proofs. But these, it happens, are directly opposed to the positions assumed. What does the North suffer by waiting? Only the burdens of the war. Its internal and foreign trade was never more active. Labor is everywhere free, productive and well rewarded. Our banks were never making money faster; our railroads were never transporting so much freight, or earning so much; the North never had more bountiful crops, and never got so much money for them; even the vast burdens of the war, the expenditures reaching $1,000,000 per day, are not felt to be a burden. On the contrary, they operate as a great stimulus to business and trade. The burdens will not be fell till the war closes. There was never before so much gold in the country, and money, for months past, has been most abundant, and was never more plenty than at the present moment.

abstract: The events of April and May, 1861, will be memorable in the history of the Government of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The events of April and May, 1861, will be memorable in the history of the Government of the United States. Washington, the seat of its Congress, the residence of its administrative power, was suddenly isolated and cut off from the loyal States, whose industrious and intelligent citizens, by persevering labor and keen business foresight, had carried the nation forward in its unprecedented march to prosperity. A handful of vagabond rebels, by burning the bridges of a single railroad, were enabled to check the political pulsations of a great nation, to spread terror and distrust throughout the region of integrity and loyally and to give strength to a distant rebellion which it otherwise could not have attained.

abstract: We published yesteruay a brief account of the flect of vessels loaded with stone, which are to be used in closing up harbors on the Southern coast. The fleet sailed on the 20th instant; and we give below a list of the vessels composing it, with their tonnage. They are all old, but substantial, whaling vessels, double-decked, to give them greater firmnees.
lead_paragraph: We published yesteruay a brief account of the flect of vessels loaded with stone, which are to be used in closing up harbors on the Southern coast. The fleet sailed on the 20th instant; and we give below a list of the vessels composing it, with their tonnage. They are all old, but substantial, whaling vessels, double-decked, to give them greater firmnees. They were stripped of their copper and other fittings, which were not necessary for so short a voyage as they will make, and loaded with picked stone, as deeply as was safe. They were purchased by the Government at New-Bedford, New-London, Nantucket, Sag Harbor, Edgartown, Mystic and Newport. In the bottom of each ship a hole was bored, into which was fitted a lead pipe five inches in diameter, with a valve so fixed that, though perfectly safe even for a long voyage, it can be very quickly removed. It is calculated that the ship will be filled and sunk to the bottom in twenty minutes after the removal of this valve. To provide against accidental jamming of the valves, each vessel is furnished with two augurs of the proper size.

abstract: The South Carolina soldiers undoubtedly acted according to the ordinary laws of war in retreating from Forts Beauregard and Walker ...
lead_paragraph: The South Carolina soldiers undoubtedly acted according to the ordinary laws of war in retreating from Forts Beauregard and Walker when irresistibly assailed by an overwhelming force; and they acted in accordance with the common impulses of human nature, too, when they quickened their flight to the rapidest possible pace. All this cannot justly be found fault with. But then it is hardly the thing that was to be expected after what we have heard. Every man, woman, child, and chattel, in the Rattlesnake State, was to wage war to the death with the invader at every footstep of his progress, and particularly at his first footstep on to the consecrated soil. The favorite figure was that of a defiant Carolinian, armed cap-a-pie, standing in the last ditch, with a black flag waving over him, while he waged war to the knife, the knife to the hilt, and (as a secession newspaper has it) thence to the shoulder, shouting every now and then, No quarter!

abstract: A new Comedy, called  the "magic marriage", was successfully produced at this house on Thursday evening' when a crowded and intelligent auditory was in attendance to record its verdict.
lead_paragraph: A new Comedy, called the "magic marriage", was successfully produced at this house on Thursday evening' when a crowded and intelligent auditory was in attendance to record its verdict. The work is in three acts, and comes from a modest, it unexperienced, pen, for although the curtain had to be raised at the end of each act in obedience to the flattering behest of the public, the author did not care to make himself known. Mr. LESTER, in a few appropriate remarks on the termination of the piece stated, indeed, that the party's name (lady or gentleman) was unknown to him.

abstract: THE GRAND REVIEW.  The grand and long expected review has at last come off. abstract: The weather having become favorable for curing. Pork packing has been generally carried on to some extent towards the close of the past week. The principal business done has been for the English market, though there has been a steady and remunerative demand for Mess and Clear Pork for shipment to Canada. The Milwaukee packers still purchasing in our market, and the Eastern shippers being moderate purchasers, together with the receipts of Hogs being smaller than was anticipated, prices have been forced higher than at any other point in the West, and the pens have been daily emptied at advancing rates, closing firm at $2 70 to $2 90 gross, with occasional sales at $3. The receipts for the past week and the corresponding period the past three years sum up as follows, viz.: In 1858, live 24,944, dressed 5,347; in 1859, live 15,613, dressed 2,624; in 1860, live 23,448, dressed 307; and in 1861, live 16,245, dressed 42. The low aggregate of our receipts the present week is owing to the fact that the farmers, having plenty of Corn to feed their Hogs, have preferred to keep them on, thinking that the mildness of the weather would prevent packers from operating freely in either live or dressed. As the present rates offer most remunerative returns to the farmers and drovers, we shall, doubtless, have a large increase in our receipts the present week. The rapid decline in Hog products in the New-York market has warned our packers of the danger of present prices for Hogs, and many of them express their intention of allowing their houses to lie idle, rather than incur an almost inevitable loss by continuing packing. Mess Pork has sold freely, at $10 25@$10 50, and Clear, at $12, the principal purchasers being for shipment to Canada. Many of our packers are making Prime Pork, with a view to the consumption of the Shoulders; it is offered at $7 bbl. Prime Mess Pork is offered at $9 50@$10 bbl. without finding buyers. Rump Pork at $6 50@$7. Prime Lard has been sold to a considerable extent for shipment to England, at 7c., and in some instances of straight brands a shade higher; No. 1 has also sold largely, at 6 1/2c. Sales of Yellow Grease have been reported at 5c., but this is considered far beyond the market. There is no demand for Cut Meats, and no quotations yet current. Green Hams and Shoulders have been sold at 3 3/4c. and 2c. lb. For hams there is but a very limited demand, but Shoulders sell freely at quotations. The principal business for the week has been in English Middles, and the principal transaction the sale of 500 boxes Long Boneless Middles, on private terms, (understood to be 5c. lb.) The transactions in Cumberland Cut, Long and Short Middles have not been large, the packers being careless to offer till the price of hogs becomes more settled. The quotations may, however, be given at 4 1/2c. for Cumberland Cut, 5c. for Long and 5 1/4c.@5 7/8c. for Short Rib in. The parking of hogs to the present time sums up about 20,000 head. Only ten houses, however, are yet at work. The market for beef cattle closes dull and lower, the receipts for the last two days being very large. Packing qualities range from $1 50@$2 50 for choice. Extra Mess has been selling at $9 and Mess at $8. No sales of Tierce Beef reported. Prime Tallow is firm and in demand, with large sales at 8c.@8 1/4c. The packing of beef cattle on the Wabash is reported closed for the season, with about 8,000 packed, against about 10,500 last year. Here our packing sums up about 21,000 head.

abstract: The Richmond Whig notices the reorganization of the army of Virginia, which has recently been determined on. The State is to be divided into military departments. The Northern Department, of which Gen. JOHNSTON, is the Commander-in-Chief, comprises the three armies of the Potomac, the Valley, and Acquia. Gen. BEAUREGARD is Commander-in-Chief of the army of the Potomac; Gen. THOMAS (STONEWALL) JACKSON, of the army of the Valley; and Gen. HOLMES, of the army of Aquia. The army corps are abolished. Instead of these, four divisions are to be established in the army of the Potomac. The First Division, which includes, besides infantry and artillery, all the cavalry of the army, is commanded by Gen. VAN DORN, the Second Division is commanded by Gen. G.W. SMITH, the Third Division by Gen. LONGSTREET, and the Fourth Division by Gen. KIRBY SMITH, who has just been made a Major-General.

abstract: There is noting new of special importance from Washington. The reconnoisance to Flint Hill mentioned yesterday, was a very suceessful one  disclosing the fact that the enemy are engaged in constructing an artillery road from that locality in the direction of Germantown.
lead_paragraph: There is noting new of special importance from Washington. The reconnoisance to Flint Hill mentioned yesterday, was a very suceessful one disclosing the fact that the enemy are engaged in constructing an artillery road from that locality in the direction of Germantown. While the reconnoissance was proceeding a large amount of foroge -- some ninety wagon-loads -- was procured. Affairs on the Lower Potomac continue without change. The army is reported to be erecting another battery at "Possum Nose," which is above any of the others.

abstract: Quite an active canvass is going on in Kentucky for Senators in Congress. We presume that JOHN J. CRITTENDEN will return to the seat he has so long honored in that body, where he will be welcomed by those of his old associates who still remain. For the other place Hon. NATHANIEL WOLF and GEO. D. PRENTICE are prominently mentioned. Either of them would do honor to the State in that position.

abstract: The Augusta Constitutionalist, of the 7th inst., says that "we have upon the coast of South Carolina ten or twelve thousand troops, and on that of Georgia eight or ten thousand, in the Confederate service, to repel the invaders. Beside these, Gov. BROWN holds in reserve seven thousand troops raised by him for such an emergency as is now presented. In addition to these, reinforcements are pouring down to the coast. It is to be hoped that the enemy will make an attempt to march to the interior."

abstract: It is a very common figure of speech, to say that in striking a blow at South Carolina, we strike at the heart of the rebellion. The figure is both apt and true.
lead_paragraph: It is a very common figure of speech, to say that in striking a blow at South Carolina, we strike at the heart of the rebellion. The figure is both apt and true. If Slavery be the life-spring of this revolt, here is the largest proportion of slaves; if anti-republicanism, here is the most conceited and swaggering of all aristocracies; if hatred of the North and the Union, here it is pushed to madness; if lust of power, in South Carolina that passion is as wild as it is ungovernable. And that immediate section of the State where our forces now are, is the cor cordium, the very heart of hearts in which all these vile peculiarities have their most intensified existence. The black element there attains its maximum ratio -- reaching in Beaufort District to 80 per cent. of the entire inhabitants, and in other of the seaboard Districts to a still higher figure; while the passions of the haughty nabobs who own these swarming slaves, uncurbed as they are either by law or public opinion, attain an almost uncontrollable development. By divine right they rule their slaves; by prescriptive right they control the legislation of the State; and their voice, through their deputies in the councils of the nation, has always heretofore been supreme. They know no restraint either upon their will or their power.
headline: {'main': 'Southern South Carolina Its Social and Political Character.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Southern South Carolina Its Social and Political Character.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Union men of Alexandria, yesterday, held their election for county and municipal officers, at which good and true Union men were elected to each office. This is a good movement in the right direction, and ought to be promptly followed up in every town and county in Virginia within our lines. That this was an occasion for a gala-dav in Alexandria, among the Union men, may easily be understood.

abstract: There has been a good deal of irregularity in the Provision market, and prices to some extent nominal. There has been a good demand for Lard, and 7 1/4c. was paid on the spot, and 7c. for future delivery for 1,200 tcs. Mess Pork has been in demand at $9 50 for the first half of December delivery, but there are few disposed to enter into contracts. Based upon an advertisement of the Commissary Department of St. Louis for a million and a half pounds of Bacon, to be delivered the next five weeks, an active demand arose for Bacon the last two days of the week, and 390 hhds. sold Monday and yesterday at 5c. for rib sides, and 5 1/2c. for clear do. Shoulders can be bought at 3 3/4c., and sugar cured Hams at the low price of 6c. Nothing done in bulk meats. There has been a fair demand for Green Meats, and about 20,000 pieces sold at 2c. [???] 1/4c. for Shoulders, 3 3/4c. for Sides, and 3 7/8c.@4c. for Hams, the market closing rather dull under the news from New-York, reporting a decline of $1 bbl. in Mess Pork yesterday, quoting it at $12 30@$13 50.

abstract: We are informed that large quantities of flour are stored in this city, and that the holders say they will not sell until they can get $20 per barrel. Comment on these fellows' principles is unnecessary. Desperate measures require desperate remedies, and we hope that the flour will be taken, the men paid a fair market valuation for it, and receive a strong hint to "leave the country for their country's good;" other extortioners whose names are furnished us, and which we shall probably publish for the scorn and execration of the community, have held the staple articles of provisions until they have risen several hundred per cent., and now the "patriots" are fattening upon what they stole from the families of the soldier. Their names always appear conspicuously in the list of donations, but they "give an inch and take an ell."

abstract: It suits the purpose of some of our people to excite alarm by pretending that we are in danger of war with England on account of the seizure of the two rebel agents, MASON and SLIDELL, on board the British mail-steamer Trent.
lead_paragraph: It suits the purpose of some of our people to excite alarm by pretending that we are in danger of war with England on account of the seizure of the two rebel agents, MASON and SLIDELL, on board the British mail-steamer Trent. Nothing can be more absurd than such an apprehension. Even if our act was entirely wrong, there is not one chance in ten of its involving war, whatever other consequences may flow from it. Many persons talk and write as if the instant she hears of it, England would send a fleet of war-steamers to bombard our cities and sweep our commerce from the face of the ocean. Even in the most flagrant cases, national insults are not resented in this summary manner. First comes a formal complaint of the wrong done, and a demand that it be disavowed. If this is met fairly, in a friendly spirit and with an evident intent to do justice, it will be followed by a protracted negotiation, which is almost certain to end in such explanations on the one side, or concessions on the other, as put all hostile measures utterly out of the question.
headline: {'main': 'The Mason and Slidel Affair Absurd Apprehension of War with England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mason and Slidel Affair Absurd Apprehension of War with England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Boston Post informs us that HAMILTON E. TOWLE, the Civil Engineer, who rendered such valuable aid in saving the Great Eastern, is about to make this City his headquarters. We desire to welcome him and express our belief that he will have no occasion to regret coming among us. At such a time as this, however, men of a scientific and practical turn of mind, like Mr. TOWLE, should be in the employ of the Government, especially while skill to plan and ability to execute has so much to do with our national success. We are informed by a gentleman who was a passenger on the big ship, that, so far, the proprietors have in no way recognized the services of Mr. TOWLE.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Post informs us that HAMILTON E. TOWLE, the Civil Engineer, who rendered such valuable aid in saving the Great Eastern, is about to make this City his headquarters. abstract: A BOLD THEFT -- ARREST OF THE THIEVES. -- Thursday afternoon a man named HENRY MALLON entered the sugar store of RAMSEY CROOKS, No. 57 Front-street, and asked to look at a directory. While he was examining it, a confederate came in and began pricing sapar. Mr. CROOKS was the only person in the store at the time besides these two men. While he was engaged in showing samples to his supposed customer, MALLON made his way to the money-drawer, which he robbed of $170 in money and a check for $130. The two soon after left Mr. CROOKS' store, and proceeded to the flour store of DAVID D. CRANE, No. 45 Jay-street, where they pursued a precisely similar game. MALLON obtained from Mr. CRANE's till the sum of $277 in cash, and two checks amounting to $250. Soon after they left the latter place the robberies were discovered, and the Police notified. Yesterday the detectives arrested them. They were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, where Mr. CROOKS identified the two, and Mr. CRANE identified MALLON. The Justice committed them to the Tombs. Neither money nor checks have been recovered.
lead_paragraph: A BOLD THEFT -- ARREST OF THE THIEVES. -- Thursday afternoon a man named HENRY MALLON entered the sugar store of RAMSEY CROOKS, No. 57 Front-street, and asked to look at a directory. abstract: -Upon the invitation of Gov. BRADISH, GEORGE BANCROFT, HAMILTON FISH and other, Rev. Dr. PIERSON, President of Cumberland College, Ky., will give two lectures on the "Private Life of THOMAS JEFFERSON," at living Hall, commencing next Monday evening. The first lecture will be substantially a repetition of the lecture which he gave recently before the Historical Society, and which elicited such warm commendation.

abstract: The above diagram will materially assist the reader in forming a correct idea of the scene of the recent operations in the Kanawha Valley, at the junction of the Gauley and New Rivers.
lead_paragraph: The above diagram will materially assist the reader in forming a correct idea of the scene of the recent operations in the Kanawha Valley, at the junction of the Gauley and New Rivers. On Friday, the 18th inst., it will be recollected, FLOYD made a demonstration against the position of Gen. ROSECRANS, probably with a view to forcing his way through, and forming a junction with the rebel forces in Southeastern Kentucky. By cutting a road through between the mountains, he succeeded in reaching a position, which in a measure commanded the New River, and the National camp at Tompkins Farm, and also the Kanawha River below the junction, together with the road running across the Gauley and along the opposite bank, communicating with Gen. BENHAM's camp further down the Kanawha. He kept up a continuous fire with shot and shell during Friday, but did very little damage -- the only effect being to stop temporarily the transit of baggage-wagons along the road. Meantime the National forces were not idle. During Friday and Friday night they succeeded in getting one or two batteries into position, and on Saturday morning opened upon the rebels with such effect, that by 2 o'clock P.M. they were forced to retire, finding the locality too warm to be agreeable. The fighting was again renewed on Sunday morning, but with similar results. This desultory skirmishing seems to have been continued for several days, FLOYD being driven successively from all his positions excepting Cotton Hill, and this he was finally forced to abandon, measures having been taken to cut off his retreat, by throwing National troops across the New-River at Camp McNeil and across the Kanawha at Camp Hattleston, and he not caring to await so unpleasant an end of his Kanawha campaign. He retreated on the night of the 10th inst., and his movement was not discovered until it was too late to overtake him, although an effort was made to do so. Cotton Hill and all the other positions in the vicinity recently occupied by the enemy are now in the possession of our troops.

abstract: A remarkably line corps of artillery arrived here yesterday morning, in the steamer New-World, en route for Washington. There were four companies of them, consisting in all of 475 men, most of them strong, sturdy looking fellows, apparently well suited for the hard work of compaigning. They have no guns at present, but a majority of them carried sidearms, and were otherwise well equipped. One company is composed entirely of Germans, of whom many are veteran artillerists who have seen rough work in various European services; and these, in default of cannon, were taking along with them their favorite musical instruments upon which to practice in the idle hours of camp life. A man in another company had for a companion a massive and ferocious looking bull-dog which he had insisted upon having enlisted with himself.

abstract: The Second Regiment of New-York State Cavalry, from Troy, arrived in this City yesterday morning, en route for the seat of war. The regiment consists of 800 men, and is to be known as the "Black Horse Cavalry." It is commanded by Col. MORRISON, ...
lead_paragraph: The Second Regiment of New-York State Cavalry, from Troy, arrived in this City yesterday morning, en route for the seat of war. The regiment consists of 800 men, and is to be known as the "Black Horse Cavalry." It is commanded by Col. MORRISON, who has seen service in Mexico, and with LOPEZ, WALKER and GARIBALDI. The men were nearly all enlisted in the rural districts, and are intelligent as well as hardy. They have been two months drilling at Camp Strong, near Troy. Previous to their departure, they were presented with a stand of colors by the ladies of Troy. They embarked on the Francis Skiddy last evening, and arrived here this morning, marching to the Park Barracks through the rain. The men are fully uniformed, but will obtain their horses and equipments in Washington. The following is the list of officers:

abstract: -- Hon. J.J. Chetwood died in Elizabeth, N.J., on the evening of Nov. 18. Mr. Chetwood was born in 1800, and was, consequently, in his sixty-second year at the time of his death. He was educated at Princeton, and shortly after graduating there was, in 1821, admitted to practice as an attorney, and as a counselor in 1825. During the years 1830, 1835 and 1836, he served in the Legislature in the capacity of Member of Assembly, with Judge Hornblower, Joseph N. Tuttle, Esq., and others; and in 1838 was a member of the Senate or "Council" of the State, as it was termed under the old constitution. At the time of his death, and from the period of the formation of Union County, he was Prosecutor of the Pleas for that county. Mr. Chetwood was widely known as an earnest, intelligent and influential member of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and as one of the directors in the New-Jersey Railroad Company. In his own City of Elizabeth, where he has resided for many years, and of which he formed one of the ancient landmarks, he was highly esteemed. In the State at large he was also almost universally known, and perhaps few men had a larger circle of undeviating friends.

abstract: ARREST OF A PHILADELPHIAN. -- A telegraphic dispatch from Washington, received yesterday, stated that the principal in the recent murder of Lieut.-Col. VAN GERBER (which took place in that City on Friday last) had just been arrested in Baltimore. His name was not given. It was stated, however, that his arrest had been secured through the instrumentality of a Philadelphian and a Baltimorean, who, having themselves been apprehended on the charge of committing the deed, had turned State's evidence.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer publishes, for the first time, an official report of the proceedings of the Virginia State Convention last Spring. It is full of interesting developments, we are told, and we wait with some impatience to read the history, and hope they may not be garbled by the authorities there. The chief instruments in the villainy, to force the Conventien to measures, are well-known to have been the Slave dealers -- men who wield a large amount of money, and are very numerous at Richmond, and whose regular business is to buy up the surplus slaves for the supply of the Cotton States. When the latter seceded, there was a law passed putting a tax of $100 upon every slave brought in for sale from a State outside of the then Confederacy -- this was done to operate upon the Border Slave States, from whence all such supplies were derived, and hence the importance to the class alluded to of taking Virginia out by any means -- some of which may be gathered from the following statement, made by a member of the Convention which passed an ordinance for the secession of Virginia, himself a Union man.

abstract: The new Episcopal Church -- to be called St. Paul's -- lately completed, on the corner of Marcy-avenue and Penn-street, Williamsburgh, will be opened for Divine service to-day. The Bishop of the Diocese will preach in the morning, Rev. Dr. GUION in the afternoon, and Rev. Dr. MORGAN (with a full choral service) in the evening. The church is capable of seating 500 persons, and in point of architecture, merit and beauty of design, is one of the first in Brooklyn. The architect is Mr. HENRY DUDLEY, of No. 229 Broadway.

abstract: We have heard a great deal about the bountiful crops at the South the present season. If this were so, the greatest abundance and low prices should prevail at a period when the harvest has just been gathered, and before any consumption can have taken place. But the reverse of abundance is everywhere the case. The burden of every Southern journal ...
lead_paragraph: We have heard a great deal about the bountiful crops at the South the present season. If this were so, the greatest abundance and low prices should prevail at a period when the harvest has just been gathered, and before any consumption can have taken place. But the reverse of abundance is everywhere the case. The burden of every Southern journal or report that reaches us is the prevailing dearth, extortionate prices and conspiracies, as they are termed, of the holders of provisions and merchandise to make the public pay five or ten prices for the necessaries of life. Such holders are denounced in the most savage terms, and if they will not abate their rates the law of the mob is threatened. Every day are the evils complained of growing worse and worse. Famine prices almost everywhere prevail; Winter threatens; the blockade of the South is daily becoming more and more effectual. The question of subsistence, consequently, begins to assume most formidable proportions, and bids fair to become one quite as difficult for the rebels to deal with as the maintenance of the war.

abstract: We publish this morning a full report of JEFF. DAVIS' Message to the rebel Legislature, contained in the Richmond papers of Wednesday last. He finds cause for congratulation in what he calls the success of the Confederate arms, and declares that in men, military means and financial condition, the Confederate States are much stronger now than when the struggle commenced.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a full report of JEFF. DAVIS' Message to the rebel Legislature, contained in the Richmond papers of Wednesday last. He finds cause for congratulation in what he calls the success of the Confederate arms, and declares that in men, military means and financial condition, the Confederate States are much stronger now than when the struggle commenced. He falsely alleges, as a reason for the invasion of Kentucky, that the National forces were about to enter Tennessee over Kentucky soil. He declares that the Union can never be reconstructed, as the causes which primarily induced a separation have been strengthened; characterizes the nature of the hostilities on the part of the United States as barbarous, and denounces the National soldiers as incendiaries and robbers. He glosses over the financial condition of the rebel States in a very hasty and imperfect manner -- evidently considering it a very delicate subject to handle -- and is disposed to apologize for imperfect mail facilities. He of course sees in the capture of Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL on board a British vessel a cause for war between the United States and Great Britain -- declaring that the seizure might with equal propriety have been made in the streets of London. The blockade he pronounces to be totally inefficient, and says that sufficient proof of this fact will be furnished at the proper time. When the proper time will come he does not state, but it will probably be after the arrival on the Southern coast of the "stone fleet," which recently sailed from New-London. On the whole, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS makes a good case for his Southern readers -- his Northern readers he probably cares as little about as he does about telling the truth. He seems, however, to have forgotten to mention the little affair at Port Royal, as we cannot find one word about it in his Message.

abstract: As I telegraphed you FLOYD retreated the night of the skirmish at Cotton Hill, leaving a strong rear guard behind him. Next morning, discovering from our scouts that he had vacated his position, we followed up to Union School-house, still apprehensive that he might attack us, knowing that in point of numbers his force was superior to our own.

abstract: The life-like scenes of the "Whaling Voyage," now on exhibition at Hope Chapel, are attracting the attention of parties who are not easily drawn toward shows of any kind. The panorama, as a means of illustrating travels, has always been held in high esteem, but rarely do we meet with such satisfactory practical episodes as Capt. WILLIAMS favors us with He has in full view before the audience his whaling boat, fully manned with a crew of hardy sailors, and goes through the whole catalogue of manoeuvres incident to capturing a leviathan of the deep. Now they leave their ship's side and bear away toward the school of whales spied out by the man on the "crosstrees." The little or "calf whales" are a sure indication to the sailor that the mother is not far off, for it is a proverb with them that the whale, unlike a fashionable mother, never loses sight of her child. Now the excitement in the boat is intense, as lance after lance is buried in the body of the monster, after all, only sufficient to give it a fright, and cause it to sink out of sight, (for the purpose, probably, of contemplating the position of affairs,) for in some twenty or thirty minutes the continent of a back is seen rising at a distance, and now the chase commences in good earnest, lasting often two days and a night. The exhausted oarsmen are represented falling to sleep as the night deepens, the Captain trying to keep them on the alert with encouragement or threats, but at last his continual "Pull away pull away, boys!" is spoken in a half-waking dream! He rouses himself out of a short nap, and after a moment's soliloquizing compassionately over the faithful fellows drooping upon their oars, he brings them to their feet and their senses simultaneously by a tremendous shout -- "Wake up! Why can't you stay awake, like I do?" Then away goes the poor little "land-lubber," (recently shipped,) over the boat side, head foremost, for a good ducking in the brine, the jolly skipper guiding the movement by a tight hold on the "stern sheets" of the doomed lad. They now sing in fine style a boatman's glee, to try its effect to keep them awake, but Morpheu gets the better of them all again, till daylight and the prospect of a successful haul upon their already crippled prey, incite them to renewed action. We have all phases of whaling voyage experience, from the taking and stripping of a prize worth three thousand dollars, to the loss, after hard chasing, of an equally valuable one -- the joy the first creates, and the wild fury that possesses the cruisers when foiled. The time consumed upon a regular whaling voyage from Nantucket to the North and South Pacific is three years; the number of miles traversed, some forty thousand; and the worth of a good homeward-bound cargo, twenty thousand dollars. To-morrow afternoon the exhibition will be opened for children and schools. No better lessons of the points treated of can be found for them in books.
lead_paragraph: The life-like scenes of the "Whaling Voyage," now on exhibition at Hope Chapel, are attracting the attention of parties who are not easily drawn toward shows of any kind. The panorama, as a means of illustrating travels, has always been held in high esteem, but rarely do we meet with such satisfactory practical episodes as Capt. WILLIAMS favors us with He has in full view before the audience his whaling boat, fully manned with a crew of hardy sailors, and goes through the whole catalogue of manoeuvres incident to capturing a leviathan of the deep. Now they leave their ship's side and bear away toward the school of whales spied out by the man on the "crosstrees." The little or "calf whales" are a sure indication to the sailor that the mother is not far off, for it is a proverb with them that the whale, unlike a fashionable mother, never loses sight of her child. Now the excitement in the boat is intense, as lance after lance is buried in the body of the monster, after all, only sufficient to give it a fright, and cause it to sink out of sight, (for the purpose, probably, of contemplating the position of affairs,) for in some twenty or thirty minutes the continent of a back is seen rising at a distance, and now the chase commences in good earnest, lasting often two days and a night. The exhausted oarsmen are represented falling to sleep as the night deepens, the Captain trying to keep them on the alert with encouragement or threats, but at last his continual "Pull away pull away, boys!" is spoken in a half-waking dream! He rouses himself out of a short nap, and after a moment's soliloquizing compassionately over the faithful fellows drooping upon their oars, he brings them to their feet and their senses simultaneously by a tremendous shout -- "Wake up! Why can't you stay awake, like I do?" Then away goes the poor little "land-lubber," (recently shipped,) over the boat side, head foremost, for a good ducking in the brine, the jolly skipper guiding the movement by a tight hold on the "stern sheets" of the doomed lad. They now sing in fine style a boatman's glee, to try its effect to keep them awake, but Morpheu gets the better of them all again, till daylight and the prospect of a successful haul upon their already crippled prey, incite them to renewed action. We have all phases of whaling voyage experience, from the taking and stripping of a prize worth three thousand dollars, to the loss, after hard chasing, of an equally valuable one -- the joy the first creates, and the wild fury that possesses the cruisers when foiled. The time consumed upon a regular whaling voyage from Nantucket to the North and South Pacific is three years; the number of miles traversed, some forty thousand; and the worth of a good homeward-bound cargo, twenty thousand dollars. To-morrow afternoon the exhibition will be opened for children and schools. No better lessons of the points treated of can be found for them in books.

abstract: The service rendered by the expedition judiciously sent to the Eastern Shore of Virginia by Maj.-Gen. DIX begins to demonstrate itself. So long as the rebels held forcible possession of the peninsula, the supplies the loyal inhabitants were eager to dispose of at Baltimore for the armies in that city and about Washington, were retained at home. The Northern fishermen were driven from the waters, and in fact, if the entire tract had been towed off and anchored somewhere under rebel guns, it could hardly have been more perfectly lost to the Union. To have restored it and made its convenient resources available for the maintenance of our multitudinous soldiery, is a deed hardly less meritorious than others which Gen. DIX has performed in this modern "War of the Public Good," and which will not be forgotten.

abstract: We gratify, this morning, a curiosity which any one will feel, to read the story with which the rebel chief has greeted his newelected Congress. His fiction is not an ingenious one, though very plentiful in lies.
lead_paragraph: We gratify, this morning, a curiosity which any one will feel, to read the story with which the rebel chief has greeted his newelected Congress. His fiction is not an ingenious one, though very plentiful in lies. The military position of the rebels, he tells us, is much stronger than when the struggle commenced -- as they have been driven out of nearly one-half of Virginia and the whole of Missouri; as Maryland has been rendered thoroughly loyal; as Fortress Monroe has been held by us, which effectually commands his own seat of Government; and as a lodgment, with a powerful force, has been made upon the coasts of North and South Carolina, it is hard to see where the rebel strength has been maintained, except about Washington, where their forces have so concentrated that no effectual resistance has been made to the progress of our arms elsewhere.

abstract: The explosion at DUPONT's powder mills, near Wilmington, which was distinctly heard in this city on Wednesday morning, occurred at 11 o'clock. The casualties are said to be three or four men killed, named SAMUEL RUSSELL, CHARLES MULHRIEN and JOHN VIZIER. A fourth man was killed, name unknown. The remains were so blackened and mutilated that their friends could not recognize them. MARTIN DOLAN was near one of the mills, and narrowly escaped. The explosion was the most powerful since the explosion of the powder-wagons in Fourteenth-street, Wilmington, some years ago. It shook many houses in Wilmington violently, and was sensible heard and felt at Point Breeze and Wilmington, but was not felt or heard at Newcastle. The dwelling-houses of the proprietors of the estate are said to be very much damaged, and considerable work and time will be required to put them in repair. The operatives in a manufactory on the opposite side of the Brandywine Creek were terribly affected by the concussion; one of the girls is said to have died from it. The glass was all shattered out of the mill, and some of the machinery displaced. -- Philadelphia Press, Nov. 23.

abstract: ARREST FOR HIGHWAY ROBBERY. JOHN ROHAN, of No. 54 Henry-street, made complaint yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY, whereby he charges that PATRICK MEARA, early yesterday morning, assaulted and knocked him down, on the corner of Madison and Catharine streets. The blows and fall ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST FOR HIGHWAY ROBBERY. JOHN ROHAN, of No. 54 Henry-street, made complaint yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY, whereby he charges that PATRICK MEARA, early yesterday morning, assaulted and knocked him down, on the corner of Madison and Catharine streets. The blows and fall rendered ROHAN helpless for a time, and while lying thus, MEARA robbed him of two hunting-case watches, one gold chain and seal attached, the whole valued at $125. The accused party made his escape at the time, but was soon afterward arrested by Officer ROBB, of the Fourth Precinct, and the Justice committed him to the Tombs in default of bail.

abstract: The bark T. Cushing, of Boston, which arrived at this port, yesterday, from Pernambuco which port she left Oct. 15, reports that when in lat. 12 lon. 45, she saw a fore and aft schooner, painted black with a white streak, and carrying a long pivot gun, and a large number of men on deck. She kept away to board the T. Cushing, but the wind springing up, the privateer was soon left far astern. The brig Lucy Darling, also arrived yesterday, also reports that a wrecking schooner arrived at Nassan, front Abacoa the Captain of which states that a privateer, carrying one large gun amidships, arrived at Abacoa, Nov. 1, for wood and water, with which she was supplied and sailed from there Nov. 4.

abstract: The United States Marshal for Michigan, arrived in this City yesterday morning, by the Hudson River Railroad, having in custody Mr. CHARLES GREEN, bearer of dispatches from the rebel Commissioners in Europe. He was arrested in Detroit, while on his way to Richmond. It appears that he arrived from Europe, via Quebec, and traveled as quietly as possible through Canada and Michigan up to the time of his arrest by the Marshal. Mr. GREEN is an Englishman by birth, and from fifty to fifty-five years of age. He has resided in Savannah, Ga., for the last thirty years, and has relatives living there who have taken a very active part in the rebellion against the Government. His sister, Mrs. LOW, has a son in the celebrated Black Horse Cavalry. Mr. GREEN is believed to be one of the strongest and most zealous Secessionists that has yet been caught. Soon after his arrival here yesterday he was taken in charge of officers to the Police Headquarters in Broome-street where the authorities made a brief examination of the accused and his effects. Later in the day he was conveyed to Fort Lafayette. The dispatches found upon the prisoner are of such a character as to render their publication at the present time improper.

abstract: On Thursday, the Orphans' Court, in Washington, was the scene of excitement. The "Barney Divorce Case" was on trial, when, as appears from the statement of sworn witnesses, Mr. DE KRAFFT, who is conducting the case on behalf of the deceased Mrs. BARNEY, was sitting at one of the desks writing, when the two sons of Mr. BARNEY came into the room, the eldest passing and taking a seat a few feet beyond Mr. DE KRAFFT, whilst the youngest paused as he came opposite Mr. DE KRAFFT, as if to inquire for a seat, when the latter held out his hand as if about to show him one. Just at this moment Mr. BARNEY, who had been sitting some five or six yards to the right of Mr. DE KRAFFT, suddenly rose from his seat, and exclaiming that "it was his child, and he (DE KRAFFT) should not have him," rushed towards the child and endeavored to pull him away from Mr. DE K. The latter rose from his seat at the same moment, and a brief struggle ensued between the two for the possession of the child. Judge PURCELL, who had not observed the first part of the movement, ordered both to resume their seats, which order was at once obeyed by Mr. DE K., the other remaining in a menacing attitude. Judge PURCELL remarked that this disorder in Court had now gone far enough, and he intended to make an example of whoover might prove to be the guilty party in this instance. The evidence of some seven or eight witnesses was taken, and resulted in BARNEY being placed in the custody of the Marshal, and subsequently imprisoned in the County jail for six hours.

abstract: The news of the capture of JAMES S. GREEN by Union troops in Missouri is followed by the announcement of the Ex-Senator's release. It is lamentable that the officer who was wise enough to make the arrest should so soon have followed the discharge of his duty by the discharge of the prisoner. GREEN is a most eligible candidate for quarters in Fort Warren. The most effective labors in the cause of the actual rebellion were those which preceded its actual outbreak. The prostitution of the Senate to the objects of latent, but now patent treason; the character systematically given to its legislation; the predominance of the embryo rebels upon all Committees; the warfare, direct and covert, levied upon every Democrat who, like BENTON, declared against the evident purpose of secession: these were the principal agencies which rendered disunion possible, and neutralized all the counteractive influences of a Republican House of Representatives. Of the men who, in the Senate, gave themselves most unreservedly and arrogantly to this preliminary business, MASON, SLIDELL, GWIN and GREEN, stood foremost -- the latter having rather the advantage of the others in swagger, insolence and shamelessness. That after the mischief was done, and the breach made irreparable, the Missouri Senator became sufficiently alarmed at the impending result to throw his influence at home into the scale of DOUGLAS for the Presidency, in preference to BRECKINRIDGE, serves in no degree to palliate his previous wrong-doing; for the advocacy of DOUGLAS in Missouri was quite as serviceable to the cause of treason as a vote for BRECKINRIDGE in Virginia. GREEN, therefore, while he has not distinguished himself in the ranks of the belligerent rebels, or, like BRIGHT, entitled himself to a commission as Brigadier, has not in any measure impaired his claims to a cell in Fort Warren; and, along with GWIN, should be sent thither, to bear the rebel Ambassadors company. A community of labor claims a community of reward.
lead_paragraph: The news of the capture of JAMES S. GREEN by Union troops in Missouri is followed by the announcement of the Ex-Senator's release. It is lamentable that the officer who was wise enough to make the arrest should so soon have followed the discharge of his duty by the discharge of the prisoner. GREEN is a most eligible candidate for quarters in Fort Warren. The most effective labors in the cause of the actual rebellion were those which preceded its actual outbreak. The prostitution of the Senate to the objects of latent, but now patent treason; the character systematically given to its legislation; the predominance of the embryo rebels upon all Committees; the warfare, direct and covert, levied upon every Democrat who, like BENTON, declared against the evident purpose of secession: these were the principal agencies which rendered disunion possible, and neutralized all the counteractive influences of a Republican House of Representatives. Of the men who, in the Senate, gave themselves most unreservedly and arrogantly to this preliminary business, MASON, SLIDELL, GWIN and GREEN, stood foremost -- the latter having rather the advantage of the others in swagger, insolence and shamelessness. That after the mischief was done, and the breach made irreparable, the Missouri Senator became sufficiently alarmed at the impending result to throw his influence at home into the scale of DOUGLAS for the Presidency, in preference to BRECKINRIDGE, serves in no degree to palliate his previous wrong-doing; for the advocacy of DOUGLAS in Missouri was quite as serviceable to the cause of treason as a vote for BRECKINRIDGE in Virginia. GREEN, therefore, while he has not distinguished himself in the ranks of the belligerent rebels, or, like BRIGHT, entitled himself to a commission as Brigadier, has not in any measure impaired his claims to a cell in Fort Warren; and, along with GWIN, should be sent thither, to bear the rebel Ambassadors company. A community of labor claims a community of reward.

abstract: SERVICES OF A NEW-YORK OFFICER. -- We are indebted to the correspondence of the Cincinnati Gazette for particulars reprinted elsewhere, of the latest and most splendid of FLOYD's successes in the way of masterly retreat. The first days of November found that commander, with his army, overhanging Gen. ROSECRANS' headquarters at Gauley Bridge, and pounding away at the Union troops in camp and along all the roads over which his position could be reached. A clever march of Gen. BENHAM's brigade, obliged him to abandon Cotton Hill, and commence a retrograde movement, closely followed by that active officer. As the felon fled, BENHAM hung upon his rear, cutting off CROGAN's cavalry, and slaying CROGAN himself, and gathering up the arms and baggage the fugitives abandoned in their terror-stricken haste. There seems to be little doubt that FLOYD's command would have been utterly annihilated, had not the pursuit been arrested by orders forwarded by ROSECRANS.

abstract: The anxiety of the Washington authorities to check communication with Richmond is not unreasonable. The San Jacinto, with Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Friday, Nov. 15; the tidings of the capture was telegraphed from Baltimore to Washington and New-York on the following day. On Tuesday, Nov. 19, the facts were formally submitted to the Confederate Congress by President DAVIS, and made the topic of comment. How long they had already been known at Richmond it is impossible to say. But, as it has required three days for the Richmond papers of Wednesday, the 20th, to reach Washington, we may presume the same time would be needed for the transmission of intelligence in the opposite direction; and that the news of the capture took some shorter cut. Two among the earliest dispatches received in New-York may explain the matter:

abstract: The expected visit of the Merrimac, and the attack on Newport's News, are the topics of conversation. The Merrimac is said to be ready; and four prisoners arrived on board the storeship Release. I learn that the sloops-of-war Germantown and plymouth are likewise raised and have their new masts in them. Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH and the fleet around here are anxious for a visit from them, to show and follow up the merits of our navy.

abstract: COMPLICITY OF THE CHURCH PARTY WITH SPAIN. -- Our latest intelligence from Mexico is not of so sombre a character as usual. The total defeat of MARQUEZ has given additional stability to the Constitutional Government, and the prospect of having peace and order reestablished throughout the Republic is becoming more cheering. Rumors of the contemplated European expedition have reached the Capital, but seem to have caused very little apprehension. Certain Mexicans think that if the Allies are unreasonable, the people will arouse themselves, and that, though on the sea-board the country will be powerless, in the interior the invaders could be put to trouble. The men, however, who hold to this opinion must know little of the real state of matters. They fancy, evidently, that the masses are unanimous, and that if Mexico were assailed, all would turn out to defend her liberties. But would such be the case? The complicity of the leaders of the Church Party with Spain promises little for the patriotism of that faction; and the recent arrest of MUNOZ LEDO, MIRAMON's Minister of State, has placed the treason and guilt of those leaders beyond question. Papers seized at LEDO's residence prove that himself, ALMONTE, MIRAMON, and other prominent chiefs of the clerical sort, determining to ruin their country since they could not rule it, had solicited Spanish intervention, and had consented that the Mexican Republic should be overthrown and a monarchy established on its ruins. A party, whose coryphoei have played so infamous a part, will make but sorry defenders of Mexican liberties. They will be much more likely to be found, when the crisis arrives, among her enemies than among her patriots.

The complicity of the leaders of the Church Party with Spain promises little for the patriotism of that faction; and the recent arrest of MUNOZ LEDO, MIRAMON's Minister of State, has placed the treason and guilt of those leaders beyond question. A party, whose coryphoei have played so infamous a part, will make but sorry defenders of Mexican liberties. They will be much more likely to be found, when the crisis arrives, among her enemies than among her patriots.

abstract: When Gen. MEIGS was here on a recent visit, he issued proposals for the supply of army cloths. This plan, we understand, was proposed by one of the leading commission houses in this city. The main object on the part of the originators was to test the capacity of our manufacturers. The bids have not yet been declared, although they were to have been opened at Philadelphia on the 15th. It is undoubtedly owing to the fact that the object was known, that many of our leading manufacturers did not send in bids.

abstract: I have lately returned from England, where I have had opportunities to inform myself about the coming Exhibition. As I took an active interest in the Great Exhibition of 1851, and as since that time I have been engaged in such business in England as to ...
lead_paragraph: I have lately returned from England, where I have had opportunities to inform myself about the coming Exhibition. As I took an active interest in the Great Exhibition of 1851, and as since that time I have been engaged in such business in England as to bring me into constant intercourse with its most enterprising men, and to make me familiar with its daily industrial life, I have thought that I might add something, in a plain way, to the information you already possess in regard to what it is best to send to the Exhibition of 1862.

abstract: - There is a barge lying at the foot of Third-street, into which workmen are busily engaged putting box after box of mill machinery for spinning and weaving cotton. There will be a sufficiency of machinery to fill two barges -fully 100 tons -- which Capt. PINK VARBLE, with his towboat Pink Varble, will tow down the Ohio River to the mouth of the Cumberland, and then up that stream into the State of Tennessee to the point where the machinery is to be set up. This machinery consists of some eighty cotton looms for the manufacture of common domestic. It was manufactured in Paterson, N.J., and has been in this city some three months or more, waiting a permit to ship. The permit has arrived at last, and the machinery, valued at $50,000, will go forward about Monday or Tuesday. It is for the McMinnville Manufacturing Company, at McMinnville, Tenn., on the Cumberland River, about 105 miles east of Nashville. Capt. PINK will have a good job of going. -- Louisville Democrat, Nov. 16.

It was manufactured in Paterson, N.J., and has been in this city some three months or more, waiting a permit to ship. The permit has arrived at last, and the machinery, valued at $50,000, will go forward about Monday or Tuesday. It is for the McMinnville Manufacturing Company, at McMinnville, Tenn., on the Cumberland River, about 105 miles east of Nashville. Capt. PINK will have a good job of going. -- Louisville Democrat, Nov. 16.

abstract: Gen. HALLECK was born in 1816, on the Mohawk River, a few miles west of Utica, Oneida County, N.Y. He is of German descent on his mother's side, being a grandson of HENRY WAGER, a near neighbor and personal friend of Baron STEUBEN, and one of the first settlers of Central New-York.
lead_paragraph: Gen. HALLECK was born in 1816, on the Mohawk River, a few miles west of Utica, Oneida County, N.Y. He is of German descent on his mother's side, being a grandson of HENRY WAGER, a near neighbor and personal friend of Baron STEUBEN, and one of the first settlers of Central New-York. On his father's side he is a descendant of PETER HALLOCK, of Hallock's Neck, near Southold, Long Island. The family name in England was originally Hallyoak, being now written Halliock, Hallock and Halleck. It is traced back to the Lords of Alnwick Castle, which, with "gallant Hotspur and his gentle Kate;" has been immortalized by the poetical genius of FITZ-GREENE HALLECK, a relative of Gen. HALLECK.

abstract: The work on the Mormon Temple, according to resolutions passed at the Conference last month, has been recommenced. Not that the foundations thereof have been exhumed they still lie "cached," buried, as they have since the Fall of '57. But other signs are visible. The rock is being hauied from the quarry and the masons are busy with the chisel and mallet.

abstract: -Information has been received by the United States authorities from ALCARDE HUTCHINSON, Esq., United States Deputy Consul at Singapore, concerning an assault committed on GEORGE ANDERSON one of the crew of the American ship Connecticut, then lying at Saigon, Cochin China. It appears that two of the crew, ANDERSON and JOHN SMITH, got into a fight, and that CHARLES DAID, a chum of SMITH's, seeing him down, rushed in and stabbed ANDERSON with a knife. The wound was a very severe one, and for three weeks the life of ANDERSON was in danger from it. DAID was taken in custody by the French authorities, on the application of the Captain of the Connecticut, and sent to Singapore, where he was put in prison. Subsequently, by order of the American Consul at that port, he -- with SMITH and JAMES WALKER as witnesses of the affair -- was put on board the bark Rocket, bound for Boston. The Rocket sailed from Penang Sept. 9, and will be due here in January. -- Boston Journal, Nov. 18.

abstract: Notices have been issued in the Dutch West India Colonies, warning all the subjects of His Majesty of Holland to observe a strict neutrality during the existing difficulties in the States of America, to respect any actual blockade, not to carry contraband of war, or convey dispatches for either of the belligerent parties, and in particular to avoid having anything to do with privateering, as those who engage in it may be looked upon by foreign nations as pirates, and will be liable to the penalties provided by the law of Holland. Instructions have also been issued to the effect that, for the observance of a strict neutrality, to privateers, under whatever flag, or with whatever commissions or letters-of-marque provided, and with or without prizes, shall be admitted to the harbors or roads, except in case of distress, and, under any circumstances, all such privateers and their prizes are to be closely watched, and be made put to sea again as soon as possible.
lead_paragraph: Notices have been issued in the Dutch West India Colonies, warning all the subjects of His Majesty of Holland to observe a strict neutrality during the existing difficulties in the States of America, to respect any actual blockade, not to carry contraband of war, or convey dispatches for either of the belligerent parties, and in particular to avoid having anything to do with privateering, as those who engage in it may be looked upon by foreign nations as pirates, and will be liable to the penalties provided by the law of Holland. Instructions have also been issued to the effect that, for the observance of a strict neutrality, to privateers, under whatever flag, or with whatever commissions or letters-of-marque provided, and with or without prizes, shall be admitted to the harbors or roads, except in case of distress, and, under any circumstances, all such privateers and their prizes are to be closely watched, and be made put to sea again as soon as possible.

abstract: We have taken occasion more than once to commend to public favor the objects for which the Sanitary Commission was organized, and the generous zeal with which they entered upon their discharge. Unless, however, we ...
lead_paragraph: We have taken occasion more than once to commend to public favor the objects for which the Sanitary Commission was organized, and the generous zeal with which they entered upon their discharge. Unless, however, we mistake indications in various quarters, the gentlemen who have the direction of its affairs, are in some danger of greatly impairing if not wrecking its usefulness by neglecting their proper sphere of duty and meddling mischievously with matters which are already in competent and experienced hands. We hear serious complaints that the Commission has become less attentive and efficient in what was, at the outset, regarded as its special field of effort, -- attention to the sanitary condition of the soldiers in camp, and its bitten by the ambition of superseding, or at least remodeling, the established Medical Bureau of the regular army. We have hitherto suppressed the representations that have reached its on this subject, lost we might throw impediments in the way of their usefulness. But the appearance in some of the public journals of articles written in the interest of their ambition, rather than of their real utility, leads us to depart somewhat from the course we had hoped to be able to pursue.

abstract: The military complexion of the day is caught up and mirrored very faithfully by our publishers. Of the new books published, there are very few which do not either directly or remotely bear on the war. The popular craving is to sniff battles, in books, if no nearer.
lead_paragraph: The military complexion of the day is caught up and mirrored very faithfully by our publishers. Of the new books published, there are very few which do not either directly or remotely bear on the war. The popular craving is to sniff battles, in books, if no nearer. We wish to be told stories of armies and of sieges; the dull themes of peace have lost all charm to stir the blood. SORIBNER avails himself of this military moment to publish new editions of two very well known works, by JOEL T. HEADLEY, The Old Guard of Napoleon, and The Life of Havelock. It would be impossible to tell the story of the Old Guard in an uninteresting way. Mr. HEADLEY's graphic pen has lent to it an interest passing that of romance. Were it not for the evidence of history, the render would refuse to believe that such men as composed this famous guard ever existed, classing them with the fabulous heroes of antiquity. It were worth a life to see them in one of their marvelous charges, sweeping as a huge wave crested with steel across the field, dashing the cannoneers from opposing batteries, and hurling battalions out of their path as the surf does pebbles. Never was the Guard called upon until there was need of their services -- never did they fail to respond to the call. When his army wavered under a scathing fire, and the tide of battle seemed turning in favor of the enemy, then it was that NAPOLEON would call upon his "column of granite" to redeem the day. And they generally did it. Through the thickest of the iron hail, let it beat fiercely as it might, they bore their conquering eagles; and their bear-skin caps, wherever they appeared, were an assurance of victory. Only once did they fail in turning the tide of battle at the critical moment, and then they did not surrender. Faithful to their boast, they died. Many a reader, as he hangs over their achivements and thinks of the sore need our country has for such iron hearts will sigh, "Oh, for an Old Guard." In regard to Mr. HEADLEY's other book, a Christian soldier is such a rarity in actual life, that the character of that noble soldier and accomplished gentleman, HAVELOCK, would interest for its novelty alone.

abstract: On Thursday evening last, the second annual exhibition of that excellent institution, the Artists Fund Society, was inaugurated by a private view of the works contributed, which are now on view for ...
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening last, the second annual exhibition of that excellent institution, the Artists Fund Society, was inaugurated by a private view of the works contributed, which are now on view for the public, at the Studio building in Tenth-street. The purpose of the Society is to accumulate a fund from which aid may be extended to members in sickness and distress, and to the widows and families of deceased members. Voluntary contributions, with this view, are tendered by the artists in general, and the works, after being placed on exhibition for about four weeks, are sold for the benefit of the fund.

abstract: Everything indicates a very good chance of clecting GEORGE OPDYKE for Mayor.
lead_paragraph: Everything indicates a very good chance of clecting GEORGE OPDYKE for Mayor. He has received the nominations of all the leading organizations of Unionists, and has a very strong support among the Germans. The impression of WOOD'S invincibility, moreover, is dying out. He lacks now many very important elements of strength which he has always had hitherto. Many very sagacious and judicious politicians believe his vote will be less than GUNTHER'S, and that the contest is really between the latter and OPDYKE. We have no doubt that the Tammany candidate will withdraw the Democratic vote from WOOD much more largely than has ever been done before.

abstract: An intelligent and public-spirited gentleman, who has just returned from England, states, as the result of his personal observation, that the New-York Herald is doing infinitely more to advance the rebel cause abroad than all the agents, official and unofficial, who have gone thither upon that service.
lead_paragraph: An intelligent and public-spirited gentleman, who has just returned from England, states, as the result of his personal observation, that the New-York Herald is doing infinitely more to advance the rebel cause abroad than all the agents, official and unofficial, who have gone thither upon that service. For the last two months its columns have teemed with denunciations, threats and insults, to the English Government, which, coupled as they are with an ostentatiously fulsome support of the Administration, are universally regarded there as indicating a settled purpose on the part of our Government to provoke a war with England, at whatever hazard and by whatever means. The ingenuity with which the Herald has prosecuted this incendiary work is only rivaled by its pertinacity. It has seized upon every possible occasion, -- and resorted to every conceivable device, -- to sting the sensibilities, wound the pride, repel the sympathy and alarm the fears of the English people. It began by recommending, day after day, the instant march of an army into Canada, under the preposterous and shallow pretext that the South would instantly join us in such an enterprise, and that thus we should end the rebellion. It has announced repeatedly that England's opposition to Slavery justifies us in declaring war against her, -- that we are already at war, -- that we have now a military force on foot which it would be folly not to use to crush her rivalry, -- that we shall certainly thus employ it, after our domestic rebellion is suppressed, if not before, -- and that all the arguments we need offer her on any subject of difference are cannon-balls and men-of-war. And in all this the Herald pretends to speak the sentiments of the Government, -- claiming that "Mr. SEWARD and the Herald" are acting in harmony on this subject, and demanding that all who oppose this policy or doubt its wisdom shall be sent to Fort Lafayette, as enemies of the Government and especially hostile to the Administration.

abstract: The amusements for the week, if not altogether fresh, are, at least, varied. At the Winter Garden Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS revive the legendary drama of "All Hallow's Eve," playing, in addition thereto, a couple of their most popular pieces.
lead_paragraph: The amusements for the week, if not altogether fresh, are, at least, varied. At the Winter Garden Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS revive the legendary drama of "All Hallow's Eve," playing, in addition thereto, a couple of their most popular pieces. At Mr. WALLACK's Theater the new comedy called the "Magic Marriage" enters upon its second week. At LAURA KENNE's the "Seven Sons" display their new coat of words, which fits about as awkwardly as the first one; and at BARNUM's the "Angel of Midnight" -- a remarkably powerful melodrama -- is played afternoon and evening to the best houses of the city. This programme bids fair to remain unchanged for some time. There will be morning performances at most of the theaters on Thanksgiving, and also at HOOLEY's Minstrels, (Stuyvesant Hall,) where an excellent minstrel company can be heard every evening. The panorama of a Whaling Voyage, at Hope Chapel, is attracting the attention it merits, and will speedily become one of the best-attended entertainments in the city. The Parisian Cabinet is also worthy of a visit.

abstract: There was nothing warlike about the speech of Mr. ADAMS, and, as he took great pains to tell us that it was wrong to suppose diplomatists ever say the thing which is not, we are bound to believe that he is fully empowered to meet with cordiality all those peaceful sentiments which seemed to fill the Guildhall last Saturday.
lead_paragraph: There was nothing warlike about the speech of Mr. ADAMS, and, as he took great pains to tell us that it was wrong to suppose diplomatists ever say the thing which is not, we are bound to believe that he is fully empowered to meet with cordiality all those peaceful sentiments which seemed to fill the Guildhall last Saturday. In some most important respects, Mr. ADAMS's speech might have been made five years ago. There is not one word about civil war, or battles on the Potomac, or blockade of Southern ports. He does not even tell us that there are some bad fellows among his countrymen, or advise us to have no intercourse with them. We ought to congratulate ourselves on this, for Mr. ADAMS assumes us that the only fault possibly to be attributed to American diplomacy is, that it might sometimes be thought too open, free, and careless; so that if there had been anything of the least importance likely to arise out of those matters he would not have entirely omitted them. Mr. Adams's speech was so highly complimentary that we could wish America could speak more frequently to us by the mouth of her Minister, and never at all in the tone common to her Press and her Secretary of State, Mr. ADAMS ran through our whole history, from Prince ARTHUR to FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE, and claimed to annex it all. We are only delighted to find from Mr. ADAMS, speaking in all his candor, that we are on such excellent terms, and that as between us and America the civil war and the blockade are literally not worth mentioning.

abstract: The wise policy of the Administration is beginning to tell upon the rebels.
lead_paragraph: The wise policy of the Administration is beginning to tell upon the rebels. The steadiness with which it has held still on the Potomac, while its vigorous preparations have drawn the whole force and attention of the rebels to that quarter, has given tremendous force to the blows it is now striking at the very heart of the rebellion on its Southern Coasts. The various extracts we have given from rebel journals, show conclusively that these blows were unexpected, -- that they have carried consternation into the rebel camp, and that they are certain to have a very marked effect upon the policy which the rebel leaders will pursue.

abstract: Recruiting has improved, though not to a very great extent. The enlistments in, New-York for the regular army, during the week ending Oct. 23, amount to twelve men and twelve boys. Several applicants were rejected upon being examined by the Doctor.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting has improved, though not to a very great extent. The enlistments in, New-York for the regular army, during the week ending Oct. 23, amount to twelve men and twelve boys. Several applicants were rejected upon being examined by the Doctor. Detachments of recruits, enlisted in Buffalo and Rochester, arrived on Saturday, and were transferred to Governor's Island, where they will be drilled for general service. Before being attached to any company, the newly-arrived recruits are kept in the tents on the north side of the island for several days, and complain very much of the cold.
