abstract: The prize brig Delta, of Liverpool, (formerly the W.M. Rice, of Boston,) in charge of Acting Master RODGERS, and Master's Mate SEWALL, from Galveston Bar, twenty-five days, arrived here yesterday. She was taken off Galveston by the United States frigate Santee.
lead_paragraph: The prize brig Delta, of Liverpool, (formerly the W.M. Rice, of Boston,) in charge of Acting Master RODGERS, and Master's Mate SEWALL, from Galveston Bar, twenty-five days, arrived here yesterday. She was taken off Galveston by the United States frigate Santee. The crew were sent to this port on board the steamer Rhode Island. The captain reported the Delta as from Liverpool for Minititlan, with a cargo of salt, and was running into Matamoras when taken. The Delta has on board the crew and cargo of the schooner Annie Taylor, from the West Indies, taken by the steamer South Carolina off Galveston, and now used as a tender. She had 200 bags of coffee and 100,000 cigars on board.

abstract: The British men-of-war Sanspareil, Donegal and Conqueror, having embarked 800 marines at Ply-  mouth, were to have sailed on the 10th, for the Gulf of Mexico, but were prevented by stormy weather.
lead_paragraph: The British men-of-war Sanspareil, Donegal and Conqueror, having embarked 800 marines at Ply- mouth, were to have sailed on the 10th, for the Gulf of Mexico, but were prevented by stormy weather. They, however, left Plymouth Sound on the 13th inst., about noon, with the expeditianary battalions of marines for Mexico, the wind blowing half a gale.

abstract: The few weeks which have elapsed since your adjournment, have brought us so near the close of the year that we are now able to sum up its general results. The retrospect is such as should fill the hearts of our people with gratitude to Providence for Ilis kind interposition in their behalf.
lead_paragraph: The few weeks which have elapsed since your adjournment, have brought us so near the close of the year that we are now able to sum up its general results. The retrospect is such as should fill the hearts of our people with gratitude to Providence for Ilis kind interposition in their behalf. Abundant yields have rewarded the labor of the agriculturist, whilst the manufacturing industry of the Confederate States was never so prosperous as now. The necessities of the times have called into existence new branches of manufactures, and given a fresh impulse to the activity of those heretofore in operation. The means of the Confederate States for manufacturing the necessaries and comforts of life within themselves increase as the conflict continues, and we are gradually becoming independent of the rest of the world for the supply of such military stores and munitions as are indispensable for war.

abstract: MORRIS MEYER, the Broadway merchant who was committed to Fort Lafayette on the 18th inst., on the ground of his accession proclivities, has been set at liberty by the direction of the Secretary of State. At the time of his incarceration there was much sympathy exciled in his behalf, and many doubted if he had been guilty of anything worthy of bonds. Superintendent KENNEDY'S orders from the State Department were, however, of such a character as to admit of no discretion as to the disposition of his prisoner, and he was therefore committed. MEYER claimed to be a strong Union man, and his numerous influential friends in the city insisted that he ought not to be sent to prison. Mr. KENNEDY immediately wrote to Mr. SEWARD, setting forth the facts, and stating his belief that young MEYER was not a man who would do any harm to the Union cause. The Secretary very promptly sent an order for his release.

abstract: The Scotia, the latest and most magnificent of the line of Cunard Royal Mail steamers, is approaching completion on the Clyde. The general dimensions of the ship are as follows: Length of keel and forerake, 360 feet; length over all, 400 feet; breadth of mould, 47 feet; and depth, 32 feet. In the construction of the hull, the most modern improvements have been introduced, towards enabling her to afford as great resisting powers as possible to the combined influences of storms and winds. The keel is composed of several bars of iron, each 35 feet in length, firmly joined together by scarves, the whole being 14 inches in depth, and 4 inches thick. The framework is of the strongest description. Amidships it consists of plates of 4-angle iron, running up to the gunwale and towards the stem and stern, while the other portions of the hull are constructed in the usual way. Owing to the arrangement of the plates, the framework is very heavy, but the amount of strength secured will be increasedly great. The frame of the bow is built diagonally, so that in the case of a collision, or contact with a rock or iceberg, the strain would fall upon the very strongest material of which the ship is composed. The Scotia would thus have a double good chance of safety, and of a successful resistance to accident, while other vessels would be in peril. In addition also to the kelsons and girders of a usual frame, others of a novel character have been introduced in order to give a superior resisting power. The Scotia is not clinker built, but the plates are laid on alternately, and in such a manner as to impart wonderful compactness and solidity to the hull. The plates at the keel are 1-16th of an inch in thickness; at the bottom of the ship they are 15-16ths of an inch, from the load watermark they are 7-8ths, and above that they are one inch in thickness. The hull consists of seven water-tight compartments. The cargo of the vessel is to be stowed in two of these divisions, 75 feet each in length, 20 in breadth, and 20 in height. These tanks are built in the centre line of the ship and are capable of receiving 500 tons measurement of cargo. They are completely water-tight, and in the event of an accident to the hull would of themselves be sufficient to keep the ship afloat. The vessel, in fact, has a double bottom under the tanks for the stowage of the goods so that if the outer shell were beaten in or strained, the inner would preserve the cargo intact. The coal bunkers are placed on each outer side of these tanks, and are made to contain 1,800 tons of coal. The engines, which are of 883-horse power, are on the side-lever principle, with two cylinders of 100 inches diameter each and 12 feet stroke of piston. The apparatus for starting the engines is also constructed so that the operation will be comparatively easy. The paddles measure 40 feet 8 inches in diameter over the rings. The accommodation for passengers is in harmony with the splendid general capacity of the ship. She has 157 cabins, affording sleeping accommodation to 300 passengers. These cabins are each 9 feet in height, which, with the excellent system of ventilation introduced, will render them airy and healthy. Surmounting the main deck there is a deck-house, the roof of which forms a promenade from stem to stern. The saloons will afford dining accommodation for above 300 persons. When the Scotia was launched her weight was about 2,800 tons, but now that the heavy weight of her machinery is on board, she is about 4,000 tons, and draws 20 feet of water.

abstract: MILITARY FUNERAL. The remains of privates JAMES SEYMOUR and WALTER G. TAYLOR, members of Company G, Fourteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., who were killed on Monday last in a skirmish with the ...
lead_paragraph: MILITARY FUNERAL. The remains of privates JAMES SEYMOUR and WALTER G. TAYLOR, members of Company G, Fourteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., who were killed on Monday last in a skirmish with the rebel cavalry, near Falls Church, were brought to this City on Friday last, and were yesterday interred with military honors. The funeral took place at the Washington street M.E. Church, at 2 o'clock P.M. the church and all the street in front of it was crowded with people who desired to pay the last sad rite of respect to the honored dead. After a prayer, Rev. J.S. INSKIP, Chaplain of the Fourteenth Regiment, delivered a brief and appropriate address, when the bodies were removed to hearses in waiting at front of the church, and they were escorted to Greenwood Cemetery in the following order:

abstract: Does not "President" JEFFERSON DAVIS know that the feuds and factions of the Confederate chiefs are an unendurable scandal, and likely to work mischief among the devoted believers in the South, and contempt in the eyes of the world? Is he blind to the fact ...
lead_paragraph: Does not "President" JEFFERSON DAVIS know that the feuds and factions of the Confederate chiefs are an unendurable scandal, and likely to work mischief among the devoted believers in the South, and contempt in the eyes of the world? Is he blind to the fact that a band of pure patriots, engaged, as he grandly says in his Message, in the sacred work of "winning liberty, through the unconquerable will to be free," look to the outside world no better than a gang of robbers, brawling and bickering over the division of the spoils? There's BEAUREGARD -- the beau sabreur el beau soldat -- publicly, and in official documents, censuring the Presidential policy, and determined either to Winter in Baltimore or go home! There is Brigadier-General W.H.T. WALKER, of Georgia, throwing up his commission, and declaring that he will "fight for the sacred cause in his native State, but will not condescend to submit any longer to the insults and indignities of the Executive." At this, Mr. BENJAMIN, the Secretary of War, rebukes him for his insolence, both to himself and to the President; whereupon the irate WALKER rejoins that the Secretary, "in trying to preserve his own self-respect, will lose the respect of the country!" Here is a pretty quarrel for you, and a scandal unworthy of any well-regulated family!

abstract: The December magazines are here slightly in advance of the frosts and snow of the month. Harper's chooses the auspicious moment for commencing its twenty-fourth volume. The publishers shake hands with the public over the cover, ...
lead_paragraph: The December magazines are here slightly in advance of the frosts and snow of the month. Harper's chooses the auspicious moment for commencing its twenty-fourth volume. The publishers shake hands with the public over the cover, and indulge in a little talk. Pointing to the past, they make brave promises for the future. Neither labor nor expense is to be spared to enrich and illuminate their pages, the circle of contributors is to be enlarged yet more, and, in fact, there is no telling how good the Magazine is to be. It may yet be deemed worthy of translation. The present number contains three illustrated articles: "The Court Rangers of California," by J. Ross BROWNE. "The Philadelphia Mint," by WALDO ABBOTT; and "The Okavango River," an interesting article made from the new book of that name by A.H. GUERNSEY -- these compilations of new books, by the way, form an admirable feature of the Magazines. Then we have "A Wife's Story," by LOUISE CHANDLER MOULTON; "Mount Victory," by ALICE B. HAVEN; a continuation of ANTHONY TROLLOPE's "Orley Farm," illustrated by MILLAIS; "The Reign of Sultan ABDUL-MEDJID," by Dr. WILLIAM GOODELL; "Still Unknown," a poem by Mrs. R.H. STODDARD; "Mr. and Mrs. Meyer," by NORA PERRY; a spirited poem by WM. Ross WALLACE, entitled "A Psalm of the Union;" two more chapters of THACKERAY's "Phillip;" "Col. BAKER," by JOHN HAY, the private Secretary of President LINCOLN and biographer of ELLSWORTH; "Blue Yarn Stockings," and the inevitable Editors' Chair, Table, Bureau, and Drawer, furnish the concluding pages.

abstract: The German Republican Central Committee met at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at the Steuben House, Bowery. Mr. TSCHZIRNER, in the absence of the regular President, Mr. A. WILLMANN, in the Chair, ...
lead_paragraph: The German Republican Central Committee met at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at the Steuben House, Bowery. Mr. TSCHZIRNER, in the absence of the regular President, Mr. A. WILLMANN, in the Chair, and Messrs. C.F. STEINHEIMER and H. RICHARD, Secretaries. The meeting was large and animated, and the best feeling prevailed, all present agreeing that the chances in favor of Mr. GEORGE OPDYKE, their candidate for the Mayoralty, were hourly increasing, and that only a determined and vigorous effort is now necessary to insure his election.

abstract: After the head of that sickening column rested at the Orchard Springs we still had a hope that somehow or other the leaders would be able to account for that fearful retreat, but that hope has now expired. abstract: A very interesting meeting was held yesterday morning at Public School No. 35, in Thirteenthstreet, in the Fifteenth Ward, on the occasion of reopening it after the enlargement and reconstruction of the building.
lead_paragraph: A very interesting meeting was held yesterday morning at Public School No. 35, in Thirteenthstreet, in the Fifteenth Ward, on the occasion of reopening it after the enlargement and reconstruction of the building. It is now one of the most spacious and admirable of the school edifices in the City. The school has always borne a very high reputation under the successive supervision of Messrs. DOANE, SMITH, and HUNTER, and has sent, we believe, more pupils to the Free Academy (over 500 in all) than any other of our City schools.

abstract: The United States Paymaster, Col. STEWART, went to Governor's Island on Saturday last to pay the recruits for the two months ending the 31st of October.
lead_paragraph: The United States Paymaster, Col. STEWART, went to Governor's Island on Saturday last to pay the recruits for the two months ending the 31st of October. The regulation, to which we referred a few days ago, that one half of the pay of recruits is to be retained until they are assigned to a regiment, we carried out, and, in consequence, many of the men refused to receive their pay, doubtless in the expectation that their refusal will lead to the canceling of the obnoxious regulation, which is not a new one, although it has not been in force during the last few years.

abstract: The rebel Congress, according to a report forwarded from Baltimore, has authorized the seat of the insurgent government to be transferred to Nashville. The Congress, it is added, will presently adjourn to reassemble there. This legislation is the slow fulfillment of an old promise.
lead_paragraph: The rebel Congress, according to a report forwarded from Baltimore, has authorized the seat of the insurgent government to be transferred to Nashville. The Congress, it is added, will presently adjourn to reassemble there. This legislation is the slow fulfillment of an old promise. Last Spring, when the fate of the Border States was still uncertain, the location of the Confederate capital was a bribe, with which it was attempted to allure each in turn. Virginia, as the most essential to the project of capturing the National capital, wasfirst caught with the bait, and the capital was removed from Montgomery to Richmond. Tennessee was next wanted, and Kentucky and Missouri were sure to follow the lead ofTennessee; and no sooner was Virginia first deceived, and then fairly subjugated by the Confederate army, than the offer was made for the final location of the Capital at Nashville. It is difficult to over-estimate the efficacy of this dazzling temptation in procuring the almost unanimous vote of Middle Tennessee for secession. Tennessee was bought; but Missouri hesitated, and what was worse, Kentucky absolutely refused to follow. This failure of a plot otherwise excellent, rendered it both unsafe and impolitic to remove to Nashville. That city was too near a hostile frontier. By railroad and river it was easily accessible to attacks from the swarming loyalists of the Northwestern States; and, indeed, so long as the main military strength of the rebellion was grouped before Washington, it would have been in the last degree reckless to have confided the rebel executive and legislature to the protection of BUCKNER's ill-organized, unprovided, and sickly mob of misnamed soldiery.

abstract: The examination in the case of the crew of the bark Augusta, who were arrested a week ago at Fire Island, has been brought to a close before United States Commissioner HARVEY, without elicting anything tending to criminate the prisoners, or to explain the nature of the intended cruise of the Augusta. Immediately on their being discharged by the Commiisioner, they were taken into custody by Marshal MURRAY, and, in obedience to orders from Washington, were sent to Fort Lafayette, where the owner of the bark, Mr. APPLETON OAKSMITH, is now confined. The reasons for sending them to Fort Lafayette have not transpired, but it is said that the Marshal has evidence in his possession indicating that the Augusta was bound on a privateering cruise. The names of the prisoners, of whom there are seventeen, have already been published.

abstract: A bright and effective Irish drama, flavored with a whisky still, an abduction case, and a sprig of shillaleh, was revived here last evening by Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS. It is called "All Hallow Eve," and has before been made known to our audiences. The ingredients we have mentioned are skillfully mixed into a plot, which, if not strong, is at least exhilarating; the principal characters being of course played by Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS, and with all the vivacity and heartiness which usually characterizes their impersonations. The remaining parts are well distributed; but the proprietor of the still seemed to be overpowered by a sense of his melodramatic opportunity, and as we think, overrated the meaning of the author, as well as the patience of the audience. There were three armed constables, too, who presented a pitiable picture of Britain's boasted power, and seemed in fact, to be more inconvenienced by the arms they carried than were those against whom they should have been directed. The last scene could be made effective without being improbable, as it is now. It is clearly an absurdity to bring in all the village lads and lasses after representing the plane where they thus suddenly pop in as extremely difficult of access. The destruction of the still by fire is in itself sufficient. The piece was relished by a large and appreciative audience.

abstract: To-day, at 12 M., will be exhibited in the Park Barracks, a section of a new army bridge, which is in course of construction for Gen. BURNSIDE's Division. If the full-sized, bridge comes up to the relative strength and portability of the model which we have seen, it will prove a great acquisition to an army intending to occupy the enemy's country. Military engineers should, by all means, examine this superstructure, which is a new application of the tension truss.

abstract: A meeting to ratify the nomination of C. GODFREY GUNTHER for Mayor was held last night, at Millerman's Hall, corner of Seventh-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street. There was a very large and respectable audience assembled by the time that the proceedings commenced. The meeting was called to order by SOLON HARDY, Esq., who nominated THOMAS MAHER as chairman. A list of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries were read and agreed to. A series of resolutions indorsing the nomination of Mr. GUNTHER, were read and unanimously adopted. Appropriate addresses were then mode by Hon. T.J. Barr, Judge Connolly, John Harpy, George Peckham and others. The meeting was a very enthusiastic one, and appeared to be actuated wite sincerity and an earnestness in the cause which had called them together.

abstract: JEFF. DAVIS, his Government and his Congress are exceedingly peripatetic. The so-called Southern Confederacy has only been in existence about threequarters of a year, and each quarter it establishes a new Confederate Capital.
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS, his Government and his Congress are exceedingly peripatetic. The so-called Southern Confederacy has only been in existence about threequarters of a year, and each quarter it establishes a new Confederate Capital. The first head-quarters of the concern were at Montgomery, Ala. That somewhat muddy town JEFF. DAVIS reached on the 16th of last February, he having previously been elected to the bogus Presidency by the Convention held at that place. After getting the machine in running order at Montgomery, the Southern Congress resolved that the whole machinery of Government should proceed as far as Richmond, Va., on its way to Washington City, which was then supposed to be within rebel grasp. Accordingly, in May, the Confederate Departments began to pack up their traps for a march of some seven hundred miles, in a northeasterly direction; and DAVIS himself reached Richmond on the 29th of that month. On the 20th of June, the Confederate Congress renewed in Virginia the session which it had begun in Alabama -- the National army not having made a "forward" movement for its dispersion. Finding Washington to be a very sour and unattainable grape, it now resolved upon a return march westward, some six hundred miles -- this time, however, moving in the direction of west by north. It is doubtless intended to make Nashville the permanent Capital of the dissolving Confederacy; but another body of men than the bogus Congress may have something to say about that ere long -- a very large body, too, armed with what THOMAS CARLYLE calls "big, long knives." Nashville is much nearer the geographical centre of this Confederacy than either of the previous Capitals -- that is, if the Confederacy includes, as probably it does by this time, Kentucky and Missouri. The Rump Breckinridge Kentucky Convention assembled at Russellville, on the southern verge of that State, and the Rump Claib. Jackson Missouri Legislature, in session at Neosho, on the southern border of that State, have probably both by this time passed secession ordinances, and declared their respective Territories part and parcel of the Southern despotism. This capital movement will be a new inducement to them to bind their fortunes irrevocably with the rebel Government. The people of the Mississippi Valley have all long looked forward to the establishment of the National Capital in their midst; and the Confederate conspirators doubtless think they have made a shrewd movement this time. It points also to the final determination of the mooted question of secession boundaries -- running the secession line up to the Ohio River, down that river to its junction with the Mississippi, thence up to the northern boundary of the State of Missouri, and thence westward as far as -- they can get.

lead_paragraph: SUICIDE OF A FRENCHMAN. -- Between 2 and 3 o'clock Monday morning, Officer GANTZ, of the Second Precinct, heard the report of a pistol while patroling his beat in Pearl-street. Upon going to the place, the found a man lying upon the sidewalk in front of No. 273 Pearl-street, with the mark of a pistol ball through his head, and an empty pistol lying by his side. An examination showed that the man was already dead. He was taken to the Station-house, and yesterday Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body. abstract: cepted the nomination of his friends, greatly against his personal inclinations, because he thought his services might be needed by the City when the question comes up of reconstructing the Union. Will not the Mayor enlighten the public a little more on this point? What does be propose to do, in order to aid that reconstruction? What measures will he advise, -- what steps will he take, what policy will he advocate looking towards that result? Will he act on his assurance to Mr. TOOMBS that if he had the power, arms and munitions of war should be sent freely into the State of Georgia? As the Mayor proposes some action on this subject in the event of his reelection, it is clearly of the highest importance that we should know what that action is. Will the Mayor explain?

abstract: The Albion has an article in reference to the Mason and Slidell affair, in which it naturally, looking at it from a different stand-point, takes somewhat different ground from that which we have taken.
lead_paragraph: The Albion has an article in reference to the Mason and Slidell affair, in which it naturally, looking at it from a different stand-point, takes somewhat different ground from that which we have taken. It thinks, first, that Capt. WILKES was "guilty of a very serious breach of international comity." If that is the extent of our offence we can get along with the case, for, although we should regret that any such broach should ever be committed, and especially now, when there are so many tendencies abroad which would help to set the two countries against each other, yet there are times with nations, as with individuals, when courtesy must yield to necessity. If we have to chase a thief into our neighbor's premises, we should be sorry to find that we had trodden upon his flower-beds, especially if he has been disposed to be edgewise towards us. But if our neighbor is not desirous of a quarrel with us he will see at once that the catching of the thief was too important a matter for us to hesitate between his escape and our neighbor's flowers.

lead_paragraph: The steamship North Star, from Aspin all on the 15th inst., arrived here yesterday, bringing the mails, passengers and treasure--$829,807--from California. She also brings another body of United States regulars from California, under command of Col. ROBERT C. BUCHANAN, and a number of officers, one of whom, said to be a relative of Dr. SCOTT, who was lately forced to leave San Francisco on account of his secession proclivities, was arrested immediately after his arrival, on the complaint of a passenger by the North Star, who charged him with entertaining rebel sympathies. After being examined it was found there was not the slightest ground for such an accusation, and he was at once discharged. The advices from California are not so late as have before been received.

abstract: NOTICE.--Widows and families of members of the Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M., who have been killed, or who have died while in the service,
lead_paragraph: NOTICE.--Widows and families of members of the Fourteenth Regiment N.Y.S.M., who have been killed, or who have died while in the service, and the wives, or children, or widowed mothers of the members of said regiment who are prisoners, are hereby notified to attend at the Chambers of Judge GARRISON, in the City Hall of the city of Brooklyn, on Tuesday and Friday, the 26th and 29th days of November inst., between the hours of 9 o'clock A.M. and 2 o'clock P.M., to have their papers drawn, to enable them to obtain their pensions or back pay, bounty, &c. Each applicant will be required to bring two persons who have been acquainted with the deceased soldier or prisoner, and his wife, family or mother, to prove their identity. JESSE C. SMITH, Esq., and the Hon. MOSES F. ODELL, will be in attendance to take proofs, and Mr. ODELL will take them to Washington.

abstract: A general meeting of the German Kuester Central Club was held, yesterday evening, in Pythagoras Hall, Dr. KORN in the Chair. On motion of Dr. KORN, who sustained his proposition in a long speech, seconded by Mr. WEIL VON GERNSBACH, C. GODFREY GUNTHER was declared to be the unanimous choice of the organization for the Mayoralty. A Committee was appointed to prepare and publish an address to the German voters, and it was determined to establish at once branch clubs in every Ward, to support the interests of Mr. GUNTHER. After making other arrangements in furtherance of their object, the Club, at 10 1/8 P.M., adjourned.

abstract: BEEVES--The receipts of Beeves are comparatively light, but the demand is moderate, there being only a few heavy buyers up from New-York, while the Eastern men are not taking quite so many as usual. There is a falling off in quality as compared with last week. Prices are about the same, and taking quality into consideration, the market is to that extent more favorable for sellers.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Monday, Nov. 25, 1861.

abstract: Let it not be forgotten that this is the last day for registering names for voting for Mayor next week. All who did not vote at the recent State election, must register their names to-day, or they cannot vote next week without swearing in their votes and securing the evidence of some other person to their identity. There is too much at stake to throw away this chance of electing a Republican Mayor of this City. Let every man who values an upright and energetic municipal government, see to it that his name is placed on the registry to-day.

abstract: The news which the rebels have permitted to escape in reference to an engagement at Pensacola, is confused and unsatisfactory. According to one form of the report, fire was opened by Col. BROWN on the 19th inst.; ...
lead_paragraph: The news which the rebels have permitted to escape in reference to an engagement at Pensacola, is confused and unsatisfactory. According to one form of the report, fire was opened by Col. BROWN on the 19th inst.; another story gives last Saturday as the initial date, with a continuation to Sunday. It is safe, however, to receive the latest time named as that of the conflict. The George Peabody transport left Fort Pickens on the 18th inst., without an intimation of the coming event, which it would have certainly brought had it been the intention of Col. BROWN to make an attack on the following day. When the Peabody left, the Colorado had just sailed for the mouths of the Mississippi to take a place in the blockading fleet at that point. The only vessels left at Fort Pickens were the Niagara and Hatteras. To have played the part in the fight, which rumor assigns to the Colorado, that vessel must have been recalled from the Mississippi and cleared for action -- movements which could not have been effected in less than several days.
headline: {'main': 'The Attack on Fort Pickens.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Attack on Fort Pickens.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: James Scott vs. Christian H. Lilienthal, Executor,  This action was brought to recover compensation for services as accountant,  The defendant was acting executor of James Polloch, deceased, who had been largely engaged in business as a Corporation contractor,  On taking charge of the business, Mr. Lilienthal found the books and accounts ...
lead_paragraph: James Scott vs. Christian H. Lilienthal, Executor, This action was brought to recover compensation for services as accountant, The defendant was acting executor of James Polloch, deceased, who had been largely engaged in business as a Corporation contractor, On taking charge of the business, Mr. Lilienthal found the books and accounts in considerable confusion and several large contracts unfinished. He employed, as alleged, the plaintiff, in December, 1857, to take charge of and examine the books and papers, with instructions to ascertain and inform him (defendant) of the state of affairs, and keep accounts of the work which was then going on. The plaintiff, as he alleged, continued in the employment until May, 1860, when the work was finished. In the complaint it was alleged that the defendant agreed to pay one thousand dollars per annum, for plaintiff's services; that he had received $949, and there was due to him a balance of upwards of $1,400. The defendant denied that he had agreed to pay any specific rate of compensation, and averred that the plaintiff had been overpaid by the sum which he had received.

abstract: We publish, this morning, the speech of Hon. HENRY WINTER DAVIS, delivered in Brooklyn, last evening, against the right of the President, without special authority from Congress, to suspend the writ of habeas corpus.
lead_paragraph: We publish, this morning, the speech of Hon. HENRY WINTER DAVIS, delivered in Brooklyn, last evening, against the right of the President, without special authority from Congress, to suspend the writ of habeas corpus. As the objections of Mr. DAVIS, are against the manner in which the writ has been suspended, rather than the act itself, they appear to us to be, at least, ill-timed, and as evidence that the best and most patriotic of men may at times be wrong-headed, and entirely mistake their vocation. Mr. DAVIS is not wholly free from charges of the kind. The weight of authority certainly sustains the act of the President. The sufferings and hardships that prisoners may endure have no bearing whatever upon the subject. These would not be alleviated by any act of Congress, so that the argument from such premises fails to have any pertinency or force.

abstract: The body of McMANUS, the Irish rebel, which was recently brought over from America, was interred in Glasnevin Cemetery, near Dublin, on Sunday. An immense procession followed the hearse to the grave. Carriages and other vehicles conveying the relatives and friends of the deceased also accompanied. Among the mourners was, it is stated, Mr. SMITH O'BRIEN. A couple of brass bands, and one of drum and fife, played "The Dead March in Saul."

abstract: The attempt of Tammany last night to revive its traditions failed painfully. There  were none of the old numbers, or old enthusiasm; the blue-lights burned fewer and bluer than of yore, the shouts were hoarser ..
lead_paragraph: The attempt of Tammany last night to revive its traditions failed painfully. There were none of the old numbers, or old enthusiasm; the blue-lights burned fewer and bluer than of yore, the shouts were hoarser and thinner, the speaking was faint and received coldly. The "Great Spirit of the Wigwam" was evidently absent, and his worshipers faithless. The truth is, Tammany has not a glimmer of hope that it can succeed in electing Mr. GUNTHER. What it failed to do when less decrepit, and strengthened by the name and tried excellences of Mr. HAVEMEYER, it cannot expect to accomplish with the help of a name so imperfectly known as that of its actual candidate, whose recommendations for an office, at this moment so vitally important, are wholly a matter of conjecture. Indeed, at the very start of the municipal canvass, Tammany had grace to confess its inability to contend with Mr. WOOD, unless reinforced by the Republicans. The Republicans having declined the alliance, Tammany assumes the responsibility of electing a man, whom it is the first article in its creed to detest, oppose and suppress. No wonder it brings to the work little of courage or animation.

abstract: The spell which has rested upon military and naval operations at Fort Pickens, was rudely broken by Col. BROWN and Commodore McKEAN, on Saturday last. On that day, according to reports which reach us through rebel sources, fire ...
lead_paragraph: The spell which has rested upon military and naval operations at Fort Pickens, was rudely broken by Col. BROWN and Commodore McKEAN, on Saturday last. On that day, according to reports which reach us through rebel sources, fire was opened by the fort upon the rebel batteries at Barrancas and the Navy-yard, while the Niagara and the Colorado engaged Fort McRae. The reports of the engagement -- which was still proceeding on Sunday night -- are extremely meagre, and bear a striking similarity to those which preceded the authentic accounts of the affair at Port Royal. According to these reports, which are contained in a copy of the Norfolk Day Book received at Fortress Monroe, the Navy-yard had been set on fire three times by hot shot thrown by Col. BROWN'S guns, and Warrington had been entirely destroyed. As an offset to these disasters, the rebels insist that in their engagement with Fort McRae, the Niagara and Colorado were so badly damaged that they were forced to haul off for repairs, and that a breach had already been made in the walls of Fort Pickens. This latter assertion, however, will be regarded as ridiculous, when it is remembered that Fort Sumter was not breached by the terrible rain of shot which was poured upon it at a much shorter range. It is worthy of note that a considerable loss of life is acknowledged by the rebels; and it is safe to conclude that they have been very badly punished. The immediate cause of the hostilities is not yet explained, but it will perhaps be found in the fact that the rebels were making active preparations for an attack upon the Fort, which were simply forestalled. The reports by the George Peabody, which left the Fort on the 18th, led us to expect immediate hostilities.

abstract: The recent advance in the rates of Sterling exchange is attracting attention, and is creating some, though apparently groundless apprehension, lest they should go to the specie point. abstract: Tammany Hall was well filled last evening, on the occasion of the ratification of the nomination of  C. GODFREY GUNTHER for the Mayoralty. Shortly after 7  o'clock, the platform was occupied by the higher lights of the Wigwam, including JOHN CLANCY, DAN.
lead_paragraph: Tammany Hall was well filled last evening, on the occasion of the ratification of the nomination of C. GODFREY GUNTHER for the Mayoralty. Shortly after 7 o'clock, the platform was occupied by the higher lights of the Wigwam, including JOHN CLANCY, DAN. E. DELEVAN, Judge CONNOLLY, Capt. RYNDERS, EDWARD COOPER, and others of equal note. The doors were then opened and the rank and file rushed in, swarming on the few seats and promising standpoints, and ornamenting the stand with all manner of devices and banners illustrative of Democratic devotion to GUNTHER.

abstract: The steamship Bohemian arrived at Portland yesterday afternoon, with advices from Europe one day later. She left Liverpool on the 14th, and Londonderry on the 15th inst.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Bohemian arrived at Portland yesterday afternoon, with advices from Europe one day later. She left Liverpool on the 14th, and Londonderry on the 15th inst. The steamship Fulton, from Havre and Southampton on the 13th, arrived at this port. The Canada, from Liverpool on the 16th and Queenstown on the 17th, is also announced as having passed Cape Race, but her news was not obtained by the agent of the Associated Press. The financial and commercial intelligence by the Bohemian is interesting. The sales of cotton for the week in the Liverpool market had been 105,000 bales, at unchanged prices for American. Consols had advanced to 93 4/8 @ 94. The bullion in the Bank of England had increased to L152,000, while that in the Bank of France had decreased 10,500,000 francs. An improvement in French money affairs was, however, expected to follow the appointment of M. FOULD as Minister of Finance, which is announced in an Imperial decree. The most important item of political news is the announcement of the dissolution of the Croatian Diet by the Austrian Emperor.

abstract: We publish herewith a clear view of the scene of the late operations in the extreme western come of Florida, concerning which the Secessionists have permitted us to receive such meagre reports by way of Fortress Monroe. The only thing definite in our present news seems to be that a fight has taken place between the National naval and land forces at Fort Pickens and the rebel forts and forces in the vicinity, in which, as far as can be judged by present appearances, the Secessionists have suffered as severe a blow as they received at Port Royal. Indeed, there is a remarkable similarity between our present secession news from the Florida coast and the news from the South Carolina coast, published eighteen days ago from the some sources. In both cases the rebels first reported to us, and in both instances they announced that the Union forces met with disaster slightly tempered with success. The first advices from Port Royal however, appeared much more dubious than this. Then the report was that one of our war ships had been disabled by the rebel guns, another was aground, while TATNALL bade fair to capture or drive away the whole Yankee fleet. The present secession intelligence is that two of our ships were damaged and had to haul off, and that BRAGG was taking the bombardment cooly and receiving Col. BROWN's shells! So that if this turns out, as we have no doubt it will, to be as neat an affair as that at Port Royal, it will only show that the mendacious rebels are a dash less mendacious than they were a fortnight ago.
lead_paragraph: We publish herewith a clear view of the scene of the late operations in the extreme western come of Florida, concerning which the Secessionists have permitted us to receive such meagre reports by way of Fortress Monroe. The only thing definite in our present news seems to be that a fight has taken place between the National naval and land forces at Fort Pickens and the rebel forts and forces in the vicinity, in which, as far as can be judged by present appearances, the Secessionists have suffered as severe a blow as they received at Port Royal. Indeed, there is a remarkable similarity between our present secession news from the Florida coast and the news from the South Carolina coast, published eighteen days ago from the some sources. In both cases the rebels first reported to us, and in both instances they announced that the Union forces met with disaster slightly tempered with success. The first advices from Port Royal however, appeared much more dubious than this. The present secession intelligence is that two of our ships were damaged and had to haul off, and that BRAGG was taking the bombardment cooly and receiving Col. BROWN's shells! So that if this turns out, as we have no doubt it will, to be as neat an affair as that at Port Royal, it will only show that the mendacious rebels are a dash less mendacious than they were a fortnight ago.

abstract: -- A member of the last Congress, being called upon to state his position with regard to this great work, asked if it was something new, or the same old concern. Upon learning that it was the original work, he wanted no other information on the subject, but opposed it heartily, without knowing, however, whether it was a steamship or a scow, or round or square, or submerged or up in the air. Wherein the member truly represented his constituents, for ninety men in a hundred are ready to swear any novelty a humbug if its general features are kept secret from them, especially when the reporters of one or two metropolitan journals, denied even the material for a paragraph, retaliate by denouncing the whole project as a stupendous swindle. Meanwhile, Mr. STEVENS has faithfully kept his engagement with the Government, locking the gates and battening the cracks of the battery inclosure, when each new barrier to the public curiosity removed further from him the prospect of recovering the large sum he had advanced to the Government in good faith, and when he was perfectly aware that a full exhibition of the work to the public would have hastened its completion.

abstract: The People vs. Chatterton. The prisoner was convicted of receiving stolen goods upon an indictment found jointly against him and one Fisher, who pleaded guilty. Chatterton was then tried separately. A motion was now made for a new trial, upon the ground that it was error to try the prisoner separate.
lead_paragraph: The People vs. Chatterton. The prisoner was convicted of receiving stolen goods upon an indictment found jointly against him and one Fisher, who pleaded guilty. Chatterton was then tried separately. A motion was now made for a new trial, upon the ground that it was error to try the prisoner separately upon an indictment found jointly against two persons. The Court refused the motion, and appeal was taken to this Court.

abstract: Capt. DUNTZE, of the bark Henry Trowbridge, from Barbados Nov. 5, arrived yesterday, and reports that the British frigates Barracoota and Cadmus were in that port.
lead_paragraph: Capt. DUNTZE, of the bark Henry Trowbridge, from Barbados Nov. 5, arrived yesterday, and reports that the British frigates Barracoota and Cadmus were in that port. The commander of the former reported on Oct. 27, 3 south of the latitude of the Bermudas, that he boarded the privateer Sumter. All well on board. The master of the Sumter informed the British officer who went on board, that while off Bermuda he had sent in a challenge to the United States gunboat Crusader to come out and fight him, which the Crusader declined to do. Did not hear of her having taken any prizes of late.

abstract: We are a smart people, but for the want of a little wholesome training in the plainest principles of political economy, we are as much victims to imaginary and groundless fears as people were two thousand years ago ...
lead_paragraph: We are a smart people, but for the want of a little wholesome training in the plainest principles of political economy, we are as much victims to imaginary and groundless fears as people were two thousand years ago who, in every phenomena, saw a supernatural agency, whose law and power they could neither penetrate nor control. A rumor got wind a day or two ago that sterling exchange was approaching the specie point. Thereupon a great terror seized the public mind. In the rout, stocks of all kinds were thrown away, with as little regard to loss or appearance as the fugitives showed at Bull Run. It is idle to say that it was merely a panic among the bulls and bears. These may be the only visible parties, but their transactions bear no ratio whatever to the whole of those of the Street or Stock Exchange. They are incapable of creating any great fluctuations, which are caused by capitalists and outsiders buying freely when in humor, and selling in a hurry, when a panic like the present seizes them.

abstract: It is natural; when a wide difference has grown up between the ideas of a people, or of the ruling classes, and the structure of their social and political organizations that they should seize the occasion of a great revolution in their external relations to recast ...
lead_paragraph: It is natural; when a wide difference has grown up between the ideas of a people, or of the ruling classes, and the structure of their social and political organizations that they should seize the occasion of a great revolution in their external relations to recast their systems of government and society, that a harmony may exist between their theories and fact -- between their supposed interests and welfare and the laws which are to protect and defend them. The South is now availing itself of such an occasion. Having accepted Slavery as the natural basis of society, the first step is to vest Government in the hands of the few, in which labor -- which is always to be owned, and never hired by capital -- is to have no participation. To labor, education and the right of suffrage is necessarily denied, because, if allowed, they would upset the government and society based upon the dogma assumed. The only end of such a system is a despotism more absolute than any yet established, as all examples of free government must be rigorously excluded from the Eastward; while the subjects of the despotism of olden times, knowing no better system, submitted quietly to the condition in which they found themselves placed.

abstract: Capt. ACKEN, who runs a boat between this City and New-Brunswick, called yesterday afternoon at the office of the Detective Police, and related the particulars of a bold and successful game which had been played upon him in the morning -- the substance of which is as follows: The Captain determined to spend Thanksgiving in a liberal way, and, therefore, before leaving the City for his home in New-Jersey, he decided to draw some money from the bank. Having drawn $50, he was in the act of going out of the bank, when he was met on the steps by a well-dressed and very polite gentleman, who asked him if his name was SMITH? The captain replied in the negative, whereupon the stranger remarked that he had an appointment to meet a Mr. Smith at the bank at that hour, and never having step him, he was, of course, liable to make a mistake. He then asked the Captain it he knew anything about cattle, at the same time saying, "I presume you are from the country?" To this Capt. ASKIN asssented. The stranger then said, "Will you walk down and look at some oxen?" Just at this point a third party appeared, and rushing up in great apparent excitement, demanded of the first stranger if he were going to look at the cattle? Stranger No. I says, Yes, but wait till I draw some money form the bank. He then went into the bank and soon emerged therefrom with a large roll of bills in his hand. Stranger No. 2 then asks, "Are you going to pay something to fasten the bargain for the cattle?" The other replied, I must remain here to meet Mr. Smith, and if he comes, we will go down together and look at the cattle, but in the meantime I will give you $100 on account. But No. 2 wished very much to have $150. His confederate had a large number of $100 bills he said, hut no fifties; would be very glad to let him have $150, if he could make the change, -- and turning to Capt. ACEIN, said: Have you $50 you van let me have until lean get my money change? The Captain said he had exactly $50, that he had just drawn from the bank, and he handed it to Stranger No. 1 without delay, Stranger No. 2 then asked the Captain to walk down and see the cattle. On the way it was suggested to the Captain that he had better go back to the bank and ascertain from his friend there, whether it was the red or the piebald oxen that he wished to purchase. The Captain returned, but found no friend at the bank: he then went in pursuit of friend No. 2, but he also was non est, whereupon the swindled Captain, beginning to feel himself sold, wended his way to the Detectives' office. The parties are known to the police.

abstract: There are two State Conventions now in session in Virginia one at Richmond, the other at Wheeling. We have got just an inkling of the proceedings and spirit of both.
lead_paragraph: There are two State Conventions now in session in Virginia one at Richmond, the other at Wheeling. We have got just an inkling of the proceedings and spirit of both. They seem to be moving in about as nearly opposite directions as it is possible for two bodies to do. The Eastern Virginia Conventi on is moving in the direction that everything in that part of the State has moved for the last quarter of a century -- backward and down hill. The Western Virginia (or Kanawha) Convention, if we may judge by the various indications that have reached us, and by the tone of the Press in that part of the State, is pressing forward in the paths of liberty and loyalty with a swiftness as astonishing as it is pleasing.

abstract: The Atlantic left her dock, from the foot of Canal-street, yesterday, at 12% o'clock, for Pert Royal, S.C. She carries a very large cargo, consisting of flour, provisions, arms, clothing for the troops, and about fifty head of cattle. Among other things, she takes out a printing press, cases, type, &c., with a view of starting a newspaper at Port Royal, to be conducted under the supervision of Gen. SHERMAN. A proper person will be selected as editor, and it is contemplated to issue a weekly sheet, which shall express the sentiments of the Government, and at the same time aid in suppressing rebellion on the soil of the Palmette State.

abstract: This regiment, which has been raised principally in the counties of Wyoming, Cattaraugus and Chautauque, N.Y., arrived in this City, yesterday, from Albany, en route for the seat of war. On Tuesday afternoon, the regiment embarked on board the ...
lead_paragraph: This regiment, which has been raised principally in the counties of Wyoming, Cattaraugus and Chautauque, N.Y., arrived in this City, yesterday, from Albany, en route for the seat of war. On Tuesday afternoon, the regiment embarked on board the steamer Knickerbocker and a barge, arriving at Jersey City the following morning, Orders were then received from the Quartermaster commanding, to proceed to Pier No. 1 North River, in order to take the boat for Amboy, by which route the regiment left for its destination. It is only ten weeks ago that the organization of this corps was first started, and in that time nearly eleven hundred men have been recruited. Nearly every profession and trade is represented in its ranks; there are five physicians, six ministers, a number of lawyers, and a sprinkling of merchants.

abstract: Pursuant to a call published in the largest back-letter in all the German papers of this City, a very considerable turn-out of the German friends of FERNANDO WOOD assembled last evening at the Volks Garten, No. 45 Bowery. A huge bonfire shed its lurid light and stifling smoke from the street in front of the "Garten" over the adjacent blocks, and a liberal display of rockets and blue-lights caused the neighboring apple-stands and beer saloons to "pale their ineffectual fires."

abstract: The consecration of to-day to the customary annual festival of Thanksgiving  observed by sixteen other States in common with us is a grateful evidence that amid the chaos of war the harmonies of society rest undisturbed. And it is cheerful to reflect that this Thanksgiving Day ...
lead_paragraph: The consecration of to-day to the customary annual festival of Thanksgiving observed by sixteen other States in common with us is a grateful evidence that amid the chaos of war the harmonies of society rest undisturbed. And it is cheerful to reflect that this Thanksgiving Day will not be a mere conventional observance, but brings with it that for which we may really be thankful. Yes! thank Heaven, we have this year to rejoice not only over bounteous harvests, bulging our barns with their plenty, not merely over public health and adequate prosperity -- but over a sublime renovation of the moral life of the nation, -- over months of such precious experience, as fills the past with fragrance and the future with beauty and faith.

abstract: Late last night, thewarehouse No. 35 Water-street was discovered to be on fire, and upon examination it was found to have communicated from a floor-beam of No. 33, in which the fire occurred on Monday night, and which, owing to the difficulty in getting water in between the floor and ceiling, had not been extinguished. The looses in No. 35 were as follows: J.S. LAWRENCE lost a large quantity of bergamot oil, the value of which could not be ascertained. It was fully insured for $3,000 in the Sun Mutual Insurance Company. Forty crates of crockery, belonging to J.C. JACKSON valued at $2,000, were all destroyed. The crockery was insured in the Manhattan Insurance Company. STURGES, BENDETE & Co. lost eighteen casks of port wine, value at $500, and insured for that amount in the Home Insurance Company. DEBOIS & VANDERVCORT, of No. 37 Water-st., were damaged by water to the extent of $6,000. Fully insured. THOMAS CONNERS, a member of Hose Company No. 10, was badly injured by a gutter falling on his head. He was taken to the hospital.

abstract: Although many a Thanksgiving dinner to-day will be the occasion of remembering those who were at home in peace last year, but are now swelling the ranks of the New-York contingent of the army, ample preparations are made to do justice to the State feast as well as duty to the National prayers. abstract: The German Union League met again at Pythagoras Hall on Tuesday evening, rather unexpectedly, however, as a large number of the delegates were supposed to be busily engaged at the ward meetings held in all the wards in favor of Mr. OPDYDE.
lead_paragraph: The German Union League met again at Pythagoras Hall on Tuesday evening, rather unexpectedly, however, as a large number of the delegates were supposed to be busily engaged at the ward meetings held in all the wards in favor of Mr. OPDYDE. It was given out that, owing to this circumstance, a desperate effort would be made to substitute the name of Mr. GUNTHER for that of Mr. OPDYKE as the nominee of the League. The friends of the latter gentlemen were, however, present in force, and as the supporters of the rival candidate had also rallied, the meeting was very full and very animated.

abstract: Senator SUMNER delivered an address last evening before the Republican Union on the "Origin and Cause of the Rebellion." Slavery was its cause, and in the extinction of Slavery must be found its cure.
lead_paragraph: Senator SUMNER delivered an address last evening before the Republican Union on the "Origin and Cause of the Rebellion." Slavery was its cause, and in the extinction of Slavery must be found its cure. The argument is brief, -- the logic compact, -- the conclusion inevitable. Extinguish the cause, if you would effect a cure, -- extract the root, if you would destroy the ache, -- kill the poison, if you would arrest decay, -- these are simple, self-evident suggestions which commend themselves to common sense and the common experience of all the world. Mr. SUMNER has a very easy task when he seeks to persuade a Northern audience that Slavery is the foe of the Union, that Slavery inspires the hearts and strengthens the arms of those who are waging war upon it, and that, if we would end the war, we must strike a death-blow at the power which gives motive and vigor to those by whom it is waged.
headline: {'main': 'Slavery and the Rebellion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Slavery and the Rebellion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 16th inst., and Queenstown on the 17th, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her advices are two days later than those received by the Bohemian. The Liverpool Cotton Market was firm, and prices were unchanged.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 16th inst., and Queenstown on the 17th, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her advices are two days later than those received by the Bohemian. The Liverpool Cotton Market was firm, and prices were unchanged. Breadstuffs were inactive, and Provisions were dull. In the Havre Cotton Market an advance of 2@3 francs is noted. There had been no change in the English funds. An improvement had taken place in the French Money Market following the appointment of M. FOULD as Minister of Finance. His conditions on taking the office had been published by a Paris correspondent, and one of them is found to be the evacuation of Rome by the French troops. From Italy we learn that a levy of eighty thousand men is ordered, but it was thought that not more than fifty thousand would be obtained, and that another fifty thousand would be levied in February. Italy will then have two hundred and eighty thousand effective men in the field. An address of the Neapolitans had been sent to GARIBALDI, praying him not to leave Italy. The new Russian campaign in Circassia had resulted very disastrously. Fifteen thousand troops had attacked ten thousand mountaineers, and after fighting six hours, were repulsed with very heavy losses, including a General of Division killed. Six thousand Russians are reported to have been killed and wounded. In Greece a conspiracy had been discovered to assassinate the King and his immediate followers during a fete. The Duke of Oporto had been proclaimed King of Portugal, but the Ministry remained unchanged. From Poland the reports are indicative of serious trouble. The military were continually insulted in the streets of Warsaw, and martial law had been set at defiance by the people. The Archbishop of Warsaw had been arrested because he refused to open the Churches.

abstract: The oration of Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, before the Young Men's Republican Union, last evening, on "The Rebellion, Its Origin and Main-spring," attracted a large audience to the Cooper Institute.
lead_paragraph: The oration of Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, before the Young Men's Republican Union, last evening, on "The Rebellion, Its Origin and Main-spring," attracted a large audience to the Cooper Institute. The room was quite filled and on the platform were honored representatives of the bench, the bar, the pulpit and the counting-house. Many ladies were also present. The meeting was organized by the selection of WM. CURTIS NOYES, Esq., as President. A list of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries was adopted, during the reading of which the names of Messrs. OPDYKE, EVARTS and CHEEVER were received with special marks of favor.

abstract: Every day makes it more and more evident that the contest for Mayor lies between WOOD and OPDYKE. One of the two will be elected, and it is for those of our citizens who have the deepest stake in the issue to decide which ...
lead_paragraph: Every day makes it more and more evident that the contest for Mayor lies between WOOD and OPDYKE. One of the two will be elected, and it is for those of our citizens who have the deepest stake in the issue to decide which it shall be. If they are content to give Mayor WOOD a fresh lease of power -- if they are satisfied with his administration of City affairs, and the general tone and spirit of his political career, they have an undoubted right to the indulgence of that preference. But they have an opportunity to elect a better man, and, if they fail to avail themselves of it, the responsibility will rest upon their own heads.

abstract: The brother of sleep, as the ancients termed death, has suddenly taken from us a young man of great energy of character, of wide and extended influence, and what is still more important in these days of private and public profligacy, a truly good, honest and Christian man. We allude to EDWARD P. RUDD, the late head of the well-known publishing house of RUDD & CARLETON. Having known Mr. R. intimately, I desire to pay a passing tribute to this memory. He was the son of Rev. Mr. RUDD, of Lyons, in this State. At the early age of 15 he entered the book-house of J.C. DERBY, at Auburn, where he remained three years. Thinking New-York offered a wider sphere for him, he came here at 18 with strong letters to A.S. BARNES & Co. With them, and with SHELDON, LAMPORT & Co., he remained until 1854. He then started for himself in Ann-street, his sole capital being his good name. EDWARD LIVERMORE, who had made quite a stir with the "Docsticks" books was attracted by his business habits and proposed partnership. At their new store in Broadway, they soon gathered round them the rising lights in the literary world, and introduced to the public several authors who are now established favorites. While the flush of popularity, Mr. LIVERMORE retired from business. Mr. G.W. CARLETON at that time (1857) had just returned from Europe, and finding Mr. RUDD a congenial spirit, the firm of RUDD & CARLETON was soon formed. They have pursued the even tenor of their way through the troubles that have  fallen like a blight on literature, acting solely on the good old maxim of "being just and fearing not."

abstract: We have no further intelligence from Fort Pickens this morning. abstract: The Congregation Bnai Israel, corner of Stanton and Forsyth streets, having no regular preacher, an address was delivered by the President of the Congregation, Mr. M.S. COHEN.
lead_paragraph: The Congregation Bnai Israel, corner of Stanton and Forsyth streets, having no regular preacher, an address was delivered by the President of the Congregation, Mr. M.S. COHEN. The speaker said that they had met there that day to [???] thanks to the Supreme Ruler for the manifold blessings bestowed on us, and for the bountiful harvest gathered, and to pray for a speedy restoration of our beloved country from one of the most horrid strifes, "civil war," and to restore our deluded brethren once more under that peaceful banner and Constitution which they had abused and desired to destroy, and to grant that the efforts of those who are now doing battle for their country might be crowned with success, and they be speedily restored to their homes and their firesides. It was true, we had had some disasters, but we had had also our victories; and who can say but that our very chastisements would turn out to our advantage, for had not the present strife developed to the world at large our strength, and would it not tend to still further establish our democratic principles of self-government? All this was the work of an Allwise Providence, who alone directed the events of things, and shaped men to work his will. The address, which was replete with logical and patriotic sentiments, was listened to with considerable attention by the members of the congregation, and a large number of strangers.

abstract: Thanksgiving Day was everywhere kept with immense cheerfulness and social joviality more so, it really seemed, than is usual in this part of the country. There were fine feastings at the public institutions, towards which the hand of charity was unwontedly liberal; private families observed ...
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving Day was everywhere kept with immense cheerfulness and social joviality more so, it really seemed, than is usual in this part of the country. There were fine feastings at the public institutions, towards which the hand of charity was unwontedly liberal; private families observed the occasion with the greater fervor, for the vacant chairs around the board that war had rendered lonely; and New-Englanders, resident in New-York, have never kept it with half so much intensity of enthusiasm since the time that the Pilgrims resolved to change their proposed fast for a festival to be ever thereafter annually enjoyed by their descendants.

abstract: A mass meeting will be held to-morrow, at the Merchants' Exchange, in Wall-street, at 3 o'clock, P.M., to ratify the nomination of GEORGE OPDYKE for Mayor. The call for the meeting is signed by some hundreds of the most prominent merchants, bankers and professional men of the City, and speeches will be made by several distinguished and practical orators. Another ratification meeting is called by Mr. OPDYKE's friends for Saturday evening, at the Cooper Institute, when an immense demonstration may be expected, in the shape of torchlight processions, a grand gathering of taxpaying citizens, and addresses by prominent speakers.

abstract: We gave some time ago copious extracts from foreign journals upon the deficit in the grain crops of England and France, which was estimated at 144,000,000 of bushels;
lead_paragraph: We gave some time ago copious extracts from foreign journals upon the deficit in the grain crops of England and France, which was estimated at 144,000,000 of bushels; the Mark Lane Express being the authority chiefly relied upon. The crops in other European countries were also short, requiring large importations, which have been made, to a considerable extent, from the United States. England, with a good crop, is always a large importer. France usually raises a supply but the deficit there the present year is estimated equal to about one-third of the usual crop, or 80,000,000 bushels.

abstract: A Thanksgiving sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. F. VINTON. The preacher remarked that it was our duty, in accordance with the teachings of Scripture in everything to give thanks. God's love was everything in this world. If a few misfortunes should come upon us, we should not suffer them to bear us down, but should look upward and with renewed courage go on anew. Even in this time we should not be cast down, but should wait and pray for peace. The preacher delivered a general sermon upon the nature of God's bounties and his bounties toward us as a people and a nation.

abstract: This regiment, designated by the War Department as the Sixty-ninth, left this City, yesterday, by the Camden and Amboy route for Washington. For some time past the regiment has been encamped at  David's Island, where it has obtained great proffciency in drill.
lead_paragraph: This regiment, designated by the War Department as the Sixty-ninth, left this City, yesterday, by the Camden and Amboy route for Washington. For some time past the regiment has been encamped at David's Island, where it has obtained great proffciency in drill. The numerical strength of the regiment is about 900. All of the men are armed, one-half with the Enfield rifle, and the remainder with Belgian rifles, which will be exchanged for Enfield rifles on the arrival of the regiment at Washington. Previous to the departure the men paraded through the City, and made quite a fine appearance. Annexed is a list of the officers:

abstract: SERIOUS SHOOTING AFFRAY. Early yesterday morning, CHAS. H. RUSSELL, colored, was shot in the leg by a pistol in the hands of FREDERICK WEINCHE, proprietor of the grocery-store No. 15 Worth-street.
lead_paragraph: SERIOUS SHOOTING AFFRAY. Early yesterday morning, CHAS. H. RUSSELL, colored, was shot in the leg by a pistol in the hands of FREDERICK WEINCHE, proprietor of the grocery-store No. 15 Worth-street. There was a large crowd in the store, making a disturbance, when WEINCHE, in order to get them away, put out the lights, and then took a loaded Colt's revolver, and fired at random among the crowd. The shot took effect on RUSSELL. The injured man was sent to the New-York Hospital. WEINCHE was arrested, and locked up in the Tombs.

abstract: Those who had fancied that our Port Royal Expedition was destined to walk through South Carolina as a destroying angel, have probably thought the quiet lodgment which Gen. SHERMAN'S forces have made on Hilton Head a very lame and impotent conclusion to a, splendid overture.
lead_paragraph: Those who had fancied that our Port Royal Expedition was destined to walk through South Carolina as a destroying angel, have probably thought the quiet lodgment which Gen. SHERMAN'S forces have made on Hilton Head a very lame and impotent conclusion to a, splendid overture. Let them be reconciled by the evidence we have to-day, that it is not to be a barren victory, though the mode of following it up disappoints their preconceived notions. The fact is, as we showed al the time of the brilliant opening of operations in South Carolina by the reduction of the forts that flank Port Royal entrance, the primary design of the expedition was not so much to establish a base of operations for immediate conquests of Palmetto soil, as to establish on some of the islands which, gem-like, stud that splendid harbor, a naval depot, which might afford a secure point d'appui for a succession of rapid flank sallies on the Southern coast.

abstract: Fort Pulaski is situated on the northeastern corner of Cockspur Island, which is separated from Tybee Island by the creek or arm of the sea already mentioned. It defends the mouth of the Savannah River and the approaches to the city. The fort, like so many others, being left to take care of itself, the Georgians, at secession times, quietly stepped in and took possession. They immediately commenced work, completing the defences, mounting additional guns, etc., till, at the time of Mr. RUSSELL's visit in May last, he thought it capable of stopping a fleet very effectually. He describes the fort as an "irregular pentagon, with the base line or curtain face inlands, and the other faces casemated and bearing upon the approaches. The curtain, which is simply crenellated, is covered by a redan, surrounded by a deep ditch, inside the parapet of which are granite platforms ready for the reception of guns. The parapet is thick, and the counterscarp is faced with solid masonry. A drawbridge affords access to the interior of the redan, whence the gate of the fort is approached across a deep and broad moat, which is crossed by another drawbridge." Sandbag traverses guard the magazine-doors, and everything is in as good trim as the rebels know how. The walls are exceedingly solid, and well-built of hard gray brick, strong as iron, upwards of six feet in thickness, the casemates and bombproofs being lofty and capacious. The garrison of the fort is 650 men, and it is undoubtedly now fully garrisoned. The work is intended for 128 guns, of which probably 8 half are mounted on the casemates. They are long thirty-twos, with a few forty-twos and columbiads. The 10-inch columbiads are en barbette. There are three furnaces for heating red-hot shot. The means of completing the armament were furnished by Norfolk Navy-yard. The channel into the Savannah River at this point is very narrow, and passes close to the guns of the fort. Mr. RUSSELL thought it would take some hard blows before Georgia would be driven to let go her grip of Fort Pulaski. The iron hand to deal those hard blows is now very close to its object.

The parapet is thick, and the counterscarp is faced with solid masonry. The garrison of the fort is 650 men, and it is undoubtedly now fully garrisoned. The work is intended for 128 guns, of which probably 8 half are mounted on the casemates. They are long thirty-twos, with a few forty-twos and columbiads. The 10-inch columbiads are en barbette. There are three furnaces for heating red-hot shot. abstract: Yesterday was observed as Thanksgiving Day, in Jersey City, more generally then is naval, and nearly all branches of business were suspended. The people that thronged the streets were as quiet and orderly as on a Sabbath day. Stimulants were resorted to only to a moderate extent, and the police were not under the necessity of [???] arrest. The ferry-boats were [???] with persons going to New-York to attend places of amusement, and many thousands from New-York went out on the cars to spend the day with their friends in New-Jersey. The churches were all well attended, and in all of them collections were taken up for charitable purposes.

abstract: A MAN FATALLY, INJURED WHILE PROTECTING HIS WIFE. -- At about 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a man named JAMES MCKIERNAN was severely injured by a knife in the hands of EDWARD MULVAHILL, a Lieutenant in the Irish Brigade. The parties were very intimate friends, and on Wednesday afternoon MCKIERNAN invited the Lieutenant to spend the night with him at his house, No. 177 East Thirty-fifth-street. The invitation was accepted, and they spent the evening together very pleasantly. When they retired, it was proposed that MCKIERNAN and MULVAHILL should occupy one room, while Mrs. MCKIERNAN was to sleep in an adjoining room, a door separating the two apartments. Towards morning, MULVAHILL stealthily left his sleeping friend, and proceeded to the adjoining room, occupied by Mrs. MCKIERNAN. She was awakened by the noise, and immediately screamed for help. Her husband ran to her assistance, but before he had time to aid her, Lieut. MULVAHILL, finding himself in an unpleasant situation, instantly drew a bowie-knife, and plunged it into the abdomen of Mr. MCKIERNAN, inflicting injuries so serious that the physician in attendance pronounced them fatal. The offender immediately fled, but the police having been notified of the affair, tracked him through different parts of the City, and succeeded in arresting him about 10 A.M. He was taken to the Twenty-first Precinct Station-house, and detained to await the result of MCKIERNAN's injuries. Coroner JACKMAN was notified yesterday afternoon to take the ante-mortem examination of the injured man. His physician thought, last evening, that he could not survive many hours.
lead_paragraph: A MAN FATALLY, INJURED WHILE PROTECTING HIS WIFE. -- At about 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a man named JAMES MCKIERNAN was severely injured by a knife in the hands of EDWARD MULVAHILL, a Lieutenant in the Irish Brigade. The parties were very intimate friends, and on Wednesday afternoon MCKIERNAN invited the Lieutenant to spend the night with him at his house, No. 177 East Thirty-fifth-street.
