abstract: The Rev. J.P. THOMPSON, at the Broadway Tabernacle, preached a sermon upon the present war, and the advantages to us as a nation. He gave a brief history of the origin of the observance of a day of thanksgiving in this country, and considered that the present occasion was one calling for special thanks on our part. His discourse would relate to the present condition of the country.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. J.P. THOMPSON, at the Broadway Tabernacle, preached a sermon upon the present war, and the advantages to us as a nation. He gave a brief history of the origin of the observance of a day of thanksgiving in this country, and considered that the present occasion was one calling for special thanks on our part. His discourse would relate to the present condition of the country. What was the cause of our present disturbed condition? It was Southern Slavery. The spirit of Slavery was essentially tyrannical and despotic, and had created at the South an aristocracy inimical to republican institutions. While republicanism was based upon just representation, the oligarchy of the South had for its foundation a species of human chattelism. The effect of this aristocratic and oligarchtic spirit had been largely dominant in the political affairs of this nation for the last thirty years. Every measure -- whether of the mails, the division of territory, or the regulation of the internal policy of the Government -- had been taken in the interest of Slavery. We, as a nation, had begun to lose sight of those patriotic sentiments which animated for fathers in the formation of the Government. Our constant and habitual deference to the spirit of Slavery was fast extinguishing our National feeling, and there was danger of our statesmen becoming mere sycophants. Even the pulpit, in its subserviency to the slaveocracy, had gone so far as to compare American Slavery to the patriarchal and Mosaic institution, and to argue that it was a benediction of mercy to the African race. Something was needed to awaken us from this lethargy, and the first gun which boomed against our flag aroused us like the trump of the resurrection. We stood upon our feet once more; the dry bones rose up and presented an array which indicated that that trumpet-call was indeed a resurrection to new life. We should thank God for this rekindling of the smouldering fires of patriotism which had so long slumbered. Another cause for thankfulness was the abundance and prosperity which had marked our progress thus far in this struggle for National existence. The history of wars showed that distress, suffering, and even famine, were the necessary accompaniments. But who among us was really suffering for the necessaries of life? We had ourselves raised every dollar needed for the prosecution of the war, and the bountifulness of our crops, and the fruitfulness of our commerce, had maintained us in a position of prosperity compared with that of any nation ever before engaged in war. Another, and the highest cause of thankfulness, was the success which had thus far attended our efforts in maintaining Constitutional Government. Though our arms had met with some reverses, yet, on the whole were in a conquering position. The spirit which had been aroused in the nation was ominous of success. It had come to be considered, once again, glorious to die for a good cause. A LYON and a BAKER were shining examples of devotion to their country. Intelligent foreigners had predicted the overthrow of the Government, through lack of loyalty in the people. But we were beginning to return again to the spirit which animated the patriot fathers. Whatever names in the conduct of this war might hereafter fill the official roll, the prudence and wisdom of WINFIELD SCOTT, and the promptitude mid bravery of the men of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, would never be forgotten. [Applause.] Not only must this rebellion be put down, but Slavery incarnated in it must be extirpated. Let it be known that righteous men, praying men were working and praying without ceasing for this end and that they would never rest satisfied until the dragon of rebellion was cast into the bottomless pit, and the cover shut down, never again to be raised. [Applause.] This was no time to put on sackcloth, but rather garments of praise and gladness. God was establishing his government upon the earth; he was giving the land to the saints, if they only knew enough to take it. We should take courage and go on from conquering to conquer, until the whole earth shall be under the divine government, and the land be filled with the glory of God.

abstract: Commencing with the Commissioners, who after providing for the appropriate observance of the day by the inmates of the Lunatic Asylum and Almshouse, took dinner with the twelve hundred little children under their supervision at Randall's Island, ...
lead_paragraph: Commencing with the Commissioners, who after providing for the appropriate observance of the day by the inmates of the Lunatic Asylum and Almshouse, took dinner with the twelve hundred little children under their supervision at Randall's Island, we pass to the record of this unpromising Thanksgiving at the Five Points House of Industry. Long will the happy disappointment be remembered of Pelion on Ossa piled in the way of poultry, vegetables, and all sorts of good things, sufficient to satisfy the nine hundred youthful partakers and their invited guests. In the dining-room where this feast was laid no less than three hundred thousand meals have been furnished this year, to the beneficiaries of this useful institution. Crossing the space in front of the building we come to a corresponding institution conducted by the ladies of the Methodist Church. Here we find five hundred children in joyous anticipation of a hearty dinner, and a useful present afterwards. Every child has, through the kindness of those faithful friends of the Mission, Mrs. DEUEL and Mrs. SKIDMORE, received an entire new suit of clothes, including a pair of good substantial shoes for the girls and boots for the boys. The Chapel was adorned with large flags and intermediate mottoes in moss upon the walls, such as "He that giveth to the poor shall not lack." In the schoolroom were laid tables to accommodate from twelve to thirteen hundred persons, and the provisions, looming in every direction, was a curiosity, not only in quantity but in quality. For instance, one huge loaf of bread from Mr. CROOKS weighed two hundred and fifty pounds. The butchers of Washington and West Washington Markets vied with the vegetable and poultry dealers in that bountiful locality in representing themselves. Sheep, whole and in halves, to the amount of a dozen, were dumped into the receptacle at the Mission. A porker, of no slender proportions, from CORSEN & SHIELDS, was stuffed and roasted and served up in a state of entirety, "occupying a position" upon the huge salver, so natural as to repel the invading knife of a humane carver. His porkship was flanked by another happy effort of New-York bakers, in the form of a roll, weighing one hundred pounds, being a gift from Mr. HOYLER. Messrs. CROOKS & HUSEY have this year, as usual, gratuitously cooked all the raw material sent to the Mission. The exercises consisted of singing by the children, after which, prayer and addresses by the clergymen present, followed with dialogues by the pupils -- the whole president over and conducted by Mr. A.K. SANFORD.

abstract: Thanksgiving day was observed throughout the city, in obedience to the proclamations of the Governor of the State and the Mayor of the city. Nearly all regular business was suspended, and services were held in many churches. At some there was regular preaching, while at others festivals were given, at ...
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving day was observed throughout the city, in obedience to the proclamations of the Governor of the State and the Mayor of the city. Nearly all regular business was suspended, and services were held in many churches. At some there was regular preaching, while at others festivals were given, at which impromptu addresses were made and the children of the mission schools were provided with a good substantial dinner. The usual dinner was given at the Truant Institution, when addresses were made. The children of the Industrial School in the Eastern District were supplied with a bountiful dinner at the Odeon, when large donations of clothing were received. The many sermons were delivered with particular reference to the condition of the country. Rev. F.S. DE HASS, at the Washington-street M.E. Church, took is a text, "The Origin, Progress and Destiny of our Country." Rev. Mr. HESTER, Pastor of the State street Congregational Church, preached from the text: "The Ruler above all Rulers; at the Elm-place Church. Rev. Mr. BARTLETT look for his text," It is not the voice of them that shout for mastery, neither is it the voice of them that cry for being overcome; but the voice of them that say 'Do I hear;' at the South Congregational Church, Rev. Mr. CLARK bared his remarks upon "The Unity of the American Union;" at the Church of the Pilgrims, Rev. Dr. STORRS took for his text, 1st Kings, 5th chapter, 3d, 4th and 5th verses. The reverend gentleman detailed the horrors of war in all its phases, but believed that the experience of Solomon would apply to this country; that this was a great war, and would result in benefiting the country. The people would be forced to learn subordination and economy, and these qualities would be felt throughout the world. All great wars, with all their calamities, had ever benefited nations, and he ascribed many of the inventions which had contributed most to the benefit of mankind as the direct or indirect results of war, by stimulating the energies of man.

abstract: We should like to know what Mayor WOOD means by his constant assurances that, if reelected Mayor, he will take measures for the restoration of peace.
lead_paragraph: We should like to know what Mayor WOOD means by his constant assurances that, if reelected Mayor, he will take measures for the restoration of peace. Does he mean anything, or is he simply practicing upon the credulity of his hearers? Has he any communication with the rebels which enables him to give such assurances? Has he any plan for ending the war, without crushing the rebellion? If he has, why does he not inform the public what it is? His constant harping on this subject, suggests that possibly he may still be in correspondence with TOOMBS, and sending him fresh assurances that, if he had the power, arms should be freely sent from New-York to the State of Georgia.

abstract: Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER preached a very eloquent and effective sermon, yesterday, on the rebellion. From the sketch of it, which we publish in another column, it will be seen that he took ground very decidedly against any emancipation of the slaves by act of Congress, and insisted that, unless we wished to disgrace free Government in the eyes of the world, we must carry on this war within the limits of the Constitution. He insisted, moreover, that a Provisional Government of some kind must be established for those slaves who come into our camps for refuge.

abstract: "The powers that be are ordained of God," (Romans, xiii, 1,) was the text selected for the suggestion of his sermon yesterday, by the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER. The preacher said we have, at this anniversary of public and private gratitude to God for his mercies, all accustomed reasons, and many more, for thanksgiving and praise. Amidst the convulsions and calamities of secession, disunion, treason, and the ...
lead_paragraph: "The powers that be are ordained of God," (Romans, xiii, 1,) was the text selected for the suggestion of his sermon yesterday, by the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER. The preacher said we have, at this anniversary of public and private gratitude to God for his mercies, all accustomed reasons, and many more, for thanksgiving and praise. Amidst the convulsions and calamities of secession, disunion, treason, and the vast crimes accompanying and following rebellion on such a scale, although these things are beyond question the judgments of God against us for the sin of Slavery which has brought these very evils upon us, yet, viewed in another light, the war itself, though the worst of all wars, civil and fratricidal, is the greatest of God's mercies for our Government, country and people, if we will so receive it. For the first time in our history, it places our great national iniquity at our disposal, with power to sweep it from the country at a blow, and is rapidly uniting all parties and classes in this opinion, and in the determination so to deal with it. The opportunity is granted by God, and it is an opportunity, in fact, of national regeneration, of reintegration; not merely reunion or reconstruction as heretofore, but transfiguration. The old sole cause of disunion, crime and evil is cast out, and the law of sin and of death conquered and replaced by the law of freedom and life -- the law of the spirit of life as it is in Christ Jesus. It is an opportunity in which God offers us back again our original power over our own Government, which was fast passing from our hands, and the Government itself becoming an oligarchical despotism. It is an opportunity in which God calls upon us as a people to obey him and act as sovereigns under his rule, reserving, as our right, the right over the administration of our own Government.

abstract: We have intelligence from Port Royal to the afternoon of the 25th inst., by the arrival at this port of the steam transport Illinois, from which it appears that the report received by way of Norfolk, to the effect that a skirmish had taken place on Hilton Head Island, in which a party of ...
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence from Port Royal to the afternoon of the 25th inst., by the arrival at this port of the steam transport Illinois, from which it appears that the report received by way of Norfolk, to the effect that a skirmish had taken place on Hilton Head Island, in which a party of United States troops had been forced to retreat by the rebels, is false. No mention is made of any such occurrence in the news by this arrival -- which, however, is otherwise of considerable importance. Tybee Island, at the mouth of the Savannah River, about twenty miles southwest of Port Royal, is now in possession of our troops On the 24th the steamers Flag, Augusta, Pocahontas and Seneca, ran down there and threw in a few shells, which elicited no response, when a body of Marines was landed, and the fortifications there found deserted. Formal possession was then taken of the island. It is also announced that another expedition, under command of Gen. VIELE, consisting of two brigades, was being fitted out at Port Royal, and was expected to sail in a few days for some point further South. All the light draught gunboats were to accompany this new expedition. The condition of affairs at Beaufort appears to be unchanged. Two gunboats remained anchored off the town, which was still unoccupied by either National or rebel troops. Large quantities of cotton yet remained untouched, in store-houses and barns, and the slaves continued to come in daily in large numbers. Our troops have completed intrenchments entirely across Hilton Head Island. There was considerable sickness among them -- a prevailing form of disease being sore throat. The Illinois brought to this port the crews of two rebel schooners, captured by the sloop-of-war Dale. Our correspondence from Hilton Head gives highly interesting details of events which have occurred since the date of previous advices.

abstract: In allusion to current events, Dr. WILLIAMS in  his discourse yesterday said: When trails are encountered, instead of succumbing, instand of exclaiming, "all is lost" we should believe it right to rejoice in the Lord, to rejoice always and to encourage one ...
lead_paragraph: In allusion to current events, Dr. WILLIAMS in his discourse yesterday said: When trails are encountered, instead of succumbing, instand of exclaiming, "all is lost" we should believe it right to rejoice in the Lord, to rejoice always and to encourage one another, not only in spirit of subduing trials, but because of those very trials. How it may seem to some incongruous that a day of Thanksgiving should be kept, while such trials are convulsing this nation. How sad to the heart, cherishing the love of man, is the thought of all the rancorous enmities that are now festering in the bosom of the nation; how awful the spectacle of a great Republic torn by fratricidal strife, how exasperating those voices wafted from over the seas, rejoicing in our calamity and asserting the combined success of our Republic hence forth to be an impossibility, and yet the faith of the believer is justified by the renewed exhibition of God's Providence in refusing to draw the hasty, rash, inconsiderate inferences which so many suggest. We may not only talk the trials in patience, but rejoice over them, and out of the very heart of such trials, it is but just that we should give thanks to Almighty God: we have reason as a people to give thanks. We have reason for thanks as we remember all His bounties to our forefathers, as we see all that He did for the planters who first settled in our land and what He accomplished for us in those early tunes of trouble, making us grow most rapidly in wealth, spreading our arts how swiftly and how widely over the face of the globe. Yet, supposing disaster, and ignominy, and gloom, should now be drawn over all the past, there would still be cause for thanksgiving for the successes and glories of that past. But we have reason to believe these times of peril betoken only a future still more glorious than the past, for whom he loveth he chasteneth. So he dealt with his own beloved Apostles, and especially with Paul, the chief Apostle of our faith. We have reason to bless God for these times of trial, because of the great national evils they have to some extent rebuked and checked. Our political parties were fast becoming scheming organizations, in which all the craft and venality which have marked the darkest stages of nations in the Old World, were becoming rooted, and poisoning our national life. We were, in our worldly prosperity, becoming a mere material brute. What the Bible calls "filthy lucre" was becoming more and more, under the name of the "Almighty Dollar," the Holy One of this nation; and material advancement was supposed to be the duty of every one who wished case, and influence, and happiness. If anything has occurred to check this awful tide -- if God, no matter how sharply, has thrown his own broad dyke across this gushing flood -- is there not reason for earnest, solemn, united thanksgiving.

abstract: According to usage, all the churches of New-York and Brooklyn were opened for Divine service yesterday, and the attendance was generally large and respectable. The leading theme of all the sermons was the one suggested by the nature of the service, -- the reasons for thanksgiving to Almighty God; -- but, naturally enough, in almost every instance the discourse turned upon the rebellion, the lessons it teaches, the spirit in which it must be met, and the prospect which it holds out. We give below abstracts more or less extended of as many of these discourses as our space enables us to publish, -- regretting that we are compelled to omit many in the highest degree worthy of notice.

abstract: Morning services were held at this Church yesterday, Rev. A.H. VINTON, the Rector of the Church, officiating. His text was the second verse of the 103d Psalm: "Bless the Lord, oh my soul, and forget not all his benefits."
lead_paragraph: Morning services were held at this Church yesterday, Rev. A.H. VINTON, the Rector of the Church, officiating. His text was the second verse of the 103d Psalm: "Bless the Lord, oh my soul, and forget not all his benefits." He considered the duty of thanksgiving was earlier than the duty of prayer, because God anticipates our desires and supplies our wants before we have the sense of need or intelligence to ask relief. It was, moreover, not only the earliest, but a perpetual duty, for as the bounty is constant gratitude should be not less habitual. He dwelt to considerable length on the innumerable blessings and benefits we were constantly receiving from the hand of God, and our unmindfulness of them, and thought there was a special fitness in setting apart occasions for thanksgiving as we needed the majesty of a solemn period to stir us to the most spiritual of holy duties, praise. Placed as we are in a community where, notwithstanding crying iniquities, there is an almost redeeming power of morality, under the protection of law, whose very force resides in the general reverence for law, wrought into the substance of the American mind, with a fabric, of Government reared on the justest theory of human rights, a theory hitherto proved to be just by the most successful experience, never shaken, although assaulted from without, and only until recently settled the deeper on its foundations from the commotions within. We have stood politically and socially on an eminence of advantage, where it is entirely safe to say no people has ever before reached. The foundations of [???] other Governments have been laid on two facts, the force of the ruler, and the ignorance of the ruled. The theory of those Governments takes for granted the inferiority of their subjects, it presumes them to be incapable of wise political action, and by its very tendency, perpetuates that inferiority. When the founders of our Republic broke the bonds of historic precedent, and established a system of equal laws and popular rights, they chose a course, whose successful issue would be the most exalted state of human advancement and blessing. If some wise political seer with the programme of our Government before him had undertaken to forecast its history, his reflections would undoubtedly have taken this form. It is an experiment. If it shall ultimately succeed it will be the glory and crown of humanity. If it fail, man will fall to a greater depth than ever, because it will be the depth of disappointment and, of course, despair. Beyond all doubt man can be fully developed only as he is free. Whether his development be for good or ill depends on the direction his freedom takes. On this point lingers his social destiny, and here resides the solemn peril of self-government. The reverend Doctor considered, at some length, the innumerable blessings that would naturally flow from such a government. But suppose, be safe, the prophetic glance had pierced the crisis that threatens the nation to-day, would be then exult and praise? Would he thank God for the clamor, fury, blood and death, of fraternal hate and sectional battle of passion, that had seized one-third of the nation, and acting like a madness blindest to its nearest interests. He thought so, for reasons both general and special. No nation had ever reached the citadel of security and empire without marching through the field of its own slain, and swimming a ditch filled with its own blood; that the majority of wars that make up the history of nations have been civil wars, whose fury was the pledge of surer and safer peace. In our long and intense prosperity we had felt so little the restraints of law on individual action, that we had almost forgotten there was a Government at all, and from that luxurious dream we needed to be aroused. "Have we a Government?" was the thundering appeal that echoed from the siege of Sumter, and thrilled every loyal heart like the voice of God, with an enthusiasm purely divine. That great truth has at last been vindicated, and if we cannot bless God for this, what earthly boon can stir our benumbed souls to grateful recognition. He thought it a sin to despair of the Republic. He did not doubt that the war would be a long one, which must cause a change in the social institutions of the South which no quick victory could accomplish. If, said he, it should happen that by the reduced value of the slave a change should be induced in his condition and position; if the system of Slavery should be readjusted, and free labor substituted for forced and servile, to the equal advantage of master and man, then, Ethiopia stretch out her unmanacled hands to God, and the loud hallelujah should burst forth from all the oppressed made free.

abstract: Rev. Dr. RAPHALL delivered a discourse yesterday in substance as follows:  My friends, we meet this day in conformity to a time-honored custom, and in compliance with an invitation sent forth by his Excellency the Governor of this State and his Honor the Mayor of this Metropolitan City, to join our fellow-citizens of all denomination ...
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. RAPHALL delivered a discourse yesterday in substance as follows: My friends, we meet this day in conformity to a time-honored custom, and in compliance with an invitation sent forth by his Excellency the Governor of this State and his Honor the Mayor of this Metropolitan City, to join our fellow-citizens of all denomination in offering thanks to Almighty God for the many mercies that during the year which is now drawing to its close, He has vouchsafed to bestow on our State and on our City. The proclamation issued by the Governor is a document so remarkable, so truthful, so fraught with and suggestive of the real feelings of the universal religion, that the bare reading of it from the pulpit might be a sufficient discourse for the day. It is so complete that to it I have to add but little, and from it I can detract nothing. But, my friends, we are Israelites. Our religion teaches us that under no circumstances is the mind permitted to despair. Our religion commands us that it is our duty to return thanks for the chastisements which the justice of God inflicts upon us, as sincerely and as devoutly as we do for those blessings which His mercy bestows upon us, even as the prophet Isaiah tells us in the first verse of the twelfth chapter, "Thus shalt thou say on that day: I will thank Thee, O Lord, though Thou wert angry with me, for when Thy anger departed, Thou consoledst me. Behold God is my strength; in Him I will trust, for my strength and my harmony is the Lord; He also is my salvation." These words are to guide our reflections on this day of mixed emotions. It is a great, a pleasing sight, when in the midst of peace and of plenty, millions of people join to give thanks unto the all- plenteous Father of Heaven for the gifts he has bestowed upon his children. It tells well for the kindliness of human nature.

abstract: The return of the intended cruise of the bark Augusta, about which there has been some doubt, has at length been explained by the confession of one of her crew, who was arrested at Fire Island, and, together with his companions, was sent to Fort Lafayette, after having been discharged by the United States Commissioner for want of evidence. We yesterday stated that it was intended to make a voyage to the coast of Africa for a cargo of slaves and accordingly, the Marshal yesterday arrested Mr. J.W. PINCKNEY, who shipped the crew of the Augusta, and a man named JACOB APPLEBY, doing business in Broad-street, who is said to be in part owner of the vessel. They were sent to Fort Lafayette, where OAKSMITH, the other owner, together with the crew, are now confined.

abstract: James R. McDonald vs. Spencer Q. Stokes et al. -- This action was brought to recover the amount of a draft. The defendants set up a counter claim for $8,000, the value of four stallions, alleging that the plaintiff had converted them to his own use. It appears that one of the horses was presented to a certain Miss Ella Zoyara, a circus rider, by the King of Sardinia. The original letter of presentation was in Court, and in it the horse is described as dapple gray, 6 years old, 15 hands high, and used as a saddle horse.; The King presented it "to the illustrious lady Zoyara as a tribute to her great equestrian skill and to her virtue as a lady."

abstract: Two or three days ago Com. ROGERS was sent in the Flag to make a reconnoissance of Tybee Roads and to place buoys in the channel. On Friday night he returned and reported his belief that Tybee was abandoned. He was ordered to return wish his own steamer, the Flag, supported by the gunboat Seneco and steamer Pocahontas, to make a reconnoissance in force.

abstract: Our Quebec correspondent, in the above letter informs us that the military authorities of Canada have concluded, in view of Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch on harbor defences, to fortify the frontiers of the Province. We presume that even a council of war, composed of such luminaries as Lord MONCK, Sir FENWICK WILLIAMS and Col. VAYNTER, would not dream of attempting to fortify a frontier some three or four thousand miles in extent.
lead_paragraph: Our Quebec correspondent, in the above letter informs us that the military authorities of Canada have concluded, in view of Mr. SEWARD'S dispatch on harbor defences, to fortify the frontiers of the Province. We presume that even a council of war, composed of such luminaries as Lord MONCK, Sir FENWICK WILLIAMS and Col. VAYNTER, would not dream of attempting to fortify a frontier some three or four thousand miles in extent. Even the ten thousand volunteers that, our correspondent says, the Government propose to call out would be barely sufficient to man the walls of Quebec -- a single point in the enormous line. It is very likely, however, that the sense of an imaginary danger has induced the military authorities of Canada to meet in consultation, in order that the Home Government may be convinced they are vigilant, and that Lord MONCK, the new Governor, is going to come up to Lord PALMERSTON's expectations. They may have ordered that the fortresses of Canada shall be repaired and placed in a high state of efficiency; and everyone knows that putting a fortress in a proper state of defence has a highly belligerent sound. In this case it would be a vox of pretaera nihil.

abstract: We are still without definite intelligence from Fort Pickens, though enough has reached us to warrant us in believing that the fighting there has resulted to the decided advantage of the National cause. A flag of truce came down from Norfolk to Fortress Monroe on Thursday, but brought no news--the rebels refusing to give any information whatever.
lead_paragraph: We are still without definite intelligence from Fort Pickens, though enough has reached us to warrant us in believing that the fighting there has resulted to the decided advantage of the National cause. A flag of truce came down from Norfolk to Fortress Monroe on Thursday, but brought no news--the rebels refusing to give any information whatever. We find in the Philadelphia Inquirer, however, a dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated the 27th, purporting to give additional particulars of the fight, but which appears to be merely an exaggeration of the rebel reports already published. According to this dispatch, based on the statement of persons from Norfolk, no breach had been made in the walls of Fort Pickens, though one was expected to be made on Monday, when BRAGG, with reinforcements which he expected, was to storm the fort. The storm of hot shot and shell concentrated upon the Navy-yard from the fort had at last fired the place so effectually that the rebels found it impossible to extinguish the flames, and the buildings had been entirely destroyed, together with a large amount of army and ordnance stores. Pensacola had been evacuated by order of BRAGG. There certainly could have been no necessity for this, unless the rebels were suffering a disastrous defeat, as the place is eight miles from the scene of operations. Another bad indication for the rebels is the declaration said to have been made to his men by BRAGG, that he would never surrender alive. The ill-success of the National vessels against the rebel batteries is again mentioned, the number engaged being five -- the names of the Niagara and the Colorado only being given. The former is stated to have been almost riddled with rockets, while the Colorado was thoroughly disabled. We shall probably receive a true report of the engagement to-day or to-morrow.

abstract: The Sixty-third Regiment, which is the Third Regiment in the First Irish Brigade, landed in this City on Thursday, from their encampment on David's Island. The intention was to immediately embark on a Camden and Amboy boat, en route for Washington.
lead_paragraph: The Sixty-third Regiment, which is the Third Regiment in the First Irish Brigade, landed in this City on Thursday, from their encampment on David's Island. The intention was to immediately embark on a Camden and Amboy boat, en route for Washington. They were landed at the foot of Fourteenth-street, North River, in the early part of the day, and made a very creditable appearance on their march down Broadway, the men being, at that time, apparently sober. A large crowd witnessed the passage of the troops till they arrived at the foot of Battery-place, where the boat was lying ready to take them on board. But at this point a different scene began to be enacted. The first three companies passed through the gate on to the pier at which the steamer was lying, in good military style. Several women desiring to follow them, were repulsed by the guard in attendance at the gate. This created considerable excitement among the soldiers, and in order to keep out all who did not belong to the regiment, as well as to restore order in the ranks, a halt was ordered, and the gates closed. Several of the soldiers thereupon broke rank, and the example being immediately followed by others, in a very short time a large number of the regiment started for the saloons and drinking shops in Battery-place, West and State streets. They were, of course, accompadied by their relatives and friends, who had followed them for the purpose of witnessing the embarkation. Soon a scene of the greatest confusion and disorder prevailed. Soldiers, who a short time before were orderly and obedient, were now either raving with passion, or so stupidly intoxicated as to be unable to walk. The ranks were broken, and the scene at this time is represented, by those who witnessed it, to have been of the most disgraceful character. Finally the gates of the pier were opened, and the order given for all belonging to the regiment to march in. The soldiers, accompanied by their friends, rushed forward; but the latter being driven back with force by the guard at the gates, all again became a scene of confusion, and a disgraceful riot spread through the whole, extending itself as the numbers increased, and the passions of the men became more inflamed. Those who were outside declared they would not go unless their friends could be admitted inside the gates, and those already in, were anxious to get out on a short furlough. But the officers had determined that neither party should be gratified. Bayonets, knives, and other weapons were then freely used, and it is reported that several were seriously wounded. The officers, for a time, had no command over their men, and when the soldiers inside found there was no way of escaping by the gates, many of them rushed forward towards the northern side of the dock, in spite of the great exertions of their officers to prevent it, -- and some of them succeeded in escaping by the way of a schooner which was anchored in the vicinity. Others climbed up the side of the gates, in doing which, two fell into the water, and one man is believed to have been drowned, as he was heard making cries as if strangling, and is not known to have been rescued.

abstract: The Tammany Democracy was called to assemble last evening in mass meeting, at the corner of Eighty-sixth-street and Fourth-avenue. They were told that Mr. JAMES T. BRADY would address them, as also other popular and accomplished orators. The night was wet and dirty; more so in Yorkville than people down town have any idea of; consequently only some two or three hundred gathered at the appointed time. There were tar barrels and torches in plenty, a few fireworks and a small cannon; but all these failed to produce the slightest approach to enthusiasm. Mr. BRADY did not appear, and the speakers who did exert themselves were mostly of the rough-and-ready order. Rain came down at intervals whilst the proceedings were going on; mid about 9 1/2 o'clock so much of it began to fail that even the "unterrified" longed for shelter, and speedily dispersed.

abstract: Pensacola harbor is the best harbor on the Gulf of Mexico. It is completely landlocked, and has twenty-two feet of water on the bar at low tide. East Bay admits frigates of the largest class, and is entirely sheltered from all winds. The town of Pensacola, which is the principal seaport of West Florida, had, a year ago, a population of about 4,000; but a great part of these fled from the ruin and terror that had overtaken the city. The houses are generally old-fashioned Spanish structures. The Alabama and Florida Railroad, which connects the town with Montgomery, (Ala.,) was completed shortly after secession. That part of the road then unbuilt was finished with great haste by DAVIS orders, so that troops and munitions might be hurried forward for the capture of Fort Pickens. Although that is nine months ago however, Pickens is as yet uncaptured -- nor, we judge by the latest news, is it likely soon to be captured. The climate is exceedingly healthful, except for occasional and rare visitations of yellow fever. The creole element predominates in the resident population. In 1814, Gen. JACKSON drove out the British, who had established themselves there by permission of the Spaniards, and assaulted and took the city and adjacent forts. Again in 1818, Gen. JACKSON, in consequence of Indian incursions on United States territory, took possession of Pensacola, and obliged Fort Barrancas, to which the Spanish Governor had retired, to capitulate. In 1821, the whole territory was ceded to the United States. We hope it will turn out that Col. BROWN is no unworthy successor of Gen. JACKSON.

abstract: The leading topic of interest in Europe, according to our advices by the Canada, is the revolution just effected in the French financial administration, affecting as it does in vital particulars the foreign and domestic policy of the Empire. M. FOULD, in accepting the portfolio of Finance, has dictated a variety of highly important reforms, tending not only to lessen the Imperial power by important concessions to the people, but to remove from European politics the standing menace afforded by the vast military and naval preparations of France. The deficit in the revenues,which has called for these changes, exceeds $200,000,000. It is the task of M. FOULD to reduce this overdraught, and to prevent its recurrence -- a labor in which the Emperor will assist him by the surrender of any necessary powers.

abstract: This regiment, Col. MCKEAN, which has been quartered for some time past at Saratoga Springs, arrived in this City yesterday on its way to the seat of war. On landing the men were marched to the Park Barracks, where a substantial meal was provided for them. The men during their stay at Saratoga were fully uniformed and equipped, but were not armed. When at the Park Barracks they were furnished with Enfield risks. After obtaining refreshments the men were drawn up into line in front of the City Hall, and were presented with a regimental flag and guide colors by HIRAM KETCHUM, Esq., who made a brief and appropriate speech. Col. MCKEAN, on receiving the flags, said that he felt justly proud in handling the flag just presented, to Color-Sergeant BEMIS, a descendant of the BEMIS in whose fields one of the fifteen battles of the Revolution had been fought. The regiment then marched down to Pier No. 1, North River, and took the boat for Amboy. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: -- Our London correspondent mentions a rumor that upon the arrival of the James Adger at Southampton, the British Government was led to believe that the errand of that steamer was to overhaul the Royal mail packet expected from the West Indies, and arrest Messrs. MASON and SEIDELL. The story proceeds, that a steam-frigate was dispatched to follow and watch the James Adger upon her departure, and only desisted from the chase when it became obvious that the American vessel had other business.

abstract: We have news of interest from Canada. It seems that the military members of the Government have held a council of war, and have resolved to put the frontier in a condition of defence.
lead_paragraph: We have news of interest from Canada. It seems that the military members of the Government have held a council of war, and have resolved to put the frontier in a condition of defence. The forts already in existence will be strengthened and new ones will be erected, by way of precaution against assumed designs of a hostile character on the part of the United States. There can be little doubt that these measures are taken in conjunction with the home Government, -- and they will probably be followed by steps to put the Canadian militia on a footing of better preparation for effective service. As a matter of course we have no right to regard this as in any sense a hostile movement.' We have no idea that it has anything whatever to do with any prospective movements of England toward breaking the blockade of our Southern ports, or interfering in any way with the attempt of our Government to reestablish its authority over the Southern States. But it is one more symptom of a growing alienation between the two countries, -- one additional step toward a position of mutual distrust and dislike, when it takes but little to inflame public feeling on both sides, and substitute passion for judgment in the treatment of questions of difference.

abstract: A large concourse assembled yesterday, at 3 P.M., on Wall-street, in the vicinity of the Merchants' Exchange, for the purpose of ratifying the nomination of GEORGE OPDYKE, Esq., for the Mayoralty. As the call for the meeting had indicated, the occasion was to have been celebrated under the auspices of the "merchants" of New-York, and at the appointed time many of our leading business men congregated in the Rotunda of the Exchange, to which a brisk shower of rain drove all who had come to participate in the proceedings. It had been originally intended to hold the meeting on Wall-street, the addresses to be delivered from the front colonnade of the Exchange, as the interior of the building is unfitted for public speaking. Among the groups in the damp and icy-cold rotunda, were noticed Messrs. WM.M. EVANS, SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, DAVID DUDLRY FIELD, HENRY NICOLL, and others, who had been announced or expected as speakers.
lead_paragraph: A large concourse assembled yesterday, at 3 P.M., on Wall-street, in the vicinity of the Merchants' Exchange, for the purpose of ratifying the nomination of GEORGE OPDYKE, Esq., for the Mayoralty. abstract: Tammany Hall has published a small card for circulation giving certain figures to prove that in the late canvas for Judge of the Marine Court the Tammany candidate polled more votes than either the Mozarter or the straight Republican. They find it convenient to omit all mention of the fact that HIRAM KETCHUM was a candidate and divided the Republican vote. The card asserts in large capitals that "figures do not lie." That is very true if they are left to tell their own story. But many people who use them make them like most effectually.

abstract: Gen. FREMONT, lately recalled from the command of the Western Department, arrived in this City on Thursday from St. Louis, reaching here by way of Albany and the Hudson River Railroad. He was accompanied by Mrs. FREMONT and two members of his Staff, who were with him on service in Missouri. Taking rooms at the Astor House, he has remained within doors all day, and manifests the utmost reserve in his communications. He was, however, visited by many personal friends during the morning.
lead_paragraph: Gen. abstract: Whatever difficulties may attach to the question of the negro slaves, viewed as a political problem, there can be no doubt of the social duties which are imposed on the Government by the new relations in which the slave population finds itself in that district of South Carolina now held by the Union forces.
lead_paragraph: Whatever difficulties may attach to the question of the negro slaves, viewed as a political problem, there can be no doubt of the social duties which are imposed on the Government by the new relations in which the slave population finds itself in that district of South Carolina now held by the Union forces. The strange dissolution of society in that locality -- a phenomenon which has hardly its like -- has left a population of many thousands, who have all their lives depended on a master race for such poor guidance as they got, in a state of helpless bewilderment -- human debris left stranded there by the social wreck.

abstract: The news from Western Florida is still very meagre, and, being from rebel sources, is still very dubious. The rebels, however, talk a good deal less loudly of them own doings, while they are singularly reticent about ours.
lead_paragraph: The news from Western Florida is still very meagre, and, being from rebel sources, is still very dubious. The rebels, however, talk a good deal less loudly of them own doings, while they are singularly reticent about ours. They had not breached the walls of Fort Pickens nor captured the Fort, but they were greatly excited, were calling for reinforcements and swearing they would never surrender alive, while Col. BROWN had burned down the Navy-yard and the town of Warrington, and the rebels had evacuated Pensacola. This is certainly a considerable "come down" from the news of two days ago. But still it is so unsatisfactory that the public will not be contented till reliable advices arrive, and these must now be very close at hand.

abstract: There are those who deprecate the errand on which the stone-laden squadron has gone, and characterise the blocking up of the harbors of Charleston and Savannah as vindictive, unstatesmanlike, and calculated, as they express it, to "exasperate the South." This view of the matter would hardly oc-...
lead_paragraph: There are those who deprecate the errand on which the stone-laden squadron has gone, and characterise the blocking up of the harbors of Charleston and Savannah as vindictive, unstatesmanlike, and calculated, as they express it, to "exasperate the South." This view of the matter would hardly occur to one who had any serious interest in the crushing of the rebellion; and accordingly they who entertain it are the very men who opposed the idea of naval expeditions to the Southern coast -- in fact, who have opposed every active measure of the Government: and for the self-same reason -- that such steps would "exasperate the South!" There may be people who are imposed on by this feeble sophism: they can be only such as wish to be imposed on. It is a strange plea on which to claim immunity from the richly earned punishment destined to fall on that rebellious race. They would hardly venture to urge it themselves, for they have a stricter sense of logic -- they who, maddened by an insensate hate, have drawn from the dark caverns of passion whatever elements could add horror and atrocity to their assassin war.

abstract: -- SAML. HOTALING, Esq., has declined the nomination for Mayor in favor of GEORGE OPDYKE. abstract: We are obliged to do so much to disgust the Southern mind that there is a heightened gratification in being able occasionally really to satisfy it. From the Richmond Enquirer we gather that it has been reserved for Gen. SHERMAN to offer a grateful sop of the kind to the Southern Cerberus.
lead_paragraph: We are obliged to do so much to disgust the Southern mind that there is a heightened gratification in being able occasionally really to satisfy it. From the Richmond Enquirer we gather that it has been reserved for Gen. SHERMAN to offer a grateful sop of the kind to the Southern Cerberus. It professes to think that the introduction of Confederate terms -- such as "The Great Sovereign State of South Carolina," "Confederacy," "Compact," and the like -- into that soldier's proclamation, is a concession to South Carolina theories for the purpose of mollifyng her. At the same time it illustrates the wisdom of this policy by the example of Daniel in the lions' den, who, "though assured of the Divine protection, did hot think it desirable to do that which would provoke the animosity of its inmates, but, on the contrary, conciliated them by a gracious behavior."

abstract: It is impossible that one should stand and see this fine weather go by, and the close approach of dreary December, without the deepest anxiety.
